text: There's been a seven-figure ORGANIZATION catcher near the top of every international class dating back through 2016, and ORGANIZATION is this year's model. He's a little less polished on defense than most of his predecessors but has a plus arm and mature, strength-driven power. He has everyday offensive ability if he can remain lithe and mobile enough to catch.

After appearing in 19 games but making only one start as a ORGANIZATION freshman in 2016, PERSON transferred to JC of ORGANIZATION and dominated as a starter, posting a 1.56 ERA with 118 strikeouts in 81 innings. The performance, along with a heavily scouted bullpen session in late May, during which he hit 102 mph, gave the right-hander some serious helium ahead of the 2017 Draft. The ORGANIZATION ended up selecting PERSON 28th overall with the second of their two first-round picks, then signed him for slightly above slot value at $2,452,900. PERSON continued to thrive in his pro debut, turning in a lights-out performance across two levels, though he's been plagued by injuries in 2018. A back injury delayed the start of PERSON's season until early May, and when he finally took the mound, the right-hander logged just 1 2/3 innings in the ORGANIZATION State League before being struck by a line drive that resulted in a fractured right forearm. PERSON's four-pitch mix is highlighted by the best fastball and slider in GPE's system. He was consistently up to 97-98 mph with his fastball during the spring and threw even harder in his pro debut, at times bumping triple digits, albeit in shorter stints. PERSON has already cleaned up his slider since signing and now throws it with more power and tilt in the upper 80s, giving him a legitimate put-away pitch to complement his explosive fastball. His changeup is currently ahead of his curveball, with the former grading out as an average pitch and the curve being more fringy. There's some concern regarding PERSON's durability because he had a screw put in his right elbow in high school, but the 6-foot-6 hurler was nothing but healthy and durable in junior college and during his debut. Provided he stays healthy, PERSON seems well on his way toward becoming a No. 3 starter, perhaps more if he can improve his secondaries and overall command.

PERSON has diverse athletic bloodlines, as he's the grandson of former ORGANIZATION of the ORGANIZATION and also is related to former ORGANIZATION power forward PERSON and former ORGANIZATION quarterback PERSON. He reclassified to enter the Draft a year early in 2014, turning down the ORGANIZATION as a 23rd-rounder before signing with the ORGANIZATION for $550,000 as a 20th-rounder out of GPE (Fla.) JC the following June. He spent his first two pro seasons in GPE ball before hitting 15 homers in low Class A in 2017.A switch-hitter, PERSON has some of the best raw power in GPE's system and does more damage from the right side. He's strong and has plenty of bat speed, leverage and loft in his swing, but he will have to show he can make consistent contact in order to tap into his pop. PERSON made strides with his approach and discipline last year but has been overly aggressive in 2018.PERSON has to produce at the plate because he doesn't offer much value on the bases or in the field. He's a below-average runner and corner outfielder, though he does have some arm strength. He may be best suited for first base, which would put even more pressure on his bat.

As one of the youngest regulars in the LOCATION League in 2012, PERSON more than held his own. He's an aggressive hitter with a slap line drive stroke. While he does have a knack for making contact, he does need to develop his approach and become more selective. That way he can get on base more and use his plus speed to greater effect. He can defend at shortstop, though he's inconsistent, making the flashy, above-average play, but making too many mistakes of concentration or trying to do too much. PERSON needs to put on weight and get stronger and the ORGANIZATION were encouraged that he had added some muscle during the offseason, something that will be essential if he's going to hold up over the rigors of a long full season.

After a bonus-skimming scandal rocked the FACILITY' international scouting department in 2008, it didn't make a significant signing for five years. That drought ended when PERSON signed PERSON, ORGANIZATION's No. 2-rated prospect in the 2013-14 international signing period, for $1.6 million out of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON and hamate maladies limited him to a total of 91 games in his first two full pro seasons, but he finally started to hit as hoped when he stayed healthy in 2017.PERSON combines bat speed and strength with loft and leverage in his right-handed swing, giving him as much raw power as any FACILITY prospect. He hit just .225/.283/.356 with a 36 percent strikeout rate in his first three years a pro, when his stroke often got too long and too steep. Getting regular at-bats has helped him make adjustments this year, as he has started to recognize pitches better and become less pull-happy.PERSON's arm strength is just as jaw-dropping as his power, and those two tools make him an easy fit for the right-field profile. He's already starting to mature and could lose a step off his presently average speed once that process is complete. That shouldn't stop him from becoming an average defender, however.

Acquired in the ORGANIZATION swap, the wispy PERSON has three average pitches that could continue to improve either through reps and improved feel (the changeup), or mature physicality (the fastball). His 11-7 curveball has good shape, depth, and bite, his delivery is graceful, smooth, and repeatable. Stagnant development likely leaves PERSON with a collection of 50-grade pitches and command, relegating him to the ORGANIZATION. 5 starter realm. But while you can quibble about which areas he's most likely to improve (at age 21, the body and velocity may be done growing), it seems likely that some of the stuff will due to the frame, delivery, and athleticism.

GPE is the victim of big bonus expectations that eventually cratered when the available money was largely spent. He's expected to settle for a high six figure bonus with the ORGANIZATION and is a smaller righty with some effort to his delivery, but consistently shows three average or better pitches with good feel for his craft. There isn't much margin for error for him to turn into a league average starter, but he's by far the most advanced of any arm in this class and he's so young that he doesn't need physical projection to improve by a good bit.

PERSON was so advanced as a prep star in GPE that scouts viewed him more like a college pitcher than one in high school. He lived up to that evaluation, racing to the ORGANIZATION in his first full professional season as a 19-year-old. But PERSON's progress hit a roadblock in 2013 when he underwent PERSON surgery in June. PERSON returned to action this year, and he looks to be on his way to recapturing his top-tier stuff. His fastball sits in the mid-to-upper 90s, and it has touched triple digits. PERSON's best secondary pitch as an amateur was his cutter, but the ORGANIZATION took it away to force him to improve his other offspeed offerings. PERSON's curveball and changeup have both improved, and they have plus potential. PERSON is an exceptional athlete and his work ethic and makeup are very well regarded. He profiles as a front-line starter if he can make a full recovery from surgery.

GPE aggressively, PERSON reached the Class A Advanced California League in 2013 at age 19. The ORGANIZATION think he can develop into a top-of-the-order catalyst in the future.PERSON's best tool is his speed, and he has more than enough to be a threat on the basepaths and to give him range up the middle. The GPE switch-hitter's actions and his arm are good enough for shortstop, but he's also seen time at second base thus far in his pro career. PERSON has no power to speak of, relying on making contact and using his speed for his offense. Some added strength and improvement of his on-base skills will certainly help him down the road.If the bat can come along, PERSON has the chance to be an everyday shortstop, though a career as a speedy and dynamic utility type is nothing to sneeze at.

Enamored with PERSON's triple-digit fastball, the ORGANIZATION gave the left-hander a $650,000 bonus -- more than $400,000 above the recommended slot value -- out of PERSON in the sixth round of the 2014 Draft. He showcased his big fastball the following year during stints in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn and GPE Atlantic Leagues, and then opened even more eyes with a strong ORGANIZATION performance. The results weren't quite there for PERSON in 2016, although it didn't keep him from reaching to Double-A in just his second full season. He's fared considerably better this season in his return to the level, where he's been deployed as a starter but also has been limited to no more than three innings per outing. PERSON's elite fastball gives him closer potential, as he'll routinely hit 100 mph (or higher) while sitting comfortably at 95-99. Beyond that, however, PERSON remains very raw. The ORGANIZATION have worked with PERSON to simplify his delivery, with the goal of improving his fastball control, though his struggles have continued in that regard. His slider has its moments, registering in the low 90s, and nets him whiffs, but overall is a below-average offering due to a lack of consistency. With his big fastball from the left side and knack for missing bats, PERSON's upside as late-inning reliever in undeniable. The ORGANIZATION will continue to develop him as a starter for the time being, though he's unlikely to stick in that role without making massive gains as a strike-thrower.

PERSON entered the spring as a college performer primed to do well on GPE day, but an uneven junior season that saw him briefly lose his spot as the Friday night starter put his stock in question. He righted the ship a bit near the end of the spring, giving him a bit of an up arrow as the GPE approached.A three-year starter for GPE, PERSON has long concerned scouts with his low three-quarters arm slot. He was throwing from a higher slot in the fall and sinking the ball better while throwing his slider with more depth. Back down lower this spring, the fear was that plus his workload was wearing on him. He can still crank his fastball up to 94 mph and his slider will show good break and tilt at times. He will flash an average changeup as well.With a big, physical body that could add strength, PERSON generally stays around the strike zone. A team that feels some rest and adjusted mechanics is all he needs could find a steal by taking advantage of his up-and-down spring.

GPE picks beyond the ORGANIZATION Round are not allowed to be traded, but international bonus pool slots can be, even once the signing period has begun. That's how PERSON, along with right-hander PERSON, came to the D-backs from the Phillies, as the latter traded up to pick up more money to spend on the international market.A non-drafted free agent out of PERSON and State (after first attending PERSON), PERSON got a shot to start in 2015 after pitching well in relief in the ORGANIZATION right after signing. The D-backs kept him in a rotation once they got him and he opened some more eyes there. The 6-foot-5 lefty has some definite arm strength, sitting 92-95 mph with his fastball. He'll mix in a slurvy breaking ball and a changeup, both of which show glimpses of being serviceable. More than anything, PERSON needs to refine his command, and there's hope his pitches will all get more consistent if he can find the strike zone more consistently.PERSON is definitely a diamond in the rough and a long way away from the big leagues, but with size, arm strength and a three-pitch mix, the D-backs see no reason why he can't keep working out of a rotation.

GPE is an energetic, multi-positional speedster with an infectious style of play. He's an aggressive hitter who strikes out a ton, but he played everywhere but first base and catcher last year and could find a big league role as a versatile bench piece.

An excellent athlete, PERSON was considered the top two-way player in the 2013 Draft class. In the end, however, scouts couldn't pass up his combination of size and stuff from the left side, and GPE selected him seventh overall as a pitcher.PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s, and there is projection left in his lanky frame. He only began throwing a curveball a couple years ago, but it already shows the potential to be an above-average pitch. In the absence of a breaking ball, PERSON's changeup blossomed, and it has the potential to develop into a plus offering.Despite his height, PERSON's athleticism gives him a chance to learn how to repeat his delivery well enough to have solid command. Though he is further away than most of the ORGANIZATION's top pitching prospects, PERSON's ceiling might be the highest of all of them.

Command-oriented pitchers can often dominate young, inexperienced hitters at the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION. The move to Double-A in 2015 was a stiff test for PERSON, though he made some good adjustments. Moving to hitter-friendly Las Vegas in 2016 proved another challenge for the right-hander, although it didn't keep him from making his big league debut in August en route to 10 appearances (three starts) with the ORGANIZATION. In February, the ORGANIZATION acquired PERSON in exchange for cash considerations.  PERSON has long been among the best control artists in the ORGANIZATION, with a career 1.5 BB/9 ratio in more than 795 innings. He's had success in the past with average stuff across the board -- though he can touch 94-95 mph with his fastball on occasion -- and shows a willingness to throw all of his pitches at any point in the count. PERSON's tendency to nibble at the zone rather than attack hitters has resulted in more hits allowed and fewer strikeouts as he's climbed the ladder, although it has come with a better ground-ball rate.  The key for PERSON's future will be the development of his breaking stuff. If he can sharpen that, he has the chance to carve out a role as a back-end starter in the big leagues.

In the 2017-18 international period, the ORGANIZATION weren't allowed to spend more than $300,000 for any one prospect based on their aggressive spending the previous year, something they would eventually be heavily penalized for. They did, however, manage to sign 20 players for six-figure bonsues, including PERSON, a GPE defector who got $190K to sign and has the makings of an intriguing bullpen piece.PERSON has a classic two-pitch power mix that he's already showing can overpower professional hitters. The right-hander misses bats with both pitches, starting with a fastball he typically throws in the 94-97 mph range with good riding life to it. He complements it with a solid hard slider that can get slurvy at times.While he's never going to have pinpoint command, PERSON was doing a better job of finding the strike zone in his second season after an up-and-down debut in the GPE. If that trend continues, he could eventually develop into a setup-type short reliever at the back end of a big league bullpen.

While there are many catching prospects who are offensive-first type backstops, GPE is the other way around. The GPE native gets raves reviews for his defensive toolset. He has a plus arm, one of the best among PERSON catchers, and gets rid of the ball quickly. His athleticism leads to excellent agility behind the plate, with an ability to sit and block pitches in the dirt. His bat is behind his glove, though he's shown glimpses of offensive ability as well. He has a line-drive swing with gap power. There might be more pop if he can refine his approach. That's been GPE's biggest shortcoming, a tendency to chase pitches. Still very young, GPE has the potential to develop into an everyday backstop, especially if the bat comes along.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

PERSON was a toolsy, volatile high school prospect who had strikeout issues against varsity pitching. The way his hands load and his stride have both changed since he's entered pro ball, which has improved his once putrid timing. There are still some bat-to-ball issues, but PERSON is trending up and has a shot to be a multi-positional infielder with power.

PERSON put himself on the prospect map by leading the LOCATION with nine homers and 33 walks as a Sacred Heart sophomore in 2015, only to slump in the ORGANIZATION that summer and again as a junior. He fell to the 17th round of the 2016 Draft, signed for $80,000 and didn't do much in his pro debut. But he has opened eyes since with his power and patience, combining for 30 homers and 176 walks in his first two full seasons while reaching Double-A.PERSON has quick hands and a pull-heavy approach, giving him more pop than a typical 175-pounder. He's an extreme flyball hitter who makes a lot of loud contact from the right side of the plate, though the ORGANIZATION would like to see him cut down his swing and make more regular contact. He works deep counts and draws a lot of walks, giving him healthy on-base percentages despite subpar batting averages.With solid speed and an aggressive nature, PERSON can steal an occasional base. Some club officials believe he's the best defensive infielder in the system, and his quickness and arm strength allow him to play second and third base and serve in a utility role if needed. If he can put the bat on the ball more consistently, he could be an everyday shortstop in the mold of ORGANIZATION.

A ninth-round pick in 2017 out of GPE Tech who tended to be a bit too hittable during his college career, PERSON had an up-and-down first full season of pro ball with the ORGANIZATION. While he finished second in the organization in strikeouts and capped off his year with a good start up a level in the ORGANIZATION State League playoffs, the left-hander gave up more hits (168) than innings pitched (154) in the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON can be prone to creating his own big innings with one mistake. He often fought his delivery, causing his stuff to not be as sharp. That was particularly true of his breaking ball, which can get caught between a curve and a slider. He needs to rely on movement, deception and command because of his lack of plus stuff, starting with an 87-94 mph fastball that can sneak up on hitters due to his deception, but often lacks movement. He might need to pick one breaking ball to help define it better and give him a third solid pitch, behind his above-average changeup. He goes right after hitters and fills up the strike zone (2.0 BB/9 in 2018).PERSON finished off his first full season much more strongly than he started it. His ceiling might be limited, but if he can carry those adjustments over, he has the chance to be a No. 5 type starter or an effective middle reliever.

At his peak, PERSON had mid-rotation stuff. He was sitting 94-97 at times during the spring of 2015, his changeup was plus, and his slurvy breaking ball was at least average. Since then his health and stuff have waxed and waned. In 2018, his stuff looked more like that of a fifth starter. Then he suffered a ORGANIZATION strain during 2019 spring training. He's now an oft-injured 24-year-old backend starter prospect who may benefit from a change of scenery.

While the ORGANIZATION lost PERSON to free agency prior to the 2015 season, they did get the 34th overall pick in that year's Draft as compensation. That turned out to be PERSON, who has shown that his power output at ORGANIZATION was not an aberration, with big home run totals in each of his first two full seasons. PERSON has legitimate pop to all fields thanks to a very quick bat. While there is some swing and miss to his game, he has worked hard at shortening his swing and developing a better plan at the plate. He has shown some ability to draw walks, helping somewhat to offset the strikeout rate. His bat will have to be his carrying card because he is a below-average defender in left field. He has limited speed and a below-average arm, but the ORGANIZATION feel he'll eventually be adequate out there. The ORGANIZATION will live with fringy defense as PERSON continues to show he can punish the baseball at the upper levels of the system. If he continues to develop, he could be a left-handed-hitting middle-of-the-order run producer in the near future.

PERSON couldn't crack PERSON A&M's staff as a freshman, appearing just four times all season, but he earned the closer's role and held onto it as a sophomore and junior, saving 16 games combined. That landed him in the fifth round, where the ORGANIZATION gave him full pick value as a college reliever who could be quick to the big leagues.PERSON has done nothing but pitch out of a bullpen, and he'll continue to do so, but he actually has a starting pitcher's repertoire. He'll work with a 93-96 mph fastball in shorter stints, and he backs that up with a changeup that he throws with good deception and that has splitter action to it. PERSON has thrown both a true slider and more of a hybrid breaking ball, and both have been average pitches. Not the biggest guy in the world, there was some concern about his longer arm action, but he has never been hit well.He might not be future big league closer material, but his stuff combined with his ability to throw strikes could allow him to move quickly and settle in as a Major League setup man down the road.

PERSON is a flashy shortstop defender with good bat speed. As is typical for switch-hitters this age, both swings are in need of polish. Projections on the bat vary. PERSON is committed to PERSON, where his father coaches. He's rumored to be a target of GPE, GPE, and PERSON in the late first and comp round.

PERSON threw a shutout to win the title game of the heavily scouted 2015 World Wood Bat Association World Championship showcase, but his polish stood out more than his stuff. That contributed to him going undrafted the following June, as did his commitment to GPE. He still fits the same profile in 2019, but three years of success as a member of a weekend rotation in the LOCATION should get him picked in the first four or five rounds.PERSON lacks a true plus pitch, but he has several effective offerings and there's no clear consensus as to which is his best. Though his fastball velocity is nothing special at 88-91 mph and a peak of 93, his heater plays up because he sinks and commands it so well, and it works well in concert with his changeup that features similar movement. He has improved his curveball this year, and both it and his slider/cutter can be solid pitches.Without overpowering stuff, PERSON has little margin for error and thrives by limiting his mistakes. He has tremendous feel for locating, manipulating and sequencing his pitches, and he tossed complete-game shutouts against two of the ORGANIZATION's better clubs (ORGANIZATION and GPE) this spring. He tunnels his offerings well, adding to his deception and his chances of becoming a No. 4 or 5 starter.

PERSON PERSON in northern GPE has had four players drafted over the years, but none since 1999. Thanks to his solid all-round skills as a catcher, ORGANIZATION will undoubtedly be the first PERSON product to be selected this century, possibly in the top three rounds.None of ORGANIZATION's tools jump out as plus, but the sum of all of his parts make him an intriguing catching prospect. He has a solid hit tool, making consistent hard contact. There's some power in his right-handed swing, with a bit more to come as he physically matures. ORGANIZATION is a capable defender, with average receiving tools. Grades on his arm have varied this spring, but it has turned out he's been catching with some arm problems for much of this year, leading many scouts to think his arm is a tick above-average when healthy.While ORGANIZATION isn't the kind of GPE prospect who wows you, he also doesn't have any glaring holes. Solid all-around backstops are hard to find, and the dearth of them in the GPE class should help this GPE commit's stock in June.

Â By reaching Double-A Bowie in his first full professional season, PERSON put himself on the fast track. He returned there in 2013 and led the LOCATION with a 3.26 ERA. PERSON hasn't repeated that level of success this season with Triple-A Norfolk.PERSON's fastball sits in the low-90s, and it can touch 95 mph. He throws from a steep downhill angle and uses his fastball's heavy sink to generate ground-ball outs. None of PERSON's offspeed pitches truly stand out, but he adds to their deception by throwing them all from the same arm slot. Though he fills up the zone, PERSON has more control than pinpoint command.Some scouts think PERSON's stuff would play up in the bullpen. But his build suggests a workhorse starter, and GPE believes he can fill that role in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON pumped his fastball up to 97 mph as a GPE high school senior in 2016, but concerns about his delivery, wildness and signability left him undrafted. He continued to show velocity but had difficulty finding the strike zone in his first two years at ORGANIZATION, pitching just eight innings as a sophomore last spring. After shortening his arm angle and raising his slot a bit in 2019, he has thrown consistently harder than any college pitcher available in the Draft.PERSON has sat at 95-97 mph and hit 101 with his fastball multiple times as a junior. His heater not only features premium velocity but also high spin rates, giving it riding action up in the strike zone. His slider has more power than bite, reaching the upper 80s and showing flashes of becoming a plus pitch at times yet also playing as a below-average slurve in the low 80s at others.A pure reliever, PERSON doesn't have a third pitch, still has effort in his delivery and still battles the strike zone on a regular basis. He has potential as a closer if he can develop a more reliable slider and cut down his walks. If not, his upside would be along the lines of PERSON.

Though GPE weighed 160 pounds and had a mid-80s fastball as a high school senior in 2013, GPE area scout PERSON liked his loose arm and signed him for $32,000 as a 30th-rounder. He advanced slowly until breaking out in 2016, when he topped low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION relievers in strikeout rate (12.8 per nine innings) and opponent average (.198) and was no less effective when he transitioned to the rotation in late July. He was on his way to establishing himself as the system's best pitching prospect until he hurt his elbow and needed PERSON surgery after three dominant outings in high Class A last year. GPE returned to the mound this June after a 14-month layoff and showed that he can still overmatch left-handers and tie up right-handers with his plus downer curveball. He also misses bats and elicits weak contact with a low-90s fastball that peaks at 96 mph and gets on hitters quick. His changeup needs more work than his other two offerings but his willingness to use it bodes well for its development.A bit small for a starter, GPE compensates with athleticism and a quick arm. His control and command were unreliable early in his career but he began to make significant progress in the last two years before he got hurt. If he can't last in the rotation, he could have a future as a seventh-inning reliever who wouldn't be limited to being a lefty specialist.

PERSON helped key PERSON's run to its first PERSON Series title when he moved from closer to starter last April, not allowing a run in his first 29 2/3 innings in his new role. He has excelled again in 2015, as he was college baseball's hottest pitcher down the stretch and the LOCATION pitcher of the year.PERSON has an electric arm that delivers 93-97-mph fastballs and power breaking balls. His changeup is an effective third pitch and coaches and scouts alike rave about his competitive makeup. Some scouts think he'd be best off channeling his energy into becoming a closer because he lacks size, his delivery features effort and his control can get wobbly at times.A 15th-round pick by the ORGANIZATION from a GPE high school in 2012, PERSON would have gone in the top five rounds had he been signable. Now he's one of three Commodores who figure to go early in the first round in 2015, joining PERSON and PERSON.

Signed in November 2013, PERSON spent his first pro season in the ORGANIZATION before impressing during his brief GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION native graduated to full-season ball in 2016, earning mid-season All-Star honors in the Class A ORGANIZATION at age 19, though he did wear down physically late in the season. He continued to climb the ladder in 2017, beginning the season in the ORGANIZATION State League before moving up to Double-A at the midseason mark. PERSON's live arm generates easy velocity in a fastball that consistently sits between 92-95 mph with late life. His slider registers in the mid- to high-80s, thrown with late, short slicing action, and he also has the makings of an advanced changeup that he's already comfortable deploying against right-handed hitters. He's adept at changing hitters eye levels from an over-the-top release point, though some scouts worry about PERSON's ability to create favorable downhill plane given his height.PERSON should be able to tack on strength to his wiry frame as he matures physically, and in turn it should improve his durability. He has the arsenal and control profile to develop into a big league starter, although his fastball-slider pairing also give him a bright future as a reliever, one who can get outs on both sides of the plate.

PERSON may have come off the board earlier in the 2014 Draft if not for a bout of forearm tightness that sidelined him for three weeks as a high school senior. The ORGANIZATION were thrilled to find him still available with the 30th-overall pick, and then signed him for $1.75 million. PERSON rewarded the ORGANIZATION by dominating in his first two pro seasons and then reached Double-A at age 20 in 2016. However, it will now be up to the ORGANIZATION to further his development after they acquired PERSON and PERSON in the ORGANIZATION Lucroy-Jeremy Jeffress Trade Deadline blockbuster.PERSON combines stuff and feel better than most young pitchers. His strong build allows him to maintain his 92-97 mph fastball deep into ballgames, and his low-80s slider gives him a plus second pitch. PERSON threw his changeup sparingly as an amateur, but has developed it enough as a pro to where scouts view it as a potentially average pitch. Meanwhile, a clean and repeatable delivery has helped to make PERSON an accomplished strike-thrower early in his career.Much like GPE, PERSON impressed last summer in his brief ORGANIZATION debut, and he continued to do so in 2017, his first full year with the organization. He lacks projection in his physical 6-foot-3 frame and needs to stay healthy, but PERSON has both the stuff and command profile to develop into a No. 2 starter.

PERSON's athleticism has been the key to his success an amateur and the belief is that his natural abilities will help propel him through the ORGANIZATION and ultimately to the big leagues. After targeting lean, athletic, middle-of-the-field players in recent international classes, the ORGANIZATION continued down that path in 2019 with PERSON, whom they signed for $2.1 million out of the ORGANIZATION at the outset of the July 2 period.The tall and large-framed teen already shows advanced hitting skills and knowledge of the strike zone, and it's easy to envision him filling out nicely into his highly projectable frame. He makes solid contact from the right side of the plate and is known for hitting line drives to all fields. He has shown flashes of emerging power and projects to be an average hitter.What's certain is that PERSON is true centerfielder and has the skill set to stay at the position as he grows and develops. He projects to be a plus runner and that skill will help make him into an above-average defender.

PERSON showed well in GPE's rotation as a sophomore but was unable to make progress the next year, spending much of the season in the bullpen with underwhelming results. The ORGANIZATION selected him in the 23rd round that June, and he pitched at both Class A levels during his full-season debut before advancing to Double-A in 2016 and making his big league debut early in the '17 season.A physically strong right-hander, PERSON pitches with a plus fastball that sits 94-96 mph and touches 97 with late sinking action that has resulted in strong ground-ball rates throughout his career. His low-80s slider plays well against right-handed hitters thanks to its depth and tilt, at times flashing above average, though his overall consistency with the pitch leaves much to be desired. PERSON holds his own against lefties in spite of his lack of a changeup, but he may need to add the pitch to his arsenal in order to retire them at the highest level.PERSON has the ability to work more than one inning, which he did in 23 of his 48 appearances (including four starts) in 2016. That stamina could make him a long reliever in the big leagues, though he does have the potential for a greater role if he can improve his slider and fastball command.

The son of former big league pitcher PERSON and brother of the ORGANIZATION' PERSON, PERSON has moved slowly and steadily, one level at a time, up the ORGANIZATION' organizational ladder ever since he was taken as the ORGANIZATION. 5 overall pick in the 2014 Draft. His move to the upper levels of the system in 2017 was largely a successful one, including a ORGANIZATION invite and LOCATION All-Star nod, though he did struggle in the second half of the season.Gordon is the type of player who may not jump off the page with any one tool, but does a number of things well. He's typically employed a successful contact-oriented, line-drive approach from the left side of the plate. He did show more extra-base power in Double-A, but with that came a higher strikeout rate, though an increased walk rate offset that to a degree. He's a solid runner with good instincts and will steal a base on occasion, and is a tick above-average defensively, both in terms of his arm and overall actions at shortstop. Many have felt his range points to being a better fit at second base and while he did still primarily play short, he did see more time on the right side of the infield in 2017.Gordon will be 22 for all of the 2018 season and is knocking on the big league door. He's more of a high floor than ceiling type and isn't far away from showing just what kind of solid everyday big leaguer he can be, on either side of second base.

A fifth-round pick out of GPE in 2012, PERSON had what was supposed to be his first full season all but wiped out by PERSON surgery. He returned to action in 2014 with PERSON, where he earned All-Star honors in the LOCATION, and he was named as a ORGANIZATION All-Star in '15 with PERSON. Though he didn't fare as well with the move to Double-A in 2016, a late-season injury to PERSON enabled PERSON to make his big league debut on Oct. 2.PERSON is an advanced receiver who can frame, and he's long received praise for his ability to handle a pitching staff. His arm is plenty strong -- even after PERSON surgery -- and consistently plays up thanks to his quiet footwork, clean transfer and quick release. As a right-handed hitter with good contact skills, PERSON is at his best when he employs an up-the-middle approach, though it does detract from his power potential. He hasn't hit for much of an average as he's climbed the ladder, but he has retained a strong approach and continues to get on base at a solid clip.PERSON profiles as a defensive-minded backup at the highest level, though concerns do remain about his overall hitting ability.

While he lacks a standout tool, PERSON has a well-rounded skillset and might be able to tap into more power if he starts using his lower half more efficiently in pro ball. He projects, defensively, to right field.

The ORGANIZATION didn't have a first-round pick in 2016 after signing PERSON, but felt fortunate when PERSON, perceived by many to be a first-round talent, fell to them in the second round and the 59th overall pick of the GPE. After three years of producing at ORGANIZATION, he's continued to do so as a pro, bringing a career .312/.363/.469 line with him to the ORGANIZATION courtesy of the PERSON trade. He was a week into his ORGANIZATION organization debut with Double-A Altoona when a broken hamate shelved him for an extended period.While none of PERSON' tools jump off the page, he does a lot of things fairly well. He's a switch-hitter who has shown he can hit for average from both sides of the plate and did so for all of his first full season following a rough April. He can drive the ball and there could be more over-the-fence pop if he can continue to make adjustments and refine his approach. There is some swing-and-miss to his game that concerns some, but he did cut his strikeout rate in the second half of 2017. PERSON has played all three outfield positions during his pro career and has enough speed to stay there should the ORGANIZATION want him to. He's probably a better defender in a corner, but profiles as a solid big league regular when all is said and done.

GPE hasn't produced a first-rounder since the ORGANIZATION made PERSON the fourth overall choice in 2006. PERSON entered 2015 with a chance to end that drought because he had the stuff and physicality to become one of the first college pitchers taken, but he went down in mid-March with a shoulder impingement and never returned to the mound.Scouts liked the way PERSON pitched off his 89-94 mph sinker with the GPE collegiate national team last summer. At times he'll hit 97 mph with his heater and back it up with a plus slider and solid changeup, though not on a consistent basis. His stuff was down this year before he was sidelined.A 21st-round pick by the ORGANIZATION as a GPE high schooler in 2012, PERSON has a classic starter's build at 6-foot-5 and 220 pounds. He throws strikes but needs better command in order to miss as many bats as his stuff indicates he should.

PERSON initially impressed scouts on the showcase circuit as a left-hander with impressive movement on three potential above-average pitches. He continued to pitch well this spring, and he ultimately became the highest drafted high school player from GPE when the ORGANIZATION selected him 12th overall in June.PERSON' fastball has hit 95 mph, but he more typically throws it around 90-91. He doesn't need big velocity to miss bats, however, as his low arm slot produces tremendous run and sink on his heater.PERSON' upper-70s slider has so much lateral break that at times he struggles to keep it in the strike zone, and his changeup dives at the plate. PERSON' small stature and unconventional delivery lead to concerns about his long-term viability in the rotation, though his athleticism gives him a real chance to make it as a starter.

â¢ 7/19: PERSON reinstated from ORGANIZATION shoulder injury that kept him out for his entire sophomore season at ORGANIZATION hurt PERSON's stock leading into the 2016 Draft despite a healthy junior campaign. Those concerns weren't assuaged when he threw just one inning in his pro debut due to elbow soreness, but he took a huge step toward erasing doubts with a dominant and healthy first full season that saw him lead the Minors in GPE (1.39) while pitching across two levels and attending the ORGANIZATION. He was shelved for an extended period in 2018 with right biceps tendinitis that limited him to just 67 innings in Double-A, but made up for lost time with an impressive performance in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON made his big league debut early in the 2019 season, tossing three scoreless innings out of the bullpen to record a save. PERSON's fastball usually sits in the 93-95 mph range, but he can reach back for more when needed. He throws it with sink and run, making him effective both at getting ground-ball outs and missing bats. His slider is at least above average and represents his best secondary offering, thrown with power, at 85-87 mph, and late biting action that nets him whiffs and is especially lethal against righties. He also throws an effective curveball in the low 80s and has feel for a mid-80s changeup, though he'll need to refine the latter to neutralize left-handed hitters. He's around the strike zone with his entire four-pitch mix.The strong and athletic PERSON has helped remake his delivery with remarkable success, but concerns likely will persist on account of his arm action and low three-quarters slot. If he can stay healthy, PERSON's combination of athleticism, stuff and command point to a ceiling of a mid-rotation starter.

PERSON was just a sophomore when the ORGANIZATION took three ORGANIZATION (left-hander PERSON, catcher PERSON and third baseman PERSON) in the first seven rounds of the 2011 Draft. But the ORGANIZATION went back to the well the next year, selecting PERSON in the fifth round. While a midseason promotion to Double-A PERSON reunited him with PERSON and GPE, PERSON has already passed them as a prospect. He has a quick, compact swing that allows him to catch up to any fastball. His slight frame doesn't produce much power, however. Defensively, PERSON has soft hands and a good arm. He has quieted some of the concerns about his range, though he still might end up at second base or as a utility infielder. PERSON earns high marks for his confidence and work ethic.
PERSON was part of the ORGANIZATION trade and he's spent time in Double-A every year since 2016. He has standard 40 FV, middle relief stuff, but he's 28 and has a long injury history.

A cousin of PERSON, PERSON has drawn comparisons to GPE, PERSON and PERSON since the ORGANIZATION made him the 28th overall pick in the 2009 Draft. PERSON used him as part of a four-player package to pry PERSON from GPE in December 2010, and PERSON appeared in the ORGANIZATION and made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in 2013. The ORGANIZATION' new front-office regime opted not to protect him on their 40-man roster this offseason, instead trading him to the ORGANIZATION for left-hander PERSON Bartsch.While PERSON' well above-average speed has helped him hit for average and steal bases throughout his pro career. He uses the entire field and will work some walks, but he strikes out too much for someone who doesn't drive the ball. Some scouts worry that his lack of strength will allow big league pitchers to simply overpower him.PERSON is a quality defender in center field, covering plenty of ground from gap to gap. His fringy arm isn't a huge liability but isn't conducive to filling in as a right fielder. He has turned out to be more like PERSON than PERSON or ORGANIZATION, and projects more as a fourth outfielder than an everyday player.

After a somewhat lackluster first full year in 2011, where he finished with a 4.11 ORGANIZATION in the LOCATION, it may have been surprising to some that PERSON was double-jumped to Double-A to start the 2012 season. He rose to the challenge, finishing second in the organization in batting average against, third in strikeouts and fifth in ORGANIZATION. He has pretty good stuff from the left side with a fastball that touches 93 mph. It has good sink to it, eliciting many groundball outs. He has a curve and a slider and can vary them well. He maintains good arm speed on his changeup, giving him the chance for a four-pitch mix. He'll need to cut down on his walks, but he's not far from being ready to help out the big league rotation.

It's not uncommon for a team to draft a college reliever and give him a chance to start. It becomes unusual when that pitcher goes out and finishes in the top 10 in ORGANIZATION in each of his first three full pro seasons, as PERSON did in 2013-15 before being dealt to GPE in January 2016. PERSON made his ORGANIZATION debut in a spot start for PERSON at the end of May and then made two more starts at the end of the season. He's found success pitching off of his low-90s, heavy, sinking fastball. Using that closer mentality from his days at ORGANIZATION, he goes right after hitters, inducing weak contact early in counts. His slider is a solid average hard breaking ball with bite that misses bats. While his changeup isn't quite as good, it is effective at neutralizing left-handed hitters. His walk rate has gone down each year since his summer debut and he continues to get a good amount of groundball outs.His brief big league debut was just a taste, with PERSON very close to being ready to fulfill a ceiling as a mid-to-back of the rotation type of starter at the highest level.

PERSON made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in 2013, building off his solid 2012 season that saw him nearly win the LOCATION batting title. PERSON understands what his game is -- making consistent contact, spraying line drives with a little gap power, while using his speed to make things happen. He has very good speed, and his instincts on the basepaths make him even better. That speed works well in the outfield, where he's capable of playing all three spots well. His lack of power may mean he's never going to be an everyday corner outfielder, but a career as a top-of-the-order catalyst in center or as a valuable fourth outfielder seems a distinct possibility.

PERSON displayed a 92-96 mph fastball as a reliever at ORGANIZATION, but his elbow often bothered him after he pitched. He preferred playing on an everyday basis anyway, and showed enough promise as a middle infielder to get drafted in the seventh round last June. His .388 batting average would have led the Rookie-level PERSON if he hadn't been promoted to high Class A and fell a few plate appearances short of qualifying.The ORGANIZATION already consider PERSON one of the more advanced hitters in their system. He handles the bat and controls the strike zone better than most of their prospects. He's an average runner with no more than gap power, so most of his offensive value comes from his ability to get on base.PERSON played some shortstop in his pro debut, but his arm doesn't respond well to longer throws, so he's better suited for second base. A reliable defender with sure hands, he excels at turning the double play.

PERSON entered the spring with the potential to be one of the top college arms in the 2013 Draft class. Some inconsistent performances hurt his stock a bit, but the ORGANIZATION, known for liking big arms, couldn't let this GPE right-hander's pure stuff get by them in the first round. PERSON's fastball is a plus pitch, one that can touch 96 mph. He complements it with a very good hard breaking ball. PERSON and with a good delivery, PERSON ran into trouble with command and the fact that everything he threw was hard. His ability to change speeds effectively will be a key to his future as a starting pitcher.

GPE's Saturday starter, behind PERSON, PERSON fits the mold of the college lefty, one who has average stuff but with some knowledge of pitching.PERSON's fastball will touch 91 mph, though there is some room for growth in his frame, meaning he could gain a tick or two with some maturity. His curve has been inconsistent but has the potential to be an average breaking ball. He doesn't throw his changeup enough, and it will have to improve as he moves to the next level.Generally around the plate, if PERSON can develop three average pitches, he has the chance to be a big league starter in the future.

Everything you say about PERSON, you can say about PERSON, except for one thing: his size. PERSON doesn't "look the part" quite as much, but he still has just as many tools as his fellow GPE prepster. A right-handed hitter, PERSON ran a 6.6 second 60 at the LOCATION Pro Showcase over the summer. He also might have a more advanced bat than most of the high schoolers in the class, with a quick, short stroke that generates more power than you might expect given his frame. The lack of physicality might concern some, but his collection of tools should keep him high on GPE boards all spring.Like PERSON, PERSON made the rounds this past summer and played well. That continued into the spring, including a two-homer game when he faced off against his GPE contemporary. PERSON might have the higher upside, but some scouts said watching PERSON was like evaluating a college hitter because of his "now" tools.

PERSON's ability to hit was brought into question by amateur scouts, but he's already hit his way to Hi-A at age 19 and hasn't slowed down. PERSON's arm strength has come and gone throughout his last two years of baseball but he's still running well enough to play center field so there's no need to decide between left and right as a defensive home right now. He reminds many of PERSON and PERSON.

Thompson-Williams played for two years at FACILITY CC before transferring in 2016 to GPE and becoming the ORGANIZATION' fifth-round pick that June. After a nondescript pro debut that continued throughout his first full season, Thompson-Williams was one of six Minor Leaguers to record at least 20 homers and 20 stolen bases during a breakout 2018 campaign, much of which he spent in the ORGANIZATION State League before receiving a late promotion to Double-A for the LOCATION playoffs. The ORGANIZATION took note of the performance, and ultimately acquired him, along with PERSON and PERSON, from the ORGANIZATION in the PERSON deal in November.Thompson-Williams has an intriguing blend of tools, most notable among them the power-speed combo that netted him the 22 homers and 20 steals that ranked first and third, respectively, among ORGANIZATION farmhands. He drives the ball to the big parts of the field, showing above-average power from the left side of the plate, though questions remain about his ability to make consistent contact and hit for average against advanced pitching.Above-average speed helps Thompson-Williams to make an impact on the basepaths as well as in center field, where scouts consider him to be an above-average defender with an average arm, one capable of playing all three outfield positions. The potential exists for Thompson-Williams to develop into an everyday player, though a fourth or fifth outfielder role is more realistic.

PERSON was a new name to most scouts last summer when he starred as the sparkplug for collegiate PERSON, playing center field and batting atop the lineup along with FACILITY 2018 first round second baseman PERSON. PERSON showed bat control and gap power, and was a fringe first rounder for many off that first, extended look on PERSON, but he came out this spring looking like a different player. He had become more physical and changed his swing to incorporate his added strength, lifting the ball and evolving from a gap-to-gap speed player into a potential monster with plus raw power, arm strength and speed. 
PERSON didn't put up the gaudy numbers you'd expect for a guy with top level tools in a mid-major conference who had also hit with wood on the GPE, and it was because his new swing would get out of whack. His weight transfer was too aggressive at times, causing him to lose balance and be in a poor position to hit offspeed stuff. PERSON's developmental issue is dialing in his swing mechanics and approach to something that best takes advantage of his explosive tools, which could be a multi-year process.

The GPE signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, and then sent him stateside for his pro debut the following year. He's continued to progress in the face of aggressive assignments and has held his own as one of the youngest players at each level to begin his career. PERSON moved up to the full-season ORGANIZATION last year and made developmental strides on both sides of the ball as PERSON's everyday catcher. He returned to PERSON this season to hit .347 over 60 games and received a promotion to Class A Advanced Lynchburg in late June. The switch-hitting PERSON knows how to handle the bat. He has natural hitting ability from both sides of the plate and makes hard contact consistently, while his combination of physical strength and bat speed produces good raw power. PERSON began to tap into that raw frequently last year in the ORGANIZATION, and he's continued to make strides in that department in 2016.PERSON continues to develop behind the plate, where he projects to be at least an average defender. His well above-average arm strength is his best tool and helped him throw out 31 percent of would-be basestealers in 2015, and he improved upon that mark by posting a 44-percent caught-stealing rate this season in his return to PERSON. And while he's improved as a blocker and game-caller as a result of handling advanced pitching staffs, the 20-year-old still has significant gains to make as a receiver. With undeniable upside, PERSON has all the ingredients to develop into an everyday catcher in the big leagues.

PERSON surged from two homers as a ORGANIZATION sophomore to 18 (fourth in ORGANIZATION Division I) as a junior in 2015, spurring the ORGANIZATION to select him in the sixth round. He has been one of the system's most productive hitters ever since, slamming 61 homers in his first three full seasons despite missing two months in 2018 with an oblique injury. He stood out with a huge spring in big league camp in 2018, but that still couldn't change the fact that he's blocked in GPE with PERSON and PERSON at his two best positions.Thanks to his strength and solid bat speed, PERSON provides left-handed power to all fields and does damage against both southpaws and right-handers. Though he's extremely aggressive and his strikeout rate rose from 21 percent in 2017 to 32 percent last year when he tried to do too much to make up for lost time, his hand-eye coordination generally allows him to make repeated hard contact. He never has walked much but is capable of batting .250 with 25 homers if he gets regular at-bats in the big leagues.Though PERSON works hard to maintain his conditioning, his lack of speed and quickness limit his value on the bases and in the field. He has spent the majority of his pro career at third base and has enough arm strength for the position, but he has limited range and has been prone to errors there. His best position is first base and he can play an adequate left field but doesn't cover much ground.

It's possible PERSON would have been PERSON's best everyday option at catcher toward the end of last year, but a desperate need for pitching depth facilitated his trade to PERSON for PERSON. PERSON is an athletic catcher with a plus arm, average receiving skills, and some feel to hit. After struggling to perform with the bat during the first several years of his career, PERSON has two straight season of league-average offensive performance at ORGANIZATION and Triple-A. He has a pull-and-lift style of hitting, but not enough raw power to optimize that kind of approach. He's a safe bet to be a quality backup and has a non-zero chance to hit a little more than we expect and be a low-end regular.

The Rule 5 Draft is all about finding a diamond in the rough. That's particularly true in the case of GPE, who was initially a second-round pick by the Twins in 2014 after a tremendous career as PERSON's closer. He's had trouble staying healthy, however, missing nearly all of 2016 with an elbow bone bruise and then needing PERSON surgery in May of 2017. The ORGANIZATION thought his arm strength was worth the gamble, sending international bonus money to get him from the ORGANIZATION, who took him third in December's Rule 5.GPE rehabbed from surgery and was back on the mound in GPE, with the ORGANIZATION hopeful he can rediscover the nasty power stuff that made him look like a future closer. His fastball sits easily in the upper 90s and has hit triple digits. He backs that up with a nasty plus slider that serves as a true strikeout pitch and can even mix in a changeup against left-handed hitters. ORGANIZATION has been an issue and while hit doesn't have to be pinpoint, his time missed hasn't helped him learn to find the strike zone more consistently.The ORGANIZATION are pleased he made it back to competitive pitching in 2018. When he's ready, he'll have to spend 90 days on the big league active roster to get past Rule 5 restrictions.

PERSON led ORGANIZATION prepsters in homers for three straight years and offered some of the best power among high school middle infielders in the 2014 Draft, but a so-so senior season and signability issues left him unselected and headed to PERSON. After playing sparingly as a freshman, PERSON erupted to hit 11 home runs the next year, then he blew past that total with 19 homers as a junior before going to the A's in the second round. After signing for $1.7 million, PERSON showcased his impressive power by hitting eight homers in 46 games as PERSON's everyday right fielder. Assigned to the GPE League for his first full season, PERSON logged just 10 games before a wrist injury landed him on the disabled list for nearly three months.PERSON's power is his calling card. The big left-handed hitter has impressed scouts with his bat speed and strength dating back to his high school days, and he's shown that he can get to it consistently in the past year-plus after shortening his swing and adopting a more selective approach. PERSON's improved approach also has helped him in using the entire field, though much of his power remains to his pull side. And while strikeouts will always be a part of PERSON's game given his power-over-hit profile, he does offset some of those concerns with perennially strong walk rates and on-base skills.A shortstop in high school, PERSON saw time at first base at ORGANIZATION before finding a home in right field, where his above-average arm and power profile are clean fits. He's a below-average runner but moves well underway, and with improved reads and routes, he could become an average defender.

PERSON no doubt benefitted from decision makers picking in the top five to 10 coming in to see PERSON, as his name seems to be in the mix at many of those teams' second picks. He's a stocky, athletic catcher with a fine arm, and surprising bat speed and power. He hit .320/.420/.626 this year, emerging as a likely Day 1 selection. PERSON hasn't caught a lot of pro-quality stuff at ORGANIZATION, so that part of his skillset remains somewhat unclear, but we think he's athletic enough to improve if it's initially an issue.

GPE has posted big power numbers everywhere he has gone in the last three years, starting with setting school records at LOCATION CC for batting (.419) and homers (16) in 2016, when GPE signed him as a fourth-rounder. He topped the Rookie-level PERSON in runs (63), total bases (161) and ORGANIZATION (1.052) during his pro debut, then encored by winning GPE League MVP honors and leading the Class A Advanced circuit in extra-base hits (61) and slugging (.514) during his first full season. He followed up in 2018 by pacing all Double-A hitters in homers (29) and the ORGANIZATION in extra-base hits (55) and total bases (232).Compared to PERSON for his power and surprising athleticism in a big frame, GPE can knock the ball out of any part of any ballpark thanks to his strength and leverage. His 6-foot-6 build comes with a naturally long right-handed swing that, coupled with his aggressive approach, resulted in a ORGANIZATION-worst 192 strikeouts and 34 percent whiff rate in 2018. He went through five different batting stances during the season as he searched for a way to make more contact, and the ORGANIZATION think he'll be able to do that after reworking his stroke during the offseason.GPE displays average speed out of the batter's box and is a step quicker once he gets going, which enabled him to play center field for the majority of his first three pro seasons. He's an average defender up the middle but better suited for a corner. His strong arm fits perfectly in right field, as does his power profile.

PERSON was premium prospect out of a ORGANIZATION high school, reportedly turning down over $2.5 million to go to Stanford as he had long wanted to do. There, PERSON had various injury issues and his stuff and command didn't progress as many had hoped, but he still showed glimpses of his upside from high school. In instructional league, he ran his fastball up to 96 mph, which didn't happen often in college, and his signature hammer curveball flashed plus once again. PERSON is still in the nether region of starter vs. reliever given his uneven track record and command that doesn't consistently flash average, but his power stuff will play in any role if he can continue showing what he did in instructional league.

PERSON is the nephew of PERSON, cousin of PERSON, Jr. and the two July 2nd prospects train together under PERSON in the GPE. The ORGANIZATION went hard after PERSON Jr. but ultimately pulled out when the price got too high and ended up gettign arguably the best 1-2 punch of prospects in this year's class with PERSON. PERSON has some of the same actions and swing mechanics as last year's top player, PERSON, and, like PERSON, also projects to move to third base eventually, but will play shortstop for the time being. PERSON isn't explosive like PERSON, who has 65-70 raw power and comparable bat speed, while PERSON is more above average in both regards, though PERSON has a much more under-control swing, so his offensive profile is more hit over power right now, though he should tap into that power more often in pro ball as he matures.

The son of former 11-year Major Leaguer Fernando PERSON ranked 30th on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 prospects list for the 2015-16 international period before signing for $700,000 with the FACILITY, who shipped him to the Padres the following June as part of the PERSON trade. He made an immediate impact in his pro debut, finishing the season as a 17-year-old in the Class A Short-Season LOCATION, and then emerged as a top-flight prospect in 2017 as he became the first 18-year-old in ORGANIZATION history to post at least 20 home runs and 20 stolen bases. Perhaps even more impressive was how PERSON handled himself after making the jump directly to Double-A PERSON in GPE, and he continued to draw raves in his return to level in 2018 before undergoing season-ending surgery for a fractured thumb in late July.PERSON has all the ingredients to become an offensive force in the Majors, as his bat speed, leveraged swing and overall capacity to make adjustments all portend a future plus hitter with plus power. He proved vulnerable to spin and sequencing early in the year but tightened his approach as the season progressed en route to pacing the ORGANIZATION with 75 walks. Many evaluators believe PERSON is merely scraping the surface of his offensive potential, as he still has considerable room to grow into his tall and athletic frame. That larger frame doesn't currently impede PERSON's abilities at shortstop, where he makes highlight-reel plays on a daily basis thanks to his athleticism, range and rocket arm, though further physical development could ultimately force him to third base. Even if that's case, PERSON's bat gives him the ceiling of a perennial All-Star, possibly even an ORGANIZATION candidate in his prime.

PERSON hits low-lying lasers, with several balls off the bat in excess of 115mph during PERSON's opening weekend in GPE. If sneaky plus-plus raw power exists, PERSON has it, as he generates it without taking max-effort hacks. There are teams that don't like PERSON in this range because they think he's a bad defender and/or they are concerned about his 20% strikeout rate, But PERSON's career 15% walk rate should help satiate the stat-driven people in draft rooms and his power numbers could take a jump if pro instruction coaxes more lift out of his swing. He checks every box for the risk-averse, analytics-driven clubs, which means he has a lot of potential homes in the 10-20 range.

Another talented infielder from GPE, PERSON is listed as a shortstop, and he could stay there once he signs with a ORGANIZATION team and makes his way through the club's ORGANIZATION system.That said, some scouts believe PERSON is better suited for second base or even third base because of his versatility and arm strength. Evaluators also like his footwork, good hands and fluid actions on defense. PERSON say PERSON has a good feel for hitting and should be able to hit for average. Some evaluators do question his power potential, but there is a belief that he will get bigger and stronger as he matures. PERSON also like the fact that PERSON knows the game and continues to show signs of improvement in every area. PERSON is based in GPE, GPE, and is trained by former ORGANIZATION infielder PERSON at the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION are the favorites to land PERSON.

The GPE signed PERSON out of GPE in 2014 because they liked his left arm and his feel for pitching at such a young age. While he had up-and-down results in the rookie levels of the system, they always felt there was a legitimate starting pitcher prospect in there and he started to show up in 2017, dominating from extended spring training all the way through his full-season debut in the ORGANIZATION League.While no one will ever mistake the smaller left-hander for a flamethrower, an uptick in overall stuff has certainly helped PERSON, as he missed more bats in 2017 than he had previously in his career. The velocity of his fastball his increased and he's now averaging 91 mph with it and touching 93 mph, thrown with good life to get ground-ball outs. He might have the best changeup in the system that fooled hitters on both sides of the plate and his big, looping curve improved as well, going from a third pitch that needed a ton of work to a third pitch he can count on. He can throw strikes with all three pitches, all coming from a very easy and repeatable delivery.There is a big up arrow next to PERSON's name currently as he pitches at age 20 in 2018. With the increased velocity and improvement in his breaking ball, he's made a big jump in the GPE system and used his pitchability to move more quickly.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, GPEFavorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, who is committed to ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION, was selected as a 2016 Underclass 2nd Teamer. The ORGANIZATION, GPE, native has participated in tournaments like the 2015 GPE World Series, the 2015 ORGANIZATION World Championship, the 2016 17U Perfect Game World Series and the 2016 ORGANIZATION World Championship.Gallegos is still raw, but he is lean and scouts see him as projectable. The right-hander has a funky, off-balance delivery from a three-quarter arm slot, but his fastball presently sits at 86-88 mph. He needs some time to develop, but if he adds strength he will continue to intrigue even further.

A very prominent high school prospect, PERSON matriculated to GPE and became a core of their lineup almost immediately. Though his swing is somewhat grooved, he's an athletic swinger with power who is also quite good at third base. He's in the mix for teams picking 30-50, with GPE and GPE as rumored landing spots.
GPE has feel to hit from both sides of the plate and a non-zero chance to stick in center field, though he isn't as sure a bet to stay there as the some of the true burners ahead of him on this list.

When PERSON was taken in the first round of the 2013 Draft, he was thought to be perhaps the best pure high school hitter in the class. He really started living up to that billing in 2015, when he won the ORGANIZATION State PERSON and then went on to hit very well in the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON has always had a very good approach at the plate and tremendous hand-eye coordination. That has led to good batting average and on-base numbers, as he topped .300 in two of his first three professional seasons. There has always been some question about how much power PERSON will have, but he started showing more extra-base pop during his breakout campaign. His walk rate jumped from 4.5 per nine innings in his first two seasons to 6.5 in his third, a sign that he's more likely to become a late-inning reliever than a frontline starter.

At times, PERSON looks like a stiff, velo-only bullpen prospect. At others, he's competing in or near the zone with four pitches, including a splitter that got much better over the winter. All four pitches give hitters a vastly different look. PERSON' mid-90s fastball has tailing action, his curveball has vertical depth and eats up hitters who are cheating on velo, the split has late bottom when it's on, and the slider has horizontal, cutting action. The movement profile of PERSON' fastball may not be the best for missing bats, but it's likely to be an impact pitch because of the velocity. He could end up with three average secondaries (there's a chance the split becomes better than that) and enough strikes to start, making him a potential No. 4/5 starter.

In many ways, the 2014 season was a huge success for PERSON, as the GPE native competed well as an 18-year-old in the ORGANIZATION. Both have the chance to be solid average pitches, but they need to be tightened up, as his curve gets loopy at times. His command should improve with more experience.PERSON cites former big leaguer PERSON as a mentor. If PERSON can return to full health, the former GPE reliever should be able to watch his pupil with pride in the middle of a big league rotation in the future.

PERSON is an above average runner whose strides allow him to adequately traverse center field for now, though he has a very projectable frame and could move to a corner. His swing is flat and his timing is poor, but PERSON has loose hands and gorgeous extension through contact. He has the physical tools to thi, he just needs a mechanical adjustment, and it's even more imperative he gets one if he eventually moves to a corner.

Primarily a reliever in his first two seasons at FACILITY A&M, PERSON opened his junior year as the ORGANIZATION' No. 3 starter and claimed the top spot in their rotation by mid-April. He won his first eight decisions over his first nine starts, boosting his ORGANIZATION stock into the first three rounds. His fastball operates in the low 90s and tops out at 94 mph, and his sink and downhill plane allow him to pound the bottom of the strike zone. He can throw his low-80s slider for strikes or entice hitters to chase it off the plate, and he does a nice job of locating his average changeup to keep left-handers honest.PERSON has an easy delivery and no trouble repeating it, allowing him to steadily improve his control throughout his college career. He doesn't have the sexiest ceiling, but he has a high floor as a safe bet to start. His track record of performance in multiple roles in the rugged LOCATION also helps his cause.

PERSON ORGANIZATION and PERSON are in the big leagues making large contributions. PERSON could be the next homegrown bat to make a huge impact in GPE. The third baseman has a ton of bat speed and has the ability to drive the ball from both sides of the plate, and he should continue to tap into his raw power. His improvements with his approach and plate discipline are helping him become a better all-around hitter. PERSON is an above-average runner and his athleticism, not to mention his plus throwing arm, will help him stay at third long-term. He has the chance to be a very good everyday big leaguer whose tools work very well on both sides of the ball.

GPE isn't typically a hotbed for high school pitching talent, though a good arm comes from the region from time to time. In this year's PERSON class, right-hander PERSON is the top talent, even with his injury, and while PERSON isn't in the same conversation, he is the best left-hander from the area.Aside from his left-handedness, PERSON has size, stuff and projectability working in his favor. The 6-foot-4 southpaw has room to grow into his frame, which means there could me more to his fastball in the future, which he can throw anywhere from 86 to 93 mph, sitting comfortably right around 89-90 mph. His slider projects as at least average, if not more, once he tightens it more consistently. It can have some slurve action to it, but it has enough depth to be a potential swing and miss pitch. He doesn't use a changeup at all and hasn't needed it at his high school level. He has a funky delivery, all arms and legs, which adds deception, but he still throws strikes.Scouts have watched PERSON carefully, particularly since last summer's PERSON, and were running in to see him as the weather warmed in GPE. He's committed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE, but a team might be willing to gamble on his upside from the left side to take him early enough to sign.

One of the best high school position prospects in the 2013 Draft, PERSON saw his chances of going in the first round disappear when he tore the meniscus in his right knee in a season-opening doubleheader. PERSON has good speed but isn't as quick as he was in high school, though he did make noticeable gains with his basestealing technique and reading pitchers in '17. PERSON can hold his own in center field, where he gets good jumps and takes efficient routes on fly balls, but he likely profiles better at an outfield corner long-term. He's seen time at all three spots early in his career, portending a potential career as a fourth or fifth outfielder in the big leagues.

PERSON has thrown just three pro innings since signing, as the minor flexor strain that shelved him after his draft turned out to be a prelude to surgery. He was given a ORGANIZATION injection in an attempt to avoid PERSON, but it was unsuccessful and he was operated on in early July of 2018. His velocity ticked up the following spring and he was touching 96, then sat 92-95 in his few pro innings before his injury. If his stuff comes back, he has No. 4 starter upside.

Ever since the D-backs acquired PERSON from the ORGANIZATION for a ORGANIZATION B pick, all the outfielder has done is hit. He's mostly played the corners, but he also is capable of manning center field.Just 22 for all of the 2017 season, the move to Double-A was a good test for PERSON and his contact-oriented approach. If he can grow into a little more extra-base pop, he could become an everyday corner outfielder, though he likely profiles better as a fourth outfielder, a role he will get a chance to fill right away in 2018.

PERSON was a bit of an afterthought as a prospect after he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $55,000 in 2011. He took home the award again the following season while finishing the year in Double-A, prompting the ORGANIZATION to add him to their 40-man roster. PERSON stands out most for his natural hitting ability, as he's an advanced left-handed hitter with a mature approach and a clean, repeatable swing that generates hard contact from line to line and gives him utility against same-sided arms. He has some pop, too, albeit mostly to the gaps, but the ORGANIZATION believe he'll eventually clear more fences once he becomes comfortable turning on the ball and letting the barrel fly. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON as a can't-miss athlete, PERSON is a unique prospect because of his incredible production as both a wide receiver and as a hard-throwing right-handed pitcher.With a commitment to GPE for baseball, PERSON may potentially leave behind a highly successful football career that featured 34 touchdowns in one season, the second-highest single-season mark in GPE high school football history.After hitting over .400 and going undefeated as a pitcher in 2016, PERSON was named to the ORGANIZATION baseball team, a roster made of the best baseball players in the state of GPE. PERSON took the ORGANIZATION by storm in his first full professional season, showing why many evaluators had rated him as the top talent in the 2012 Draft class. PERSON landed an above-slot bonus from the GPE as a seventh-rounder in 2011, forgoing his commitment to PERSON. PERSON's defense, much like his bat, has steadily improved, though questions remain about whether he can catch regularly at the highest level. He's worked to clean up his footwork in recent years while also making gains as a blocker and receiver. He continues to show a strong arm, and it helped him throw out a career-high 37 percent of attempted basestealers in 2017.

The compensation pick the ORGANIZATION received for losing PERSON to free agency, PERSON signed for $1.9 million as the 30th overall pick in 2013.
