PERSON struck out in 35 percent of his plate appearances over his first three pro seasons, in large part because he's still figuring out how to deal with breaking pitches.A shortstop in high school, PERSON has a strong arm and average speed that many scouts thought would fit best at third base. With PERSON and PERSON at third base, the ORGANIZATION moved him to second base in 2014. PERSON had adapted well to his new position and should become at least an average defender there. Now without those obstacles, but the possibility of PERSON playing second for a long time, the ORGANIZATION might consider giving PERSON a look at the hot corner.

Any baseball field PERSON is on, he looks like he belongs, whether it was as the youngest regular in the ORGANIZATION in 2012 or in a big league stadium at the ORGANIZATION. An argument can be made that PERSON is the best defensive shortstop in the Minors. Not only does he have an outstanding arm and well above-average range, but those tools play up because of his off-the-charts instincts and feel for the position. But he's far from all glove. He has a quick swing and advanced approach that leads to hard line drives to all fields. He has some power, particularly to the pull side, but can also play small ball. An above-average runner, those instincts allow him to be a basestealing threat. His tools combined with his plus plus makeup have most believing he'll make an impact in GPE in a hurry.

A very prominent high school prospect, PERSON matriculated to GPE and became a core of their lineup almost immediately. Though his swing is somewhat grooved, he's an athletic swinger with power, who is also quite good at third base. He has a shot to be an everyday third baseman.

PERSON has quickly taken to pitching since the ORGANIZATION moved him from the infield to the mound after signing him out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012. He stood out in the ORGANIZATION League the next year, but his progress was slowed in 2014 by a left wrist fracture that kept him out the final two months of the season. PERSON has a projectable frame and a powerful arm. His fastball already reaches 98 mph and his power curveball has plus potential as well. He also throws a changeup, which is still in its nascent stages of development. He has proven to be adept at generating groundballs.Thanks to his athleticism and exciting stuff, PERSON has a lot of upside. More than anything, he needs to get more innings under his belt so he can learn more of the nuances of his craft.

ORGANIZATION was started a few years ago in GPE as a place for high-level high school level players to focus more of their day on baseball, while taking care of classwork online through the ORGANIZATION. ORGANIZATION has been one of the better products of the academy to date, with some serious upside, though it does not come without risk.There is no question that ORGANIZATION looks the part of an impactful offensive player and has the bat skills to go along with it. He has tremendous raw power with the ability to drive the ball with the kind of different sound you hear from some hitters when he makes contact. With that power, however, comes some considerable swing and miss issues, as scouts see a grooved swing. It goes a long way when the ball is thrown in that groove, but he doesn't always adjust when it's not. A fringy rurnner, ORGANIZATION is a capable outfielder with a very strong arm, and he gets high marks for his makeup. If a team believes he can make enough contact to tap into that power, it could see him as a future run-producing right fielder and take him early enough to keep him from heading to ORGANIZATION.

He lasted 26 rounds in the 2011 Draft, yet PERSON commanded a $175,000 bonus after boosting his stock in the ORGANIZATION that summer. PERSON didn't get much of an early return on its investment as he posted a 4.73 ERA in his first three pro seasons, but he had a breakthrough season in Double-A in 2015. He trusts his changeup more than his curveball, though the latter shows flashes of becoming an average third offering with some depth.PERSON has improved his control significantly during the last two years, enhancing his chances of becoming a back-of-the-rotation starter. He doesn't miss a lot of bats because he doesn't have a standout second offering or sharp command, so he might be best as a middle reliever who might pitch in the mid 90s in short stints.

PERSON nearly signed with the ORGANIZATION for $80,000 as a 23rd-round pick out of high school in 2010, but the deal died when a physical revealed a bone chip in his elbow. He spent a year each at FACILITY (Fla.) JC and PERSON (Fla.) JC before turning pro as a fourth-rounder in 2012. He spent his pro debut as a reliever, then skipped a level, became a starter and led the Class A Advanced PERSON with 139 strikeouts and 9.4 whiffs per nine innings last year.With his four-pitch repertoire, PERSON should be able to remain in the rotation. He throws 90-93 mph on a downhill plane and can reach 96. He has improved his secondary pitches since signing, as his hard slider and sinking changeup can be solid at times, and he also can mix in a decent curveball.PERSON lacks a true plus pitch but still has the ceiling of a No. 3 or 4 starter. There may be a little more projection remaining in his 6-foot-4 frame, and his clean delivery is easy to repeat and allows him to throw lots of strikes.
A plus runner likely to stay in GPE has present gap power and a fair amount of physical projection.

PERSON's massive raw power and frame drew comparisons to PERSON and garnered him a $950,000 bonus as a supplemental first-round pick in 2012. He homered three times in his first five pro games but has battled injuries and strikeout issues since.PERSON's bat speed and strength allow him to hit balls farther than most players. His very long arms create good leverage but also give him a very long swing. He's not going to realize his power potential unless he can make more contact, do a better job of recognizing pitches and learn to solve breaking balls.Though PERSON has below-average speed, he moves well around the first-base bag. He still has work to do defensively after leading high Class A ORGANIZATION first basemen with 19 errors, more any player made at that position in any league in 2014.

One of four international shortstops to get a bonus of at least $750,000 from the ORGANIZATION during the 2014-15 international signing period, PERSON landed $1 million out of GPE. Because he was the oldest of the group, GPE pushed him the most aggressively, but he struggled to solve low Class A pitching in 2016. He has looked much more comfortable at the plate after returning to the LOCATION League this season.The ORGANIZATION handed PERSON a seven-figure bonus in part because they believed he had a higher offensive ceiling than most shortstops. He squares up a lot of balls with a sound left-handed swing and has a patient approach. He has some sneaky power and could be a double-digit home run threat once he adds some strength to his skinny frame.PERSON has plus speed and already possesses basestealing instincts. He has the tools to be a solid defender at either shortstop or second base, though he's erratic and must improve his consistency. He has a strong arm but doesn't always show it unless he has to.

PERSON was a big name out of high school, reportedly turning down seven figures to go to PERSON knowing he would be an eligible sophomore due to his age. He had an up-and-down sophomore spring. PERSON came out of the chute blazing hot and had top-10 pick buzz for the first month of the season, then slowly regressed. PERSON thought he needed a delivery adjustment in to make him more direct to the plate, a way to improve his fastball control. They also thought he was too reliant on his curveball. To that point, hitters late in the season would sit on the pitch, knowing he had trouble locating his fastball and that he barely threw his changeup. It led to some bad outings, including one at GPE where he allowed 11 runs. 
Since being drafted, PERSON has worked more frequently with all three of his pitches, throwing 66% of his pitches for strikes, and his velocity has remained in the 92-94 range even as he throws every fifth day (mostly) rather than once a week. He could end up with three above-average pitches and be a No. 4 or No. 4/5 starter.

The FACILITY snagged one of the best power hitters available in both the 2016 and 2017 Drafts, spending first-round picks on catcher PERSON and PERSON. The latter bashed 21 homers (second in ORGANIZATION Division I) as a sophomore and 22 (en route to winning PERSON player of the year honors) as a junior last spring, becoming the first PERSON hitter ever taken in the first round. Signed for $3.7 million, he had little trouble adjusting to low Class A pitching in his pro debut but missed all of 2018 after rupturing his left Achilles tendon while running out a grounder in February and then tearing it a second time while rehabbing in May.Because he's a stocky right-handed slugger with some arm bar in his swing, PERSON draws comparisons to former GPE third baseman PERSON. With his strength and solid bat speed, he could produce 25 or more homers annually, though he needs to make adjustments to hit more balls in the air after posting a 1.5 groundout/airout ratio in his first taste of pro ball. With his patient approach and ability to make consistent contact, he should hit for average as well as power.PERSON isn't the most graceful athlete but gets the job done in all phases of the game, making him sort of a corner-infield version of PERSON. He's quicker than he looks, displaying average speed out of the batter's box and decent range at third base. With a solid arm, reliable hands and a strong work ethic, he should be able to stick at the hot corner.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON has played the guitar, piano and saxophone since he was six years old and accomplished his goal of being fluent in GPE Chinese after studying the language for four years. PERSON is a superb talent who can't help but take max-effort swings at just about everything. His approach and early-career maturity issues (which have improved but still exist) slowed his development a bit and he only has half a season at Double-A despite being 23 and having played pro ball for six seasons. But PERSON has great bat speed, power, and an innate feel for impacting the bottom of the baseball and lifting it into the air. If he weren't so aggressive (he appeared to be under a mandate to see more pitches in 2018) he'd be an easy plus future hit, plus future power center field prospect in the middle of our top 100. But the volatility created by the impatience, combined with PERSON's noticeably thicker 2018 frame, has created apprehension. His upside is huge, but so is the risk. Ultimately, he shares many traits with Phillies outfielder PERSON (though PERSON's a better defender by a wide margin), and, like PERSON, PERSON might just be such an amazing offensive talent that he'll be fine eventually despite his issues and several developmental bumps in the road.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON made his professional debut the next year in the ORGANIZATION. His performance and tools stood out in the league, leaving scouts optimistic about his considerable upside. He has continued to excel after coming to the GPE in 2015.PERSON is an excellent athlete and has impressive physical tools. He has an advanced approach at the plate and projects to be able to hit for average and power as he physically matures. He has well above-average speed and covers a lot of ground in the outfield. His strong arm will help him man a corner outfield position if he loses a step as he gets older, but he has a good chance to remain in center. PERSON understandably is still raw and learning to harness his physical ability. He's a long way away, but he already has given evaluators reason to be excited about the kind of player he could become.

PERSON had PERSON surgery in July and will miss most of 2018, if not all of it. He's also a reliever with lots of effort in his delivery. Once you get past those two things, there's only good news: he sits 97-100 and hits 102 mph, his slider is regularly plus to plus-plus and he's developed a changeup that's also plus. The rare plus three pitch mix and enough command to have some idea where those pitches are going makes him a near unicorn. Also, the surgery is less risky when you only need the guy to be healthy for 6 years, throwing 20-30 pitches at a time. Look for PERSON to deliver on his first round pedrigree as an elite reliever for the Sox in 2019, with the upside of one of the top 5 relievers in the game.

The way PERSON has pitched in 2013, it's somewhat curious why he wasn't the school's Friday starter from the start of the season. Regardless, he's pitched like one, showing a three-pitch mix and the ability to throw strikes with all three.PERSON's fastball will touch 93-94 mph and it has some late sink to it, giving him the ability to generate ground-ball outs. When he stays on top of his breaking ball, it's a solid curve with good tilt to it. He doesn't throw his changeup much, and it needs some work, but it has the chance to be a third average offering.Tall and strong, PERSON may not be among the elite-level college arms in this class, but he may not be too far behind.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $2 million just before the 2015 ORGANIZATION calendar turned over, then traded him to GPE for PERSON a few months later. In his pro debut, PERSON was a force of nature at Low-A before his in-game power tapered off after promotion to Hi-A Buies Creek. PERSON does have plus raw power and good feel to hit with a swing that has enough natural loft that scouts thihnk he'll hit for contact and power. That may take an adjustment that gets PERSON hitting the ball in the air more often, but the hope is that he just starts doing that naturally without mechanical compromise. PERSON looks athletic and fleet-footed enough to play an outfield corner right now but he's already a massive 225 pounds at a age 20 and will probably end up at first base. He has the physical capability to mash enough for first and his first season was encouraging. If the feel for airborne contact starts coming, he could move way up this list during the summer.

Coming out of the box, he gets down to first base in 4.22 seconds. In the field, PERSON has an average arm and with practice, should continue to improve upon taking more consistent routes to fly balls.

After a year of sitting 90-94, GPE's fastball velocity fluctuated pretty significantly both start-to-start and within individual games, often resting in the upper-80s like it did while he was in college. But he was also up to 95 at times, even reaching back for that kind of heat late in his starts. Some of the drop in velocity may have been artificial, a result of GPE working more on sinking and cutting his fastball rather than just throwing it hard. He's a plus on-mound athlete who we anticipate will be a sinker/changeup No. 4 or 5 starter relatively soon. His season ended in mid-July due to an oblique strain.

It's rare for a top high school right-hander out of GPE to be described as projectable, but it's a label that fits PERSON well. He has already seen his velocity jump in the past year, and scouts think he can make more gains, thanks to his long, lanky frame. PERSON's fastball now sits in the low 90s and can touch 95 mph, with good life. He has also made strides with his slider and shows an improving feel for his changeup. He repeats his easy delivery well and throws a lot of strikes as a result. PERSON earns praise for his makeup and intelligence.

PERSON was selected sixth overall out of a ORGANIZATION high school in 2014, and was among the most celebrated prep bats of all time. He ranked at the top of his class for three years and was projected to move from catcher to right field because of his prodigious talent at the plate, like PERSON and PERSON before him. PERSON PERSON surgery sank PERSON's 2018 season and he's now a 25-year-old who has yet to pitch a meaningful slate of innings above A-ball. An exceptionally athletic, twitchy and lean high school catching prospect, PERSON is a potential plus defender with a plus arm and visible leadership qualities. He also has a chance to grow into above average raw power, but scouts aren't sure if he's going to hit.

Up until the 2018 season, PERSON had hit at every point in his career. GPE spent his first three seasons at FACILITY coming out of the bullpen before sliding into the starting rotation as a senior. That he's still relatively new to starting gives him untapped potential in the role, too, and the hope is that he'll begin to miss more bats as he refines his secondary pitches.

PERSON's lack of arm strength really boxes him in at second base, which means he has to hit enough to be a regular there because defensive versatility, and therefore a viable utility role, isn't part of his profile. PERSON popped up at the same event as PERSON late in the summer, with an even louder performance, but his swing has gotten a little stiffer and some scouts think he's a left fielder.

Revered as one of the 2014 PERSON's premier athletes, PERSON was set to pursue a career in both baseball and football at ORGANIZATION before the ORGANIZATION offered him nearly $700,000 over slot value as their second-round pick. Signed for $995,000 as an 11th-round pick in 2009, PERSON never really got going offensively in the ORGANIZATION system with the exception of winning the high Class A ORGANIZATION League batting title with a .313 average in 2013. PERSON has an NBA shooting guard build at a long-limbed 6-foot-5. He towers over almost all of his peers and has rare physical projection. It might seem like PERSON has been on prospect radars for an eternity, having signed out of the ORGANIZATION back in 2007. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON commit PERSON was invited to PERSON's inaugural Scouting PERSON game back in 2015 and was selected as a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a 2016 ORGANIZATION in the last two years. The ORGANIZATION challenged PERSON after signing him out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012 and he was the youngest position player in the ORGANIZATION in 2014. PERSON's competitiveness and smarts on the mound, however, have him bucking the odds, with a chance to be a lefty swingman or No. 5 starter in the future.

d'Arnaud has been snakebitten the past two years by knee injuries that have prevented him from graduating to the big leagues. PERSON rebounded from winning one game as a sophomore at ORGANIZATION to earning ORGANIZATION pitcher-of-the-year honors as a junior in 2014. Why do scouts like PERSON? Let's start with the fact that some evaluators believe he might have the best all-around swing in the entire class. GPE to sign as a 16-year-old GPE in July 2011, PERSON had to wait more than three years before the ORGANIZATION gave him a $10,000 bonus in December 2014. His upper-80s slider and low-80s curveball are more notable for their velocity than their bite and can get slurvy at times, while his changeup can get too firm. PERSON racked up 40 saves during his four years at ORGANIZATION and dominated for two summers on the Cape before signing with the ORGANIZATION as a 10th-round pick in 2017. The change is the better secondary offering, one that receives above-average grades from scouts, and was instrumental in him holding left-handed hitters to a .167/.254/.294 clip in 2018. He's an adept strike-thrower with all three pitches, demonstrating above-average control and command against hitters on both sides of the plate.But perhaps what's most intriguing about PERSON is that he can induce whiffs with relative ease. Working 66 2/3 innings in his first full season, he struck out 37 percent of the hitters he faced while averaging 13 strikeouts-per-nine. PERSON doesn't fit into a neat box as a big league reliever, but there's something to be said about his sustained dominance, and it would surprise no one in the organization if he continued his accelerated climb towards the Majors.

Built like a one of the moai sculptures on PERSON, PERSON faces size-based questions about his ability to catch long term. But he has a plus arm, he's procedurally advanced for a 20-year-old, and he has the leadership qualities and intangibles that have an outsized impact at catcher. He also has plus power, enough to put balls out to right center, though PERSON' current approach to contact doesn't often enable it. He pulls just about everything. 
PERSON' future is heavily dependent on him staying behind the plate and ideally, he'd catch more than just 33 games (last year's total at an affiliate, not including extended) throughout the course of this year, and show that the workload doesn't detract from his bat or agility. The power gives him a shot to be a regular, though a backup role is probably more likely.

Most college shortstops have to move to a less challenging position in pro ball. That won't be an issue with PERSON, who was billed as arguably the top defensive shortstop in the 2015 Draft class before going No. 20 overall to the A's and signing for $1.95 million. PERSON's impressive range is a product of his athleticism and plus speed, and scouts rave about his first-step quickness as well as his overall instincts. His arm is a clean fit at shortstop and enables him to make highlight-reel plays, but he can also get rid of the ball quickly while on the move without sacrificing accuracy. PERSON has a tendency to make errors when he tries to do too much, though he did settle down and displayed improved tempo and body control in 2015.A disciplined hitter with good bat-to-ball skills, PERSON is at his best when he's spraying line drives to the opposite field. He does have a tendency to get tied up and roll the ball over to the left side, however, and his simple, low-effort swing prevents him from utilizing his limited power. Even if the bat doesn't pan out, PERSON's glove alone could make him an everyday shortstop at the highest level.

PERSON was a potential second-round pick last year as a sophomore-eligible at ORGANIZATION but went unpicked after a shoulder injury sidelined him for the entire season. He didn't require surgery and has bounced back so well this spring that he's a likely second-rounder and figures to be the first college choice from the state of GPE. His heater is tough not only because of its velocity, but also because his extension in the front of his delivery makes it appear faster and it features run and sink. His layoff didn't help his control and command, but he has a sound delivery and they should be at least average in the long run.

When PERSON had been on the mound as an amateur, scouts liked what they saw. The ORGANIZATION liked what they saw enough to roll the dice and take him in fourth round of that year's PERSON and he's responded with a solid first pro season.Pitching more than he has in years, PERSON has been working largely with an average fastball, though he's shown he can touch 94-95 in shorter stints, and the ORGANIZATION are interested to see if that comes back the more he adjusts to pitching consistently. PERSON can elicit swings and misses with his slider, but while he has a changeup, he hasn't always been able to show a feel for it. His command has improved the more he's pitched and he has a solid delivery and arm action. Because of how much time PERSON missed in college, the ORGANIZATION are treating the lefty more like a high school or junior college pitcher in terms of his development. If he can continue to pitch like he did in his first full season, the kid gloves will eventually come off.

PERSON improved in each of his three years at ORGANIZATION, earning Big GPE All-Conference honors as a junior. The ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the 12th round that June, signing him for $150,000. He's done nothing but produce as a pro, using his blend of hitting ability, speed and defense to move quickly through the ORGANIZATION' system. He was a ORGANIZATION All-Star in his first full season and played just five games at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Lakeland at the outset of 2018 before advancing to Double-A, where he was an LOCATION All-Star and produced a .317 average with 23 steals. His approach is geared toward hitting the ball back up the middle, and he does so often using a short left-handed swing. While PERSON's contact is mostly of the ground-ball variety, it actually plays into his strength because he's a plus-plus runner with well-below-average power. PERSON is a skilled bunter, with the ability to lay it down either line, and he's an aggressive, sometimes over-aggressive basestealer. He fared better against same-sided arms (.340 average) than righties (.301) in Double-A. PERSON's wheels enable him to play center field, and he's seen significant time at all three outfield spots in full-season ball. That versatility, along with his speed and bat, give PERSON a clear path to the Majors as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON was a lightly-scouted multi-sport high school athlete in GPE who also played hockey before he arrived at the ORGANIZATION of GPE. Soon after he stepped on campus, scouts saw and become enamored with the enomrous athletic potential he had. He still hasn't quite tapped into it, at least on offense. PERSON has 70 speed and defensive ability in center field, along with a 60 arm and average raw power. As a 6-foot-4, 210 pound athletic specimen, he'll probably play forever. There's some bat control and feel for oppo gap contact here, but PERSON's approach and feel for hitting is lacking, holding back his everyday potential. Most scouts project him as a good fourth outfielder in the ORGANIZATION mold.

After PERSON's very strong showing in the ORGANIZATION last summer, scouts were very excited to see him in action as a junior at ORGANIZATION. He throws strikes with all of his offerings.Whether PERSON reaches his ceiling will come down to the development of his secondary pitches -- in particular his changeup, which will be crucial for him in terms of neutralizing left-handed hitters. He will also need to learn to differentiate between his slider and curveball, though that might happen organically as he faces more advanced hitters.

PERSON was one of the best players on the summer showcase circuit in 2016, showing a rare combo of hit, power and speed tools, though it was unclear if he fit better in the infield or center field. PERSON still largely think PERSON' tools play best in center field long-term and he performed even better than expected in his pro debut.

He'll hit 94 mph with his fastball, and he has a good curve and changeup to go along with it to give him a good three-pitch mix that he knows how to use effectively.There is some question about his arm action, but the real concern might be about his medical record. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: PERSON FACILITY MLB Player: PERSON was chosen as a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a 2016 ORGANIZATION First Teamer while also participating in the 2016 ORGANIZATION. PERSON, a top 500 recruit, is committed to the ORGANIZATION Trojans.The lanky southpaw has lots of ability to work with. He has a loose arm but creates some deception with his long length and three-quarter arm slot, and he can dial his fastball up to 90 mph.While PERSON is still working on his throwing mechanics, further development should help improve his control and offspeed stuff. He has a chance to succeed as a starter if he puts all the full package of skills together.

| Overall:4/5  Coming from a cold-weather climate in GPE, scouts were running to see PERSON in high school in the days leading up to the GPE, and his strong performances in his senior season allowed him to go in the second round. While he's not the tallest right-hander in the world, he's very strong and durable. He can run his fastball up to 94 mph and spin a very good curveball, and even has a good feel for a changeup. PERSON will also mix in a good cutter, giving him the chance to have four Major League average or better pitches in the future. Like many young pitchers, he'll need to refine his command, but that's not a long-term concern, as he gets high grades for his mound presence and work ethic.

PERSON ORGANIZATION has had its fair share of draftees, PERSON being by far the most successful, but only seven have been taken in the top three rounds of the regular Draft in June. PERSON is the latest player to have joined that exclusive list after the PERSON made him their third-round pick in 2017.A product of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks, PERSON's 6-foot-4 frame and plus fastball garnered plenty of attention in the spring as he regularly bumped 95 mph throughout his starts. He throws two breaking balls, a fringy curveball and a slider that flashes above average. He mixes in a viable changeup as well. PERSON's arm action can get a bit long, making it tougher for him to repeat his delivery. That, in turn, leads to command issues.PERSON's arm strength, durable frame and potential four-pitch mix should allow for his continue development as a starter in pro ball, especially if he can make strides with his control and command. Should that not work out, shortening PERSON up and putting him in the bullpen could allow his fastball-slider combination to play up and get him to the big leagues more quickly.

A native of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION shortly after his 17th birthday in 2011. He's performed well in three professional seasons since, advancing to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League as a 19-year-old in 2014.  PERSON has an advanced approach at the plate and knows how to put the barrel of the bat on the ball. A switch hitter, he shows off good power from both sides of the plate in batting practice, but employs more of a line-drive approach in games.  PERSON already has a big frame, raising some questions about his future position. He has a strong arm, but a move across the diamond or possibly to an outfield corner is not out of the question. Wherever he ends up defensively, PERSON's bat looks like it'll be good enough to carry him through the ORGANIZATION.

Recruited by PERSON as a two-way player, PERSON saw little action as a pitcher or an infielder as a freshman in 2014. He did, however, experiment with dropping his arm slot, which improved the velocity and life on his fastball. The ORGANIZATION liked the results enough to draft him in the 12th round out of ORGANIZATION (Fla.) JC in 2015 and sign him away from an ORGANIZATION State commitment for $100,000.PERSON worked with a mid-80s fastball from a more conventional three-quarters arm angle. While most pitchers lose velocity when they throw from a lower slot, he saw his fastball jump to 92-94 mph and top out at 97 while at ORGANIZATION. In his third pro season, he was operating at 94-98 mph with quality sink that yields a lot of groundouts before sustaining a slight tear in his trapezius muscle in mid-May.Hitters have trouble squaring up PERSON's sinker when he keeps it down in the zone. He backs it up with a hard, sweeping slider that is quite effective against right-handers. He's having much more success against left-handers in 2017 after they hit him hard in his first two years as a pro, and if he keeps that up, he could start to rise quickly through the Minors.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in December 2013, PERSON has since developed into one of the more accomplished hitters in the ORGANIZATION. The GPE's youngest everyday player on Opening Day in 2016, PERSON went on to win the circuit's batting title and ORGANIZATION award at age 19, and then garnered Double-A ORGANIZATION All-Star honors in 2017 before a standout turn in the prestigious ORGANIZATION. PERSON stands out as much for his approach and plate discipline as he does for his pure hitting ability. He has an advanced knowledge of the strike zone as well as excellent pitch recognition, a combination that netted him the ORGANIZATION's top on-base percentage (.398) in 2017, and has resulted in more walks (153) than strikeouts (135) in four professional seasons. PERSON' bat-to-ball skills are impressive, and he produces hard line drives across the entire field with a compact, level swing. His raw power, meanwhile, is better than his numbers suggest, though PERSON' should be a consistent source of extra-base hits thanks to his knack for pounding the gaps. PERSON has solid arm strength and can get the job done at shortstop, but he offers more upside at second base, where he's a plus defender and has spent the bulk of his pro career.PERSON proved plenty capable at shortstop in 2017, first in Double-A and then in the ORGANIZATION, and should continue to see some time there moving forward. His ultimate defensive home, however, is likely second base, where he profiles as an above-average defender with good range and arm strength. Overall, PERSON has the ingredients to hit atop a lineup while manning a middle-infield position for a long, long time.

If it hadn't been for some struggles in Triple-A and then injuries that shelved him for more than a month, ORGANIZATION likely would have seen some time in GPE in 2012. He had a huge 2011 season that put him firmly on the "future closers" map and despite the hiccup in GPE, he still should be there. He'll throw his power sinking fastball up to 97 mph and back it up with a hard slider that has cutter-like action. He'll mix in an occasional changeup for a different look, though it's not really an effective part of his arsenal. He made up for lost time in the ORGANIZATION and looked much more like the ORGANIZATION of old, putting him in line for a big league job soon.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

Projectable left-handed pitchers aren't easy to find in the GPE. The ORGANIZATION feel they have one in PERSON, whom they signed away from an GPE commitment by giving him $775,000, more than $100,000 over the value assigned for the pick in the third round of the 2015 GPE.The North Carolina high school product has the chance to have a three-pitch mix, though there is work to be done. PERSON can run his fastball up to 93 mph at times, and there might be some more in the tank as he matures. His curve is fringy at present, but he knows how to spin it, and it could eventually develop into a solid breaking ball. He has a feel for a changeup, but he didn't thrown it much as an amateur. The biggest issue with PERSON is his delivery, which has some effort and some mechanical flaws that need to be cleaned up. PERSON is strong and fairly athletic, so the ORGANIZATION hope he can make the adjustments necessary to consistently tap into his raw ability on the mound.

PERSON was one of the most explosive talents in the 2018 July 2nd class, getting the second highest bonus at $3.5 million, behind only 22-year-old PERSON center fielder PERSON. PERSON is currently ranked behind a number of players in his class because we still aren't sure how his contact skills will project. He has big bat speed and projects for at least 60 raw power, along with sticking somewhere in the infield. We aren't sure how his body will develop, and thus the raw power and the position where he'll land are open questions. More importantly, he takes a high-effort, torqued-up cut at the ball, and the Jays like that he has eye-hand contact, but there's still a ways to go to turn this intriguing ball of clay into a more finished product.

Thompson-Williams showed enough glimpses of his athleticism translating into production in two years at FACILITY ORGANIZATION and then one season at GPE to get taken in the fifth round of the 2016 Draft by the ORGANIZATION. Things really didn't start clicking for the outfielder until 2018, when he put in a 20-20 season, mostly in the ORGANIZATION State League, and earned a bump up to Double-A for the LOCATION playoffs. The ORGANIZATION had always liked his tools and acquired him in the package for PERSON last November.DTW's power-speed combination has always been intriguing, but it's possible he tried to rely too much on his natural gifts in his first year-plus of pro ball. But he put in the work leading up to the offseason, which led to him producing 22 homers and 20 steals. He has serious raw pop from the left side of the plate, and he can drive the ball to all fields. If he can learn to control the strike zone a bit more consistently, he could make enough contact to have plus game power.Thompson-Williams has played all three outfield positions and has the skills to play center field on a regular basis. A career as a fourth outfielder might be in the offing, but a repeat of his 20-20 breakout could have evaluators projecting more.

PERSON's powerful right arm has enticed scouts since his amateur days in the ORGANIZATION. But he has struggled to harness his stuff and will have to sort out his control issues as he advances in the ORGANIZATION. He was making some strides in the ORGANIZATION State League when he was one of two arms sent to the Phillies in the ORGANIZATION Revere trade.PERSON throws his fastball in the low to mid 90s and is capable of touching 98 mph. His slider and changeup both show promise, though both pitches remain inconsistent. PERSON never has thrown many strikes as a professional. His wildness and smaller frame may make him better suited to be a reliever in the long run, and ORGANIZATION moved him to that role in high Class A in 2015.

Some pitchers wow with arm strength and radar gun readings. Others impress with an advanced knowledge of how to pitch. PERSON fits squarely in the latter category.The PERSON ace may not have a pitch that grades out much better than PERSON average, but he really knows what to do with the three he has. He can touch 93 mph with his fastball, but he usually sits in the 89-91 mph range, adding and subtracting at will. He can throw his curveball for strikes when necessary, and his changeup can serve as a deceptive out pitch. PERSON will continue to refine his command with a smooth delivery that he should be able to repeat consistently. PERSON finished his season with three straight complete-game victories, giving scouts a little glimpse of what he can do as a starter at the next level.

PERSON could be the ORGANIZATION' next success story with converting college relievers into pro starters, following PERSON and the since-traded PERSON. A 2017 fifth-rounder signed for $320,900, he made just four starts in three years at ORGANIZATION, which preferred to use him as a multi-inning reliever. After posting a 1.35 ERA in his brief pro debut, he has missed most of 2018 after surgery to remove a blood clot from his pitching shoulder.As a college reliever and in short pro stints, PERSON sat at 92-95 mph with his fastball and peaked at 97. His spike curveball can be more devastating and also harder to control, combining power and 12-to-6 break. Both PERSON and PERSON added velocity and maintained it over a full season after shifting to the rotation, and if that happens with PERSON he could have a pair of well-above-average pitches.PERSON rarely employed a changeup in college, so adding a reliable third pitch will be a focal point of his development. Improving his control and command are also on his to-do list after he averaged 4.5 walks per nine innings at ORGANIZATION. He has a strong frame and his arm works well, so he should have the durability required to start.

GPE has some of the best feel for contact in the minor leagues and, until recently, was continuing to hit well at Triple-A as a 20/21-year-old. His recent struggles aren't all that concerning and he continues to project to make an elite rate of contact while playing an up-the-middle defensive position.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON McCutchen A two-sport athlete, PERSON also plays both running back and wide receiver for the LOCATION ORGANIZATION football team. PERSON made his varsity baseball team in 2015 and significantly contributed as both a pitcher and hitter. The live-bodied outfielder flashes exciting tools that are brimming with upside, and he is beginning to refine his raw ability.

PERSON didn't have a lot of buzz coming into the 2014 GPE, but the PERSON liked his tools and grabbed him in the fourth round.PERSON has a simple swing and does a good job of putting the barrel on the ball. He produces good bat speed, and scouts believe that will translate into power as he physically matures. Though he was announced as a shortstop during the GPE, he primarily played third base during his professional debut. His arm strength, hands and range all profile well at the hot corner. PERSON praise PERSON for his makeup and understanding of the game, two traits that will help him continue to develop as he advances in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON' talent could have landed him in the second round of the 2011 Draft, but his strong commitment to pitch and also kick for the football team at FACILITY dropped him to the 14th round. The ORGANIZATION signed him at the deadline for $2.5 million, still a Draft record for after the third round, then watched him flounder with control issues and minor injuries for his first five pro seasons. He has broken out in 2017, blowing away hitters with three power pitches and finally reaching Double-A.PERSON is throwing better than ever, ranging from 94-100 mph with a fastball that has some run and sink. When it was trying to develop him as a starter, GPE had him concentrate on improving his fastball command, which cost him some feel for his curveball, his best offering as an amateur. His hard downer curve in the lower 80s is back in his arsenal, and he also has developed an upper-80s slider that's even more of a wipeout pitch.Though he's a good athlete, PERSON never has had a pretty delivery and still struggles to find the strike zone. If he can acquire even average control, he could become a closer. While that may be too much to ask, he has the pure stuff to help the ORGANIZATION in the near future.

PERSON pitched out of GPE's bullpen in 2013, then served as the ORGANIZATION' No. 1 starter in 2014 when the team finished second in the ORGANIZATION World Series and featured a first-round pick (PERSON) and two supplemental first-rounders (PERSON, PERSON). Entering the 2015 season as the top college lefty in the GPE class, PERSON's drop in velocity and command issues did concern some and then a lat strain shelved him in GPE, somewhat clouding his GPE status.A GPE high school product who removed himself from the 2012 GPE, PERSON has been up to 94 mph in the past, but was sitting around 89-91 mph this spring, with some saying the dip was because he was throwing too many sliders, a plus pitch. The fastball can play up because of its life and angle and his ability to work it to both sides of the plate and he backs it up with that slider and a solid changeup.PERSON usually fills the strike zone, but was nibbling too much leading to an uptick in his walk rate. Even with that and the injury, his track record, arm strength and stuff should still get him drafted in the first round.

PERSON was sitting in the mid-80s as a rising junior but got himself into excellent physical shape and was touching 97 at showcase events last summer. He has an average curveball, below average changeup and lacks the mechanical grace and fluidity of most of his peers.

The first high school player selected in the 2013 Draft, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION rather than play football and baseball at FACILITY A&M. His development has been slowed by some arm and shoulder issues, but he appears headed in the right direction, especially after a very strong second half to his 2015 season.That's a good sign, especially since he threw a lot more innings than he had previously in his pro career. On any given day, PERSON will show flashes of four plus pitches. It's just a question of him using them all consistently. He can touch the mid-90s with his fastball, though he'll typically sit in the low-90s with a ton of sink that has produced extreme ground-ball rates. His slider continues to be his better breaking pitch, but he made progress with his curve and is more confident, using it more in strikeout situations. His changeup gives him a fourth, at least, PERSON average offering.There has been some concern about PERSON's low strikeout rate, especially given the quality of his stuff. He's young enough to learn to miss more bats and he'll be just 21 for all of the 2016 season as he attacks the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION' system.

PERSON began his professional career about as well as he possibly could have, and he pitched in the ORGANIZATION Game just a year after being drafted. While he probably won't repeat that level of success, he has all the tools necessary to become a solid Major League starter.PERSON throws his fastball in the mid-90s, occasionally running it up to 98 mph. He commands the pitch well, and he throws it effectively to both sides of the plate. PERSON' changeup and curveball are both solid offerings, but they have room to improve.PERSON has quickly reached the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION, joining a large group of nearly big league-ready starters in the ORGANIZATION's system. That abundance of pitching will give PERSON the time he needs to refine his game as he progresses toward his profile of a middle-of-the-rotation starter.

The way PERSON's jersey billows down from his long, skinny limbs throughout an eccentric, slowly-paced windup makes him look like a backup dancer in some kind of vampire musical. Despite the head whack that comes at the end, he's able to throw strikes with his fastball and has a sufficiently deep repertoire for starting. He is the ORGANIZATION' type, possessing a fastball/curveball combination that plays well in sequence at the top and bottom of the strike zone. The rest of his stuff is just okay but enables PERSON to attack hitters in various ways, either by working his cutter in on the hands of lefties or by dipping his slider beneath the zone. He has a No. 4 or 5 starter's mix or could end up a dynamic multi-inning reliever.

Pitchers who are under-sized right-handers with unusual deliveries will likely be compared to PERSON in perpetuity. It might fit for PERSON, who was able to pitch at two levels, reaching Double-A in 2012 at age 20. PERSON has an exciting repertoire, with the chance to have four pitches (or more) at his disposal. His fastball can be a plus, thrown up to 94 mph with an ability to maintain velocity deep into starts. His tight downer curve should be at least above average, he likes to mix in a very effective cutter, and he'll show a decent slider now and again as well as a solid changeup. He has the kind of attitude you like to see on the mound, the type who likes to prove doubters wrong. He should be ready to show them as a No. 3 type starter in the big leagues in the next year or so.

After emerging as the closer for GPE and the GPE collegiate national team as a sophomore, PERSON missed six weeks with a sore arm during his Draft year in 2017. He continued to excel when healthy, prompting the FACILITY to take him in the fifth round, and he hasn't any problems since. He went 9-0 and converted 14 of his 15 save opportunities in his first full pro season, posting a 1.40 ERA with 89 strikeouts in 58 innings between two Class A stops.PERSON's success almost exclusively results from his fastball, which parks at 92-96 mph and tops out at 98. His heater doesn't feature a lot of life, but he can blow it by hitters at the letters or use his size to throw it down in the zone with plane. His low-80s slider has some bite at times but gets slurvy too often, and his changeup doesn't feature much action or deception.Scouts don't like the wrist wrap in the back of PERSON's delivery, which affects his feel for his secondary pitches and his command, if not his ability to throw strikes. He'll need to improve his slider and changeup because he can't handle more advanced hitters with just his fastball. Expected to move quickly in 2019, he instead missed the first 10 weeks of the season with a lat strain.

While PERSON was a third-round pick, he was the second college catcher selected in the 2013 Draft, behind only PERSON was drafted largely because of his defensive profile, and he has a good one. PERSON has proven himself --- first at ORGANIZATION II LSU-Eunice, then at ORGANIZATION -- to be an outstanding catch-and-throw guy. He controls the running game with his strong and accurate arm, and he moves well behind the plate while also displaying excellent hands. Since joining the GPE, he's already shown the natural leadership -- working well with pitchers -- teams covet from a backstop. PERSON's offense is still a work in progress, though there is perhaps some strength and power to come.It will be PERSON's glovework that gets him to the big leagues. At the very least, he can get there quickly as a defensive-minded backup.

At the start of the 2017 college season, PERSON was seen as a potential top of the GPE kind of prospect, especially after a strong sophomore season and summer pitching for the GPE National PERSON over the summer. Minor arthroscopic knee surgery kept him from fall ball and that clearly contributed to a sluggish start to his 2017 season, though his stuff came back a bit as the spring progressed. The PERSON were thrilled when he fell to GPE. 18 overall, then watched him help pitch GPE to a ORGANIZATION World Series title before signing him for $3.5 million.When he's going full strength, as he was at the end of the spring, PERSON's fastball will sit around 93 mph and will touch 95 mph consistently with good sink. His slider is a true out pitch, though he threw it a little too much in college. He showed a solid changeup more over the summer, with a good feel for a future Major League average offering. He's more control over command, but he stays around the strike zone.The PERSON went over pick value to sign PERSON, but only slightly. If the uneven start to his junior season was only a blip, they may have gotten a top 10 talent at a bargain rate.

One could argue the 27-year-old ORGANIZATION doesn't belong on a prospects list, but he's not even the oldest player on The ORGANIZATION, and you'd probably like to know more about him, so here we go. ORGANIZATION teams had interest in PERSON when he was a teenager and several of them courted him before he was drafted into ORGANIZATION. Though minor ailments limited his early-career workload, he's been one of the better starters in GPE for the last six years and has been especially good for the last two, before PERSON posted him. He started getting into pitch design after his parent club installed a ORGANIZATION unit in 2016. 
Like a lot of GPE pitchers, PERSON has a kitchen sink repertoire that features a splitter and various breaking balls. Everything is above-average, except for PERSON's fastball. PERSON, PERSON is similar to ORGANIZATION, although his stride direction is more direct to the plate and his delivery has a brief intermission as his landing leg descends (pause) then everything comes home. His arm action is efficient and PERSON's slot is vertical, something it seems that more analytically inclined teams prefer. He sounds like a mid-rotation starter who, for our purposes, will enter his decline phase earlier than everyone else on this list because of his age.

As a draft-eligible redshirt sophomore, PERSON hit .324/.376/.528 with 11 homers at ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION drafted him in the 38th round. He didn't sign, returned to school, hit .287/.496/.810, with 23 homers, stole 18 bases, and was drafted 35th overall. PERSON was totally sure what to make of such remarkable improvement, and PERSON lives in the dreaded right/right 1B/DH bucket for most evaluators, but he had among the best raw power in his draft class and emphatically torched the best conference in college baseball. 
Since entering pro ball, PERSON has performed and moved quickly, slugging 22 homers at Double-A in his first full pro season. His breaking ball recognition is questionable, and may be exposed more this year at ORGANIZATION. The swing and miss issues combined with the defensive limitations are a bit of a problem, but PERSON has more power and is more athletic than most other hitters of this statistical ilk (like the ORGANIZATION and C.J. Crons of the world), so we like his chances of being a major league contributor fairly soon. We just doubt that he's an average or better everyday first baseman, and instead think he's a corner platoon bat.

PERSON' fastball velocity has climbed each of the last three years and is now in the upper-90s. He struck out 171 hitters in 114 innings at ORGANIZATION in 2018 before the ORGANIZATION brought him to the big leagues for six appearances (some out of the bullpen, some as a starter), and he struck out more than a batter per inning there, as well. He was slated to compete for a spot in GPE's rotation during the spring but was sidelined with a quad strain, and may begin the regular season rehabbing or in a lesser role due to the late start.
PERSON' secondaries can sometimes be easy to identify out of his hand, but purely based on movement, they're both plus. His command may limit him to a relief role, or at least a starting role that carries fewer innings than is typical, but he has high-leverage big league stuff, and was perhaps 2018's biggest prospect surprise.

A two-sport star in high school, PERSON's raw tools and athleticism led PERSON to select him in the second round in 2012. Able to focus solely on baseball for the first time, the former prep running back took off in '13, his first full professional season.PERSON is an elite athlete, and he takes advantage of his above-average speed in all phases of the game. His speed is more of a weapon than his power, but he generates enough bat speed to drive balls into the gaps. As PERSON gets more experience, his speed is good enough to make him a good defensive center fielder.PERSON still has a ways to go, but the early returns have been encouraging for PERSON.

PERSON established himself as the best college power hitter available in the 2015 Draft, leading the ORGANIZATION with eight homers the prior summer and then hitting 11 in 40 games as a junior despite breaking the hamate bone in his right hand. After signing for $1.4 million as the 31st overall pick, he paced the short-season LOCATION in homers (12) and slugging (.551) during his pro debut. He struggled when he reached Double-A in mid-2016, but he made adjustments and hit well there and in Triple-A this year.PERSON's big 6-foot-4 frame gives him a lot of strength and leverage, and he uses it to crush balls to all fields. His left-handed swing naturally gets long because of his size, so he probably won't hit for a high average, but he doesn't swing and miss excessively for a masher. He ran into trouble when he first got to Double-A when he expanded his strike zone, then showed more discipline in his return in 2017.While he has a strong arm, PERSON's lack of speed limits his defensive value. After spending most of his time at ORGANIZATION in right field, he spent his first two pro seasons in first base and worked hard to become an adequate defender. With PERSON ensconced in GPE, the ORGANIZATION have played PERSON mostly in left field this year, but he doesn't have much range.

Ever since signing out of GPE in 2014 at age 16 in 2014, PERSON has shown a feel for pitching that belies his age and experience. While that hasn't translated to consistent statistical success as of yet, the organization thought highly enough to send him to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON's playoff run in 2016, giving up two runs in 10 innings over two starts. He made his full-season debut in 2017 at the age of 19.Based on a radar gun, PERSON's fastball is fringy, in the 89-91 mph range, but it plays up because of its life and his ability to command it well. There might be more in the tank velocity-wise as he physically matures and he's already shown a penchant for groundball outs. His best secondary pitch is his changeup, which could be a plus pitch when all is said and done. He throws a big, looping curve ball which will need refinement as he moves up the ladder, but he did start missing more bats in 2016.While PERSON throws a ton of strikes, improvement of his command within the zone will help him continue to miss bats and generate weak contact, as he's been a bit too hittable in the early stages of his career. With time and physical maturity, he could develop into a solid back half of the rotation starter.

PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 45th-round pick out of high school in 2010, then created buzz by pitching in the mid 90s during the fall at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC. Signed for $350,000 as an 11th-rounder in 2011, he led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION with a 2.25 ERA two years later but missed all of 2014 following PERSON surgery. After the ORGANIZATION eased him back in during '15, he ranked second in the Double-A PERSON in strikeouts (133) and third in strikeout rate (8.5 per nine innings) last year.PERSON's best pitch is his fastball, which sits in the mid 90s with heavy sink. His mid-80s slider gives him a solid second offering when he stays on top of it. His changeup lags behind the rest of his arsenal because it gets too firm and he had trouble locating it for strikes.The key for PERSON is maintaining a direct line to the plate, because when he doesn't, his pitches lose their sharpness and wander up in the strike zone. He has decent control but his command isn't as fine, so some scouts think he'll be better suited for the bullpen. His fastball sat at 97-99 mph and repeatedly reached triple digits when he was a reliever in the ORGANIZATION in 2015.

PERSON' older brother, PERSON, was a 2014 fourth-round pick of the ORGANIZATION out of high school. PERSON opted to head to PERSON rather than sign in 2015 as a 22nd-round pick of the ORGANIZATION. He's been a three-year member of the ORGANIZATION' rotation and stepped into the Friday night role when PERSON went down with an injury, though he missed some time with biceps tendinitis.Assuming health, and PERSON was back on the mound in May, the right-hander has a solid three-pitch mix coming from a high three-quarter delivery and easy arm action. He'll throw his fastball in the 92-95 mph range with good sink. His 80-83 mph slider is inconsistent, but it has sharp break and he can land it for strikes when it's on. His changeup should be a third average offering, a solid offspeed pitch with good sink to it as well.PERSON doesn't miss a ton of bats, but goes right after hitters. He did pitch well on the Cape in brief performances for two summers, which certainly won't hurt his chances of getting drafted in the top five rounds.

The best college power hitter available in the 2015 Draft, PERSON topped the ORGANIZATION with eight homers the previous summer and hit 11 in 40 games as a ORGANIZATION junior despite breaking the hamate bone in his right hand. He has produced as advertised since signing for $1.4 million as the 31st overall pick, leading the short-season LOCATION with 12 homers in his pro debut and slamming a total of 45 homers in his first two full seasons while advancing to Triple-A. His 24 blasts last year were six more than anyone else hit in the organization in the Majors or Minors.PERSON's massive 6-foot-4 frame affords him plenty of strength and leverage, allowing him to hit the ball out of the park from foul pole to foul pole. Though he recognizes that his raw power means he doesn't have to swing for the fences, his left-handed swing can get long and he gets in trouble when he expands his strike zone. His whiff rate jumped to a career-worst 29 percent in Triple-A last year and he'll have to develop more patience to hit for average against advanced pitching.Primarily a right fielder in college, PERSON spent most of his first two pro seasons at first base and worked diligently to become an average defender there. He's blocked by PERSON in GPE, however, so he shifted to left field last May. His lack of speed limits his range, though he does have solid arm strength.

Another exciting arm talent who cannot stay healthy, PERSON has thrown just 20 innings in parts of three pro seasons. His injury issues date back to his college days at ORGANIZATION when he had shoulder trouble that the coaching staff initially said was hamstring tightness. ORGANIZATION has surgical command of a low-90s heater and plus power changeup. The ORGANIZATION went over slot to sign PERSON away from a football scholarship at ORGANIZATION and they likely knew it would take some time to put his considerable raw tools to consistent use on the baseball field. Though he was one of the more polished high school pitchers in the 2015 Draft, PERSON lasted until the ORGANIZATION' fourth selection at ORGANIZATION. 44 because he wasn't very physical and didn't dazzle radar guns. A reliever as a junior at ORGANIZATION, ORGANIZATION has been developing as a starter since joining the FACILITY and enjoyed a successful first full sason. PERSON's older brother, PERSON, is a pitcher in the ORGANIZATION organization and made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in 2014. He's seen time at all three spots, and his strong arm and speed are assets there.Defensively, PERSON began as a third baseman, but the ORGANIZATION moved him to the outfield in 2015. He's seen time at all three spots, and his strong arm and speed are assets there.

Every Draft class has a fair share of prospects who make a name for themselves the spring of their Draft year. GPE is yet another intriguing high school hitter from Georgia.An athletic outfielder who may not quite be in the ORGANIZATION Meadows/Clint Frazier stratosphere, he can do a lot of things on the baseball field. The LOCATION high school standout had a very successful first full season, spending the year in the LOCATION League and finishing fourth in strikeouts despite being on an innings count. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Player: PERSON committed to GPE Diego State after garnering attention for his hard-throwing ability at ORGANIZATION. He has played in two ORGANIZATION Championship tournaments, won the 2015 GPE World Series and earned a spot on the 2016 Underclass 3rd Team for his efforts.Some scouts have noted that the right-hander has impressive stuff. An GPE transfer from the junior college ranks, PERSON pitched to underwhelming results for two seasons out of the ORGANIZATION' bullpen ahead of his selection by the ORGANIZATION in the 36th round of the 2017 Draft. But after a stellar pro debut in which PERSON posted a 1.47 ERA with 10.0 strikeouts-per-nine across three levels including Class A Hagerstown, it's clear that the ORGANIZATION drafted a better player than even they had expected. His slider is his go-to secondary offering, flashing above average, and he also demonstrates feel for throwing a splitter. PERSON had no problems throwing strikes in his pro debut after pitching with below-average control as an amateur. PERSON' strike-throwing ability will be tested at higher levels, as will the consistency and quality of his stuff. But if his pro debut is a sign of what's to come, PERSON, once healthy, could make a quick rise through the ORGANIZATION en route to a late-inning role in GPE's bullpen.

One of the strengths of the 2015 Draft is high school outfielders, and that's apparent in GPE. PERSON likely will be a first-round choice, PERSON should go in the top two rounds and PERSON won't last much longer if teams believe he's signable. The Aâs continue to aggressively pursue talent in GPE and they think PERSON has the chance to be a pretty exciting table-setter one day. The ORGANIZATION made PERSON their third-round pick in 2013, targeting the GPE ORGANIZATION native for his immense raw power. With an exciting combination of stuff, command and feel for pitching, GPE looked like he was headed on a fast track when he skipped a level, going from the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League up to the Class A Advanced PERSON in 2015. The ORGANIZATION will understandably take it slow with the right-hander, but the 22-year-old should resume his climb to big league starter status.

The amateur side of the scouting industry is fearful of prep bats from the LOCATION because they face bad pitching during the spring, and are tough to evaluate as hitters. This, PERSON's slightly advanced age relative to other high schoolers, as well as a deep, late first and early second round group of high school outfielders pushed him into the second round despite having first round physical ability. PERSON is a high-effort player with good instincts on the bases and in the field. He probably doesn't have the pure speed for center but has a small hope of staying there based on his feel. Heading into the 2016 GPE class, there were catchers who had better offensive profiles, and there were backstops who were better defensively, but no one seemed to have a better chance of being a solid all-around big league catcher than GPE. It clearly impacted his hitting as he batted only .185 and slugged .265, but he hasn't been able to get back to being the average hitter that he was pre-injury, one with some power to tap into. While he hasn't handled the bat, GPE has impressed the organization with his defensive play. He's great working with pitchers, calling a good game to go along with solid blocking and receiving skills. His throwing has improved, and he'd thrown out just over 33 percent of potential base stealers in his career heading into 2018.GPE deserves some slack because of the injuries, but he does have to show he can stay healthy and be productive at the plate. If he can do that, he could shoot back up this list and reclaim his mantel as one of the best overall catching prospect from his GPE class.

Off the mound, PERSON is polite and professional. He has all the makings of a late-inning bullpen guy in the near future.

PERSON was originally signed by the ORGANIZATION in December 2010, but after two uneventful summers in the ORGANIZATION, he was first loaned then sold to GPE in the ORGANIZATION, where he played from 2013-17 before signing with PERSON in March 2018. PERSON showed an ability to hit for average throughout his ORGANIZATION stay, hitting .300 or better in four of his five seasons. A 2011 Draft pick out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE, ORGANIZATION has a reputation of being a solid catch-and-throw receiver and a natural leader behind the plate.Hicks struggled in Double-A in 2013, but the good news is he went back this past year, performed well and earned a promotion to Triple-A. His best tool is his arm, throwing out a combined 38% of would-be basestealers in 2014 (He's at 47% for his career). He greatly improved other aspects of his defensive game, cutting his passed balls total from a whopping 17 in 2013 to just two this past season. He also bounced back with the bat, hitting for average albeit without much power. How much he hits will determine his ultimate role, but he appears just about ready to help out as a big league backup soon.
GPE runner and thrower can play both middle infield spots, hit-over-power type that has limited projection left.

Acquired as part of the return from PERSON for PERSON, PERSON has a near-ready relief profile that might yield multi-inning value because of the depth of his repertoire. He brings 95-98 mph heat from the left side and complements it with a bevy of inconsistent secondary offerings. Opinions vary scout to scout as to which of PERSON's other pitches is best. The changeup has the best movement but PERSON struggles to set it up because he can't locate his fastball consistently. His slider is short and cuttery, the curveball has depth but lacks bite. Taken together, they could be enough to flummox hitters one time through the order, but probably not several times.

PERSON's stuff never took a step during his senior spring, but he's still sitting in the low-90s with average breaking stuff and one of the smoother teenage deliveries in baseball. He's a tremendous ball of soft clay for player dev to mold, an old-school high school pitching prospect.

GPE reminds some scouts of GPE catcher PERSON Contreras.He's lean, muscular and boasts a strong athletic body. He's not a burner on the bases, but he still runs the timed 60-yard run in 6.7-6.8 seconds, which is notable speed for a catcher.There's some pop to his bat and he has a reputation for hitting line drives to all fields. He has shown good bat speed along with some home run power. Both are expected to increase as he grows and develops more strength. For now, his offensive game is ahead of his defense.He'll eventually have to harness some of his aggressiveness and athleticism, but what makes him so fun to watch is how well he moves behind the plate. That said, he flashes above-average arm strength, good range and overall adequate defensive actions. Like most catchers his age, he's still working on his receiving skills and calling games. He's going to stay behind the plate despite displaying the type of athleticism and overall abilities that could lead to a position change.He trains with PERSON and PERSON in GPE. The GPE are the front-runners to sign the teenage catcher.

A product of the ORGANIZATION' efforts in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON's full-season debut in 2015 was a bit uneven. His arm strength and his makeup, though, have PERSON bullish on his future. The young right-hander, who will be 21 for all of the 2016 season, can touch 96 mph with his fastball and will sit in the 92-93 mph range with a very loose arm action. PERSON's changeup is his second-best offering, and he throws the offspeed pitch with good arm speed and deception. His curve gets slurvy, mostly because he tends to change his arm slot when throwing it. He and the ORGANIZATION have worked hard on his delivery to get him to repeat his slot, angle and direction, which will not only help his breaking ball, but his command as well. PERSON gets high marks for his worth ethic, earning the first Fortuna Award in the organization for his commitment on and off the field in 2014 following his GPE debut. It's that work ethic that has the ORGANIZATION confident he can reach his ceiling.

PERSON fits under the description "Have bat, will travel" perfectly. In this case, it's not to other organizations, but rather to a number of defensive positions. A third baseman in college, he played there, second base and a little outfield during his 2011 summer debut in the ORGANIZATION system. In 2012, he played second exclusively and he may yet end up in right field. The simple fact is if PERSON keeps hitting like he did in 2012, they're going to find a place for him in the lineup. He won the organizational batting crown and topped it in slugging percentage while showing he wasn't just a product of his ORGANIZATION location by continuing to mash when he moved up to Double-A. He has the chance to be an above-average hitter with at least average power, regardless of what position he's asked to play.

By now, it's clear what PERSON can and will do on the baseball field: He'll hit for power, he'll steal some bases, he'll strike out a lot. PERSON has 20-20 potential thanks to his above-average power and speed. He also has the ability to play strong outfield defense at any of the three spots, though he's largely been a center fielder throughout his career. And yes, he will strike out a good amount. In years past, he's shown an ability to draw walks to help offset that, but he's never going to be a guy who hits for a high average. Whether his swing and miss tendencies will keep him from being a productive everyday outfielder in the big leagues remain to be seen, but it's time for him to get an extended look.

The Phillies haven't shied away from paying physically mature prospects big bucks on the ORGANIZATION market. PERSON is a thick-torsoed righty with premium arm strength and a workable delivery. His breaking stuff is inconsistent and needs to be tightened. This is an arm strength/arm action/athlete buy without present feel for spin or physical projection, but PERSON has had recent success with arms like this.

GPE has big time pull-side lift in his swing, has 45 raw power already at age 17, and a fairly projectable 6-foot-2 frame that portends more. He'll reach down and barrel balls near his shoe tops and also crush mistakes. He's too aggressive right now and probably has to move to a corner eventually, so our early assessment of the profile is that it's very risky. But as far as teenage power projection bats go, this is a good one.

ORGANIZATION' older brother PERSON is among the best catchers in baseball and was a late bloomer, breaking through at age 23 in Double-A.
