He has been defensively advanced for years, both in his tools and his mental approach to the game, in part due to help from his brother. PERSON projects as an above average defender with a plus arm. ORGANIZATION has also gotten stronger and is growing into his man strength after establishing a feel to hit, so he has a well-rounded approach now. He toned down his swing in 2018 and is slowly adding elements as he feels comfortable, rather than making a noisier swing work all at once. ORGANIZATION stands out because there are not many 21-year-olds who project for average to above offense along with above average defense, and have the makeup/mental part of the game under control without any major red flags like injuries. The scouts who like ORGANIZATION really like him--rounding up on both the tool grades due to makeup and his overall value due to a high floor at a position that's a wasteland in the majors right now. This top 10 could be in almost any order, and ORGANIZATION may be the guy with the biggest variance as to where various baseball people rank him, which is a positive when his ranking peers are mostly MLB-ready, heavily-pedigreed prospects with much more track record.

At times, PERSON can sit 93-97 mph and touch higher with his heater, mixing in an above average to plus slider, so the consistency is the issue as the upside is there. UPDATE: We've gotten a few reports that PERSON's breakout statistical year has come with much more of the mid-90's, above-average-to-plus stuff version we saw in glimpses last year.

PERSON had been yo-yo'd back and forth between the bullpen and the rotation during each of the previous two seasons, but was left to air it out in relief for all of 2018 and broke out, striking out 72 hitters in 64 innings and reaching Triple-A. He's a classic two-pitch, single-inning reliever. PERSON sits 93-96 at times, 91-94 at others, and has a power mid-80s slider. The slider has bat-missing movement away from righties but just kind of tumbles when PERSON tries to throw it for a strike. He doesn't have a great way of attacking lefties, which is part of why his usage may be limited.

The ORGANIZATION have legitimate catching prospects at every level of their system, none with a higher floor than PERSON. He started at three positions (third base, catcher, shortstop) in three years at ORGANIZATION but became a full-time backstop soon after turning pro as a sixth-rounder in 2014. He won PERSON in each of the last two years and made his big league debut this June, only to see his season end with surgery on his non-throwing shoulder a month later.Defensively, PERSON is ready to play regularly in the Majors right now. His receiving and blocking seemingly improve every year, and he gets the most out of his strong arm with a quick release and accurate throws. ORGANIZATION officials love his leadership skills and his ability to run a pitching staff.PERSON had the worst offensive year of his pro career in 2017, batting .241/.275/.323 in Double-A, and didn't hit much better this year. He continued to make contact and exhibit a good two-strike approach, but PERSON will try to get him to drive more balls and add some loft to his compact right-handed swing. More selectivity also could help because he rarely walks.

The ORGANIZATION used both of their 2014 first-round choices on left-handers, taking PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 17 and PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 28. While PERSON pitched in the World Series later that year and established himself in the ORGANIZATION' rotation after being part of the PERSON trade, PERSON has seemed light years away from the big leagues while going 10-20 with a 5.43 ERA in Class A the past two seasons. His promise as a polished left-hander with the potential for three solid pitches earned him a $1.925 million bonus, but his stuff backed up in 2015 and 2016 before improving this year. PERSON often sits in the high 80s and tops out at 93 mph with his fastball, though his velocity has ticked up a notch in 2017 and the ORGANIZATION hope his athleticism and projectability mean that there's more left in his tank. His curveball looks a lot better this season, going from average at best to a plus offering at times. He also has a solid changeup.When PERSON is going well, he shows the aptitude to locate his fastball on either side of the plate and throw strikes with all three of his pitches. He's intelligent, but he's also something of a perfectionist who has had to learn to deal with adversity. While his changeup, build and pitchability used to garner him comparisons to PERSON, he now projects more as a ORGANIZATION. 4 starter.

PERSON starred at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ga.), going 13-0 as a junior in 2015 and winning the clincher in the GPE state 6-A championship series that also wrapped up the ORGANIZATION. 1 national ranking. His talent dictated that he would have gone in the top five rounds of the 2016 Draft, but he fell to the ORGANIZATION in the 35th because he was set on attending PERSON and becoming part of college baseball's top recruiting class. After two years as a reliever, he has fared well as the ORGANIZATION' ORGANIZATION. 1 starter.PERSON excels at pitching to contact with a 91-93 mph fastball that tops out at 95, creating groundballs and awkward swings with sink and the extension in his low-three-quarters delivery. His low-80s slider can be a solid offering when he stays on top of it, though it also can get sweepy and slurvy at times. His fading changeup similarly varies between effectiveness and inconsistency.Strong and durable, PERSON does a nice job of repeating his simple mechanics. He doesn't overpower hitters but he puts his pitches where he wants and limits damage done by walks or home runs. He's one of the safer bets in this year's college class to become at least a back-of-the-rotation starter.

There's no question PERSON stands out on the baseball field because of his size. The ORGANIZATION are hopeful he can do so with his bat as well. While some felt the ORGANIZATION State product would go a bit earlier on GPE night, the ORGANIZATION were happy to get PERSON's offensive potential at the bottom of the first round. PERSON's raw power from the right side of the plate is legitimate and if he can hit consistently enough to tap into it, it could be a plus tool in the future. That "if" might've been why he didn't go earlier, though PERSON isn't an all-or-nothing, one dimensional player. He actually has some plate discipline, runs well for his size and has a strong arm, giving him all the raw tools to develop into a prototypical corner outfielder in the future.

A native of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON made an impressive full-season debut in 2013 at ORGANIZATION A Hagerstown. He continued that success the next season with PERSON and in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's arm strength and athleticism behind the plate leave no doubt he has the skills necessary to catch in the big leagues. He blocks balls in the dirt well, already shows an aptitude for pitch framing and is improving as a game-caller.PERSON made progress offensively in 2014, but his bat remains well behind his glove. He has some pop and his easy swing gives him a chance to eventually hit for more average. As he moves up to the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION, his advanced defensive ability will allow the Nationals to be patient and allow his offense further develop.

PERSON enjoyed a breakout campaign as a ORGANIZATION sophomore, continued to star during the summer for the GPE collegiate national team and put a bow on his ORGANIZATION stock by hitting 15 homers with 44 steals as a junior. The ORGANIZATION made him the fifth-overall pick that June, and PERSON signed for $4,125,000, the largest bonus in club history. PERSON surgery after PERSON's pro debut delayed the start of his first full season, and he never got on track after returning and continued to struggle in the offseason PERSON. The ORGANIZATION still decided to push PERSON up to Double-A in 2018, and he responded to their challenging by becoming the first Minor Leaguer to amass at least 20 homers and 20 steals. PERSON had a quick left-handed bat and a knack for making hard contact as an amateur, leading scouts to project him to hit for both power and average. As a pro, however, PERSON has struggled to control the strike zone, often chasing pitches well out of the zone with a lengthy swing that's led to high strikeout totals -- he led the ORGANIZATION with 156 strikeouts in '17 -- early in his career, albeit with good walk rates. That propensity for whiffing will always be part of PERSON's game, though it's less concerning now that PERSON is trusting his hands, driving the ball the other way and consistently hitting for power.PERSON's plus speed makes him a threat to steal, but his jumps on the basepaths require refinement. His wheels also serve him well in center field, where he's seen the bulk of his playing time as a pro and shows at least average arm strength. PERSON's pro career hasn't unfolded as the ORGANIZATION had hoped, but the club remains optimistic that the toolsy outfielder, with a few key adjustments, can achieve his potential.

In just a couple of years, PERSON has gone from an interesting Day 2 Draft pick from an ORGANIZATION program to a pitcher on the cusp of the ORGANIZATION. His bread and butter is his heavy power sinker, which reaches 94 mph and generates a ton of groundball outs. His above-average changeup is his second-best pitch, but he can also throw his hard slider and curveball for strikes.PERSON streaked up the organizational ladder a bit under the radar, then was much more hittable than he had been previously. His ability to make adjustments should still give him the chance to pitch at the back of a big league rotation.
GPE may be the best of a deep crop in the GPE prep ranks, showing above average hitting ability, raw power and arm strength with a long track record of hitting.

A late bloomer who went undrafted out of high school, PERSON parlayed a strong junior season as PERSON's Friday starter into becoming a second-round pick.Tall and lean on a 6-foot-5 frame, PERSON has some room to fill out. And what he has is already pretty good. The left-hander pitches downhill, with natural cutting movement on his fastball. His short, sharp slider is an out pitch at times. PERSON has solid feel for a changeup, though it's still a work in progress. He is generally around the plate with all of his pitches and has been one of the nation's top strikeout pitchers.Taken a round after the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON, PERSON gives GSP another college arm who could move fairly quickly through its system and into the big league rotation.

Signed for $100,000 out of GPE in 2011, PERSON had PERSON surgery before he made his pro debut. He has progressed rapidly since and made his big league debut last year, when he served four different stints in GPE. His heater can get flat at the higher end of his velocity range, so he needs to be careful to keep it down in the zone. He has a second plus pitch in a low-80s curveball and does a nice job of manipulating its spin and shape.PERSON also has a fringy changeup from his days in the rotation and occasionally will use it against left-handers. He has pounded the strike zone throughout his career and isn't afraid to challenge big leaguers. He has a higher floor than ceiling, looking like a good bet to become a seventh-inning reliever.

PERSON, a product of the ORGANIZATION' aggressive acquisition of high school pitching talent in the GPE, got an over-slot deal in the fourth round back in 2010 and was on the cusp of being ready to contribute to the big league staff when he needed PERSON surgery in May.PERSON's rehab went well and he returned to competitive pitching in the second half of the 2016 season. He has good command, thanks to a free and easy delivery he repeats consistently.The ORGANIZATION won't rush PERSON back, just like they didn't with fellow TJ recipients PERSON and PERSON, but he does appear right on schedule and should get back to carving out a career as a No. 3 or 4 starter soon enough.

PERSON, a native of the ORGANIZATION, made his GPE debut in 2013 and quickly showed off his exciting potential for GPE scouts. Though PERSON hasn't played full-season ball yet, his feel for the game belies his age.

PERSON sat out all of 2016 after transferring to PERSON & Mary from GPE, where he had appeared in just 12 games out of the bullpen as a freshman. PERSON led PERSON to the 2012 College World Series championship, hitting .476 with two homers to earn Most Outstanding Player honors. His ability to recognize pitches and control the strike zone translates into consistent line drives to all fields.He still figures to top out at 15 homers per season, so PERSON's chances of becoming a big league regular hinge on his ability to handle second base. He has made progress there but still struggles with his footwork and probably won't become more than an adequate defender. His average speed and arm strength hinder his ability to play on the left side of the diamond, so his fallback option would be as an outfielder rather than a utilityman.

The ORGANIZATION also acquired PERSON, the ORGANIZATION 2018 4th round pick out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE. As an amateur at ORGANIZATION, GPE was seen as an fringe-to-average bat with above average power, questionable catcher defense, and arm strength that may push him to first base. We think he'll be able to catch part time and also have enough of a bat to contribute at first base, ORGANIZATION, or as a pinch hitter. He's moved down a bit for us since last season as his strong start and improved defense early in 2018 tailed off a bit later in the season, which is somewhat common for players who are dealing with physical change during the longest full-time catching spell of their lives. Some scouts questioned GPE's bat control and thus his hit tool and game power in late 2018 looks, so looks early in 2019 may tell us if this was a slight regression in tools, or just temporary fatigue he can get past. The likely outcome looks like a valuable switch-hitting backup catcher whose bat you want to get in the lineup most days, which we value the same we would a low-end regular.

Because PERSON wasn't a regular on the showcase circuit last summer and didn't stand out at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in the fall, he barely registered on the radar of scouts. That changed this spring, when his tools took a step forward and evaluators flocked to GPE Antonio to see him. ORGANIZATION (GPE) High outfielder PERSON rode a similar path to a third-round selection by the ORGANIZATION in 2017, and PERSON could land in similar territory.PERSON has some arm bar in his left-handed swing, though he overcomes it with advanced feel for hitting. PERSON strong with good snap in his wrists, he has above-average bat speed and raw power. While his offensive potential is impressive, he has little track record against quality competition.If PERSON continues to develop and improve, he could wind up with solid or better tools across the board. The GPE recruit has plus speed and should be able to stick in center field once he improves his reads and routes. His strong arm will allow him to play anywhere in the outfield and produces an upper-80s fastball on the mound.

The ORGANIZATION knew that PERSON -- a high school product who didn't catch much in high school because of his athleticism -- would take time to develop. An injury-interrupted first full season didn't help in that regard, either. The ORGANIZATION made the decision in 2014 to move him to third base, at least for the short term.Pittsburgh's aggressive promotion of PERSON to full-season ball in 2013 proved to be challenging for the GPE prepster, particularly defensively. Shoulder problems hurt his development, but PERSON made strides offensively at instructional league, and the ORGANIZATION believe in his bat and work ethic.PERSON should get a mulligan for 2013, and the move to third will allow him to let his bat develop more, not to mention free up a playing-time logjam with ORGANIZATION.

There is little question the ORGANIZATION have some aptitude in evaluating, drafting and developing college hitters. The big league roster is all you need to see as proof, with PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON serving as perfect examples. ORGANIZATION could be part of the next wave of college bats to impact PERSON's advanced approach at the plate, with excellent plate discipline and a good idea of the strike zone, has helped his transition to pro ball. He has both strength and bat speed from the right side, with the chance to have at least PERSON average in-game power, which was on display as he slugged .516 during his pro debut and reached full-season ball. ORGANIZATION moved around defensively at ORGANIZATION, but played third base exclusively during his pro debut. He has a solid arm, though needs to work on his accuracy, and he's a fringy defender. The ORGANIZATION believe he has a chance to stay there.ORGANIZATION has quickly become the top third baseman in the system and there's not much in front of him blocking his path. Assuming he plays solid enough defense, he could hit PERSON in a hurry.

The ORGANIZATION of GPE has had five pitchers reach the big leagues, the most recent being PERSON, who saw time up with the A's in 2018. PERSON's ascent up the ORGANIZATION' ladder since being a sixth-round pick in 2015 hasn't necessarily wowed anyone, but he's knocking on the door after reaching Triple-A and leading the organization in ORGANIZATION in '18, earning him a spot on the 40-man roster. He seemed certain to be the next Zips hurler to make it to the highest level in 2019, but a forearm strain and elbow inflammation has kept him out of action for most of the season.PERSON's two best pitches are his fastball and slider. He'll pitch in the 92-96 mph range with his heater, thrown with sink. His slider flashes plus and it's firm, around 88 mph. It has some dart-like life to it and sometimes looks more like a cutter, a pitch he gets a lot of weak contact on the ground with. He started mixing in a curveball to give hitters a different look and he also has a changeup, though that's too firm with not enough differential from his fastball. He can throw strikes with all of his offerings.With more of a ground-ball oriented approach to pitching, PERSON has never missed a ton of bats. The one exception to that was when he pitched in relief in the ORGANIZATION in 2017. While he has the arsenal and durability to be a back-end starter, there are some who think he might have more long-term success as a two-pitch reliever.

As a sophomore at ORGANIZATION in 2018, GPE collected the second-most strikeouts in school history. When he followed that up with 11 shoutout innings for ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION, he looked poised to be one of the more intriguing college lefties in the 2019 ORGANIZATION class. But a forearm issue slowed him early as his velocity dipped, hurting his stock considerably, though he was pitching better as the ORGANIZATION approached.At his best, GPE leans heavily on his fastball-curve combination. When he's 100 percent healthy, he'll sit around 90-92 mph with his heater. His breaking ball is a pure curveball that he throws a lot as his out pitch. It will flash plus at times, but he doesn't always land it consistently. He does have a below-average changeup, but rarely is asked to throw it. An unorthodox delivery that includes a head snap adversely impacts his command on a regular basis.Having put the forearm injury behind him helps his stock, but because of the effort in his delivery and his difficulty in finding the strike zone consistently, most see a move to the bullpen in GPE's future. In shorter stints, his two-pitch repertoire could play well and still land him in the top five rounds.

Seen as a safe pick, PERSON garnered some consideration for the first overall pick of the 2013 Draft before landing with the Marlins at ORGANIZATION. 6 overall. He was having a solid, if unspectacular, first full season when PERSON sent him to GPE in the ORGANIZATION deal.PERSON comes from a baseball family (his uncle, B.J. PERSON, and his brother, PERSON, have both played professionally), and he has a good understanding of the game. He is a pure hitter with an advanced approach. PERSON wonder how much power he will have, however, as his swing is more geared to produce line drives than home runs. PERSON is a below-average runner, but it doesn't hold him back defensively. He is sure-handed, and he has a strong arm.While PERSON's power will likely determine his impact, few doubt he will become a solid Major Leaguer.

GPE parlayed his impressive turn in the 2014 Cape Cod League with a strong junior year at ORGANIZATION into a second-round selection in the '15 PERSON. The ORGANIZATION gave the right-hander a $1,108,000 bonus as the ORGANIZATION. 55 overall pick, and GPE quickly rewarded the organization by pitching well at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin in his pro debut. A right forearm strain suffered early in 2016 led to a two-month disabled-list stint, and GPE was ineffective when he finally took the mound. PERSON healthy in 2017, GPE finally furthered his development, pitching well over 22 starts (3.38 ERA) with PERSON and then finishing his season on a high note in Double-A.Listed at 6-foot-6, 265 pounds, GPE has an imposing presence on the mound. He's sacrificed some of his velocity for better command, though he still sits comfortably in the low 90s and at times higher, with an upper-80s cutter enables him to effectively attack left-handed hitters under the hands. His changeup is below average because he throws it too firmly, albeit it with fastball-like arm speed. His curveball, though still slurvy at times, has improved as a professional and receives average grades from evaluators. He throws all four pitches for strikes, and knows how to utilize his height to drive the ball down in the zone.GPE's strikeout rate backed up in 2017 as he focused on throwing more quality strikes and working deeper into games. While he still needs to refine his secondaries and fastball command, as well as answer some lingering questions about his durability, GPE has all the ingredients needed to become a big league starter.

Concussions slowed PERSON's progress through the ORGANIZATION after the ORGANIZATION made him the 10th overall pick of the 2011 Draft, but he overcame those ailments to make his Major League debut in September 2014. PERSON has well-above-average speed and uses it to his advantage. He knows how to bunt for a hit and sprays line drives to all fields. He has minimal power but has the tools to be a prototypical top-of-the-order hitter.  PERSON was a third baseman in college and was quickly shifted to second base by the ORGANIZATION. They also gave him regular work in the outfield in 2014, and he may eventually carve out a role as a super-utility player in the ORGANIZATION.

The last infielder from ORGANIZATION's to make a splash in the ORGANIZATION and then the big leagues was PERSON, who was a first-rounder in 2011 and is now the ORGANIZATION' starting second baseman, a former All-Star and ORGANIZATION winner. PERSON doesn't quite fit on that scale, but then again, few thought PERSON would be this good, either.Like PERSON, PERSON plays shortstop for ORGANIZATION's, but will likely need to shift over to second base at the next level. He has a very good internal clock that helps him slow down the game, and he gets rid of the ball quickly, but many feel his arm, average at best, isn't enough to stay on the left side of the infield long-term. His hands and feet should work just fine at second. Not the biggest guy in the world, PERSON has shown a strong hit tool this spring from the left side of the plate, with an advanced approach that has led to more walks than strikeouts in his college career. He has some extra-base power and can run into a few homers along the way.PERSON isn't going to jump into the first round like PERSON did six years ago, but he is performing well for a good college team at just the right time. A team that sees a little PERSON in him could take him in the top five rounds.
A strike-throwing lefty with plus changeup projection, GPE projects to the back of a rotation.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, who is committed to the ORGANIZATION, has a 2016 ORGANIZATION honor under his belt and has garnered an All-Tournament Team slot in the 2016 PG/Evoshield National Championship with his travel team ORGANIZATION. On the high school scene, the shortstop is a two-year varsity baseball letterwinner at FACILITY, as well as a 2016 All-CIF Division II First Team selection, and he was named a ORGANIZATION All-Area First Team selection in 2016. He helped lead his high school club to a league title in his junior campaign, hitting over .400 with 30 RBIs in 31 games.The small-bodied middle infielder has athletic ability. He makes plays, and once he adds more strength, PERSON's bat and arm give him a chance to better his prospect status.

GPE and toolsy, PERSON has developed considerably in his three years at ORGANIZATION State.While there's still some swing and miss to his game, he's progressed tremendously at the plate. The more consistent of a hitter he can become, the more he can tap into his outstanding raw power. He's a good runner who's even better underway, and he has a cannon for an arm. He's strong and physical and might very well fit the profile for a right fielder at the highest level.The team that believes PERSON will hit enough will be the one to take him in the early stages of the GPE.

PERSON was a legit top-3 round talent as both a hitter and pitcher coming out of high school in 2014 and some were surprised when the ORGANIZATION took him in the 2nd round and announced him as a hitter. He's rewarded their faith, showing the expected plus bat, but not quite delivering on his game power potential, while also losing a step and becoming a right fielder, when he was a serviceable center fielder as an amateur. There's some maturity concerns that have dogged PERSON for years, but he's essentially big league ready with a 60 bat and arm, along with the potential for a fun position player pitcher option.

Though PERSON helped ORGANIZATION win the GPE 7-A state title and finish No. 2 in the final national rankings in 2013, he didn't live up to expectations at the plate and concerned teams with his commitment to PERSON. Thus the ORGANIZATION were able to draft him in the 30th round, where they signed him for $440,000. After a lackluster debut, he was one of the best hitters in the short-season ORGANIZATION York-League as an 18-year-old last summer before he tore a thumb ligament in July.With his hand-eye coordination and all-fields approach, PERSON should hit for average. He shows promising patience and a willingness to use the whole field. Though he hit just one homer in 46 games during his first two pro seasons, he has the bat speed and strength to hit at least 15 longballs per season as he gets stronger. PERSON has below-average speed but moves well enough to play on the outfield corners rather than at first base. He has a solid arm that delivered low-90s fastballs when he was a two-way player in high school.

The son of former big leaguer PERSON, this Colorado high school middle infielder had scouts heading to the ORGANIZATION to check out his tools. There are many things to like about PERSON, who is committed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE should he go that route. He has some bat speed and some strength from the right side of the plate. He has some speed and likes to make things happen on the basepaths. He's agile and should be able to defend up the middle. Most feel, however, that it won't be at shortstop, with a shift to second base a likelihood in the future. There is also some concern about the swing and miss in the offensive part of the game.Even with those concerns, PERSON's raw tools and PERSON lineage are sure to draw more than a fair share of interested teams when the ORGANIZATION rolls around.

The projectable right-hander has had trouble turning his raw potential into performance thus far In his brief career. The ORGANIZATION sent PERSON to full-season ball in 2011 and he struggled, walking more batters than he struck out. He cut his walk rate in 2012, but he was down a level in the short-season LOCATION and didn't have much other success. His ceiling, athleticism and arm strength still make him worth watching. He still has the potential to have a plus fastball, though his secondary pitches and, obviously, his command need a lot of work.
One of the first deals in the class, PERSON hasn't been scouted much as a result. He doesn't have much physical projection but has advanced feel for contact and can probably still behind the plate.

PERSON entered last summer as perhaps the top player in the entire class, and certainly among the high school set. A combination of a relatively pedestrian summer showcase performances and an extremely high expectation bar, a trend that has continued this spring, caused his star to fade, though he's still one of the better prep players in the nation.PERSON does everything fairly well, though a lack of a true plus carrying tool is one reason why scouts were a bit down on him. Most feel he has the chance to be a plus hitter with an advanced approach at the plate using a high-contact, line-drive spray kind of approach. With a lean frame, there is some question about how much strength he'll add, with believers thinking power will come. Most feel he is a long-term shortstop, though some don't see it as a slam dunk. Some feel PERSON suffered more from being seen for so long that he was bound to get knocked simply for not being the best player on the field at all times. Others haven't seen him dominate the way they feel a top-of-the-Draft prospect should in high school. He is committed to ORGANIZATION, which could become an issue depending on when he's selected.

The ORGANIZATION had to draft PERSON twice before they could land him. A two-way player as a left-handed pitcher/outfielder at GSP (GPE) JC, he turned them down as a 38th-rounder in 2010 before agreeing to a $77,000 bonus as an 18th-rounder the following year.PERSON has a pair of solid pitches in a low-90s fastball that peaks at 96 mph and a curveball with power and 12-to-6 break when it's on. He also has a fringy slider and changeup.Because PERSON has a four-pitch repertoire, GPE tried him as a starter in his first two full pro seasons. But there's effort in his delivery and he struggles to repeat it, compromising his ability to find the strike zone, so he became a full-time reliever after returning from an elbow strain in mid-2014.

PERSON began his college career at GPE (GPE) JC, winning the ORGANIZATION III Junior College World Series and the D-III juco pitcher of the year award in 2014 after leading that level in wins (10) and finishing second in strikeouts (87 in 71 2/3 innings). He transferred to PERSON in 2015 and opened this season in its weekend rotation before inconsistency landed him in the bullpen. He has thrived in that role, however, showing enough arm strength to go in the first five rounds.When he locates his pitches, PERSON is hard to handle. He attacks hitters with a 90-94 mph fastball that's difficult to barrel if he keeps it down in the strike zone. His low-80s slider has been sharper in shorter stints and can overmatch left-handers, and he rarely uses his below-average changeup now that he's coming out of the bullpen.PERSON is just 5-foot-9 and generates his hard stuff with some effort in his delivery. He doesn't always repeat his mechanics, which costs him command. Despite some success starting in the ORGANIZATION last summer, he profiles strictly as a pro reliever who might be useful in high-leverage situations, especially against lefties.

Prime's breakout in his full-season debut in 2014, during which he led the organization in home runs and tied for the system lead in GPE, may have come as a surprise to those outside of the organization, but the Rockies weren't shocked to see the big first baseman produce.One of the harder workers in the system, Prime greatly improved his ability to turn on inside pitches, hitting the ball out front in order to create power to his pull side. There's still a good amount of swing and miss to his game, and he needs to improve his plate discipline so he can continue to tap into his above-average raw power consistently. Prime is still growing, showing up to Spring Training a half-inch taller. PERSON 6-foot-5, Prime is more agile than you'd expect. He has quick feet and soft hands that work well at first base, which should allow him to be a solid defender. Prime might just be scratching the surface. As he grows into his already strong body, there might be more power to come, allowing him to profile very well at the infield corner position.

GPE's stuff took off whhen he lowered his arm slot a bit last year. He's had middling success this season but is also at Double-A, missing a bat per inning, in his first full pro season. He's a potential #3 starter.

PERSON went from walk-on to 22nd-round pick in three years at Tennessee-Martin, then blew out his elbow in his first full pro season with the Royals in 2013. He regained his secondary pitches and command quicker than most pitchers who had PERSON surgery, and he jumped from Double-A to the Majors in 2016. PERSON appreciated his strike-throwing ability but designated him for assignment after signing PERSON in February, then dealt him to the ORGANIZATION for outfield prospect PERSON Dewees.PERSON works off his fastball, which plays above its average 91-95 mph velocity because he sinks it, maintains it into the late innings and locates it where he wants. Though his solid changeup is his best secondary pitch, he got away from using it during his brief big league debut. He utilizes a pair of breaking balls but his curveball and slider are average at best.While PERSON doesn't have much margin for error, he doesn't make many mistakes. He pounds the bottom of the zone but can get hittable at times because he's around the strike zone so much. He gives GPE some big league-ready starting pitching depth, though bone chips in his elbow have sidelined him for much of 2017.

PERSON pitched to mixed results as a swingman during his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION and didn't fare much better as a junior in 2014 after a move to the bullpen. His raw stuff continued to improve throughout his college career, though, and the ORGANIZATION took notice, eventually selecting PERSON in the 14th round that June. He struggled as a starter early in his pro career surrounding PERSON surgery in 2015, but moved to the bullpen in 2018 and promptly took off in the new role, turning in a strong first half with PERSON, then posting a 0.92 ERA over 15 appearances after a July promotion to Double-A. After the season, the ORGANIZATION added PERSON to their 40-man roster. A big and physical right-hander, PERSON will show two plus pitches in any given outing. He reaches 97-98 mph with his heater and throws it with late life that makes it difficult to lift for hitters on both sides of the plate. His breaking ball is equally dynamic, thrown in the upper 80s with sharp, downer action that helps him miss bats with ease. Pitching at two levels in 2018, PERSON averaged 12.9 strikeouts-per-nine, with a 16 percent swinging strike rate. PERSON's ability to induce whiffs with both pitches makes his below-average control (4.4 walks-per-nine in '18) a lesser issue, though there is some concern over whether hitters will continue to chase his stuff outside of the zone at higher levels. Given the ORGANIZATION' history of aggressively pushing their best relief prospects, PERSON could soon find himself in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was regarded as one of the top prospects in GPE when PERSON signed him in 2008. Now, after slow but steady progress through the ORGANIZATION, he is close to realizing that potential and helping the Indians in the Majors.Defense has always been the strongest part of PERSON's game. His arm, glovework, range and ability to make plays while coming in all make him an above-average defender at third base.At the plate, PERSON isn't quite as advanced, but he has made strides recently. His hand-eye coordination makes him difficult to strike out, even though he is something of a free-swinger. PERSON has a good feel for hitting, and he makes good use of his solid raw power.

PERSON had built a reputation as one of the better college closers in the game, collecting 28 saves over his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION and pitching extremely well out of the bullpen in the ORGANIZATION last summer. When moved into the rotation for his junior year, though, his stuff backed up and knocked him down several pegs on GPE boards everywhere. When pitching in shorter stints, he would crank his fastball up into the 94-97 mph range consistently. His very good changeup would play off of that, and he lived largely off of that two-pitch mix. As a starter, PERSON has been very vanilla, largely pitching with an 89-91 mph fastball and trying to use his fringy breaking ball more frequently. He's moved around to various spots in ORGANIZATION's weekend rotation as a result. Any team considering taking PERSON in the top five rounds will be doing so based on his track record and success on the Cape. A return to a bullpen could allow him to move fairly quickly through a system as well.

One of the more well-rounded position players in the 2015 Draft class, PERSON has solid tools across the board. Evaluators who like him think several of those could develop into plusses, though he'll have to get picked early to deter him from his Stanford commitment. PERSON has a fluid, compact left-handed swing and a good feel for hitting. He uses the entire field, has performed well against quality pitching on the showcase circuit and with the GPE 18-and-under national team, and is growing into some power. He's not especially quick out of the batter's box but flashes plus speed at times once he gets going.PERSON has enough speed and arm strength to play all three outfield positions, though he profiles best in right field. Scouts have compared him to PERSON and ORGANIZATION prospect PERSON, a high school first-rounder in 2011.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Player: PERSON is an PERSON commit who was selected as a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a 2016 ORGANIZATION First Teamer. PERSON participated in the ORGANIZATION All-American Games, the 2015 ORGANIZATION Games, the 2015 ORGANIZATION and the 2016 ORGANIZATION. He also made the 2015 17U ORGANIZATION Development Program roster, allowing no runs and just one hit in two innings pitched. PERSON is both lean and physically projectable. The PERSON commit has polished mechanics and he is smart with the baseball on the mound. The hurler features a sneaky two-seam fastball that sits at 89-91 mph and a curveball with sharp, late break, the latter of which can be a future out pitch.Overall, scouts note that PERSON is a fearless competitor who challenges hitters inside and displays a confident demeanor.
PERSON was a late-rising small school arm in the 2019 draft. He has a workhorse build, mid-90's velocity, feel for spin and glove side location, and some other starter traits.

PERSON was a member of the 18-and-under national team that won the World Cup in GPE last September. He played well in the tournament, tying for the team lead with nine ORGANIZATION, and continued his strong play through the spring. PERSON is a solid defender behind the plate. His arm is slightly above average, and he is a steady receiver. Offensively, he has an advanced approach and a balanced, level swing. He creates good bat speed and projects to have at least average power.PERSON's father, PERSON, pitched for two seasons in the ORGANIZATION and spent several years as a coach in the ORGANIZATION organization. J.J., a GPE recruit, has clearly benefited from his father's instruction, and scouts praise his makeup and feel for the game.

GPE has a solid set of tools across the board, but it's his hitting ability that stands out.The 16-year-old has a medium frame with wide shoulders and lean body that will fill out in the future. At the plate, the shortstop shows plus bat speed with good timing, rhythm and a mature approach when he's in the batter's box. He has a gift for barreling up balls and has a strike zone awareness that's beyond his teenage years.He hits line drives to all fields and his power is starting to show. He's expected to add more strength once he signs with a team and his body continues to develop. On defense, he has a chance to stay at shortstop because he shows good actions at the position, soft hands and good footwork. He has slightly above-average arm strength with accuracy and has shown the ability to throw from different angles. He does not have blazing speed, but he's doesn't clog the bases, either. He's been praised for his work ethic along with his good makeup and the team that signs him will likely envision him as an everyday middle infielder in the big leagues on day.GPE trains with PERSON, a member of ORGANIZATION's PERSON, at FACILITY in GPE, GPE. The Marlins are the favorites to sign the teen.

It hasn't been the most direct career path for this Rutgers product, but PERSON has an intriguing set of tools he's just learning how to use consistently.A football player in college, PERSON didn't return to baseball until his senior year, where he promptly had a huge season and moved up ORGANIZATION boards in a hurry. PERSON has the tools to be a run-producing third baseman with the ability to hit for average and plenty of power. He runs well for a guy his size, and he brings a football mentality to his game on a daily basis. PERSON had some rough edges due to his time away from the game, but he started to smooth them out in 2013. More reps will help, and the end result could be PERSON becoming an everyday corner infielder.

PERSON stood out as a 15-year-old because of his one, truely freakish ability: he has a stone-cold 80 arm (clocked in the mid-80's with a radar gun) and a quick release that allow him to regularly post pop times below 1.80 in games, which is generally a 70-grade time. PERSON is a mature-bodied prospect and a 30 runner presently, someone who appears 'unathletic' on the surface. We often talk about football and baseball athleticism as being two different things, and PERSON is not football athletic, but definitely is baseball athletic. Instead of timed speed or visible strength, he displays quick-twich movement, first step quickness, and overall explosion through strength in the forearms, wrists, and hands. PERSON is an ideal case study in the differences, as he's got soft hands and is mobile behind the plate, and has solid average raw power with similarly graded bat control. The ORGANIZATION may have a 5 defensive catcher with a 5 bat, 5 raw power, and an 8 arm here. That would be quite a find for $600,000, especially given the current wasteland that is big league catching.

PERSON should develop into a prototypical right fielder with a very strong arm, the ability to drive in runs and some baserunning skills to boot, but that development was put on hold when reconstructive elbow surgery forced him out for the entire 2013 season. The toolsy outfielder wasn't ready for the GPE League in 2011 and had to go back down to the ORGANIZATION. When he moved back up a level in 2012, he took the ORGANIZATION by storm, earning a promotion to Double-A. There is little PERSON can't do on the field. He has tremendous bat speed, which should help him develop more power, and improved plate discipline has been a key to him becoming a better all-around hitter. It's not just at the plate where PERSON needs to tone things down at times. He's very aggressive on the basepaths and in the outfield, sometimes to a fault.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

PERSON's power/speed combination intrigued scouts when he was a GPE high schooler, but his strong commitment to Wake PERSON caused him to slip to the 38th round and the Nationals in the 2014 Draft. A consensus PERSON, he saw his numbers dip as a sophomore and struggled with wood bats in the ORGANIZATION last summer. He has rebounded in 2017, matching his home run total from his first two seasons (10) midway through the spring.PERSON has a higher ceiling than most college players in this Draft. He has the strength and bat speed to hit for power and the plus speed to steal some bases and possibly stick in center field. He enhances his on-base ability by drawing a healthy amount of walks and hit-by-pitches.Scouts aren't totally sold on PERSON's right-handed swing, so he'll have to prove he can make consistent contact with wood bats. He also needs to improve his reads and routes to remain in center as a pro, and his fringy arm will dictate a move to left field if he can't.

GPE has parlayed a strong Cape showing into attention this spring where he flashes #3/4 starter upside with a low-to-mid-90's fastball and a plus changeup. Went lower than talent suggested in the draft due to needing TJ after signing.
Strong-bodied infielder with present power.

PERSON hit 93 mph with his fastball as a freshman at GPE (Mo.) JC in 2012, but he went undrafted because he's small and was committed to GPE. After he proved himself as a reliever and a starter against tougher LOCATION competition, he signed for $150,000 as a 12th-rounder in 2014. He reached Double-A midway through 2016 and has established himself as one of the better lefty starting pitching prospects in a GPE system thin in that department.PERSON lacks a plus pitch, relying instead on mixing four offerings and deception to succeed. His fastball sits in the low 90s and peaks at 95 with some run on it. His changeup regressed a bit in 2016 but is solid once again, and his slider improved when he had to use it more often a year ago. He also uses a slow curveball to give batters a different look.His delivery isn't the smoothest and features some effort, though it also makes PERSON' pitches tougher to pick up and doesn't prevent him from throwing strikes. He doesn't miss a lot of bats and his velocity tails off in the later innings, so he might be better suited for middle relief than for the back of a rotation. He lacks the dynamic breaking ball to profile as a lefty specialist.

The ORGANIZATION aren't afraid to take high school pitchers in the first round, having done so with seven of their last 14 selections. Their latest is PERSON, who lasted 22 picks last June because the industry tends to downgrade prep right-handers on GPE day. Outside of PERSON, who went No. 2 to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON had as good an arm as anyone in the 2014 high school class and he signed for $2.5 million.PERSON began his high school senior season by hitting 100 mph during a preseason scrimmage and continued to bring the heat for the rest of his spring and into his pro debut. He usually works at 93-95 mph with impressive life and command. His hard breaking ball can make hitters look bad as well, combining curveball depth with slider velocity in the low 80s.PERSON also exhibits some feel for a changeup, which should become at least an average third pitch. There isn't much projection in his relatively short and stocky frame, but that doesn't matter because his present stuff is plenty good enough to make him a starter. He also does a nice job of throwing strikes for a youngster.
GPE body and swing, could be high-contact ORGANIZATION with speed

Precipitation and misfortune forced Double-A PERSON to play three double-headers in a row in late May (not on consecutive days, but still) and, suddenly, the club was in need of pitching reinforcements. The ORGANIZATION promoted PERSON directly from extended spring training to make a spot start, just three days after his 20th birthday. It's further evidence of PERSON' advanced on-mound craftsmanship, which enables him to succeed with limited stuff. He has now had two strong years of performance at short-season affiliates on the back of a sinking and tailing upper-80s fastball and a slurvy 78-82 mph breaking ball. PERSON' delivery is pretty rough but it doesn't appear to detract from his command, and it may actually help make him tougher for hitters to time. Little things like that are important, as his stuff exists on the margins. If his command maxes out, he'll be a sinker balling backend starter.

PERSON ranked No. 1 on MLB.com's Top 20 international prospects list last summer and he received one of 10 seven-figure bonuses handed out to international amateurs during the signing period, coming to terms on the opening day of the period. He's yet to make any kind of debut, either in the ORGANIZATION or in the GPE, but he's dazzled scouts with his bat speed, hitting mechanics and raw power. He's also opened eyes with his speed and instincts on the bases. His all-around speed combined with his aggressive style, strong arm and athletic body have brought about comparisons to GPE outfielder PERSON when he was the same age.

PERSON rocketed from a sub-6-footer with a mid-70s fastball when he entered PERSON (PERSON) to 6-foot-7 and low-90s heat by the time he was a sophomore. He has continued to improve, impressing on the showcase circuit and with the GPE national 18-and-under team last year and pitching better than ever this spring. He has been spectacular in the GPE 5-A state playoffs, striking out 53 and allowing just two unearned runs in 27 innings to earn four wins and pitch the Mules into the semifinals, and he could be the second high school right-hander drafted, behind PERSON' PERSON has a complete three-pitch arsenal, starting with a 92-97 mph fastball with some cutting action at the lower end of that range and some running life at the upper end. His power curveball tops out in the low 80s with tight spin and good depth, and he'll sometimes turn it into a harder slider. He has upgraded his changeup and used it more this spring, and it drops at the plate and shows flashes of becoming a third plus offering. PERSON also have liked how PERSON has firmed up his large frame, which looked soft at times in 2015. He has good body control for a big kid and does a nice job of repeating a delivery that doesn't feature much effort. There were some initial concerns about the ORGANIZATION State recruit's signability, but he has pushed himself high enough in the Draft to where it shouldn't be an issue.

As the 2017 draft approached, it seemed like there was a strong possibility that PERSON would matriculate to GSP. It was unclear if circumstances would align in such a way that he'd find a home; it would take a team that had a strong evaluation of PERSON (some teams were more apt to project on his fastball than others), a pick near where his talent level made sense, and the pool space to coax him away from college. It turned out the ORGANIZATION were that team, and PERSON signed for $2.1 million, about $400,000 over slot, as a second rounder. After a year and a half of pro ball, PERSON's stuff is basically the same. His fastball resides in the low-90s and he'll show you an above-average curveball and changeup once in a while. He has better command than is usual for a pitcher this age and size, so he comfortably projects as a starter, likely of the ORGANIZATION. 4 or 5 variety.

The ORGANIZATION hoped they were getting a good-hitting high school bat when they nabbed PERSON with an above-slot deal in 2011, but they don't really know what they have yet because he hasn't been able to see much time in actual games so far. He signed late and played in just eight games after being drafted, then missed the entire 2012 season with a shoulder injury that required surgery. When PERSON is healthy, he has a line-drive approach from the left side of the plate, and the hope is he can develop into a Major League average hitter. He doesn't project to have much power, but could have a little extra-base pop. PERSON's speed, a tick above average, should help in that regard as well and be of use in the outfield to boot. He has good range and hands, and his arm is approaching average. PERSON has the chance to be an above-average defender, either in center or left, but more than anything, he just needs to go out and play.

The younger brother of former GPE first-rounder PERSON, PERSON stood out mostly for his defense during his first two years at ORGANIZATION before breaking out at the plate as a junior, leading to his selection by the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round of the 2015 ORGANIZATION. After he signed for $335,400, PERSON took the Class A Short PERSON by storm, winning ORGANIZATION honors and leading the league in average (.358), stolen bases (47), on-base percentage (.432) and runs scored (64). As a result of his success, the ORGANIZATION sent PERSON to Class A Advanced Bakersfield to begin his first full season. PERSON hit a collective .184 between his freshman and sophomore seasons with the ORGANIZATION, and his offensive struggles carried over to the 2014 Cape Cod League, where he hit just .196 with his ORGANIZATION stock on the line. But things came together for him as a junior, and he continued to make strides at the plate in his pro debut after he shortened his swing. He's a disciplined hitter and makes a lot of contact, which in turn allows him to utilize his plus wheels. While he'll never offer much in the way of power, PERSON did show more consistent pop to the gaps in the LOCATION League.Defensively, PERSON shouldn't have trouble sticking at shortstop, where he profiles as an above-average defender with soft hands, good range and an absolute cannon for an arm. Though still has quite a bit to prove at the plate in spite of his impressive pro debut, PERSON could turn out to be one of the biggest steals of the 2015 ORGANIZATION with another strong showing in his first full season.

Up to 94 as a high school underclassman, PERSON was tracking like a traditional first round PERSON high school arm until he had PERSON and missed all but one game during his senior year. He was a wild card on draft day, but ended up going in the third round, and signing for early second round money ($1.7 million). During his first pro summer, PERSON's fastball velocity climbed from the 88-91 range up to the 92-94 area. Then, shoulder and biceps issues plagued his first two full pro seasons and his stuff was down in 2018. 
This spring, he was throwing harder than ever, sitting 94-97 at times, and showing better breaking stuff than he had previously. He's struggling to harness the new stuff, but he hasn't really pitched all that much due to all those injuries, and that he has a chance for four above-average pitches gives him more upside than a lot of the closer, safer prospects on this list. He could have a breakout summer, or it could be very bumpy.

PERSON flew under the radar in the 2014 Draft as a 14th-round pick out of the ORGANIZATION of Texas-San Antonio before a solid 2015 full-season debut in the LOCATION, giving the ORGANIZATION hope that perhaps they got more than they bargained for in the big right-hander.At 6-foot-3, 205 pounds, PERSON has a low leg lift and an early break of the hands that gives his fastball -- thrown in the 90-94 mph range and sitting around 92 mph -- some natural deception. He throws it with more angle than outright sink, but he does throw downhill and generates groundballs. PERSON threw two breaking balls in college, but the ORGANIZATION made him shelve his curveball and focus on his slider, which is improving, though he still struggles to throw it consistently. Add in a changeup and PERSON does have the chance to have a three-pitch mix at his disposal. PERSON is a starter or reliever long-term will depend on how much he can improve the consistency of his breaking ball and his overall command, though the ORGANIZATION are pleased with his work ethic and ability to make adjustments thus far in his career.

GPE is a 2018 undrafted free agent senior sign who had a 2019 breakout. He began the year in the Low-A bullpen (50 K, 9 BB in 35 innings), then in June was moved to the rotation and thrived for twelve starts. He made a few late-August starts at Hi-A, and was good there, too. GPE has fastball command and a plus changeup. He's a little light on velocity, only sitting 90-93, but he's garnered swings and misses at that velocity at the top of the strike zone so far. His changeup has bat-eluding sink and fade, and it get used against righty hitters. GPE's breaking ball is just okay, but he can land it for strikes to start counts. It's a 40-man look, to be sure. Perhaps the velo would uptick in the bullpen (all our GPE info comes from folks who've seen him start) in an interesting way, but for now GPE projects in the 5th/6th starter area.

GPE school pitchers from places like PERSON are invariably long-term projects. The ORGANIZATION knew this when they drafted ORGANIZATION, but they they thought it was a project worth taking on and going well over pick-value to do it.It might be a slow process with PERSON, but it's easy to see why the ORGANIZATION think there's a lot to tap into. He has good size at 6-foot-4 and has already seen an uptick in velocity, up to the 90-93 mph range. He uses his size well to throw downhill and there's even some deception due to a three-quarters arm slot. He throws a curve and a changeup and while both need work, he's shown a feel for each secondary offering . An ability to repeat his delivery should help him find the strike zone consistently.Talking about PERSON as a potential big league contributor would be extremely premature at this point, but with his potential, don't be shocked if he's in that conversation in the future.

One scout compared GPE to J.P. PERSON, but meant it as the amateur verion of PERSON, who lasted until the 16th pick in 2013 for a reason. GPE is also an above average to plus runner, fielder and thrower that can stick at shortstop comofortable and also has a bigger frame for the position that gives him a little more pop than usual. The question with GPE, and with PERSON as an amateur, is about his swing and how much offensive impact there will be. Obviously, PERSON has answered this question as well and as quickly as anyone could expect, but that's the obvious best case scenario for this type of prospect. The ORGANIZATION are believed to have have a deal with GPE for $2 million.

Acquired by PERSON from the ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION in July 2015, GPE excelled at the Double-A and Triple-A levels in '16 to earn a big league callup in August at age 22. However, shoulder fatigue combined with a team-imposed inning cap limited the right-hander to just five starts with the ORGANIZATION, who then sent him and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for '14 first-rounder PERSON in late November. He returned to the big leagues in 2017 with GPE, but also missed considerable time with leg and knee injuries early in the season before taking the rest of the year off in July to address mental health issues.GPE pitches with an average fastball, sitting at 90-93 mph, but it plays up thanks to heavy sinking action that yields a high number of ground balls. His curveball is his lone above-average pitch, and he also mixes in a slider and a usable changeup. The right-hander is around the strike zone with all of his pitches and knows how to keep hitters off balance and guessing by effectively changing speeds.With an advanced feel for four pitches as well as a bulldog mentality on the mound, GPE shows the makings of becoming a backend starter at maturity. Perhaps more importantly, GPE, after receiving treatment for depression and anxiety that affected him for much of 2017, has returned to the game as an advocate for mental health and hopes to change its stigma within the sport.

The GPE landed several promising pitchers with six-figure bonuses in the deeper rounds of the 2011 Draft, led by PERSON (14th round, $250,000), who already has had success in GPE. PERSON (19th, $350,000), PERSON (18th, $325,000) and PERSON (16th, $150,000) have pitched well in the upper levels of the system and soon could join PERSON in the big leagues.PERSON doesn't have a true plus pitch but he has a chance to have three average or better offerings. His 89-92 mph fastball can reach 94 and plays up because it features armside run. His solid changeup is often his best weapon and he also works with an average slider.Though PERSON made significant strides with his control and command in 2014, his walk rate increased again this season. His athleticism leads the GPE to believe he'll be able to make the necessary adjustments and develop into a No. 3 or 4 starter.

Announced as a second baseman when the ORGANIZATION drafted him, and deployed primarily in left field as a pro, PERSON's stiffness and immobility will likely limit him to first base, where he played in college. He has sufficient power to profile there but there have been questions about the contact since high school. He clubbed 22 homers in 2018, mostly at Hi-A, and will force some re-evaluation if he has a big year at Double-A. For now, he projects as a bench bat with limited defensive flexibility.

PERSON got on the national scouting radar when he had a strong performance at ORGANIZATION early during his draft spring, during which he hit 95 mph. He was scouted the rest of the spring but often sat 88-91 and hit 93 mph, working with a solid average changeup as his out-pitch, and a fringy breaking ball that comes and goes with his arm speed, stuff befitting a seventh round selection. 
PERSON changed a bit in pro ball, switching from a curveball to slider, and made that his primary off-speed pitch. His performance, despite below average velocity, was excellent thereafter and he surprised many when he went from Hi-A to the big leagues to start 2019. He's probably a back-end starter, a No. 4/5 at best, but the finished product came together much quicker than anyone expected and some of it happened with pitch development and adjustment, evidence PERSON will be able to continue making relevant tweaks as it becomes pertinent.

PERSON excelled both as a closer and starter at the ORGANIZATION of GPE before the PERSON made him their second-round pick in 2012. He got off to a strong start in '15 in his first Double-A campaign, only to suffer an early-season elbow injury for which he received a platelet-rich plasma injection. PERSON's elbow continued to bother him that fall during instructional league play -- leading to PERSON surgery that would cost him all of '16 -- while a pair of arthroscopic surgeries to address lodged tissue in the joint line in his right elbow kept him off the mound again in '17. Finally healthy to begin '18, PERSON ended a 59-month absence on the mound when he logged a scoreless performance out of Class A Advanced PERSON's bullpen on PERSON Opening Day. PERSON, when healthy, boasts an impressive fastball-slider pairing. He's shown the same velocity in 2018 as he did pre-injury, sitting in the low- to mid-90s and bumping 97-98 mph while using his 6-foot-3 frame to create a downhill angle to the plate. PERSON's slider is inconsistent at times but highly effective against right-handed hitters, giving him a two-pitch combo that's ideal for late-inning bullpen work. He'll also mix in the occasional changeup. PERSON has long been a strike-thrower, but will need to refine his command after his extended layoff.A starting pitcher prior to his injuries, PERSON was shifted to the bullpen ahead of his return and has quickly impressed in the new role, showing a combination of size, stuff and feel that has him back on track toward reaching the Major Leagues.

PERSON was under the scouting radar until a breakout campaign on Cape Cod, during which both he and teammate PERSON (a second round pick by the ORGANIZATION) emerged as top tier bats in the 2018 draft. During the spring, PERSON steadily worked his way up from the late first round to the third overall pick by hitting more than scouts expected a long-limbed power threat to hit. PERSON pulls this off by keeping his arms tucked in during his swing and having a flatter plane; as a result he's both quicker into the zone and in the zone longer than most power hitters. Ideally, hitters with PERSON's plus-plus power have more loft in their swing plane and extend their arms to generate the most power, with PERSON an example of a hitter with a similar frame and this more power-focused approach. We're projecting PERSON as a 50 bat with 60 game power and split the difference a bit--he could go even more extreme for power at the expense of contact--but there are a number of ways this offensive skillset could turn out, particularly with new and more progressive hitting instruction this year for the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's defense also could go a few different ways, depending how much weight he adds to his lean frame and how his lateral quickness ages. Defensively, PERSON looks major league average at times and clearly below average at others, but he'll get plenty of chances to make things work at third base.

Outside of perhaps left-handed high school pitching, there may not be more depth in this class than what the crop of prep catchers has to offer. ORGANIZATION, who had a big summer with PERSON's gold-medal winning 18 and under team, might be the best of the lot. ORGANIZATION is a strong-bodied, left-handed-hitting catcher, which is always in high demand. With an easily above-average arm and fast exchange, he has the catch-and-throw skills to stay behind the plate.More of an all-out effort type than a natural performer, there is still some projection to his frame, so there might be more power to come. That could make him a very good all-around backstop in the future, one who carried over a very strong summer to his spring in the ORGANIZATION, keeping him very much in the first-round picture.

ORGANIZATION's batted ball profile shifted dramatically after the ORGANIZATION acquired him from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION Chapman deal. Since high school, he had been a feel-for-contact corner guy with batting practice power that didn't manifest in games, but the ORGANIZATION got his ground ball rate down from 42% to 30% and he started to mash before they flipped him to GPE for ORGANIZATION. He hit for power in a prolonged big league look but struggled badly against breaking stuff, something that may be an issue moving forward. ORGANIZATION doesn't have a whole lot of offensive wiggle room because he's so limited on defense, but the hit/power combo suggests he is a ORGANIZATION Smith-like corner platoon bat who's ready right now.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of GPE in 2011, scouts liked the 16-year-old's size and power potential. But he went homerless in his first three professional seasons, while his natural hitting ability proved to be better than advertised. He'll try to unlock his power with a new organization, as the D-backs acquired him in April in exchange for a competitive balance PERSON pick. PERSON has a good understanding of the strike zone and solid on-base skills, and he makes a lot of contact. His projectable frame and good bat speed give scouts optimism that he will add more power as he physically matures. Speed isn't a big part of his game, but he's savvy enough to run when he gets the chance.After primarily playing left field in his first two professional seasons, PERSON moved to right field in 2014. His defense remains a work in progress, but if he makes the strength gains he's expected to, he could develop into a prototypical corner outfielder in time.

In the previous 10 Drafts, six GPE high school pitchers have gone in the first three rounds, most notably PERSON (ORGANIZATION, first round, 2007). The latest product of that pipeline is PERSON, who comes from a small prep school that never has had a player drafted.PERSON has a big frame with projectability remaining. He usually pitches at 90-92 mph with his fastball and has reached 94, which he should do more regularly as he fills out. His heater has run and sink as well, and he does a nice job of using his height to throw it on a steep downward plane.While PERSON's curveball can be inconsistent, it has some power to it and plenty of depth when it's on. He's still working on his changeup and his command. He has committed to GPE.

PERSON was a big name out of high school, reportefly turning down seven figures to go to PERSON knowing he would be an eligible sophomore due to his age. He's had an up-and-down spring, coming out of the chute blazing hot, leading to top-10 pick momentum for the first month of the season, then slowly regressing in performance, fastball command and changeup usage. Most scouts think PERSON needs a delivery adjustment in pro ball to make himself more online to the plate as a way to improve his fastball command. That would likely tease out a bit more performance from PERSON's above-average stuff, but he's been too reliant on his plus curveball. To that point, hitters late in the season would sit on the pitch, knowing he had trouble locating his fastball and he barely threw his changeup, including his disastrous outing at GPE where he allowed 11 runs. PERSON has interest as high as 11th overall to GPE and a couple other spots in the teens, but his mixed second half of the season has his likely range more in the 20s.

A Minnesota native, PERSON became PERSON's closer as a freshman. He has steadily improved since then and eventually pitched his way into the role of the ORGANIZATION ace. When the ORGANIZATION selected him 18th overall in June, PERSON became PERSON's first ever first-round pick. He impresses scouts with his stuff, size and command. PERSON throws his fastball in the low- to mid-90s and touched 97 mph this spring. He uses his height to create a good downward plane and pounds the zone. He has good offspeed stuff and is capable of generating swings and misses with his changeup as well as his breaking ball. While PERSON's peak fastball velocity suggests he could be a frontline starter, most scouts think he can at least become a middle-of-the-rotation starter in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was in the Others of GPE section on this list last year, third amongst the 2017 July 2nd signees, none of whom had played a pro game at the time. But PERSON had the strongest 2018 of the group, and he arguably already had the loudest tools. He was one of the best performing amateur hitters from GPE in his signing class (just ahead of PERSON, who's further down this list), and he was also a plus runner who could've been converted to catcher given his quickness, arm strength, and squatty, powerful frame. But the ORGANIZATION didn't want to slow down his bat by asking him to learn to catch. Some scouts who had a one or two game look at this summer didn't love PERSON's non-projectable frame, and they rounded down if he didn't hit in those short looks. But those who saw him for more than a few games saw the advanced bat amateur scouts saw. 
One enthusiastic scout described PERSON's running as plus, though he's not the typically graceful, long striding plus runner. That scout he said had a 'grinding gait, full effort, kicking up grass as he runs like the rooster tail of a speed boat.' In addition to potential plus hit and run tools, there's above-average arm strength and raw power, and now the start of a strong statistical performance record. And if things go askew at the plate, the notion that PERSON could catch is interesting. One ORGANIZATION source described PERSON as an 80 makeup guy, often a prerequisite to consider sending a player behind the plate He's a well-rounded offensive player who looks like an up-the-middle defensive fit of some kind. He may be a top 100 prospect by mid season.

PERSON is listed as a shortstop, but he has a wide range of skills that would allow him to play a different position in the future if necessary. He's been compared to a young PERSON Ramirez.The 6-foot-1, 175-pound middle infielder is known for his strong and athletic body. He has a good arm with soft hands and playable range on defense. He can make the routine plays and the occasional extraordinary play. PERSON is also considered a strong runner.What's more, PERSON is considered an offensive-minded player who shows good bat speed and features a slight uppercut swing. He makes lots of hard contact during batting practice and has the ability to show the power in games. There's the belief that PERSON could be better suited for third base or a corner outfield position, but he'll likely get every opportunity to show that he can stay in the middle of the diamond on defense as he develops.PERSON is trained by PERSON in the ORGANIZATION.

Just 19 years old this season, PERSON has already started to turn heads. He has plus-plus speed, which he puts to good use on the base paths and in center field. He swiped 33 bases in 68 games in the ORGANIZATION in 2012 and has plus range in the outfield. At the plate, PERSON uses his compact swing to hit line drives. He is a patient hitter and walked more than he struck out in the ORGANIZATION. As he physically matures, PERSON may develop power. If not, he profiles as a leadoff hitter.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2007, PERSON spent his first five pro seasons and part of a sixth in GPE ball. After finally reaching Triple-A in late April, he cracked the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster in August with his first callup to the big leagues.Though PERSON has spent much of his ORGANIZATION career as a starter, he has a brighter future as a reliever. He usually works at 92-95 mph as part of a rotation, and he's reached 99 coming out of the bullpen. PERSON' No. 2 pitch is a hard cutter/slider that pushes the upper 80s.PERSON has funky mechanics that often hamper his control and command. He shows some aptitude for a changeup and often throws it too hard, and he tips off his curveball by slowing down his delivery. PERSON might be better off by shifting to relief and focusing on his two best pitches.

PERSON was a starter at FACILITY and threw a no-hitter to beat ORGANIZATION and PERSON in 2011. He has battled injuries throughout his career and underwent PERSON surgery in 2010. His health issues scared teams again on the eve of the 2011 Draft when he was pulled from his start in the ORGANIZATION after one inning because of elbow and back discomfort. PERSON has PERSON stuff when he's healthy and could be a starter. His injury history, however, makes him a better fit in the bullpen, where his power arsenal makes him a potential high-impact reliever. PERSON throws his fastball in the upper-90s and mixes it with a solid slider and changeup. He reached Double-A Richmond this year and is moving quickly toward PERSON.

There are often expectations for a college lefty, especially from a program like ORGANIZATION, to move quickly through a Minor League system. In that regard, PERSON hasn't measured up. At the same time, though, the southpaw led the ORGANIZATION State League and came in second in the ORGANIZATION in strikeouts over his first two full seasons.Not completely a finesse pitcher, PERSON combines solid stuff with a good feel for pitching. He'll feature a fastball that's a touch above-average, commanding it well with sink to generate ground-ball outs and adding to and subtracting from it. He has the chance to throw a true curve in the future, but he'll get on the side of it and it takes on a different shape as a result. He throws a slider as well, especially against lefties, though the ORGANIZATION think the curve will be his better breaking ball eventually. His changeup gives him another offering that's slightly above-average. He throws all of his pitches for strikes and his command should only improve over time.While he doesn't have the highest ceiling in the world, PERSON isn't too far from reaching it. After moving slowly, it may not take him that much more time to be ready to contribute to a big league rotation.

A young, polished, but relatively unexplosive high schooler, GPE was a bit of a surprise second rounder in 2017 but has quickly become much more interesting thanks to a sterling 2018 season with PERSON. As a 19-year-old, he hit .352/.405/.511 for the ORGANIZATION, torching even the loftiest of expectations set by scouts who saw him during extended spring training and mostly considered GPE a future utility man. Fundamentally sound at short, he lacks the explosiveness and big arm strength scouts look for at the position, and we wonder if GPE will hit for enough power to be an impact player at any other position. 
His early career strikeout rate (7.5% in about 450 PA) suggests his bat-to-ball skills are even more promising than amateur scouts anticipated, though he's also an aggressive swinger who has been hit by nearly twice as many pitches as he has walks so far. When scouts talk about a player having 'feel, polish, instincts' and the like, and the player has numbers like GPE's contact rates, we typically round up on that player. In GPE's case, we remain cautious because the eyeball scouts are so resolute in their skepticism of the power projection.

The ORGANIZATION paid PERSON $250,000 to turn pro as a 17th-rounder at the signing deadline in 2010. Sixteen months later, they shipped him and PERSON to the FACILITY for PERSON. He was on the move last December, sent to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON. 3 came in late March when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION Holaday deal.Without a true out pitch, PERSON relies on mixing his three-pitch repertoire and an improved ability to pitch to contact. His fastball sits in the 91-93 mph with good movement. His slider has some bite and he can throw his changeup with sink. He's become more aggressive within the zone and cutting down his walk rate.PERSON doesn't have a high ceiling, but he is almost ready to reach it. He could be a No. 4 or 5 starter or a middle reliever in the near future.

Initially thought to become part of the ORGANIZATION organization during the last international signing period when he was declared a free agent in January, PERSON eventually did sign in July. Ranked No. 7 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 international prospects list, the ORGANIZATION blew past their international pool money by giving the 22-year-old PERSON shortstop $7 million to sign.A high energy player who is thought of as a glove-first prospect with excellent speed, PERSON was the 2014-15 PERSON of the Year in GPE and a former gold glove winner there. His speed allows him to have excellent range to go along with his outstanding hands. He has more than enough arm to stay at shortstop long-term. PERSON is making progress with the bat and the ORGANIZATION think he's going to hit at the highest level. His speed should allow him to be a basestealing threat as well.PERSON gets high marks for his confidence and makeup, things that should allow him to transition fairly easily to the game in this country, eventually developing into an everyday shortstop.
GPE is a 70 runner with 50 raw power that can passably play all three positions up the middle but his swing mechanics and skills can't match his tools.

PERSON led ORGANIZATION prepsters in homers for three straight years and offered some of the best power among high school middle infielders in the 2014 Draft, but a so-so senior season and signability issues left him unselected and headed to PERSON.
