Tall and projectable, he could add to his low-90s heavy fastball that already generates a ton of groundball outs. He knows how to spin a breaking ball, throwing a solid curve with good rotation and bite. His changeup has improved, though it remains behind the other two offerings. His command has improved and he's shown a good overall feel for pitching.PERSON showed tremendous mental toughness pitching through the 2014 season while his young son was very ill. That, along with the strides he has made since being drafted, has the ORGANIZATION confident he can be a starting pitcher at the big league level.

PERSON started for three years at ORGANIZATION, even hitting in the middle of the lineup there at times as a junior, before landing with the ORGANIZATION in the sixth round of the 2016 GPE. He turned in a GPE York-Penn League All-Star season during his pro debut and played across three levels, reaching Double-A in his first full season.While PERSON played both middle infield positions during his first summer of pro ball, he has exclusively played short, a big reason why he's been able to rush up the organizational ladder. He's a solid defender with excellent hands, solid range and enough arm for the left side of the infield. While he's not a burner, his speed is an asset defensively and on the basepaths. He's a switch-hitter with a contact-oriented approach, one who draws walks and doesn't strike out much.PERSON probably profiles best as a utilityman when all is said and done. Seeing him as a defensive-minded regular isn't out of the question, especially given the ORGANIZATION' ability to find big league talent in college performers taken in the later rounds of the GPE.

The ORGANIZATION landed two of the most polished pitchers in the 2015 PERSON, pairing collegian PERSON in the first round with PERSON in the third. The latter is a product of GPE's PERSON, which has produced five first-rounders and four big leaguers in the last two decades, highlighted by PERSON. He's also the son of GPE vice president of amateur and international scouting PERSON PERSON.Signed for $950,000, PERSON also had one of the best curveballs in last year's PERSON, a true downer that he'll throw in any count. His fastball usually operates at 89-93 but still gets swings and misses because it sinks and tails and he hides and locates it well.PERSON grew up around baseball and played at one of the top high school programs in the nation, so he's more advanced than most pitchers his age. He has good feel for his changeup, which has improved since he entered pro ball, and commands his stuff well. He's a high-floor pitcher with a ceiling of a mid-rotation starter.

While PERSON has hit pretty much everywhere the ORGANIZATION have sent him since drafting him in the third round in 2010, he scuffled upon reaching Triple-A in 2015. He still made his big league debut in GPE, and a shoulder injury forced him out of action for over a month.A compact swing and quick hands allow PERSON to make consistent hard contact. He can occasionally turn on a ball and drives the gaps well, but power is not a big part of his game. He knows how to take advantage of his plus speed and can be disruptive on the basepaths. He has made significant strides on the defensive side of the ball as a professional and profiles well at second base. PERSON endears himself to scouts with his hustle and hard-nosed style of play. Though his height makes it easy to label him a grinder, his tools give him a good chance to be a solid regular in the ORGANIZATION.
GPE had solid average stuff most of his career at ORGANIZATION, but some scouts thought his velocity would improve, which it did in the last month or so, allowing him to project as a 3rd/4th starter.

A four-year starter at GPE, PERSON helped the Gators reach the ORGANIZATION World Series in 2012 and '15. The leading hitter (.355) on the latter ORGANIZATION club, which may produce as many as seven position players drafted in the top three rounds, PERSON signed with the Phillies for $10,000 as a 10th-round senior. He batted .301/.362/.439 in his first two pro seasons, reaching high Class A, before GSP traded him for PERSON in December.PERSON' strong suit is his ability to make consistent line-drive contact. A switch-hitter who's more effective from his natural right side, he can drive some balls to the gaps and has occasional home run power to his pull side. While he doesn't strike out excessively, he would benefit from a more patient approach to bolster his walk totals.Primarily a third baseman in college, PERSON has played mostly second base as a pro. An average runner with arm strength to match, he doesn't quite have the quickness desired at the keystone and is a fringy defender there. He also has seen action in left field and profiles best as a bat-first utility guy who earns raves for his makeup.

There is no question that PERSON is ready to defend behind the plate at the big league level. That was apparent even before he got his first callup, a trip cut very short in his first game by an ankle sprain (he made it back up in September). PERSON has thrown out 46 percent of would-be basestealers in the Minors with above-average arm strength that plays up as plus thanks to a quick release and excellent accuracy. He's made strides with the bat as well â he hit very well post-injury in 2012 â and could be a fringy hitter. With his glove work, that should be enough to land him a big league job of some sort, though there isn't room behind the plate in GPE right now.

PERSON's 2018 was his first injury-free full season as a pro, but he was used out of the bullpen in health-friendly two and three-inning stints separated by several days of rest. He was also crushed underneath a landslide .443 BABIP and had a 7.28 ERA at Double-A. 
He has back-end starter stuff but was part of the ORGANIZATION lefty bullpen competition during the spring. During that time, PERSON worked in the 91-94 range; he can spot cutting and breaking stuff to his glove side, and his changeup is suitable for light usage versus righties. We still like him as a No. 4 or 5 starter type, though we could see justifying a bullpen move if the ORGANIZATION thought it was why PERSON stayed healthy all last year. He seems likely to be a competent part of a pitching staff in some form, and had a good showing with the 2019 big club during spring training before being sent back to Double-A in late-March.

PERSON was one of four prep hitters in the 2018 class -- along with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON -- who played together in the ORGANIZATION USA pipeline for years; all got top-two round money in the draft. PERSON is the best of the group because he offers the best contact skills while also being tied for having the most raw power, speed, and defensive value. His well-rounded skillset enticed the ORGANIZATION to take him sixth overall, but he was then traded by new GM PERSON as the headliner to acquire PERSON and PERSON. PERSON is an intense competitor who works tirelessly, to the point that some teammates and scouts think he should reel it back in a bit at times, though they point out they'd rather have a guy who's too dedicated than one who's not enough. He's a plus straight-line runner but more of a 55 on the field, and thus isn't a slam dunk to stick in center. But he has 55 raw power, so there's enough thump to profile if he ends up sliding over to right field, where his plus arm would also fit.

From GPE, GPE, PERSON is arguable the top player from his country in this year's class. The teenager has shown the ability to hit, but he has impressed scouts the most with his defensive skills. He looks the part, scouts say, because he calls a good game and takes control behind the plate.How good is PERSON? Some evaluators believe he has a potential plus arm and could be a plus defender in the future. They also like his solid receiving skills, a must for any good catcher. Other scouts consider his arm average, but they also note that it's impossible to ignore the total package and his overall potential.PERSON signed a $1 million deal with the GPE.

In many respects, PERSON is already a huge success story. He went undrafted and lightly recruited out of high school, making PERSON as a preferred walk-on. He was a three-year, and much honored, starter there and was the second-highest pick in the program's history when the A's took him in the third round of the 2016 Draft, a spot he fell to because of a broken left hamate during his final collegiate season. He's turned into one of the better all-around catching prospects in the game, excelling in Double-A in 2018, though surgery on his other hamate in July shelved him for seven weeks. He was off to a strong start in Triple-A in 2019 when he once again hit the injured list, this time with a torn left meniscus that required surgery in early May. PERSON has always stood out defensively. He's athletic and agile behind the plate, he blocks and receives well and gets high marks for his game-calling and ability to work with pitchers. He also has one of the strongest arms in the Minors, one that baserunners don't test too often and that has thrown out 35.5 percent of potential basestealers heading into 2019. He's a threat at the plate as well, with a short swing from the right side of the plate to go with a high contact rate. He's not afraid to draw walks and there could be 20-homer potential in the future.PERSON will be a big leaguer based on his glovework alone, one who could be a defensive-minded starter. Add in his possible offensive production and he has the chance to be an elite-level, all-around receiver soon.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 14, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON has deep baseball roots, as his father, GPE, played professional ball for five seasons in the early '90s and made it to high A Ball with the ORGANIZATION and PERSON Rangers.With his father as a mentor, the LOCATION commit has earned praise from scouts and was named a 2016 Perfect Game All-American, where he was the starting catcher for the GPE team.Scouts see PERSON as a solid catching prospect, both offensively and defensively. With a pop time ranging from 1.7-1.9 seconds, he boasts the ability for his arm to accelerate and throw quickly to the base. At the plate, he handles the bat really well, making good contact to all fields with power.

PERSON was the top-rated pitcher on MLB.com's Top 30 international prospects list in 2013 and the ORGANIZATION gave him $1.3 million to sign in July of that year. After making his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION last summer, PERSON was sent to the ORGANIZATION in January as part of the ORGANIZATION trade.PERSON is not the biggest guy in the world, but he has the makings of a very good three-pitch mix with the chance to command it fairly well. His fastball right now will sit in the low-90s, but he can reach back for more. While only six-feet tall, there is some room for him to add strength to his frame and that could lead to additional velocity. PERSON will show a solid curve and some pretty good feel for a changeup, though none of it consistently at this point. His delivery needs some work and that should help him command the baseball better.It may take a while, but PERSON is the kind of young arm who will prove to be the best return in a trade years after the deal was made.

The younger brother of PERSON, who pitched in one game for the 2010 Tigers, PERSON concluded his amateur career by winning ORGANIZATION honors at the 2015 College World Series. After earning three victories and a save while throwing 13 scoreless innings in relief for GPE, he signed for $722,500 as a supplemental second-round pick and reached high Class A in his pro debut. He returned there in 2016 and has been one of the GPE's best starting pitchers.A reliever as a freshman and junior for the ORGANIZATION, PERSON focused on two pitches when he came out of the bullpen. Neither his 91-95 mph fastball nor his slider is overpowering, but they both feature late life that keeps them off the barrels of bats. When he needed a third offering as a sophomore starter, he did exhibit some feel for a changeup but the pitch needs a lot of work.The Dodgers plan on using PERSON in the rotation. His unorthodox arm action adds to his deception but hampers his control and command, and he's working on getting more consistent with the front side of his delivery to help him locate his pitches better. He has a durable frame and the upside of a mid-rotation starter if he can make the necessary adjustments, and he also could advance quickly if he returns to the bullpen.

It's not a good class for college catching, so one who performs well is bound to move up PERSON boards.The switch-hitting PERSON has had to wait his time to get behind the plate, playing first and the outfield for his first two years at ORGANIZATION. He has a lot of work to do defensively behind the plate, though he does have a solid arm. He is showing, as he has with some very strong summer ball performances, that he can hit. PERSON has the chance to hit for average and power.The team that feels his defense will improve with more time behind the plate and some patience, will likely take him early in the hopes he can be a solid offensive-minded backstop.

If a post-Draft physical hadn't revealed a bone chip in his elbow, PERSON would have signed with the ORGANIZATION for $80,000 as a 23rd-rounder out of high school in 2010. Instead he spent a year each at two different GPE junior colleges before turning pro as a fourth-rounder in 2012. He'd moved slowly and steadily up the ORGANIZATION' ladder, reaching Triple-A in 2015, when he was included in the group of prospects the ORGANIZATION received in return for PERSON Hamels.PERSON can reach 96 mph with his fastball and back it up with a hard slider at his best, but his stuff dipped somewhat in 2014. He worked mostly at 89-93 mph with an average slider. His changeup remained a reliable third pitch and he continued to use a curveball to give hitters a different look. PERSON employs an easy delivery that results in very solid control and command. He lacks a true plus pitch but has consistently performed and could end up as an innings-eating mid-rotation starter.

Trenta-sized teenagers who throw in the mid-90s don't typically have any idea where its going, but PERSON threw strikes so efficiently for two months in the ORGANIZATION that the ORGANIZATION thought him fit for an August promotion. He made his stateside debut just before his 17th birthday and walked just six hitters in 50 innings all summer. So PERSON has rare size, precocious velocity, and control, though much of the rest of the profile has room for improvement. He exhibits neither notable raw spin nor feel for locating his current breaking ball,  a low-80s slurve. There's a strong chance PERSON tries several iterations of various breaking balls during the course of his development and the one(s) he ends up with will probably look much different than what he's currently using. At this point in his development, we just care about the raw spin, a trait of limited malleability, and PERSON' is just okay. It's reasonable to hope he grows into elite velocity. The fact that he's throwing this hard at this age and at this size is encouraging, though he's less projectable than one would probably assume given his age and height. All talk of PERSON' physical progression centers around reshaping his current frame rather than just adding mass, as he's already pretty filled out. This clouds the fastball projection somewhat, but he'll probably still end up throwing really hard. There's need for significant development throughout the rest of the repertoire, and it's more likely that a portion of that happens (resulting in a back-of-the rotation or bullpen role) than it is that all of it does (resulting in stardom). He signed for $250,000 in 2017.
GPE is a one-seam sinker/changeup righty with a pretty firm, inconsistent mid-80s slider. A refined slider gives him a good shot to pitch in the back of a rotation.

Pitching out of the bullpen during his three years at ORGANIZATION, PERSON compiled 22 career saves while appearing in 62 games before going to the ORGANIZATION in the 11th round in the 2015 Draft. His stuff has improved since entering the professional ranks, enabling the right-hander to make a quick rise through the ORGANIZATION. After a dominant performance with Double-A Montgomery in his second full season, PERSON opened 2018 on the cusp of the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION, where he was a mid-season All-Star with PERSON. One of many hard-throwing relievers in the upper tiers of PERSON's system, PERSON attacks hitters with a mid-90s fastball that consistently reaches 97 mph with late life. He throws a pair of quality secondary pitches in a power slider that's been up to 90 mph with late diving action, and a changeup that at times plays above its plus grade. The three-pitch mix makes PERSON effective against right- and left-handed hitters alike, and he's long showed the ability to keep the ball in the park. Big and physical with a track record of durability, PERSON could soon carve out a role as a high-leverage reliever in the big leagues. His control and command still leaves something to be desired, especially as it relates to his slider, though he did show improvement on that front early in his first Triple-A campaign.

A reliever on ORGANIZATION teams that won the ORGANIZATION World Series in 2014 and finished runner-up in 2015, PERSON opened 2016 in the ORGANIZATION rotation before returning to the bullpen and serving as closer. After signing him for an above-slot $1.6 million as a second-rounder, the ORGANIZATION sent him to low Class A, where he led the LOCATION League with 11 holds in 26 appearances. He has yet to pitch in 2017 while dealing with a bulging disc in his back that may require surgery.Pitching in shorter stints, PERSON operates at 92-95 mph with his fastball, which tops out at 97 and features late life and steep downhill plane. Though he only pitched 96 1/3 innings in three years of college, he has impressive feel for a tumbling changeup that can be a plus offering at times. He has some power to a slurvy breaking ball that fluctuates between a curveball and slider and shows more promise as the latter.While some scouts believe PERSON could make it as a starter with three pitches and a durable frame, GPE will keep him in the bullpen and expedite him to the big leagues. He could be one of the first players from the 2016 Draft to reach the Majors, though his back issues have slowed his timetable. More than just a lefty specialist, he's equipped to become a set-up man and could turn into a closer if he improves his slider and command.

After having five right-handers selected in the top five rounds of the last four GPE, PERSON has two more candidates this year in relievers PERSON and PERSON. The ORGANIZATION' career saves leader with 26 entering ORGANIZATION tournament play, PERSON might be able to make the transition to starting in pro ball.PERSON has a quick arm that consistently produces 93-95 mph fastballs with heavy sink that he can command to either side of the plate. He usually throws his low-80s slider for strikes and can turn it into more of a cutter, though it also gets slurvy at times. He shows some feel for a changeup but doesn't need it much in a relief role.PERSON has a strong, durable frame and three pitches, so a team could be tempted to try him in the rotation. He doesn't have a classic starter's delivery, but he does repeat it well. If he stays in the bullpen, he could become a seventh-inning reliever and perhaps more if he can refine his slider.

Teammate of PERSON and PERSON has emerged to be another top-5 round talent at PERSON. PERSON was eligible last year but has emerged this year, sitting 94-98 and hitting 100 mph. He also DH'd for PERSON and has some raw power.

Originally a 30th-round pick by the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON opted not to sign and instead honored his commitment to GPE, where he pitched for one season before transferring to PERSON and sitting out for all of '15. Selected by the Nationals in the 22nd round the following year, PERSON has rewarded the organization by making steady progress in each pro season and reached Double-A for the first time in June 2018. A two-sport standout who excelled on both the hardwood and diamond as a prep, PERSON stands out on the mound for his blend of athleticism, stuff and remaining projection. The 6-foot-4 right-hander pitches with a low-90s fastball that features exceptional sink and nets him a plethora of weak, ground-ball outs. PERSON pairs his heater with a quality changeup, giving him two above-average offerings, and the Nationals have been pleased with his development of a slider. PERSON possesses average control and command because he repeats his delivery and arm action well. That feel for pounding the zone allows for PERSON's three-pitch mix to play up, and he's long proved adept at keeping the ball in the park. While he remains a work-in-progress overall, PERSON's impressive development and remaining projection has led some evaluators to peg him as a future back-end starter at the highest level.

PERSON lost most of 2015 and 2016 at ORGANIZATION after a line drive to the head left him with severe concussion symptoms, then bounced back to become the second pitcher in school history with a 100-strikeout season as a redshirt senior in 2018. The ORGANIZATION offered him a $5,000 bonus as a 32nd-round pick and he has made the most of that opportunity. He began this year in extended spring training but earned a promotion from low Class A reliever to high Class A starter in GPE, and he didn't permit an earned run in his first four starts afterward.PERSON's success hinges on a sinker that rivals PERSON's as the best in the system. He has sat at 92-93 mph and touched 95 with his two-seamer as a starter, and Class A hitters have struggled to lift it in the air. He throws his curveball and slider in the low 80s, and they're reliably average offerings when they don't blend together.He has some feel for a changeup as well, enhancing PERSON's chances of remaining a starter and becoming a back-of-the-rotation option. To do so, he'll have to upgrade his control and command. He lacks a wipeout offering but his sinker gives him a chance to join PERSON as the only ORGANIZATION products to reach the Majors.

PERSON High in GPE has produced four first-round picks in the last two decades: PERSON (1995), PERSON (2000), PERSON (2000) and PERSON (2002). PERSON, PERSON's latest star, might get picked earlier than any of them because he's an offensively gifted catcher with plus arm strength to boot. His standout tool is his right-handed power, which he generates with bat speed and strength. He has enough feel for hitting that he could produce .280 batting averages in the ORGANIZATION. To do that, he'll need to curb a tendency for his swing that gets long at times which causes him to miss hittable fastballs. PERSON's arm gives him a third future plus tool. He moves better than most catchers, though his receiving will need to improve if he's to stick behind the plate. If not, he has enough athleticism and bat to make it as a right fielder. He has committed to GPE.

The trade that sent ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION has already paid the ORGANIZATION a huge dividend in the form of PERSON and, to a lesser extent, GPE d'Arnaud. If PERSON's transition to full-season ball in 2015 is any indication, there could be more payment on the way.PERSON, who received a seven-figure bonus from the ORGANIZATION when he signed in 2011 out of GPE, more than held his own at age 20 in the LOCATION. That he did so in GPE, one of the worst hitting environments in the ORGANIZATION, was even more impressive. PERSON showed some of his raw power in the first half, but he expanded his strike zone too much. To his credit, he adjusted, and his walk rate skyrocketed while his strikeout rate came down. PERSON has plus power potential, and his improved hittability could allow him to tap into it more consistently in the future. PERSON is an average runner with an arm a tick above average, with enough of each to play a capable right field. If the bat continues to click, he should have the kind of offensive profile teams want from the corner outfield position.

Could PERSON be the next Alcides Escobar? Some evaluators sure think so.Known for his quick and soft hands with good range to both sides, there's a lot scouts like about PERSON' game, including the way he turns double plays. PERSON also praise his overall defensive actions and athleticism. What's more, PERSON has a strong enough arm to keep him at shortstop in the future, but it's not unreasonable to think he changes positions in the future because of his overall skill set.On offense, PERSON shows a balanced approach at the plate, good bat speed and a slight uppercut in his swing. He's a line-drive hitter who makes hard contact and is able to spray the ball to all fields.PERSON projects to be an average runner in the future and is usually clocked between 7 to 7.1 seconds in the 60-yard run. He's also expected to hit for more power as he grows physically.The infielder from GPE, GPE, trains with PERSON and is represented by PERSON of ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION Sox are the favorite to sign him.

A Cape Cod League All-Star in 2015, PERSON continued to improve his ORGANIZATION stock the next year while helping PERSON advance to the ORGANIZATION II Championship Tournament. One of 10 finalists for the PERSON, presented annually to the nation's top ORGANIZATION II hurler, PERSON became the highest ORGANIZATION pick in GPE history when the ORGANIZATION selected him in the sixth round. Though he would garner ORGANIZATION All-Star honors in his full-season debut, PERSON's time with the ORGANIZATION came to an end in July when he was traded to GPE, along with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, in the deal for PERSON. PERSON sits in the low 90s with his fastball, touching 93 mph, but it plays up, thanks to a high spin rate, and because he locates it to all quadrants of the zone. His slider is a plus offering, thrown with short, late biting action that misses bats, and he also shows feel for mixing in a curveball and a changeup, though both are currently fringy. PERSON's strike-throwing ability is another strength. He walked just 13 batters in 107 2/3 innings as a junior, and then posted a 51-to-7 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 56 innings during his pro debut in the LOCATION League.PERSON has a clean arm action and repeats his delivery with ease, but a general lack of movement on his pitches has led some to project him in a long-relief role. The ORGANIZATION were more optimistic, believing that PERSON can develop into a solid back-of-the-rotation starter, and he certainly looked the part this season during his time in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON started at shortstop for three years at ORGANIZATION. For the first two, he was known mostly for his ability with the glove. A big step forward with the bat as a junior allowed him to be thought of as one of the best all-around prospects at the position and landed him in the fifth round, where he signed with the ORGANIZATION for nearly $100,000 below pick value.While PERSON lacks a plus tool, he does have the chance to hit and stay at short, which puts him ahead of many of his college counterparts. He's an average runner with a solid arm and gets the job done at the premium position without any flash, relying on good anticipation and a quick first step. He has fast hands and can make throws from a variety of angles. While he might be a bottom-of-the-order hitter at the highest level, he does make consistent contact and started driving the ball with more authority than he used to during his junior season. He's not a plus runner, but he does have excellent baserunning instincts.PERSON may not wow anyone with tools, but he's the kind of solid performer who ends up as an everyday shortstop on a winning PERSON roster.

After drafting PERSON O'Neill out of GPE Columbia in 2013, the ORGANIZATION turned to the GPE prep ranks for power once again in '14, selecting ORGANIZATION native GPE with the ORGANIZATION. 74 overall pick and then signing him with a well-above-slot $2 million bonus. But unlike O'Neill, who has emerged as a Top 100 overall prospect, GPE played in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION for a third straight season. A physical specimen at 6-foot-4, 220 pounds, GPE has robust raw power and a ton of bat speed from the right side of the plate. So far, though, he has yet to neither apply his power nor make contact with any semblance of consistency. In his return to the ORGANIZATION last year, his feast or famine approach resulted in a league-worst strikeout total and strikeout rate, and it's difficult to envision him making strides in that regard until he improves his pitch recognition and overall approach. Defensively, GPE's above-average arm profiles in right field, but his below-average speed does limit his range somewhat.Patience will be the key for GPE, who still has a high ceiling. If everything clicks, he's the type of player who could hit in the middle of a lineup.

After demolishing the ORGANIZATION (as was expected), PERSON had a solid 38 game run at Double-A. He turned 21 in GPE. He's hit everywhere he's been since high school and continues to look fine, if unspectacular, at shortstop. He's above-average in every way at the plate (the bat control, power, feel for opposite field contact, ability to punish mistakes) which means he's got a good chance to be an All Star if he stays at shortstop, and it looks like he's going to.

After hitting 13 homers as a sophomore last spring and then leading the GPE collegiate national team in all three slash stats at .372/.500/.535 last summer, PERSON positioned himself well in a 2018 Draft with a notable lack of catchers. But he has confounded scouts by not making more progress offensively, and they now wonder if his defense might be better than his bat. He still shows decent potential both ways, which along with his track record will make him one of the first backstops selected.PERSON's raw power is his best offensive trait, the product of strength and good-not-great bat speed, though there are questions as to how consistently he'll get to it in pro ball. He looks to crush everything to his pull side, leaving him vulnerable on the outer half of the plate. He has managed the strike zone well in college but his approach could get exploited by pro pitchers.PERSON has made strides behind the plate this spring, cleaning up his receiving and improving his framing skills. He has average arm strength that plays up a bit because he gets rid of the ball quickly and makes accurate throws. He does a nice job of running a pitching staff.

Perhaps the most bizarre prospect in a strange draft, FACILITY is a backwards (throws left, bats right), plus-running first baseman who some scouts want to see tried in center field. Other scouts find that idea inscrutable as FACILITY is a potential plus-plus defender at first, though, while he has great bat to ball skills, he lacks the game power associated with that position.

A seventh-round pick by the ORGANIZATION out of a GPE high school in 2010, PERSON opted to attend PERSON instead. He ranked seventh in ORGANIZATION Division I with 11.0 strikeouts per nine innings in 2013 -- one spot ahead of GPE. 1 overall pick PERSON -- but PERSON lasted until the fourth round because scouts were concerned that his over-reliance on his slider had sapped his velocity.PERSON's slider still is his best pitch, a mid-80s breaker with a lot of bite. The ORGANIZATION are calling for his slider a lot less than PERSON did, and his fastball has perked up. He's working in the low 90s with good sink that induces a lot of groundouts.The brother of ORGANIZATION third-base prospect PERSON, PERSON has a rudimentary changeup. He shows the control and command to remain in the rotation, though some scouts worry that his crossfire delivery puts too much stress on his shoulder and believe he'd last longer as a sinker/slider reliever.

PERSON was one of the top talents in his July 2 class and got the biggest bonus ($3.2 million) the ORGANIZATION handed out in their pool-busting effort. PERSON was seen then as a mature-framed corner type with massive raw power, but there were questions about his contact and athleticism for defense. Those are still the issues to worry about here. Reports are that PERSON has slimmed and will continue playing third base in 2019, where his plus arm has a chance to play, unlike at first base, which is his most likely destination long-term. There was some chatter of developing PERSON on the mound, either exclusively or as a two-way player, but nothing came of it. In his age-19 and 20 seasons at Low-A, he hit 23 homers in 488 plate appearances, so he can already get to his grade-70 or 80 raw power in games (one source mentioned a 117 mph exit velo), but he also struck out over 30% of the time during that stretch. This is starting to feel like a Quad-A power hitter who only gets a big league cup of coffee or has a short-lived platoon/bench role, but he's also still just 21, so we'll give the raw tools and pedigree the benefit of the doubt for one more year.

Not the biggest pitcher in the 2015 Draft class, PERSON's stock took a hit when a stress reaction in his back forced him to the sidelines for most of his senior season. The ORGANIZATION were confident enough in his health to take him in the middle of the first round.When healthy, he has two plus pitches in his 92-94 mph fastball that tops out at 96 and a tight curveball. PERSON's third pitch is a changeup that needs more work. He has an easy delivery that enhances his ability to command his pitches and his chances to remain a starter despite his smaller build.The ORGANIZATION have shown a penchant for developing young pitching in the past and by taking PERSON in the first round, the PERSON regime is showing they're more than willing to go that route again.

At the start of the GPE season, scouts get to watch top talent in warm-weather climates like GPE and GPE. As the spring warms up, which has been slow to happen in 2018, prepsters in places like the ORGANIZATION start to pop up as they can really get going. PERSON has been the case with PERSON, who was dominating high school competition, including a 17-strikeout perfect game, even with it still being cold and rainy in GPE and physically mature, PERSON has been a man amongst boys in his senior season. His fastball sits easily in the 91-92 mph range and is consistently up to 93-95 mph. He commands the fastball and his solid curveball very well, giving high school hitters little chance of success. He shows good arm speed on his changeup, throwing it with fading sink, though he doesn't have to throw it often. He also has a slider, which is behind his curve, a solid pitch that could get shelved as a pro.While PERSON isn't projectable in terms of adding strength, there is growth to come in terms of refining his already-solid stuff under pro tutelage. Committed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE, PERSON's name has been popping up in top three rounds conversations.

The PERSON brothers pitched PERSON (Tallahassee) to the GPE state 3-A championship in 2014, with PERSON spinning a shutout in the semifinals and PERSON pitching four scoreless innings to win the finale. PERSON signed for $1.1 million as a fourth-round pick that June, while PERSON would have gone in about the same area of the 2015 PERSON had he not been strongly committed to PERSON's stuff has backed up a bit, but he's still a projectable left-hander with the potential for three average pitches. His fastball ranged from 90-95 mph when he was in high school but now sits more at 88-91, though he throws it for strikes with armside run. He also has a downer curveball and a fading changeup, and any of his three offerings can be his best on a given night.Like most young pitchers, PERSON needs to add strength and gain more consistency with his secondary pitches and command. If he can do that, he can become a mid-rotation starter.

ORGANIZATION played in both the ORGANIZATION World Series, hitting a home run in GPE game defeat and in the 2013 ORGANIZATION Under-18 World Cup, where he faced a GPE team that included first rounders ORGANIZATION (GPE), ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION), ORGANIZATION (GPE), ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION), ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION) and likely 2017 first round pick C J.J. Schwarz (ORGANIZATION of GPE). ORGANIZATION has average stuff, usually sitting around 90, and a maxed-out frame, but some feel for pitching. Scouts tend to agree that he isn't quite as good at the same stage as PERSON Jen-Ho Tseng, another product of GPE whom they signed in their last international spending spree in 2013 for $1.625 million. Rumors are ORGANIZATION will get as much as $1.5 million and the Cubs are the favorite, but the ORGANIZATION were also in the mix late in the process.

PERSON struck out 133 batters as a LOCATION junior to establish a single-season record, surpassing former big leaguer PERSON on the school's all-time list. The PERSON took him in the second round that June, then assigned him directly to Class A Advanced Frederick for his first full season. PERSON pitched to mixed results early before settling in during the second half, and he built upon that success during a breakout Double-A campaign in 2018. He was named PERSON's ORGANIZATION pitcher of the year and garnered similar honors in the LOCATION after he led the circuit in wins (14), strikeouts (142), and batting average against (.225), and posted the third-best ORGANIZATION (3.27).PERSON's repeatable delivery and clean arm action allow him to paint both sides of the plate with a fastball that sits at 91-94 mph and touches 95. An above-average slider in the low 80s is PERSON's best secondary pitch, and he also demonstrates feel for a changeup that's at least average. He throws each of his three pitches for strikes and is comfortable pitching inside against right-handed hitters with his fastball. While he doesn't generate many ground balls and at times is prone to the long ball, PERSON does induce a healthy number of whiffs and induces weak contact by effectively changing speeds.The PERSON changed PERSON's heel placement on the rubber back in 2017, and that adjustment has helped him stay on line to the plate and better execute his pitches. He still has gains to make both with his control and command, but all the ingredients are there for PERSON to serve as a No. 4 starter, perhaps more, if he continues down his current developmental path.

Wherever PERSON has been, either at ORGANIZATION State during his amateur days or during his climb up the ORGANIZATION' ladder, he's hit. That ability alone has allowed him to reach the highest level of the system.PERSON has been able to make consistent contact and hit for a high average at all levels. He led the ORGANIZATION system in batting average in his first full season in 2013, then hit over .290 in 2014. That continued in 2015, allowing him to earn a promotion from Double- to Triple-A. PERSON draws a lot of walks and doesn't strike out much. He has more gap power than over-the-fence pop, though there are enough flashes to indicate that he could perhaps hit 10-12 homers per season. A good defensive first baseman, his offense didn't fit the profile for the spot, and he moved to left field in 2015.  It's possible PERSON ends up as a fourth outfielder or bat off the bench who can play a corner outfield spot and fill in at first, but as the adage goes, guys that hit tend to find their way into the lineup.

The ORGANIZATION took PERSON two picks after taking PERSON in the first round of the 2013 Draft. PERSON is hopeful the batterymates will one day make their way to PERSON Yards.There's little question that PERSON will hit himself up the ladder. He has a really good feel for hitting, with an approach that helped him win the LOCATION League batting title a year ago. PERSON makes consistent contact with a smooth left-handed stroke and shows good on-base skills as well. There hasn't been a ton of power thus far, but there should be more as he matures and picks spots to turn on balls, rather than just go the other way. A well below-average runner, PERSON's defense is behind his bat, not surprising for a young player who just started catching regularly his senior year of high school. He has arm strength, but the rest of his defensive game is raw. PERSON will need to develop his skills behind the plate to profile as an everyday, offensive-minded, catcher in the big leagues. Just 20 years old, there's time for him to hone his craft.

After going undrafted out of high school, PERSON broke out during his sophomore year at ORGANIZATION. He became the ORGANIZATION ace and earned a spot on the GPE national team last summer.  PERSON primarily relies on his sinker, which sits around 90 mph with heavy life. He mixes in a slurvy slider and a changeup. He throws a lot of strikes and comes right after hitters with his fastball.  PERSON pitched out of the bullpen with the national team and could move quickly in the ORGANIZATION if he returned there. But with his feel for pitching and three offerings that have a chance to be at least average, he could develop into a Major League starter.

The first of two consecutive high school arms the ORGANIZATION took in the first round, PERSON has followed a developmental path most teams hope a prep pitcher will follow. The GPE native went to full-season ball in his first full professional year and pitched well there under a fairly tight pitch count and innings limit. In year two, the gloves came off and the right-hander earned a midseason promotion to Double-A while also pitching well in the ORGANIZATION Game.Much of PERSON' success has come as a result of his plus fastball. It will sit in the low 90s and will consistently touch the mid-90s with the pitch, thrown with good life down in the zone and improved overall command, allowing him to miss bats. His secondary stuff still needs refinement, and he struggled at times with it after moving up to Double-A, but he can spin a very good curve, has added a slider and has continued to work on developing his changeup.Continued work on his offspeed stuff will help PERSON continue to climb the ORGANIZATION' ladder, but everything is pointing in the right direction. He looks like a future big league starter, and if his non-fastball offerings improve greatly at age 21 in 2018, he could develop into more of a frontline guy.

PERSON didn't pitch in GPE's top league or any of its national teams before he defected, so he was relatively unknown in scouting circles before he started lighting up radar guns at showcases last winter. Six months later, he received a $16 million bonus, the second-largest ever for an international amateur, as the centerpiece of the ORGANIZATION' aggressive international push.PERSON has exceptional arm speed that generates mid-90s fastballs with ease, and he already reached 98 mph with more projection remaining in his 6-foot-3 frame. His secondary offerings lack consistency, though he does flash a plus slider and throws his changeup with deceptive arm speed.The biggest question with PERSON, even more so than his lack of track record, is his ability to harness his stuff. He has trouble finding the strike zone on a regular basis, which could push him toward the bullpen if he can't develop control and command. With his upside, he'll get every opportunity to make it as a starter.

Ever since PERSON began his pro career with the ORGANIZATION back in 2012, he has tantalized with his arm strength and raw stuff, though his performance hasn't always measured up. That has continued since he joined the Reds in the 2015 PERSON deal for PERSON, though he did make his big-league debut in 2017. But in 2018, most of PERSON's season was spent at Double-A before brief stints back in Triple-A and the Majors. His season ended a little early out of precaution because of a left oblique strain.PERSON has a plus fastball that is in the 91-97 mph range, but he can consistently reach for the bigger number when he needs it. He can supplement with an often better-than-average changeup and an average slider. Though he made strides in 2018 with a higher strikeout rate, he also saw his walk rate elevate and his command and control remain fringy.At the moment, PERSON seems projected for the back end of a rotation. However, his development time to returning to the big leagues longer term would be likely shortened by a move to the bullpen. Although he has the overall command issues, that wouldn't be as much of a problem were he to become a two-pitch power reliever.

PERSON played every position but pitcher and catcher early in his professional career as a result of the infield depth in the GPE organization. But when PERSON was promoted from high Class A GPE in 2013, PERSON got a chance to fill the hole in the infield. He fared better than expected as a full-time shortstop and has continued to build on that initial success.PERSON took a step forward offensively in 2014. Some adjustments he made to his swing in the last couple years have paid off, enabling him to make more consistent contact. He's an above-average runner and has begun to better incorporate his speed into his game. Defensively, PERSON has a plus arm and moves well laterally, giving him plenty of range to both sides. His defensive prowess means that he won't have to hit a ton to carve out a role in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON firmly established himself as a player to watch with three home runs at the 2013 Tournament of PERSON, one of the first big events of the summer showcase circuit. He carried that momentum through the 2014 GPE, when the ORGANIZATION made him their first-round pick. PERSON produces impressive raw power and has the feel for hitting necessary to make use of it in games. He has a patient approach at the plate and isn't afraid to work deep in the count to get a pitch he can drive. Though he primarily played first base in high school, the ORGANIZATION moved him to the outfield after the GPE. His arm is plenty strong enough for right field, and he's athletic enough to give him a chance to successfully make the transition to an outfield corner.

It's taken a while for O'Conner to get going, but it looks like this former first-round pick is now headed in the right direction.O'Conner spent three summers in short-season ball before finally graduating to a full-season level in 2013. There, he started to show some of the extra-base ability the ORGANIZATION knew he'd always possessed. O'Conner needs to continue to refine his approach, but he's much improved at tapping into his considerable raw power. Behind the plate, O'Conner has one of the best arms in the Minors, one that allows him to control an opponent's running game. He's still learning the plate, but he has the chance to be an elite defender. It all comes down to O'Conner's bat. If it continues to develop, he has the chance to be an everyday backstop at the highest level.

GPE had been injury free since college (when he dealt with shoulder problems), until 2018, when he had hamstring issues in the spring, and biceps tendinitis later in the summer. The lost innings resulted in an ORGANIZATION stint, during which GPE was arguably the best non-Whitley pitching prospect who was a lock to start. Despite the biceps issue, his velocity was fine in the fall. GPE sits 93-96 and makes heavy use of three good secondary pitches. The horizontal action on his slider only plays away from righties, but the curveball and changeup will help mitigate some of those issues, as well as the platoon issues that may arise from GPE's lower arm slot.

Though PERSON's stuff took a downturn during his junior season at FACILITY, the ORGANIZATION believed in his previous track record enough to take him in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft. He pitched well in his first two years as a pro, then struggled at the upper levels of the system in 2017. He fared better and showed crisper stuff while repeating Triple-A this season and then pitched in the ORGANIZATION before joining the ORGANIZATION in mid-November in exchange for PERSON added a couple ticks of velocity to his fastball in 2018, working at 93-95 mph and topping out at 97 with riding action. His collection of secondary pitches is headlined by a plus curveball in the low-80s that has an elite spin rate. His slider has morphed into a true cutter that he throws with sharp glove-side slicing action and a bit of sink at 88-92 mph. He needs to refine and trust his changeup more to find success against left-handers, however.PERSON has a funky delivery, but it gives him deception and doesn't prevent him from filling the strike zone. With solid stuff and strike-throwing ability, he has the ingredients to become at least a No. 4 starter. But he often gets hit harder than he should, so his long-term role may be as a multi-inning reliever.

GPE isn't big or especially toolsy, but he performed on the ORGANIZATION and put up huge numbers this spring against so-so competition, but he got faster in the interim and now may be a center fielder.
GPE has made offensive progress in a big breakout 2019 but we still think he's more likely to end up at first base due in part to his size.

Originally Drafted by the ORGANIZATION, GPE was dealt to GPE for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION in 2011. He made his Major ORGANIZATION debut the next year, and he appeared to be on his way to establishing himself in the ORGANIZATION rotation before undergoing PERSON surgery in July '12. After returning to health and the big leagues in 2014, he was a part of the package the ORGANIZATION acquired in exchange for PERSON's fastball sits around 90 mph, with good late life. His curveball is his best secondary pitch, and his slider and changeup give him two more solid offerings. All of GPE's stuff plays up, thanks to his exceptional command.GPE went through a lengthy recovery process, but pitched well in his return. His tools give him a chance to fit as a starter in the ORGANIZATION and his stuff would also play well in the bullpen.

Because he comes from a tiny town -- PERSON, GPE, which has a population of 2,600 -- and didn't pitch on the showcase circuit last summer, PERSON was relatively unknown before he impressed scouts with his velocity and projectability at ORGANIZATION's World Wood Bat Association World Championship last October. He continued to raise his profile this spring, and the ORGANIZATION grabbed him in the second round.PERSON's best pitch is a hard sinker that runs from 90-94 mph, and it could get quicker as he fills out his frame. His slider improved during his senior season and could become a plus pitch in the future. PERSON also demonstrates some feel for his changeup, though he hasn't had to use it much.PERSON is getting better at repeating his mechanics and commanding his pitches. If he continues to develop like he has in the past year, he eventually could become a front-line starter in the big leagues.

It took a $100,000 bonus to sign PERSON away from a football scholarship to GPE. PERSON raw when he entered pro ball (what with two-sports and a cold-weather background), it took PERSON three years of adjustments before he finally experienced a statistical breakout in 2016. Since then, he has continued to make mechanical tweaks to reshape his skillset, and was rewarded with a brief major league debut in 2018. 
Once in possession of ugly bat control that enabled him to put lots of balls in play but not with any real impact, PERSON's most recent swing adjustment has him trading some of that contact for power. As PERSON's leg kick grew bigger and slower, his ground ball rate shrunk. A 45% roller ratio in 2017 became 31% in 2018, and PERSON set a career-high in homers (12) in the friendly confines of the ORGANIZATION. Though he didn't perform during a 30-game big league look, PERSON's athleticism and ability to make adjustments bode well for his future. His baseball instincts aren't great, but he has some pop that he's started to get to, he can fly, and he may get lots of playing time due to the ORGANIZATION' fairly thin outfield situation. Realistically, he projects as a good bench outfielder, but he has several late-bloomer traits and may continue to develop into a low-end regular if he falls into regular big league reps and gets sufficient at-bats.

The ORGANIZATION rolled the dice in the 2015 Draft when they took PERSON in ORGANIZATION B. The ORGANIZATION A&M left-hander had dealt with thoracic outlet syndrome early in his collegiate career, and then his junior season ended after four starts when he needed PERSON surgery. It's looking like the gamble is paying off, as PERSON's power stuff allowed him to dominate out of the bullpen upon his return and reach Double-A during his first pro season.Since returning, PERSON's fastball has touched the 94-97 mph range consistently. He's backed up that heater with a very good cutter that can touch the low 90s. He now has a distinct slider that gives him a third viable option. PERSON goes right after hitters, misses a lot of bats and doesn't hurt himself with ORGANIZATION key for PERSON is to stay healthy. If his injury woes are in the past, he has the ability to be a very effective left-handed setup man at the big league level.

PERSON became eligible to turn pro as a 16-year-old in 2008, but no one signed him out of GPE before the ORGANIZATION offered him a $7,500 bonus at the relatively advanced age of 20, four years later. Though he didn't make his pro debut until 2013, or reach full-season ball until this year, his fastball has already caught the attention of scouts.PERSON throws harder than most left-handers, dealing at 92-94 mph, and popping 97 mph on occasion. The tradeoff is that his velocity comes from a max-effort delivery, which doesn't bode well for his command or future health.PERSON's slider lacks consistency but has its moments, arriving in the low 80s, with some sharp bite at its best. He hasn't demonstrated much aptitude for a changeup. Although PERSON is currently using PERSON as a starter to get him innings and experience, his future likely will be as a reliever.

GPE turned down close to a million dollars out of high school from the ORGANIZATION, then dominated out of the pen and now in the rotation for GPE; the delivery isn't pretty but the results are and the stuff is above average to plus.

It can take the raw, toolsy athletes a little bit longer to develop at times, but PERSON could look back at the 2013 season as the year where it really started coming together.Tall and athletic, PERSON looks the part of a toolsy center fielder and now needs to build on his first extended success. He's started to learn to tap into his raw power, pulling the ball with authority instead of being satisfied with going up the middle and the other way. There's still some length and swing and miss to PERSON's game, but if he can continue to punish mistakes on the inner half, he could be dangerous. With enough speed to steal some bases, PERSON has the tools to stay in center, but he could handle a corner if needed.Patience can be a virtue with athletic players like PERSON, and the ORGANIZATION could soon be rewarded as a result.

When a GPE teenager comes and makes his GPE debut, the organization hopes he can just adjust and hold his own. PERSON went out and won the ORGANIZATION League batting title while ripping off a 29-game hitting streak.With an easy left-handed swing, PERSON has a knack for making consistent solid contact. He doesn't strike out much, nor does he draw many walks. There's more power to come as PERSON continues to mature. He's played all over the outfield and has the speed to stay in center field for now. Should PERSON outgrow the position, he has more than enough arm to play right field and could profile well there when all is said and done.PERSON will play all of the 2014 season at age 20, giving full-season ball a try for the first time.

PERSON has been well traveled since the FACILITY drafted him in the second round in 2009. First, he was sent to the D-backs in the ORGANIZATION trade at the 2010 PERSON. He worked his way from rookie ball to the ORGANIZATION with PERSON, making his big league debut in August 2013. That winter, he was dealt again, this time to the ORGANIZATION as a part of a three-team trade. PERSON has the chance to have four average or better pitches with good command of all of them. He works quickly and goes right after hitters, working both sides of the strike zone with his solid average sinking fastball. His fading changeup is an above-average offering and he throws both a tight biting curve and short, cutting slider. With good mechanics and size, he should be ready for the middle of the rotation very soon.

PERSON grew 10 inches and added about 12 mph to his fastball during his ORGANIZATION high school career, attracting pro interest but sliding to the 30th round of the 2010 Draft because he couldn't be coaxed from attending college at ORGANIZATION. A ninth-round choice by the ORGANIZATION after three years with the ORGANIZATION, PERSON plateaued as a starter when he got to high Class A but began to move rapidly after shifting to the bullpen in July 2016. He ranked second among the system's full-season relievers with a 2.20 ERA in 2017 and was similarly effective in the ORGANIZATION League.PERSON's feel for pitching stands out more than any of his individual offerings. He has picked up some velocity working shorter stints, and his fastball now operates at 91-93 mph and tops out at 95. It features plenty of run and sink, helping him log a 2.33 groundout/airout ratio last season and a 2.06 mark in his first five pro seasons.When working out of the rotation, PERSON had difficulty maintaining a consistent arm slot. He's doing a better job of keeping his delivery in sync while coming out of the bullpen, which has helped his slider improve. He has an effective changeup that helps him combat right-handers, though with three average pitches he's likely destined for middle relief.

PERSON was a standout at high school power ORGANIZATION, originally taken by the ORGANIZATION in the eighth round of the 2013 Draft. He'd hit at pretty much every stop in GPE's chain, reaching Double-A in 2017, then was sent to the ORGANIZATION in January 2018 as one of four players in return for another ORGANIZATION alum, GPE. PERSON excelled in Double-A for the first half of his first season with PERSON, then struggled after getting bumped up to Triple-A, earning a spot on the 40-man roster in the process.More than anything, PERSON tried to do too much when he got moved to the ORGANIZATION' highest level. His swing got out of sync and he was often too quick, resulting in rolling over from being out in front too often. There is some power in the bat, power he has unlocked throughout his pro career, but it often can be his own worst enemy, as he can get pull-happy and ends up out in front. PERSON does run well enough to steal some bases, though not so efficiently, and his speed gives him range to play center, though his below-average arm might be better suited to left field if he's a regular.While PERSON has improved somewhat against left-handed pitching, most of his power comes against righties. He fits more of a fourth outfielder or platoon role, though if he shows he can adjust to Triple-A, he could prove he's more of a regular.

GPE was the ORGANIZATION. 1 starter on PERSON's 2013 College World Series team, ahead of third-rounders PERSON (GPE) and PERSON (ORGANIZATION). He surprisingly lasted until the 11th round that June but shook that off to turn in a fine season as a starter in low Class A in 2014.There's little question that GPE's fastball is his best pitch. He works at 90-94 mph with some occasional life and uses his height to deliver it on a steep downhill plane. He does have a sturdy frame built for starting and has no difficulty filling the strike zone.Nevertheless, GPE may be destined for the bullpen. Both his slider and changeup are below-average offerings, and he leaves them up in the strike zone too often.

Most teams didn't evaluate PERSON as a first-round talent in the 2013 Draft, but the ORGANIZATION loved his bat, so they drafted him 25th overall and paid him a $1,866,500 bonus. He has justified their faith, winning the Rookie-level PERSON MVP award in his pro debut and finishing second in the short-season LOCATION in hitting (.333) in 2014. Last year he skipped a level to high Class A and batted .304 at age 20.PERSON is an extremely advanced hitter for his age, with outstanding hand-eye coordination that allows him to barrel balls repeatedly. He almost does so too easily, making so much hard contact that it cuts into his walk totals. Being more selective also would help his power totals, as he has the bat speed to produce 15 homers per season if he waits for pitches he can drive.PERSON has sure hands and solid arm strength at shortstop, but his fringy speed and range likely will lead to a position change down the line. PERSON thinks he's an underrated defender but also has PERSON at shortstop and PERSON at second base in the big leagues. PERSON might profile best at third base and also could wind up on an outfield corner.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON right-handed pitcher PERSON has made 11 All-Tournament Teams since 2014, is labeled as a top 100 prospect and has been included on two Showcase Top Prospect Lists. PERSON participated in the 2015 ORGANIZATION and the 2016 ORGANIZATION, and earned a 2015 ORGANIZATION and was honored with a slot on the 2016 ORGANIZATION Team.The right-handed pitcher has good size and arm strength with a feel for his secondary pitches. His fastball hovers around 90-92 mph and his curveball sits at 76-77.

PERSON excelled as GPE's closer for two seasons and set the school's single-season record with 19 saves as a junior. But scouts worried about his lack of a quality breaking ball and he slid to the 13th round in the 2012 Draft. So far, PERSON has made those fears appear unfounded. He made quick work of the GPE League and earned a promotion to Double-A Arkansas in his first full professional season. PERSON throws his fastball in the low-90s and occasionally reaches back for a little extra velocity. His main weapon is his changeup, which is a plus offering. PERSON commands both of his pitches well and isn't afraid to challenge hitters. The ORGANIZATION have used him as a closer in the ORGANIZATION, but he profiles better as a set-up man in the ORGANIZATION.

In terms of electric stuff and arm strength, PERSON has to sit near the top of most Draft boards. Some concerns about his delivery and his secondary stuff, might temper his stock somewhat.There is no question about PERSON's fastball. Delivered with a quick arm, PERSON can crank it up to 96-97 mph. At ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION, the right-hander had the top average fastball velocity according to GPE, at 94.4 mph. He does show good feel to spin a breaking ball, but it tends to be too slurvy. PERSON will call it a curveball, but it often has more of a slider shape to it, and he can't always land it for strikes. He actually has a feel for a changeup, but he doesn't often use it.PERSON is a high energy pitcher with a ton of personality on the mound, one who will quick pitch or feature a PERSON Cueto-like shimmy in his delivery. There is some effort there as well, leading some to wonder if he profiles as a reliever. There is some projectability in his body, he should add strength, and he's a better athlete than one might think at first glance. A team taking him early and signing him away from his LOCATION commitment will give him every chance to start.Prospect ORGANIZATION - PERSON, GPE.

A standout during the 2013 showcase circuit, PERSON garnered ORGANIZATION honors at the 2013 Perfect Game All-America Classic before starring for the 18U GPE national team in the World Cup in GPE. The ORGANIZATION drafted him in the fourth round the following year, making PERSON the first Nebraskan prep to be picked in the top five rounds since 1996. After having his first full pro season marred by injury, PERSON moved up to Class A Hagerstown in '16 and flashed his potential on both sides of the ball. While hasn't built on that performance as hoped this season, GPE was pleased enough with PERSON's progress that they promoted him to the ORGANIZATION in July. A right-handed hitter, PERSON has a quick swing that yields line drives across the whole field. The ORGANIZATION worked with PERSON to improve his lower-half setup during the season, and it resulted in harder contact and better pitch recognition as the season unfolded. He's physically strong and has average power potential, though it may be a few years before he learns how to get to it in games. Even if the power never arrives, PERSON's plate discipline and approach give him the chance to be a quality hitter.PERSON is a good athlete with a solid set of tools that could help him stick behind the plate, and the ORGANIZATION have been pleased with his progress as a receiver and game-caller. Though still quite raw, he has solid-to-average arm strength and promising catch-and-throw skills.

A 16th-round Draft pick in 2011, PERSON etched his name in GPE postseason lore with his performance in Game 5 of the ORGANIZATION Championship Series against the ORGANIZATION. Called on to make a spot start, the left-hander tossed 4 1/3 scoreless innings, allowing just two hits and retiring 12 of the 14 hitters he faced, to propel the Tribe to a 3-0 victory and its sixth ORGANIZATION pennant.What PERSON lacks in stuff he makes up for with pitchability and excellent command. The left-hander adds and subtracts from his upper-80s fastball and complements it with an above-average changeup. He knows how to use his curveball effectively while also mixing in a below-average slider simply to keep hitters guessing and off balance. Everything he throws plays up thanks to his plus control, as he entered the 2017 season having issued just 108 walks in 684 1/3 professional innings (1.4 BB/9).After his impressive showing in the postseason, PERSON has already been up and down with the GPE several times this season. His lack of premium stuff and perennially low strikeout rate limits his upside, but he has all the tools to serve as a fifth starter or swingman in the big leagues.

The fact PERSON was called up to the big leagues to help out for a brief spell in 2014 may have been a bit surprising. After claiming LOCATION pitcher of the year honors as a sophomore and continuing to pitch well in the ORGANIZATION and during fall practice, ORGANIZATION entered 2017 as a potential second-rounder. GPE spent his freshman year as PERSON's starting shortstop before moving to catcher as a sophomore in 2016. Built like an old school in-the-box ORGANIZATION safety, GPE is a physical dynamo whose entire offensive profile is undercut by his extreme propensity to hit the ball into the ground. PERSON's exciting GPE debut in 2013, followed by his ability to hold his own in the LOCATION League in 2014, has the organization excited about his potential to become an everyday shortstop, even if it's way off in the future.Signed in 2011, PERSON performed very well in the short-season PERSON in '13. Scouts were flocking to PERSON this spring to check in on PERSON, who has as much arm strength as any pitcher in the GPE class.The big, strong right-hander has an easily plus heater, one that sits comfortably in the mid-90s and he's shown the ability to crank it up to triple-digits this spring. PERSON was the FACILITY's first draft choice in 2011 in the supplemental first round â they didn't have a first-round choice due to the free agent signing of PERSON â and PERSON literally hit the ground running during his first full season, leading the organization with 56 steals while playing across two levels. GPE has been hurt a lot throughout his career but has been healthy for the last two seasons. He sits in the low-90s and has a plus changeup.

PERSON's amateur career didn't exactly go on a straight path, starting at ORGANIZATION, going to PERSON and then on to GPE for his junior year in 2018. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, PERSON, who is also a center on PERSON's (Ariz.) basketball team, has committed to play baseball at the ORGANIZATION of LOCATION. Texas-Brownsville shuttered their baseball program before PERSON was able to take the field for them, and he ended up transferring to PERSON. ORGANIZATION PERSON has been a must-stop for this year's PERSON season for a number of reasons. He's making strides with his changeup though it still ranks as his fourth-best pitch.PERSON's downturn came when his delivery became too violent, causing him to fall off toward first base and lose any semblance of command. A young PERSON -- big, athletic, wiry and full of potential -- is PERSON's best comp at the same age. GPE began his professional career with the ORGANIZATION as a catcher, with the GPE, Fla., native spending his first two summers of pro ball at rookie levels behind the plate after being a 12th-round Draft pick in 2013. PERSON graduated a semester early from PERSON (Fla.) and enrolled at GSP in 2012, bypassing the GPE in the process. PERSON ORGANIZATION has five Draft-eligible pitchers who can reach the mid-90s with their fastballs. GPE, power projection corner outfielder that has just okay feel to hit currently but it also young for the class.
