His combination of stuff, pitchability and aggressiveness on the mound point to a future as a frontline starter.

If you wanted to build a prototype of what a big, strong, projectable pitching prospect should look like, starting with PERSON might not be a bad idea. The ORGANIZATION had aggressively stockpiled young arms via the Draft in recent years. Some of them were used as trading chips, but PERSON remains, and for good reason. His pure stuff is outstanding, with a plus fastball and an outstanding curve to give him as good a one-two punch as any pitching prospect. His changeup projects to be at least an average offering. He throws downhill and there's room for him to add some strength. PERSON needs to cut down on his walk rate to succeed as he moves up, but he has all the makings of a frontline starter if that happens as the ORGANIZATION start to take the kid gloves off.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

The son of former ORGANIZATION defensive lineman PERSON, PERSON also has a football build that has prompted physical comparisons to seven-time All-Star PERSON. He opened last summer as the consensus top high school pitching prospect before getting passed by fellow GPE product PERSON. PERSON has passed them both among PERSON prepsters this spring, and while PERSON won't be the first prep arm selected, he still could fit somewhere in the back half of the first round.PERSON usually pitches at 92-96 mph with his fastball and can reach 98, showing hard sink on occasion and generally commanding it well. There are times when his heater gets hit harder than expected, usually when it straightens out and he leaves it up in the zone. His shoulder opens early at times, giving batters a good look at his fastball, but he's athletic enough to adjust his delivery and hide the ball better.PERSON generates power with a quick arm and little effort, something that's also evident when he snaps off a wipeout slider in the mid-80s. It needs more consistency, as does a changeup that should become at least average, but he has all the makings of a quality three-pitch repertoire. He's part of a loaded ORGANIZATION recruiting class that also includes PERSON.

It appears PERSON is all the way back after undergoing PERSON surgery in August 2011. He proved his health this spring as PERSON's Friday starter, pitching well enough to convince the ORGANIZATION to select him with the 31st overall pick. PERSON has a lively fastball that he'll throw up to 95 mph and command well, working quickly and getting many ground-ball outs. His secondary stuff -- a slider and a changeup -- isn't quite as good as his fastball, though both have the chance to develop into consistently PERSON average offerings. The ORGANIZATION have moved top college starters (such as PERSON and PERSON) quickly in the past and with his three-pitch mix and some decent pitchabilitiy, PERSON could find himself on a similarly aggressive track toward the ORGANIZATION.

The PERSON made PERSON their eighth-round pick in June 2015, and then gave him $400,000 to forgo his commitment to PERSON A&M. PERSON's dominance as an amateur carried over to his professional debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, and he built on that performance last year during his full-season debut in 2016. The ORGANIZATION acquired the right-hander from PERSON on June 30 -- while in the midst of a stretch that saw him toss three straight hitless outings of five innings --- only to have to shut him down with a forearm strain that required PERSON surgery in August.When healthy, PERSON has an impressive combination of stuff and feel. An uptick in velocity in 2015 pushed his fastball into the 92-94 mph range in his pro debut, and he's adept at locating it to both sides of the plate. PERSON's changeup is a double-plus pitch and easily his best secondary offering, thrown with convincing arm action and outstanding tumble. He also made strides with his breaking ball in 2016, throwing it with greater depth and sharper bite, giving him a promising arsenal of three average-or-better pitches. The right-hander uses his height to create good plane toward the plate, and it's only going to improve as he adds strength and gains better control of his core.PERSON still has room to grow into his highly projectable frame, and some evaluators believe his fastball will sit in the mid 90s once he's fully developed. He will need to refine his command and develop an effective breaking ball, but he shows the early makings of a potential No. 3 or 4 starter.

PERSON took a huge step forward last spring, first by adding strength to his already physical frame, and then with a breakout sophomore campaign during which he went 12-1 and posted a 1.22 ORGANIZATION in 13 starts with 117 strikeouts in 103 innings, ranking among the national junior college leaders in wins, ORGANIZATION and whiffs. Viewed by scouts as the top junior college prospect in the 2016 Draft, PERSON became the second-highest drafted player in GPE A. Logan (Ill.) CC history when the ORGANIZATION selected him in the second round.A big, physical right-hander with a three-quarters delivery, PERSON pitches at 91-94 mph with his fastball but can reach back for more, all the while using his size to create good angle to the plate. His slider has gotten harder and sharper, showing flashes of becoming an above-average pitch, and he'll also mix in a curveball and changeup, though neither pitch is particularly advanced.PERSON was a solid strike-thrower in college but has had trouble pounding the zone consistently since entering the professional ranks. He possesses the requisite size and durability but will need to improve the command of his fastball, as well as the consistency of his secondary pitches, to make it as a big league starter. If he can't, he has promise as a late-inning reliever.

The 2013 Draft class had some depth in terms of high school left-handers and it was PERSON, the southpaw out of GPE, who was the second from that crop to be taken in the first round. While he's not the biggest guy in the world, leading some to wonder about his durability, few have questions about his stuff. He can crank his fastball up to 95 mph and his hard breaking ball gives him a second potentially plus pitch. He has a feel for his changeup, though he didn't use it much in high school, and he gets high marks for his poise and pitchability. As a high schooler from the LOCATION, it might be easy to think it could take PERSON a bit longer to get to the highest level, but it shouldn't' surprise anyone if he shortens the learning curve.

PERSON pitched to a 1.37 ERA over 21 appearances out of GPE's bullpen as a true freshman and was off to a strong start in 2016 before undergoing PERSON surgery. After making a healthy return and turning another strong relief campaign as a redshirt sophomore, PERSON was moved into the ORGANIZATION' rotation in 2018 and excelled in the new role, going 7-3 with a 2.19 ERA in 16 starts en route to GPE Athletic Conference pitcher of the year honors. The ORGANIZATION took him in the 14th round that June and used him as a swingman in his pro debut before shifting PERSON back to a full-time bullpen role for his first full season. It proved a wise decision, as he quickly climbed three levels, reaching the Double-A ORGANIZATION in mid-July before he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in return for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.PERSON is capable of bumping 94-95 mph with his fastball but usually sits more in the low-90s, with the pitch playing on account of some funk in his delivery and because he hides the ball well on the backside. His slider is his lone above-average secondary pitch and makes him lethal on same-sided hitters, but he also has a good changeup that he uses to neutralize righties. He can throw strikes and miss bats with all three pitches, and hitters generally have trouble squaring him up. PERSON has been particularly effective against left-handed hitters early in his career thanks to his combination of stuff and deception, but he also shown that he can get outs on both sides of the plate while consistently inducing weak contact. Those traits suggest that he could be more than simply a situational left-hander out of the 'pen, although a ORGANIZATION role likely represents his clearest path to the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON parlayed a strong career as a starter at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, including a championship in his sophomore year, into becoming a second round pick in the 2016 Draft. Thought to be a quick-to-the-big leagues college performer, things didn't go quite as planned, though he did lead the ORGANIZATION in groundout-to-airout ratio and had the best ground ball ratio of any pitcher in baseball, including the big leagues.PERSON has plenty of fastball, typically in the low-90s, but it plays up move because of his plus plus sink and his ability to get outs early in counts as a result. He does have usable secondary weapons and understands how to pitch soft, but doesn't always use it effectively. His slider is ahead of his curve, and he has good feel for a changeup, but trusting all of it has been an issue. He's smoothed out his delivery somewhat since his college days, but is still working to repeat it consistently. That's led to more control issues than anticipated, with a 3.9 BB/9 rate in his first full season.With the potential to have a usable three or four-pitch mix, PERSON still has the chance to be a back-end starter. If it doesn't come together, his sinker-slider combination could look awfully good coming out of the bullpen.

Pitchers out of small schools taken in the 16th round of a Draft aren't typically expected to do much, and they're certainly not thought to be quick movers through a system. PERSON had an up-and-down final season at ORGANIZATION II Cal Poly and showed fringy stuff during his summer debut. But he took a big leap forward in his first full season in 2018 and shot all the way to Double-A.PERSON will flash three plus pitches at times, with his fastball, breaking ball and changeup. While he was 87-90 mph during his first summer, he's been 93-95 mph from the left side consistently out of the bullpen in 2018. Most will call his breaking ball a slider, though some see it as a hard curve, thrown in the mid-80s, that can miss bats. His changeup can also be an out pitch for him.With three quality offerings, it might be thought PERSON could start, but a lack of command, particularly with his fastball, to go along with an uptempo, aggressive delivery, make a relief role perfect for him. If he can find the strike zone a bit more consistently, he'll be ready to help out a big league bullpen fairly soon.

PERSON, a native of GPE, was one of the top amateur free agents to sign out of GPE in 2013. He had been a prominent player for a few years and was named to the all-tournament team at the 2011 16U World Championship, when he led GPE with a .414 batting average and .690 slugging percentage.  PERSON doesn't have any one tool that stands out but earns praise for his all-around play. A switch-hitter, he hits well from both sides of the plate and exhibits a good feel for the barrel. His swing is more geared for hitting line drives, but he does have some power.  PERSON was signed as a shortstop, but he also played third base during his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. The Indians still see him as a shortstop, where he has solid range and an average arm.

The ORGANIZATION paid seven-figure bonuses to three high school arms in the middle rounds of the 2014 Draft, including $1 million for PERSON in the fifth round. The earliest Mississippi prep pitcher drafted since PERSON (ORGANIZATION, second round) in 1999, he didn't reach full-season ball until his third year as a pro and struggled with his mechanics when he got there in 2016. He has cleaned up his delivery and looked much better while making the jump to high Class A at age 21 in 2017.PERSON's best pitch is his fastball, which resides at 91-92 mph, tops out at 95 and creates groundouts thanks to its sink and run. He's gaining more consistency with his curveball, which has good depth and misses bats when at its best. His fading changeup has its moments as well.PERSON is beginning to make the transition from thrower to pitcher. He still needs to improve his control and command but he's making progress in both areas. He's not very physical but he's athletic, giving hope that he eventually can develop into a No. 3 or 4 starter.

Signed for just over $2 million late during the summer of 2016, BolaÃ±os is a pretty standard fifth starter/middle relief prospect. His changeup and command both need to improve if he's going to be a clean rotation fit, but if they don't, his fastball (which lives 91-95 as a starter, but would hopefully tick up out of the bullpen) and slurvy breaking ball are typical of solid middle relievers. He's repeating Hi-A and will likely be developed as a starter for a while yet, at least until he's closer to when he needs to be added to the 40-man, two Novembers from now.

Though GPE (GPE) PERSON has sent more than two dozen players to college programs, it never has had a player drafted before the 20th round. That should change in 2018, as the ORGANIZATION have a pair of potential first-rounders in GPE and right-hander PERSON. GPE is one of the better all-around hitters in the prep class and doesn't have a glaring weakness.GPE has a quick right-handed stroke and has a track record of catching up to and punishing quality fastballs on the showcase circuit. With his strength, balance and mature approach, he makes consistent hard line-drive contact. Once he fills out his rangy 6-foot-4 frame and adds some loft to his swing, he could have plus power.An average runner out of the batter's box and quicker once he gets going, GPE is athletic for his size but won't stay at shortstop after he leaves GPE. His solid arm will play anywhere in the infield, where he probably fits best at third base but may have a chance to stick up the middle at second, and he has the makeup to get the most out of his ability. If he attends college, he'll reunite with his brother PERSON at ORGANIZATION.

The ORGANIZATION have produced some very good relievers in recent years and PERSON appears to be the next in line. After two years throwing in lower-profile roles, the right-hander took over the closer's role in 2016 and ran with it.PERSON is similar to former GPE reliever PERSON in terms of his loose, wiry body and quick arm, though some scouts feel PERSON's delivery is better than that of GPE, who ended up a fifth-round pick of the Twins in 2014. He throws his fastball in the 93-94 mph range. He complements the fastball with a frisbee slider, one that does have some depth and bite to it at times. He pounds the strike zone and pitches with good tempo.PERSON's stuff is a little short for him to continue closing games, even if he reached double-digits in saves this season with GPE. His ceiling is that of a setup man at the highest level, with the potential to be a middle reliever a distinct possibility.

The best prospect in baseball, PERSON hit a superhuman .381/.437/.636 across 95 games (mostly at ORGANIZATION and Triple-A) despite being about six years younger than the other athletes in the LOCATION and ORGANIZATION. The ball doesn't just sound different off of his bat; when he really lays into one, you can feel a thump inside your chest as if someone set off a firework at home plate. Itâs explosive, beautiful, and paradoxically violent considering that PERSON is so childlike in his shape and demeanor. He plays with a vivacious enthusiasm, totally unashamed of his own at times bizarre mannerisms, as if the way he feels when playing elite pro baseball is how most of us did with a wiffle ball in our hands during adolescence. (ORGANIZATION during ORGANIZATION, he was cranky and petulant with umpires.) 
But his is not a childlike stature. His listed 6-foot-1, 200 pounds is a farce, and on the few occasions that PERSON and PERSON (who is listed at 6-foot-3, 245) were standing near one another during ORGANIZATION, PERSON was clearly the larger human being. While he reaches an almost shocking top speed on the bases given his size, PERSON does have lateral mobility issues that impact his range at third base. He is very likely to move to first base or DH at some point in his early 20s, but leaving him at third, even if he's not very good there, might help motivate him to keep his weight in check for as long as possible, something that could be more important than the quality of his play in the field since PERSON had knee issues during the 2018 season. 
PERSON though, it matters very little where he ends up playing. This is the best hitter in the minors and the stick will play anywhere. For at least two years now people around baseball, including the late Mel Didier, swore that PERSON would be ready for and competing in the majors before he turned 20. PERSON's desire to maintain control of his talent for as long as possible scuttled that notion late last summer when they chose not to promote him, and PERSON will turn 20 in March before this season even starts. He should be up early this year, and immediately become one of the game's most exciting, productive hitters. He is the cornerstone of the ORGANIZATION franchise, and perhaps a cornerstone of our sport.

The ORGANIZATION blew past their international signing pool in 2014 with headline prospect SS PERSON getting the bulk of their pool ($2.95 million bonus) and some called Rondon the top prospect in the class, while the ORGANIZATION insisted that PERSON ($400,000 bonus) was much closer in talent than their bonuses and reputation would indicate. Today, PERSON is the clearly superior prospect and one of the top five in his singing class due to his quick-developing plus raw power and advanced feel to get to his power in games without excessive swing and miss. He's also deceptively quick and instinctive in the outfield, with a nonzero chance of playing center field at the upper levels, but likely settling in as an above average right fielder.

In his first two years of college, PERSON had more success in summer ball than he did at PERSON. He redshirted in his first season with the ORGANIZATION and played sparingly in 2015, but he earned all-star honors in the ORGANIZATION and PERSON leagues. He led the Cape with 15.6 plate appearances per strikeout and finished eighth in the batting race at .315 last summer, and he has recorded similar numbers as PERSON's everyday third baseman this spring.PERSON has good feel for hitting and rarely swings and misses. The downside is that he makes contact so easily that he draws few walks, so his batting average will be more impressive than his on-base percentage. While he homered just once in 34 games with wood bats on the Cape last year, leading to some concerns about his power, he has driven the ball consistently as a redshirt sophomore.PERSON has below-average speed but has worked hard on his conditioning and his quickness at third base. He's a decent defender with good hands and an average arm, though he could be in trouble if he doesn't have the pop to profile at the hot corner. He doesn't have the tools for second base and the offensive demands would be even greater in left field.

This is a very physical teenager with some of the best present raw power in his signing class and a good chance to play a premium defensive position at catcher. PERSON has a strong, physically mature build that inspires PERSON comparisons. He has excellent lateral mobility despite his size, and his receiving was alright, but not great, when he caught pro-quality stuff at showcases. 
He checks all the other beloved catcher skillset boxes: PERSON is poised and engaged with his pitchers, he has a great arm, he looks built to meet the position's physical demands, and makes an attempt to frame pitches when he can. There's a chance he outgrows the position but he's deceptively athletic for his size, and we'd call it unlikely. There's not as much room for power projection here as there is for most others this age, but there's enough to profile at catcher. PERSON's approach is geared for well-timed, pull-side gap contact. He's a potential regular who'll likely spend his first pro season in GPE, as he's too physical for the ORGANIZATION.

A third baseman at the start of his college career at FACILITY, GPE moved behind the plate after a strong freshman season. The ORGANIZATION, with a strong track record of finding college talent in the later rounds, nabbed GPE in the seventh round of the 2016 Draft, and he promptly double-jumped from A ball to Double-A over the course of his first full season. He then capped things off with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION League.In his short time as a pro, GPE has shown a knack for barreling up the baseball, making consistent hard contact to all fields. An aggressive hitter from the right side of the plate, he doesn't walk much, but he also doesn't strike out. His power will be the last tool to come for him, but he's already showing some over-the-fence pop. While his arm strength is solid average, it plays up because he's accurate, and he threw out 45 percent of would-be basestealers in 2017. He has solid average hands and he's continuing to learn the nuances of game-calling.GPE didn't disappoint in handling the challenge of the double-jump to Double-A while still learning his craft as a backstop, seriously upgrading his prospect profile. The ORGANIZATION have a good problem on their hands with two potential big league regulars in GPE and PERSON at the top of the system.

GPE of the ORGANIZATION Dempster trade with the ORGANIZATION in mid-2012, PERSON excelled in his first full season in the ORGANIZATION organization. He led the Double-A LOCATION with 41 doubles, 62 extra-base hits and 230 total bases, helping his cause in a crowded GPE third-base picture. But he has regressed in 2014, struggling in his first Triple-A exposure and not performing much better after returning to Double-A.PERSON never has exhibited the smoothest swing or a lot of patience at the plate, but he always made plenty of hard contact in the past. That has happened less frequently this year as he has gotten himself out too frequently by chasing pitches out of the strike zone. The best-case scenario for him is that he could be a .250 hitter with 18-20 homers per season in the big leagues.A potential ORGANIZATION, PERSON exhibits outstanding body control at third base. His hands, arm and footwork are also assets. But his defense won't matter if he can't perform better at the plate, and even if he does, he won't dislodge PERSON as the ORGANIZATION' third baseman of the future.
GPE's velo was on the rise just before the draft, averaging just over 90 for the first time in his career, but in the postseason was back to 87-91 when he had to rely more on finesse.

The ORGANIZATION forfeited their 2015 first-round pick to sign free agent PERSON and sent their supplemental first-rounder to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade. When PERSON made its first choice at ORGANIZATION. 51 overall, it was thrilled to find that PERSON was still available. He's a part of the same ORGANIZATION Community High (PERSON, Fla.) program that produced 2014 ORGANIZATION first-rounder PERSON, who's now with the Nationals.Signed for $1.2 million, PERSON had some of the easiest velocity among high school pitchers in the 2015 Draft. He usually deals at 90-92 mph and tops out at 96 while expending little more effort than if he were just playing catch. Once he adds strength to his 6-foot-4 frame, he could have a consistent mid-90s fastball.PERSON's secondary pitches need more consistency yet show promise. His curveball has power and depth and his changeup features fade and deception. His delivery and athleticism bode well for his ability to fill the strike zone.

The ORGANIZATION signed the identical PERSON twins for $450,000 each out of GPE in 2012 and traded them four years later, shipping infielder PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in a July deal for PERSON and PERSON to the FACILITY as part of the ORGANIZATION blockbuster in December. Overshadowed in the ORGANIZATION trade package by PERSON and PERSON, PERSON has considerable upside of his own as a switch-hitting center fielder with five-tool potential. An injury to his left knee hampered him in his first season with his new organization and led to surgery to repair a torn meniscus, but he has impressed once healthy again in 2018 and homered off a 102-mph fastball from the ORGANIZATION' PERSON in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON Game.PERSON is still very much a work in progress offensively because his stroke gets long and he's still learning to recognize pitches and control the strike zone. He has impressive bat speed and strength in his hands and wrists, and GPE hopes to unlock his raw power by getting him to take a more direct path to the ball. With his plus speed and basestealing acumen, he could be a 20-20 player if he improves as a hitter.PERSON has the tools to play anywhere in the outfield. PERSON briefly pushed him to right field when they were teammates at short-season PERSON in GPE's system, but he otherwise has been a center fielder. He has solid range and a plus arm in center.

An effective three-year college starting pitcher at GPE taken in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft, PERSON found his home in the ORGANIZATION system as a reliever and racked up 64 saves in his first three years. But in 2018 at ORGANIZATION, he was employed mainly in a set-up role, pitching well enough to earn a spot on the 40-man roster.PERSON has an often deceptive three-quarters delivery that enables him to hide the ball well. Able to throw up to 97 mph, he can also keep hitters guessing by changing arm angles and tempo or shortening his stride. Unless he develops his below-average and seldom-used changeup, he could have time managing left-handed hitters in the big leagues. He could temper that with by burying a backdoor slider in on lefties.While he certainly has the mentality to be a big-league closer with a delivery not unlike PERSON or PERSON, his stuff projects as a likely better fit as a middle reliever or right-handed matchup specialist. PERSON doesn't walk a lot of batters nor he is victimized much by the long ball, and he is capable of racking up strikeouts.

A two-sport star in high school, PERSON kind of got lost amid the many talented prep arms in the 2018 class, but he was in the second tier, wire-to-wire, for the clubs that emphasize athleticism and projection. He pitches in the low 90's with an average-ish fastball, a slider that flashes above-average, and a repeatable delivery that can produce above-average command. This is a prototypical high school projection arm: size, arm strength, some spin, and premium athleticism. PERSON has now take a multi-sport athlete with each of their last two second round picks. Elevating PERSON above other prep arms in the system is his more consistent velocity, health and physical and technicaly projection.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the fourth round in 2011 Draft out of PERSON (Fla.) CC, only to see him spend his first three seasons in GPE ball before having a breakout full-season debut in '14. The ORGANIZATION acquired him in May 2015 in exchange for two international bonus slots, and PERSON continued to impress in his first season in the system, reaching Double-A for the first time, and he was added to the 40-man roster following the year. His 2016 campaign was marred by a left shoulder injury that kept him from taking the mound until late in the offseason. PERSON healthy in 2017, PERSON scuffled in the first half while pitching in Triple-A PERSON's starting rotation.   An athletic southpaw, PERSON pitches at 89-93 mph with his fastball but can reach back for a few extra ticks, throwing the pitch down in the zone with late life and running action so as to induce ground-ball outs. His hard, sweeping slider is above average, flashing plus at times, and it's a major weapon against left-handed hitters. PERSON's changeup lags behind the two offerings, which has caused problems against right-handed hitters throughout his career and limits his ability to turn over a lineup.  PERSON has cleaned up his mechanics since joining the ORGANIZATION and it's allowed him to repeat his delivery more consistently. His control remains below average, though, and he'll need to develop a more effective changeup to remain a starter. If that doesn't work out, PERSON's fastball-slider pairing and strong track record against lefties could help him carve out a bullpen role as soon as 2017.

UC PERSON had a pair of pitchers from its staff get drafted in the top five rounds in 2015, with PERSON going No. 4 overall and PERSON landing in the fifth. While you typically "Never Say Never" in the GPE, it's unlikely PERSON will land in GPE territory, but the three-year starter should hear his name called before PERSON did.Right now, PERSON is the epitome of the advanced, yet not exciting, college arm. A Sunday starter a year ago, the right-hander has served as ORGANIZATION's Friday night guy after a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION last summer. He doesn't have a true out pitch, using three average offerings effectively. He generally pitches around 90-91 mph, but there could be some more velocity to unlock at the next level. He mixes in a solid slider and changeup and pounds the strike zone with all three pitches.A lack of a true out pitch limits PERSON's ceiling, but his polish and track record will interest many teams. The fact he could move quickly and teams won't have to "PERSON" him should also work in his favor.

PERSON hit .413 at ORGANIZATION's River (Fla.) CC as a sophomore in 2015 and impressed the ORGANIZATION in a pre-Draft workout, so they took him in the 12th round and signed him for $100,000. After a mediocre pro debut, he spent the first six weeks of 2016 in extended spring training but went on to win the ORGANIZATION League batting title with a .358 average. He has continued to hit in 2017, challenging for the batting lead in the high Class A ORGANIZATION League.A right-handed hitter, PERSON utilizes an extreme opposite-field approach and has a knack for placing balls where fielders can't get them. He has turned on a few more pitches this year but is still specializing in serving line drives to right field. The tradeoff is that he doesn't produce much power, so much of his offensive value comes from his ability to control the strike zone, make contact and get on base.PERSON's best pure tool is his well-above-average speed, which he's doing a better job of translating into stolen bases. He's a legitimate center fielder with enough range and arm strength to play anywhere in the outfield.

A two-way player at LOCATION, serving as a first baseman and closer, PERSON was one of the more intriguing seniors in the GPE class of 2015. The PERSON had him begin his career as a starting pitcher. It didn't take, but a move to the bullpen at the end of the season and during instructs did, which should hasten his arrival to the big leagues.PERSON did get stretched out and worked on developing his pitches as a starter, but his stuff really played up once he was shortened back up as a reliever. In those outings, his fastball sat in the 95-98 mph range with some good movement. His slider got crisper too, a plus breaking ball that misses bats. Getting back into attack-the-hitter mode, PERSON found the strike zone with greater consistency in short stints.The PERSON didn't want PERSON to compete with just his fastball, a lesson he learned while scuffling through his time as a starter. The bullpen is his full-time home now, and he should start moving more quickly now as a setup type who can handle multiple innings.

PERSON had two relatively nondescript offensive seasons as PERSON's starting catcher before breaking out as a junior and hitting .310/.432/.563. That the 2016 Draft class featured an underwhelming crop of catchers and college hitters only added to PERSON's value, and the ORGANIZATION took him with the 72nd overall pick in June. He signed for slightly less than pick value, made his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League and then advanced to full-season ball in 2017. A switch-hitter, PERSON showed vastly improved feel to hit during his junior season, hitting for average and some extra-base ability, while walking more than he struck out. But because he lacks physicality and has only average bat speed, scouts are skeptical about his power translating in the ORGANIZATION. On defense is where PERSON really shines, and there's little doubt that the former Pac-12 Defensive Player of the Year can stick behind the plate. He has average receiving skills and an average arm that has been effective at times in controlling the running game. The floor might be higher than the ceiling with PERSON, but there's a lot to like in a guy who could develop into a solid backup catcher, possibly even a starter.

The ORGANIZATION got the power lefty from the ORGANIZATION at the 2012 trade deadline for PERSON and they should be able to reap the benefits soon. PERSON has struck out close to 12 per nine innings over the course of his ORGANIZATION career, using a power two-pitch combination to go right after hitters and miss a lot of bats. His fastball can be plus, up to 95 mph with late life and sink. His hard slider gives him a second plus offering, a breaking ball with late bite that heâs not afraid to throw at any point. As his 56 saves attest, PERSON has been used to close games and assuming he can maintain his average command, thereâs no reason to think he canât serve the same role in the big leagues.

As a high schooler in GPE, PERSON looked like he had a chance to be a five-tools monster. He was a svelte-but-strong 6-foot-3 with plus, unpolished bat speed, plus-plus footspeed and every physical trait necessary to stay at shortstop. A positive ORGANIZATION test ahead of the draft tanked his stock, and PERSON exhibited a steady physical decline in the year and a half that followed this revelation. Still viable at shortstop, PERSON's ability to swing the bat with verve has evaporated. His age and frame are still indicative of physical growth, but unless PERSON reclaims some of the offensive explosion he showed in high school, he profiles as a glove-only shortstop prospect.

Growing up in GPE, PERSON didn't have many opportunities to face top competition. His high school didn't have a baseball team, but he managed to play his way into the first round of the 2011 First-Year Player Draft.Despite his atypical background, PERSON has a mature approach at the plate. He lines balls from gap to gap and he knows how to work a walk. PERSON's swing has a little length to it, and he has been prone to high strikeout totals early in his career.PERSON is a center fielder now, but his average speed may eventually force him to into an outfield corner. His game still needs refining, but PERSON's on-base skills and quick hands give him the potential to be a solid Major Leaguer in time.

Hailing from the same GPE high school as GPE right-hander PERSON, PERSON took an over-pick-value deal to sign rather than attend the ORGANIZATION of GPE, where his uncle had been an All-American pitcher.PERSON's solid stuff, projectability, makeup and bloodlines, make him an intriguing prospect. He already throws 88-92 mph, and there's room for growth in his 6-foot-5 frame -- with more angle than life currently on his fastball. PERSON has a feel for spinning the ball, but needs to add more power to his curve. He also could use more deceptive arm speed with his changeup, though it has some promising fade.PERSON has a loose arm that works well, and he could have three solid or better pitches once he gets stronger and maintains a consistent arm slot. With a former All-American uncle and a father who starred collegiately as well, the upside is clearly there.

The best athlete available and the fifth overall pick in the 2011 Draft, PERSON turned down a scholarship to play quarterback at ORGANIZATION to sign for $7.5 million -- still a record for a drafted position player. He struggled to translate his considerable tools into production at the plate during his first three pro seasons, hitting .237/.326/.388 with 348 strikeouts in 310 games, but has made encouraging progress in 2015.Mechanical adjustments that PERSON honed during the offseason, such as adding a bit of a leg kick and smoothing out his right-handed stroke, have resulted in more success. He still can be fooled by offspeed pitches, though he's making more consistent contact than he had in the past. His strength, bat speed and leverage create at least plus raw power and he now has a better chance to tap into it.There's nothing wrong with PERSON's defense. He has solid speed, takes direct routes in center field, and parlayed his strong arm into a high Class A ORGANIZATION League-best 14 outfield assists last year. He's also an astute baserunner who projects to steal 20 or more bases per season at a high success rate.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON commit, PERSON is touted as a catching prospect, though he has played multiple positions in high school. He was named to the 2016 Underclass 2nd Team and has played in two ORGANIZATION World Championships in the past.PERSON has a high leg kick at the plate and will over-swing at times, but he makes decent contact, and scouts note his aggressive approach. In the field, he has a slightly below average arm, but it should get better as he has more time to develop.

Though there aren't many quality up-the-middle college players in the 2017 Draft, GPE PERSON had two of the better ones in shortstop PERSON and PERSON. A former walk-on, PERSON for much of his freshman year and played first base for much of his sophomore season. He starred as a center fielder in the ORGANIZATION last summer and then continued to shine there this spring en route to being taken by the ORGANIZATION in the first competitive balance round.PERSON's ceiling is that of a top-of-the-order tablesetter in a big league lineup. He has a quick left-handed bat, an eye for drawing walks and a mature approach at the plate. He concentrates on making line-drive contact during games, and while there are some concerns about how much impact he'll make with his bat, he flashes some raw power in batting practice, especially to his pull side. PERSON uses his plus speed well on the bases and in center, though some scouts would like to see him take better routes on defense. His fringy arm strength is enough for his position, though it will limit his usefulness in right field if he becomes a fourth outfielder rather than a regular.

PERSON had three remarkably consistent years at ORGANIZATION and ended his college career with a .340 average. He has excellent hitter's timing and bat control, and his swing is athletic but compact, enabling not only high rates of contact, but also promising contact quality. That's not to say PERSON will have in-game power. He's a line drive hitter, an old school, two-hole type of hitter, the kind who's sort of an endangered species in the current big league hitting environment. Some teams considered PERSON's lack of power to be a bit of an issue in their pre-draft evals and thought he was more of a tweener fourth outfield type, a projection echoed by pro scouts who saw PERSON in the summer and fall. 
He has plus speed, speed that PERSON exhibited during instructional league even after he had been shut down for the summer with a foot injury. His frame is maxed out and he can't afford to slow down much and still be viable in center field every day, but while this creates some long term risk for his profile, he's fine out there right now. His most likely path to a sizable everyday role involves PERSON out-hitting what we currently have projected for his bat.

The son of former big league player and manager PERSON, L.J. PERSON was a senior sign out of UConn who received a bonus more than $140,000 under the pick value of where he was taken. He's proven to be an even bigger bargain than anticipated, hitting his way through two levels of A ball before double-jumping to help out Triple-A Las Vegas in the playoffs, though he missed the start of the 2015 season due to a 50-game "drug of abuse" suspension. PERSON's best tool is his bat, a right-handed hitter with an advanced approach at the plate and solid on-base skills. While he's never going to be a huge home run hitter, he does have some extra-base ability. He doesn't seem to fear facing better pitching, and his bat got going further into the 2015 season. There were concerns about PERSON's defense, but he's improved at second base and the ORGANIZATION think he can stay there. An average runner, he might also be athletic enough to move to the outfield if needed. For now, PERSON will work on putting the suspension behind him and trying to prove he can develop into a decent offensive-minded second baseman.

PERSON, who received the second highest bonus in the ORGANIZATION Sox 2017 international class at $1.4 million -- just behind PERSON's $1.6 million -- was the buzz of the LOCATION instructional league and has exciting potential. After dominating the ORGANIZATION during the summer, PERSON got a late call-up and played two games in the ORGANIZATION before his summer was shortened by a minor injury. He reminds some scouts of a potential everyday shortstop who takes a few games to grow on you. Unlike many high-bonus, July 2nd prospects, PERSON doesn't have loud, flashy tools, or exceptional twitch or physical projection. He's more of the steady, low-key type of player with excellent feel for defense (common among prospects from GPE, where there's more of a game-focused development) and high-quality contact. He projects to be an above-average bat with average raw power, and the swing attributes to have a chance to get to most of it. Deceptively quick for his size, PERSON has average speed and the defensive instincts to cover more ground than his raw foot speed indicates, as well as a plus arm. There's a chance PERSON outgrows shortstop, but he'd likely be at least above-average, if not plus, at third base in that event. It may be a card full of 5's (except for arm strength) on the 2-8 scale, with very little pro experience, but scouts are excited about what little they've seen here and think he could be a first division regular if the bat develops enough.

The biggest thing holding ORGANIZATION back so far has been health. If he can stay on the field, he has the chance to contribute.ORGANIZATION turned out to be the ORGANIZATION' top signee in 2012 when PERSON didn't sign. A variety of leg issues allowed him to amass only 84 games in just over a year of pro ball. ORGANIZATION does have solid tools across the board. He has the chance to hit, with some power, from the right side of the plate. ORGANIZATION has the speed to steal a base and potentially stay in center field, though some think left field might be his eventual home.Before figuring that out, ORGANIZATION needs to get a full season of at-bats in. If it can all come together, he has the potential to at the very least be a valuable fourth outfielder type.

PERSON works in the low-90s with a flat-planed fastball that plays at the top of the zone and a snap dragon, 12-to-6 curveball. He's not that projectable, but he's athletically built and has a good arm action. He needs to refine his strike-throwing pretty badly and it would be nice if he ended up throwing harder, but the repertoire works well together.

PERSON could have been a top-three-rounds pick out of a ORGANIZATION high school in 2014 if he hadn't been intent on going to GPE, where he starred for three years. The most dynamic player on the GPE collegiate national team in the summer of 2016, he had the best all-around tools of any collegian in the 2017 Draft. Concerns about his strikeout rate caused him to slide to the ORGANIZATION with the ORGANIZATION. 23 overall choice, where they signed him for a slightly over-slot $2,897,500.PERSON is a quick-twitch athlete who will be a legitimate five-tool player if he hits. He has plus-plus speed, a quick left-handed swing and deceptive strength. He struck out in 24 percent of his college at-bats, swinging and missing against hittable offerings at times, leading to worries about his pitch recognition and whether he'll reach his offensive ceiling.Even if he doesn't hit for a high average, PERSON still can help a team win games in a variety of ways. He did a better job of using his lower half to generate power this spring and knows how to use his speed to steal bases. He also plays a quality center field and has drawn comparisons to an in-his-prime PERSON with a significantly stronger arm.

PERSON spent almost all of his first three pro seasons in GPE ball after signing for $25,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2010. He led PERSON's all-prospect rotation with 11 victories and led the entire system with a 2.74 ERA in 2014, when he also won the decisive game of the low Class A ORGANIZATION playoffs.Though he has a 90-92 mph fastball that touches 95, PERSON is more about efficiency than overpowering hitters. He fills the strike zone and gets a lot of groundouts with the sink on his heater, but he doesn't miss a lot of bats.That may change if PERSON' slider continues to improve and can keep opponents from sitting on his fastball. He has yet to demonstrate much feel for a changeup, a shortcoming that eventually could lead him to the bullpen.

As a sophomore, PERSON moved back and forth between pitching on Fridays and PERSON. In his junior season, the right-hander has been PERSON's Friday night ace all year and has been one of the more consistent college pitchers on the LOCATION this season.After a strong performance over the summer on the GPE, PERSON came out of the gate this spring pitching extremely well and helping his profile. Even as he's leveled off a bit, he's continued to perform, albeit in a slightly weaker LOCATION Conference. With a very quick arm, he delivers his fastball lin the 92-95 mph range. His secondary stuff isn't quite as good, but his hard slider can be an out pitch at times and he'll mix in a curve and changeup as well. While some worry that his arm is too quick and that effort in his delivery could mean a move to a bullpen, he's shown the ability to maintain velocity deep into starts.PERSON is also an excellent athlete, reminding some of D-backs prospect PERSON. That should help him repeat his delivery consistently and give him the chance to reach his ceiling as a mid-rotation starter.

GPE is the kind of prospect who sneaks up on people. He doesn't wow you with any particular skill, but you can't help but like him more the more you see him play. That doesn't mean he doesn't have tools. He led the FACILITY organization in batting average and hits while playing at three levels in 2012. He then played 112 games with Triple-A Charlotte in 2013, but posted only a .241/.293/.296 slash line. The 2012 PERSON is a hard-nosed player who can spray line drives all over the field from both sides of the plate. He is capable of playing three infield positions and handles either up-the-middle spot capably. He may not have the highest ceiling in the world, but he's the kind of player who finds his way onto winning ballclubs.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, who had committed to PERSON, opted to transfer to ORGANIZATION for his final season of high school baseball. PERSON was a member of the 2015 17U ORGANIZATION Development Program and had his best game in the ORGANIZATION' 5-3 loss to the Stars in the second game of their schedule. PERSON tossed one inning, giving up just one hit and no runs while striking out two. Beyond ORGANIZATION, the pitcher participated in the 2016 ORGANIZATION and made four All-Tournament teams in four years, including the 2016 17U ORGANIZATION Championship when he played with PERSON Prime. The slender hurler pairs a fastball that touches 90 mph with a slow curveball that sits in the low 70s and a changeup in the 80s with cutting action. With some slight mechanical adjustments, PERSON could further improve his prospect status as he rises up the ranks.

The ORGANIZATION had been linked for months to PERSON, a GPE defector, before signing him in late July for $1.5 million and a matching penalty for exceeding their international bonus allotment. He was one of GPE's biggest expenditures as it exceeded its international pool for the first time. Though he had limited success in sporadic playing time in 2012-14 in GPE's PERSON, he was one of the league's youngest players and fared better in the island's 18-and-under and 23-and-under leagues.PERSON stands out most for his offensive potential. He has a quick right-handed bat and has added strength since defecting, giving him intriguing raw power for a middle infielder. He's aggressive at the plate but makes consistent contact and uses the entire field.While PERSON has just average speed, the ORGANIZATION believe he'll be able to stay at shortstop. He has good actions and a quick first step, giving him range to both sides. He also has soft hands and solid arm strength that should fit well at second or third base should he need to change positions.

Square-shouldered and long-limbed, PERSON already creates terrific pull-side lift with his swing and might grow into considerable raw power. He's very unlikely to stay at shortstop with some scouts moving him way down the defensive spectrum to either an outfield corner or even first base.

PERSON had $1 million evaluations on GPE when he was in high school, just about half a million shy of what it likely would have taken to sign him. He matriculated to PERSON, where his abilities sufficed to push phenom PERSON over to second base. Indeed GPE is the rare college player who scouts saw as capable of playing shortstop. He's a plus-plus runner with a plus arm, and infield-worthy footwork and actions. Neither acrobatic nor sexy in any way, GPE's look as a defender, and his overall profile, has been compared to J.J. PERSON's. Like PERSON, GPE also has some power but his college swing likely needs to be altered for him to get to it in games. With player development now firmly ensconced in the era of swing changes, it seems reasonable to anticipate that GPE will make some adjustments. The track record for college shortstops is not great, but GPE has everyday tools.

PERSON had a tumultuous and eventful amateur athletic career. He starred as a dual threat high school quarterback in GPE, and continued playing football in college even after the ORGANIZATION, who at the time were able to offer PERSON a now defunct two-sport deal structured to incentivize him to eventually commit to baseball, drafted and signed him. His college football career and home life were both tumultuous, as LOCATION went winless during PERSON's first year under center, and several members of his family had legal troubles. PERSON eventually transferred to PERSON, where he was asked to play safety. But that didn't last long and he soon committed full time to baseball. 
He's dealt with constant injury as a pro and has issues with quality of contact when healthy. Though he's a remarkable athlete with huge raw power and speed, we're bearish on PERSON's ability to hit breaking stuff and do enough damage to play everyday. He projects as a bench outfielder. Because PERSON has only been totally devoted to baseball since 2015, there's a chance some of what currently impairs his on-field production can be remedied, but he has to stay on the field to develop that stuff.

In 2016, the ORGANIZATION took four high school pitchers with their top six picks and signed all of them. PERSON, a prepster from GPE, was the last of the quartet, getting $1.2 million to forgo his commitment to the ORGANIZATION of GPE. After leading the system in ORGANIZATION in his first full season, he streaked across three levels of the Minors to make his big league debut in 2018, the first high schooler from his GPE class to do so.Once upon a time, people saw PERSON as a future reliever because of his size, stuff and bulldog mentality. A former high school football player, PERSON goes right after hitters with his three-pitch arsenal. His fastball typically sits in the low-90s, but he's shown the ability to ratchet it up to 97-98 mph at times, and he throws it with a lot of sink to get ground-ball outs. His breaking ball still gets slurvy at times and can look like a slider or a curve depending on when you see it, but it's an effective pitch, especially when it's harder and tighter. His changeup keeps improving and flashes above-average at times. All of his stuff plays up because he can command it well and has shown fearlessness on the mound throughout his quick run up the organizational ladder. He's convinced evaluators he can start, with a ceiling perhaps as a mid-rotation starter, though the ORGANIZATION' pitching depth could send him to the bullpen, at least in the short-term.

GPE won't wow you with tools, but he's the type that just goes out and gets the job done. The one thing he's shown he can do is hit. He makes a ton of contact, rarely strikes out, draws walks and looks like he should be able to continue hitting for a high average. He's the perfect No. 2 type hitter, one who can move runners, hit-and-run and hit when behind in the count. He makes the plays defensively without much flash. He played second base in the ORGANIZATION in 2011 and many feel that he'll eventually slide over there permanently and become a very solid everyday big leaguer on the right side of the infield.

PERSON, who had a cameo in the movie "The ORGANIZATION" as a high school quarterback, started at shortstop for four years at ORGANIZATION but lacked the quickness to play there as a pro. The ORGANIZATION moved him behind the plate as soon as they signed him for $40,000 as an eighth-rounder in 2013, hoping he can make the same successful infielder-to-catcher transition that PERSON made a decade earlier.PERSON's conversion is off to a promising start, as he made the low Class A ORGANIZATION All-Star Game in his first full pro season and the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON in his second. He has the soft hands, arm strength and leadership skills needed to make it work, though his release and receiving will require a lot more polish. He also has spent time at third base in 2015, enhancing his versatility.Though he has posted solid offensive numbers as a pro, PERSON probably won't hit enough to be more than a big league backup. He makes contact but doesn't have much power and rarely walks.

The ORGANIZATION had success drafting an athletic catcher in 2010 when they picked J.T. GPE, a converted shortstop, in the third round. Five years later, the organization hopes to have similar success with the development of backstop PERSON, its sixth-round pick from the 2015 Draft who received an above-slot bonus of $540,000 to forgo his commitment to PERSON State.Similar to GPE, PERSON stands out for his all-around athleticism behind the plate. His plus arm strength is his loudest tool, but he also earns praise for his actions and receiving skills. The ORGANIZATION believe that he will eventually come into his own as a hitter, especially after he flashed some offensive potential during his 2015 pro debut by hitting .321 with two homers over 18 games in the ORGANIZATION League.A fractured right hand suffered last August delayed the start to PERSON's 2016 season, and he then landed on the 60-day disabled list in early July with a left hip injury. But once he's healthy, the ORGANIZATION are optimistic that he can develop into an athletic, defensive-oriented catcher who can also contribute with his bat.

PERSON began his college career at ORGANIZATION State (Fla.) JC before transferring to GPE and leading the ORGANIZATION in home runs (16) as a junior in 2016. The PERSON made him their third-round pick that June, and PERSON immediately rewarded the club with a strong pro debut. That success followed PERSON into his first full season, as he erupted to hit .329 with 32 home runs and 32 doubles between Class A Advanced PERSON and Double-A Bowie, and then became the first player from his GPE class to reach the Majors when the PERSON called him up in September. Facing high expectations in 2018, PERSON was limited by shoulder injury during Spring Training and struggled to find his swing back in Double-A before landing on the disabled list with an ankle injury in May. PERSON features a short but explosive swing, combining bat speed with natural feel for the barrel to generate hard contact to all fields, with easy, plus raw power to his pull side. He can handle velocity fine and has a knack for punishing mistakes, though an aggressive approach does make him vulnerable to quality secondary offerings. That should improve with experience, giving PERSON the potential for an above-average bat with similar, if not better power in his prime. PERSON spent much of 2017 in center field before reaching the Majors, where he logged more time in right (14 games) than center (eight). His speed and range, both slightly above average, make him a quality defender at both positions, while his accurate, plus arm is a natural fit in right. Revered by club officials for his "grinder" mentality and all-out playing style, PERSON is on the fast track to becoming an impact, everyday player at the highest level.

ORGANIZATION might have surpassed PERSON (ORGANIZATION, 10th round, 2010) as the highest pick ever directly out of the ORGANIZATION if he hadn't moved to GPE for his high school senior season. The son of a 1988 Olympics taekwondo participant (ORGANIZATION) and a former sprinter (ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION), he may have the best chance to remain a starter among the ORGANIZATION's best prep arms this spring. He's also strongly committed to GPE, so he could slide out of the top five rounds.Projectable and athletic, ORGANIZATION could have two plus pitches once he matures physically. He can reach 95 mph early in games and sit at 90-93 with riding action for stretches, though his velocity faded a bit as the ORGANIZATION approached. He gets good break on his upper-70s slider, which should be a more dynamic offering once it adds more ORGANIZATION already shows the ability to throw his changeup for strikes. He has a fairly clean delivery, which allows him to repeat it well but doesn't provide much deception. He could have the upside of a No. 3 starter once he gets stronger.

Drafted out of a GPE high school in the 22nd round in 2012, PERSON decided to attend PERSON. He barely pitched for the ORGANIZATION as a freshman, then transferred to GPE for his sophomore season. If he doesn't turn pro this summer, he'll move on to Auburn.PERSON draws mixed reviews. Scouts who like him praise his big, athletic frame and his arm strength. He works with a 91-93 mph fastball that touches 95 and features some sink and armside run, and he also flashes a promising low-80s slider.PERSON's detractors question his delivery -- which features a long arm action with a hook in the back -- his secondary pitches and his toughness. He has a decent changeup that could be helpful if he refined it with more use, and he also throws a slow curveball that he might be better off scrapping. He throws strikes but needs better command.

PERSON's explosive toolset is undermined by his exploitable, pull-heavy approach to contact and his propensity to chase. These deficiencies make him very easy for right-handed pitchers to beat by feeding him breaking balls away, which he can often neither touch nor take. Despite this, there's a viable path to big league playing time for PERSON because he sees lefties well-enough to hit for difference-making power against them, and his speed and arm are assets on defense. He has a chance to be a good role-playing ouitfielder, but PERSON's approach means his floor is like the bottom of a wet paper bag.

PERSON was pitching in the ORGANIZATION as a 16-year-old when the ORGANIZATION signed him in 2011. He had no trouble adjusting to pitching in the GPE and was the youngest player in the ORGANIZATION on Opening Day in 2013.PERSON throws his fastball in the low- to mid-90s with good movement. His slider is his best offspeed pitch, and his changeup shows promise. He is the nephew of former ORGANIZATION reliever PERSON, and his bloodlines seem to have helped. He has better command and more pitchability than most teenagers.PERSON underwent PERSON surgery in July 2013 and returned to the mound this July, a little less than a year later. Though he missed most of the 2014 season, he won't turn 20 until Spring Training 2015, so he has time on his side and the stuff to get back on track.

When PERSON was selected in the first round of the 2014 Draft, the hope was that he'd be a quick-to-the-big-leagues type college hitter. After his first full season, when he reached Double-A albeit without dominating, it looked like he might still fit that profile. A full season in Double-A in 2016, however, saw him go in the wrong direction.PERSON got off on the wrong foot when he injured his hamstring playing for PERSON in the World Baseball PERSON in March 2016. Though he joined PERSON in mid-April, he didn't really have his base under him as a result of the injury. PERSON falls into the bad habit of trying to generate power too much, forcing him to pull off the plate and lose coverage of the outer third. A shortstop at ORGANIZATION, he still sees some time there, but he saw more at second, where he's an above-average defender while also mixing in some good glovework at third.PERSON did finish the 2016 season on much better footing than he started, raising his OPS by 120 points in the second half. He was able to use that as a springboard to a bit of a bounce-back 2017 season that saw him reach Triple-A.

The D-backs were very cautious with PERSON during his debut season after signing him out of GPE for $450,000 in 2014, partially because of a back issue and partially to manage his innings. The slender right-hander nevertheless made a very strong first impression, including an appearance in the 2015 ORGANIZATION. After being held back to start the 2016 season, PERSON struggled with an assignment to the GPE League and was moved back to short-season ball, with concerns about his durability mounting.PERSON has shown the ability to pitch off of his low-90s fastball, commanding it precisely to all parts of the strike zone. He also has an outstanding changeup that serves as an out pitch, getting swings and misses consistently. His curve is still developing, but he knows how to spin it, and it could at least be PERSON average. He does have some physicality, but his 6-foot-1 slight build hasn't lent itself to adding strength.The D-backs had hoped to take the gloves off in terms of PERSON's development, but that hasn't been the case. If they can get him physically ready, his advanced feel for pitching, mound presence and plus makeup should all let him start to move up the ladder, with a chance to pitch in the middle to back of a rotation in the future.

PERSON' swing needs work. His stride and bat path both have problems, but he swings hard and has promising hand-eye coordination and bat control despite his current issues. Additionally, PERSON has a lean, projectable frame, he's a plus runner and athletic infield defender who already has experience at multiple positions, and he has above-average bat speed. Some of the mechanical components in the batters box will need to improve, but the raw material here is exciting. Most players this age are older high school or junior college draft prospects. Measured against amateur players his age, PERSON would probably go in the top 50 picks.

A highly regarded two-way player coming out of high school in 2012, PERSON was selected in the compensation round. The A's made him a full-time hitter, and PERSON showed why in 2013. He ranked second in the ORGANIZATION with 23 home runs as a 19-year-old. PERSON has shown even more power this season in high Class A.PERSON has a quick and easy swing that gives him the potential to hit for average as well as power. His swing does have a tendency to get long, making him prone to strikeouts.PERSON is a well-below-average runner, which contributed to the A's moving him across the diamond from his high school position of third base. PERSON has good hands and he looks like he could develop into an excellent defensive first baseman.

The ORGANIZATION actually picked PERSON one spot ahead of PERSON in the first round of the 2009 Draft. While PERSON was rocketing to superstardom, PERSON had trouble staying healthy. He finally did so the past two seasons, hitting a combined 40 homers while reaching Double-A, before GPE sent him to ORGANIZATION in a trade for PERSON Freese.PERSON has the tools to hit for some average and power in the big leagues. He has a quick bat, and he has room on his frame to add some more strength. PERSON is very aggressive at the plate, something pitchers might exploit at higher levels.PERSON has played all three outfield positions in the Minors, fitting best in right field with his average arm and his fringy speed. The ORGANIZATION have a logjam of outfield talent, so his versatility could help when he is ready for ORGANIZATION.

A 23rd round pick in 2011 from GPE, PERSON has never been considered much of a prospect. But he has hit everywhere he's gone, from college to the ORGANIZATION, and his breakout season at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Inland Empire has been too much to ignore. None of PERSON's tools stand out, but he does everything well. He creates good bat speed from the left side, which translates into solid power. He is an aggressive hitter and has room to improve his pitch recognition. Defensively, he has settled into left field after moving around the diamond in college. That puts more pressure on his bat, but as he's shown so far, that might not be a problem. PERSON will have to prove his breakout isn't a product of the GPE, but he has firmly put himself on the map as a prospect.

Though PERSON shows no signs of ever slowing down, the ORGANIZATION invested in a pair of promising young third-base prospects in 2016. After signing PERSON for $675,000 as a third-round pick in June, they landed PERSON three months later for $1.1 million. He played two seasons in GPE's top league as a teenager, batting a combined .259/.335/.328.Like PERSON, PERSON doesn't have one standout tool but does possess the potential to contribute across the board. His raw right-handed power attracted the most attention from scouts, and he has the approach and hitting ability to translate it into game production. His speed reportedly has improved since he left GPE, with some evaluators now giving it above-average or plus grades.PERSON played five positions in GPE's PERSON: third base, first base, second base, right field and left field. He has average arm strength and should have enough quickness to stay at the hot corner. If he can't handle third base, the outfield corners are his likely next destination.

The younger brother of ORGANIZATION pitching farmhand PERSON, this PERSON will make it to the next level with his bat. Both PERSON and PERSON are speedy shortstops with rare power for the position who also have issues making contact. PERSON is rangy and athletic, and has good defensive footwork and plenty of arm for the infield's left side. His hands are just okay, so evaluations of his defense can vary depending on what individual scouts think is important to play the position, and some teams want to see him tried in center field. 
PERSON has plus-plus bat speed and his hands work in a tight, lift-friendly circle, but he's so explosive that at times he's out of control (this is where the strikeouts come from). He managed to get to the power at Hi-A in 2018, when he homered 19 times, and if he can stay at shortstop and continue to mash like that in games, he'll be a good everyday player. We have PERSON in the 45 ORGANIZATION tier of the 2019 draft, which puts him in the mid-to-late first round; we like PERSON a bit more than that and think he'd be in the 10-15 range on a draft board. He'll move into the top 100 with continued statistical success at Double-A.

There wasn't a better story at the 2015 ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON than PERSON. He originally signed with the ORGANIZATION for $725,000 in 2006 and stagnated for four years in low Class A before getting released in 2013. He served stints in three independent leagues before signing with the ORGANIZATION last October, and he has put up huge numbers in the upper levels of the Minors this season.If PERSON gets to the big leagues, it will be his huge power that takes him there. He probably won't post high batting averages and on-base percentages, but he has found more success since toning down what had been an all-or-nothing approach. While PERSON has a strong arm and broke into pro ball as a third baseman, he's strictly a first baseman. He's a well below-average athlete and runner who's a shaky defender.

Signed in November 2013, PERSON spent his first pro season in the ORGANIZATION before impressing during his brief GPE debut last year in the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION native graduated to full-season ball in 2016, earning mid-season All-Star honors in the Class A ORGANIZATION at age 19.PERSON's live arm generates easy velocity in a fastball that consistently sits between 92-95 mph with late life. His slider registers in the mid- to high-80s, thrown with late, short slicing action, and he also has the makings of an advanced changeup that he's already comfortably deploying against right-handed hitters.There are concerns about PERSON's ability to create downhill plane given his height, but, so far, he's shown that he can keep the ball in the park. Meanwhile, he should be able to tack on strength to his wiry frame as he matures physically, which should in turn improve his durability. PERSON has the arsenal and control profile to develop into a big league starter, although his fastball-slider pairing also give him a bright future as a reliever, one who can get outs on both sides of the plate.

PERSON was primarily a reliever at ORGANIZATION before the ORGANIZATION drafted him in the 20th round in 2010. He began his professional career as a reliever, but PERSON moved him to the rotation in 2012 and he has responded well.PERSON's fastball sits around 90 mph, and he pairs it well with an above-average cutter. His curveball and changeup give him a chance to have four Major League-average or better offerings. PERSON has solid control and mixes his pitches well.PERSON is versatile enough to be either a starter or a reliever. If he did end up in the bullpen, his fastball-cutter combination would play up nicely. PERSON could soon fill either role for the ORGANIZATION.

Scouting grades: Hit: 60 | Power: 50 | Run: 30 | Arm: 60 | Field: 55 | Overall: 55Regarded as the best two-way GPE prospect since PERSON in 1973, ORGANIZATION won the PERSON Two-Way Player of the ORGANIZATION in each of his three seasons at ORGANIZATION. He went 11-3 with a 2.56 ORGANIZATION and a school-record 146 strikeouts in 16 starts on the mound as a junior while also hitting .341 with 18 home runs and 57 RBIs to win the ORGANIZATION and PERSON as college baseball's top player. GPEed fourth overall by PERSON in June, ORGANIZATION received the second-highest signing bonus ($7,007,500) under the current set of GPE rules. ORGANIZATION operates with a 92-95 mph fastball that he commands well against hitters on both sides of the plate, though his velocity is prone to dipping as he works deeper into games. Both his curveball and cutter project to be above-average pitches, and he showed good feel for a changeup during his pro debut after using it sparingly at ORGANIZATION. At the plate, ORGANIZATION's smooth left-handed swing and mature all-fields approach led some evaluators to label him the best college bat in his class as a potential .300 hitter capable of hitting 20 homers per season. His lack of speed limits him to first base, but he proved a sound defender during his pro debut, and could become above average in time.

The ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the second round of the 2011 Draft because they saw him as a projectable outfielder with a big league body and multiple potential plus tools. When he hit just .221/.254/.275 during his first three pro seasons, they turned him into a pitcher in 2014. Twelve months after PERSON made his first professional mound appearance, he reached Double-A.Though PERSON did attract scouting interest as an amateur pitcher, he has advanced more quickly than anyone could have expected. A product of the same FACILITY (GPE) program that spawned PERSON, he had no trouble reacclimating himself, showing feel for pitching and the ability to repeat his mechanics and throw strikes.PERSON's best pitch is his fastball, which sits at 91-94 mph and reaches as high as 97. His slider has made strides this season, grading as a plus offering at times. PERSON's changeup lags well behind his other two pitches, limiting his ceiling to that of a late-inning reliever.

A 12th-round pick from GPE who signed for $100,000 in the 2016 Draft, PERSON was largely a reliever in college. After a stunning pro debut pitching out of the bullpen, he moved into the rotation in 2017, finishing fourth in the system in strikeouts and sixth in ORGANIZATION, then moved up to Double-A, where he finished off a playoff no-hitter. His development is now in the hands of the D-backs, who acquired him in a three-team trade in February that sent PERSON to GPE York.PERSON picked up velocity in his introduction to pro ball, as his fastball soared from 90-93 mph to 93-97. His mid-80s slider can be a wipeout pitch at times but lacks consistency. To prepare him for starting, the ORGANIZATION had him focus on refining his work-in-progress changeup during instructional league, with terrific results.With an athletic delivery that he keeps in sync, PERSON should be able to provide strikes after sometimes battling his control while with the ORGANIZATION. He had ulnar transposition surgery on his pitching elbow in the fall of 2015 and also missed time with back and knee issues in college, but he proved to be durable over 27 starts in 2017. Even if he returns to the bullpen, he could be a valuable arm for the D-backs in the future.

PERSON has a power forward build at 6-foot-8 and is an extreme power projection long shot. Scouts see 65-grade future raw power and a chance to stay in center field, so PERSON may be the heir to the ORGANIZATION young adult son hitting prospect throne.

PERSON worked almost exclusively out of the bullpen during his first two years at PERSON, but a move to the rotation in the ORGANIZATION last summer opened a lot of eyes and had many wondering if he could start long-term at the next level. While hopes to see him in that role during his junior year were dashed when he returned to the bullpen, the PERSON deemed his overall upside worthy of a fourth-round pick as well as an above-slot bonus of $500,000. A big and physical right-hander, PERSON was effective as PERSON's closer this spring, setting a Cardinal record with 16 saves. After reaching 95 mph in the GPE, he was mostly sitting 90-91 mph and occasionally hitting 92-93 on the gun as a junior. His curveball remains effective and is his go-to out pitch, showing the ability to miss bats with it at times, while his changeup remains a distant third pitch. There is some effort to his delivery, resulting in inconsistent command as well as an inability to maintain his velocity deeper into outings when he was starting.PERSON has the strength and body to be a rotation workhorse, though he'll first need to refine his delivery. Most evaluators peg him as an effective setup type reliever who could move quickly in a bullpen role, especially if the velocity can return.

PERSON may actually be even smaller than his listed size of 5-foot-9, 180 pounds. But what he lacks in size, he makes up for in hustle. His motor elicits comparisons to PERSON. PERSON has a short, compact swing that allows him to make a lot of contact. And he has more power than his size would suggest, but it still grades as below average. PERSON is a plus runner and knows how to steal a base. He has improved his defense and is a capable second baseman.

Emerged in high school hitting the mid-90's, wasn't used a ton at GPE, then emerged as their second best starter this year. Works 93-95, touched 97, can land and average curveball and his changeup is usable, but he's more control over command and may fit better in relief.

PERSON put up video-game type numbers at ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION this spring, raising his Draft profile in the process, then created a huge amount of buzz by hitting triple digits consistently in a bullpen session in late May. The ORGANIZATION drafted him with the second of their two picks in the first round, then signed the flame-throwing righty for slightly above slot value at $2,452,900. There is no question about the quality of PERSON's fastball coming from his 6-foot-6 frame. He was consistently up to 97 mph all spring and has shown an ability to throw strikes with it as well. His secondary stuff, however, has been inconsistent. He throws both a slider and a curve, though the latter is his fourth pitch, and on some days he has two distinct, effective breaking balls. At other times, they run together, and it might serve him well to focus on just one at the next level. His changeup has improved, but it also comes and goes.There is an injury history with PERSON -- he had a screw put in his right elbow in high school -- but he was nothing but healthy and durable in junior college. There's some debate over whether his future lies in the rotation or out of the bullpen, where his stuff would play up, but the ORGANIZATION feel that PERSON has all the ingredients needed to become an impact starter.

PERSON was a two-way standout at GPE, playing the outfield and pitching on Saturdays for the top college program. His offensive game took a big leap forward during his junior season, moving into top 10 pick conversations. The ORGANIZATION nabbed him at ORGANIZATION. 8 and gave him $5.1 million to sign, an above-pick value deal.PERSON uses the entire field and while he often featured more of an inside-out swing from the left side, he did start to show more power during his junior season. While not a burner, PERSON does have above-average speed. He is capable of playing center field, but whether that's his long-term home remains to be seen. He is capable of playing all three outfield spots, with at least an average arm.After his huge junior season, which saw his stock soar, PERSON hit the ground running during his pro debut, moving to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League after a brief stop in the ORGANIZATION. He kept moving quickly during his first full sseason, hitting his way to Double-A Reading.

GPE was a low-bonus, late-round, small school pick who still wasn't really on the prospect radar for most clubs until 2018. His velocity took a step forward (up to 98 mph) and the added armspeed helped his 50 to 55 type stuff grade out a tick better. This improvement made him a lock to be a Rule 5 pick if not protected, so PERSON added him to the 40-man roster.
