He has a nasty breaking ball that combines slider velocity (81-85 mph) with curveball depth. He also has the makings of an effective changeup, though he doesn't use it much in relief.Because he has three pitches and a clean delivery, PERSON could get a chance at starting in pro ball. He'll need to improve his command but shows some feel for pitching to all four quadrants of the strike zone.

PERSON averaged just 5.0 strikeouts per nine innings in his first two years at ORGANIZATION before changing the grip on his cutter/slider while watching video of PERSON. That sparked a stunning 2017 junior season, during which he threw the first perfect game in GPE history, went 43 straight innings without allowing an earned run and set school records for strikeout rate (11.3) and opponent average (.173). After signing for $901,900 as a second-rounder, he continued to miss bats in five brief pro starts.Hitters don't see the ball well against PERSON, who has a deceptive delivery and generates swings and misses without a true plus pitch. His best offering is his improved cutter, which sits in the upper 80s. He added velocity to his four-seam fastball last year, pitching at 90-93 mph, and also has a decent curveball and a fringy changeup.Going back to his early days in college when he didn't have his weaponized cutter, PERSON challenged hitters and filled the strike zone. He has a strong build and is efficient with his pitch counts, so he should be able to log plenty of innings toward the back of a rotation.

PERSON has some of the best pure stuff in baseball, running his fastball up to 97 mph, flashing a 60 slider at times, and relying heavily on one of the best changeups in the game, which is a 70 for most scouts. His short arm action is a giveaway that he converted from catching while at GPE. The issues holding PERSON back are that he consistently works behind in the count and seems focused on putting up big velo numbers, which affects his fastball command and allows hitters to sit on his offspeed pitches. Like PERSON and PERSON, hope was bright in the past year that PERSON could fix his issues and become a big league contributor, but none of the three have changed much in the interim and now have shorter developmental ropes as they enter their mid-20's.

Another quality PERSON pitching prospect plucked out of GPE ball in a trade, PERSON needed PERSON surgery when the ORGANIZATION set their sights on him in 2013. That didn't stop them from wanting him as the player to be named from the ORGANIZATION in a deal for PERSON, even if he would miss all of the following season. He returned to the mound in June 2015 and made his big league debut 15 months later.PERSON had a mid-80s fastball when he signed for $75,000 out of the ORGANIZATION, and it has gotten stronger as he has. He now operates at 92-96 mph and tops out at 98 while using his 6-foot-7 frame to generate difficult downhill plane. He also throws a power curveball that can range from well above average to slurvy, a decent slider and an improving changeup that shows flashes of becoming a plus offering.PERSON made nice strides in 2016 with his changeup and control, and at this point he mainly needs innings to build consistency. He totaled just 203 1/3 innings in his first six pro seasons, and the 97 he worked last year represented a career high. He missed time in 2016 with elbow tendinitis and a suspension for violating team policy, and he got hit with an 80-game suspension this July after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON GuerreroArellano a ORGANIZATION commit who was a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a 2016 ORGANIZATION Second Teamer. The top 500 recruit made four All-Tournament teams in 2015, including with the ORGANIZATION in the 2015 ORGANIZATION World Championship and PERSON in the 2015 ORGANIZATION World Championship. The big, strapping athlete has a high hand stance at the plate and while he shows promise, he needs to shorten his swing to continue to improve at the next level.

When the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the seventh round of the 2012 Draft and went over pick value to sign him away from attending PERSON, they knew the right-hander was a bit of a long-term project as a position player who emerged as a pitching prospect during his senior year of high school. It took until his fourth summer to reach full-season ball, but he's been moving at a steady clip since, heading to Double-A for the 2017 season.PERSON always had a tall and projectable frame and he's grown into it. He throws his fastball in the 90-95 mph range and he's shown an ability to use his 6-foot-5 frame to throw it downhill and get groundball outs. He throws both a curve and a slider, with the former a bit ahead of the latter. His changeup continues to improve the more he throws it. He's generally around the strike zone with all of his pitches.While PERSON has been in pro ball for six years, he might still have some upside while getting close to being ready to knock on the door as a back-half of a rotation type starter.

PERSON hit 96 mph with his fastball as a ORGANIZATION high schooler but blew out his elbow two weeks before the 2015 Draft and had PERSON surgery. He redshirted during his first year at ORGANIZATION, then produced uneven results over the next two seasons while also battling some shoulder issues. The ORGANIZATION signed him for $200,000 as an 11th-rounder last June on the basis of his upside, which was evident during his pro debut and instructional league.PERSON's fastball velocity fluctuated during his final season at ORGANIZATION, dipping to the low 90s at times and topping out at 98 mph at others, and his curveball was similarly inconsistent. As a pro, he worked at 93-98 mph and hit 100 with his heater and spun some well-above-average curves with power and depth. He even showed promise with a changeup he didn't utilize much in college.After battling the strike zone at ORGANIZATION, PERSON displayed better control after GPE cleaned up his lower half in his delivery. He still has a long ways to go to prove he can remain healthy, maintain quality stuff and locate his pitches. While the ORGANIZATION will continue to develop him as a starter, he could move quickly as a reliever.

PERSON ranked as the ORGANIZATION's top position prospect entering 2016 because he offers the best combination of hitting and athletic ability. He should become the highest pick in ORGANIZATION history, surpassing current teammate PERSON, who declined to sign with the ORGANIZATION as the 35th overall choice in 2015. A 33rd-round pick by the ORGANIZATION as an Illinois high schooler in 2013, he broke out as a sophomore last spring and continued to star during the summer, leading the GPE collegiate national team in GPE (.971), extra-base hits (nine) and steals (11). PERSON has a quick left-handed bat and makes consistent hard contact, giving him the potential to hit for both power and average. He uses the entire field well and has done a better job of managing the strike zone and making consistent contact this spring. PERSON has plus speed and knows how to use it well on the bases, and no player this year can match his combination of 39 steals (fourth in the nation) and 15 homers entering the ORGANIZATION Division I playoffs.Though he has spent most of his career at ORGANIZATION in right field, PERSON runs well enough to play center field and should get a chance to play there in pro ball, though some scouts question his instincts. He has the offensive production and arm to profile at all three outfield positions, and obviously he'd offer the most value if he can play in the middle.

Yet another talented ORGANIZATION prospect with deep baseball bloodlines, PERSON is the son of four-time All-Star PERSON and the brother of ORGANIZATION farmhand PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION took 51st overall back in 2011. While PERSON didn't come off the board quite as early as his brother, his impressive hitting ability still got him an above-slot signing bonus of $1,100,000 as ORGANIZATION's second-round pick. He put on a hitting clinic in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League after signing, batting a robust .427/.451/.732 in 22 games, and then did so once again across two full-season levels in 2017, when he paced all Minor League hitters with a .362 average and captured ORGANIZATION MVP honors. The move up to Double-A in 2018 brought a new challenges for PERSON, though he was anything but overmatched at the more advanced level, earning midseason All-Star honors in the LOCATION as well as his second straight ORGANIZATION All-Star Futures Games selection. PERSON proved an advanced hitter during his amateur career, and his raw power was on display when he won the Under PERSON All-American Game home run derby in GPE. He combines plus bat speed with a violent-but-controlled swing to produce tons of hard contact from line to line, and scouts like his chances of becoming a plus-or-better hitter with above-average power. He's an average runner with good range and instincts at shortstop, and the ORGANIZATION plan to keep him at the position for as long as they can. Some believe he's best suited for second or third base, or perhaps even left field, but so far he's passed every test at his natural position.Much like his teammate and friend PERSON, there seems to be no limit to PERSON's offensive ceiling. His career-to-date points to a bright future as a perennial All-Star who could regularly compete for batting titles.

We assume PERSON was hurt for much of 2018 (he threw just two ORGANIZATION innings) but it's unclear what ailed him. In 2017, he had some wild fluctuations in velocity (he was seen throwing anywhere between 93 and 100, but mostly sitting 94-98), which continued when he threw in 2018. PERSON was 94-96 in the spring and then didn't pitch until late in the summer when he was 92-93. If his arm strength bounces back, he'll move up this list.

A major signing from the 2011 international signing period, PERSON got just over $1 million to sign with the ORGANIZATION out of GPE at age 16. His full-season debut in 2014 was marred by leg injuries that limited him to 49 games and he was held back in extended spring training in 2015 because he was out of shape.While PERSON doesn't have the build of, say, PERSON, he has tools and athleticism to spare. An above-average runner, PERSON uses his speed to cover a lot of ground in center field and he is capable of being a basestealing threat. PERSON has shown an ability to spray line drives to all fields and has a decent approach at the plate, especially given his age. PERSON is unlikely to be a big part of his game, but if his on-base skills continue to improve, that won't be as important as a top-of-the-order type catalyst. PERSON's arm is fringy, but he has all the tools to be an everyday center fielder. Just 20 years old, PERSON did perform well once he got to GPE in the ORGANIZATION State League. Time is on PERSON's side and given the outfield depth in the system, that's not a bad thing.

PERSON signed for $500,000 (late third, early fourth round money) as a fifth round high schooler in 2017. He has a four-pitch mix headlined by a slider/cutter and his 88-92mph fastball plays up because it approaches hitters at a tough angle. He'll likely make his full-season debut in 2019 and projects as a No. 5 starter.

For the second time since the start of 2013, PERSON found himself in a new uniform following the non-waiver PERSON in GPE, this time going from GPE to PERSON in the ORGANIZATION Gomez/Mike Fiers deal. After a strong showing at Double-A between the two clubs, the left-hander was the talk of the ORGANIZATION, where he showcased electric stuff and led the circuit in ORGANIZATION. PERSON built on his ORGANIZATION performance back in Double-A during the first half of the season and reached Triple-A for the first time in his career in June.PERSON's stuff took a major step forward in the ORGANIZATION, where he was consistently 94-98 mph with his fastball and demonstrated improved feel for a plus slider, using it to induce whiffs from hitters on both sides of the plate. He has always featured some crossfire to his delivery, but he added even more deception by shifting to the first-base side of the rubber during the regular season, causing his fastball-slider pairing to play up consistently.Though there's increasingly less concern about PERSON's ability to remain a starter, the southpaw still needs improve his changeup and show he can pound the zone with greater frequency, as he still experiences bouts of wildness. But should starting not work out, there is little doubt that PERSON could make an impact out of the bullpen thanks to his high-octane stuff and huge strikeout potential.

PERSON had an unusual amateur career, graduating early to get to GPE, then not playing much and transferring to a junior college, where the ORGANIZATION drafted the behemoth late in 2015. He is a physical monster with huge raw power, and has a good enough approach to draw walks and pick out pitches he can drive. The bat control, defense, and long-term athletic ability are all behind and concerning, but there's a platoon or bench bat future here if he keeps hitting.

In recent Drafts, the ORGANIZATION had sought out athletic college outfielders, often in the later rounds. Jared PERSON came in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft and, to a lesser extent, there was PERSON from the 2014 Draft. PERSON was the next in line, an eighth-rounder from 2016 out of ORGANIZATION State who had a terrific pro debut and then made it to Double-A in his first full season. The ORGANIZATION liked what they saw there and during his stint in the ORGANIZATION to acquire him from GPE in December's PERSON trade.PERSON has long employed an advanced approach at the plate. He walked more than he struck out in three years of college ball and has a .368 on-base percentage in his ORGANIZATION career, which has helped him to advance quickly. He makes consistent contact and has some extra-base ability. His plus speed is his standout tool and he likes to put it to good use, bunting for hits often and being aggressive on the basepaths. His speed helps him in the outfield, where he can play above-average defense in all three spots. He has the skills to play center field, but he has played in both corners as well thus far as a pro.PERSON is ready to play full-time in the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION system. If he stays with his approach, he could be big league-ready fairly soon, perhaps fitting the profile of an effective fourth outfielder.

C.J. PERSON and his brother, ORGANIZATION PERSON (ORGANIZATION HS in GPE, drafted by the ORGANIZATION), were both drafted lower in 2018 than their talent suggested. PERSON slipped due to demands as an over slot high school pick, while C.J. was old for a junior college player and is limited to a corner, though scouts have some debate about which position is his best fit. C.J. had a big pro debut, getting to High-A and playing in instructs in a season that saw him in real games from late January until October. He has plus raw power and a plus arm, with deceptive contact skills and at least passable defense at all four corner spots. The upside is a low-end regular or the correct side of a corner platoon, which is more likely to happen if he continues to move quickly through the system. His pro ball batted-ball outcomes were lucky but he also played among the longest seasons in all of organized baseball, putting up big numbers at every level.

PERSON was PERSON's guy on last year's list when he profiled as a contact-oriented, multi-positional bench player with no power. At some point in 2018, his hands became more active and his swing took on more movement, becoming whippy and more explosive, and the quality of PERSON' contact was able to improve without costing him much in the way of contact. It culminated in an eye-opening September cup of coffee -- an apt phrase for PERSON, who plays like he is extremely caffeinated --  during which PERSON slashed .293/.349/.483. September numbers can be noisy because the talent pool has been diluted by roster expansion, but we're cautiously optimistic that PERSON has become a different hitter. Namely, a gap-to-gap hitter capable of really punishing pitchers who try to beat him with heat on the inner half. 
Defensively, he's perfectly fine at third base and in the outfield corners, and fringy at second base; we'd rather not have him play shortstop. PERSON's departure should enable PERSON to see big league reps. We think he's a valuable bench option and has a chance to be more than that.

The ORGANIZATION ace was in the conversation to go No. 1 overall in the 2017 PERSON right up until the ORGANIZATION made their selection. Instead, PERSON went No. 5 overall to the ORGANIZATION and he signed for an above-pick value of $7 million. The eighth ORGANIZATION pitcher taken in the first round in the past 10 PERSONs, PERSON pitched sparingly during his pro debut following a long college season, though he competed well in a brief taste of the Class A Advanced PERSON League.PERSON has four pitches, all of which will flash at least better than average, with the ability to throw all of them for strikes. He throws his plus fastball in the 94-98 mph range and can comfortably sit around 95-96 mph, maintaining his velocity deep into starts. He has two distinct breaking balls, with his hard curve a plus pitch that is just a touch ahead of a power slider. His changeup might be a touch behind the other three, but it's a usable weapon and he will throw it at times with above-average deception and movement. While PERSON struggled a little with command during his junior year, he is physical and athletic enough to repeat his delivery and throw more than enough strikes. His combination of size, stuff and projectability point to a future frontline starter, one who should move up the ORGANIZATION ladder quickly.

There's a group of evaluators that believes PERSON is the best teenage prospect on the international market this year. In fact, some rank him ahead of GPE's PERSON, who has been considered the top player in class of 2016 for close to two years.Here's why: PERSON has shown premier polish, poise and instincts on the mound. He's also extremely competitive and has a fastball that has been clocked in the 90-95 mph range. PERSON has been compared to a young PERSON because of the way he approaches hitters and commands his pitches on the mound.Some evaluators believe PERSON could eventually be a No. 1 or No. 2 starter in the big leagues if he continues to develop at a normal pace. While in GPE, PERSON pitched for GPE's 12-and-under team, 15-and-under team and 18-and-under team. He was the ORGANIZATION of the 15-and-under World Cup in GPE in 2014.PERSON left GPE during the winter of 2015 and trains in the ORGANIZATION with PERSON.

The ORGANIZATION were a fun team to check out in 2015 because of the presence of PERSON and PERSON on the staff. PERSON might have more polish, but PERSON's arm strength gives plenty to be excited about.Based on pure velocity, PERSON has a top of the scale fastball, one that hits 99-101 mph and sits consistently north of 95 mph. A lack of movement and below-average command keep it from being an 80 on the scouting scale. The rest of his stuff is raw. His changeup is a bit more consistent than his breaking pitches and he will show an above-average offspeed pitch from time to time. PERSON is working on both a curve and slider, with the former ahead of the latter, an 11-to-5 breaker with good rotation and depth at times. He started to show the ability to throw strikes more consistently with his secondary pitches during his jump to full-season ball in 2016.With room to fill out and get stronger, PERSON could start repeating his delivery more effectively as he matures. He has a long way to go, but a triple-digit fastball is always a good place to start.

It certainly hasn't come easily for PERSON, the ORGANIZATION' first-round pick in 2013. He's hit a bunch of home runs, he's struck out a lot, he's served an 80-game suspension and he's been traded (from the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION late in 2016). His first full season with PERSON was also his first in Double-A, and it didn't go so well. The ORGANIZATION didn't add him to the 40-man roster, but he was not selected in last December's Rule 5 Draft.While his 2017 season was a disappointment, there were some positive signs, including a reduced strikeout rate and a strong August that saw him hit .316/.393/.481, numbers that perhaps can be used as a springboard. He was adjusting to the ORGANIZATION' approach to hitting, and the organization thinks there's more pure hit tool than he's shown. The raw power is legit, and if he can make more consistent contact, it will show up in games more often.Demerirtte has already shown he can be an excellent defender at second and has more than enough arm for third. He's athletic enough to play the outfield, so the ORGANIZATION might expose him to that in 2018 to help maximize his versatility and value as a power-hitting utility type.

While the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the second round out of high school in 2015, his older brother PERSON went undrafted as a prepster two years earlier. He blossomed into a fifth-round choice out of PERSON in 2016, when he shared PERSON pitcher of the year honors. He ascended to Double-A two years after turning pro and pitched well in five starts there before getting shut down with an oblique injury last July, then made 11 starts at that level in 2019 before requiring PERSON surgery.Lambert succeeds by mixing four pitches that all grade from average to solid. He has added some spin and riding action to his fastball, which sits at 91-94 mph and tops out at 96. His 12-to-6 curveball is his most reliable secondary pitch, while his fading changeup helps him against left-handers and he can land his lateral-breaking slider for strikes.Lambert's athleticism helps him repeat his delivery and throw consistent strikes. He doesn't have much margin for error and helps his cause by being stingy with walks and home runs. With some of the best metrics and polish in the FACILITY system, he has a ceiling of a No. 4 starter.

A ORGANIZATION World Series hero who had two successful seasons in GPE's rotation, PERSON quickly pitched his way to Double-A in his first full season after being drafted in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft. The upper level proved to be a challenge for the left-hander, with adjustments needing to be made for him to keep climbing the ORGANIZATION has three pitches he can throw for strikes at any point in the count, though none of them register as above average. His fastball sits around 90 mph, but he'll attack hitters with it. He does a very nice job of mixing in his average slider and changeup to keep hitters off balance. When he's at his best, he gets groundball outs early in counts. When he got to Double-A, he started nibbling around the zone too much, reverting to a college mentality in trying to miss bats too much. He needs to go back to commanding the baseball the way he's capable and not give hitters too much credit.PERSON is not overly physical, and he had two stints on the disabled list with a forearm strain in 2917, so for him to be able remain as a starter, he needs to be more efficient and in the strike zone early in counts. If he can get back to that mindset, he can get back to making it quickly to the big leagues as a No. 4 or 5 starter.

GPE had done nothing but hit since finding his footing as a 19-year-old in the LOCATION League in 2012. He stumbled a bit in his first taste of Triple-A in 2014, but came on strong in the second half and earned his first big league callup in September. In 2013, he split his time between Class A Advanced Clearwater and Double-A Reading, and he led all Phillies PERSON in batting average (.320), home runs (31) and ORGANIZATION (103).GPE's best tool is his power, which he has begun to tap into more as he matures. His quick hands allow him to drive the ball to all fields. GPE is a bottom-of-the-scale runner.Despite GPE's lack of speed, he is a solid defender at third base and has a strong arm. The Phillies have given him some time at first base, but a position change is not necessarily in store for GPE.

While PERSON was overshadowed at the start of 2013 by PERSON, his teammate with Double-A Chattanooga, he built off his strong finish to the '12 season to make a name for himself last season. PERSON played in the 2013 All-Star Futures Game, and his .497 slugging percentage was the best in the LOCATION League.While none of PERSON's tools truly stand out, he has the potential to be a five-tool player. PERSON has a patient approach at the plate and big raw power. He has proven to be vulnerable against left-handed pitching, and he will need to shore up that part of his game. PERSON is a solid runner, and he makes good use of his speed on the basepaths and in the outfield. PERSON has the range to play center field and an arm strong enough for right field, if necessary.PERSON's father, PERSON, got a cup of coffee with the Dodgers in 1985. PERSON should soon surpass his father's career achievements.

One of the best on-mound athletes in the 2018 AZL, PERSON is a converted shortstop with a delivery that looks an awful lot like PERSON's. The ORGANIZATION acquired him on 40-man crunch day from GPE for depth starter, PERSON. PERSON sits only 88-92, but that should tick up as he physically matures. His fastball has natural cut, and at times, he throws what looks like a true cutter in the 84-87 range. He also has a 12-to-6 curveball that flashes plus. 
PERSON could develop in a number of different ways. PERSON could make a concerted effort to alter his release so PERSON is more behind the ball, creating fastball life/rise that would probably play better with his curveball. Alternatively, they might nurture his natural proclivity for cut, and see what happens. Either way, this is an exciting athlete with workable stuff who'll be 19 all summer. He has a chance to start, which is why he's ahead of several other arms on this list who throw harder/are closer.

The ace of a 2012 ORGANIZATION (Calif.) JC juggernaut that also included outfield prospects PERSON (now with the GPE) and PERSON (GPE), PERSON went in the fourth round of the 2012 Draft. He needed PERSON surgery midway through his first full pro season but returned last June and quickly regained his stuff. He missed the first two months of 2015 with a neck injury before returning in mid-June.PERSON's arm strength has been evident since he was a star quarterback in high school. He operates at 92-94 mph with his fastball, tops out at 96 and has heavy sink that elicits a lot of groundballs. His second option is a low-80s slider that's solid at times but flat at others.Refining his changeup will be crucial to PERSON remaining a starter, and he also needs better control. If he can't add enough polish, he could move to the bullpen and possibly turn into a set-up man.

After the ORGANIZATION blew past their international bonus pool and spent $8.2 million in 2013-14 -- and landing elite prospects PERSON and PERSON in the process -- baseball rules prohibited them from spending more than $250,000 on an individual player in the next signing period. They still found an intriguing hitter in GPE, whom they purchased from the GPE Red Devils in December 2014. He had no trouble making the jump to low Class A at age 19 last year, batting .310 while playing steady defense at second base, though shoulder soreness has hampered him in 2017.GPE's hands work at the plate and in the field as well as those of any ORGANIZATION prospect. With his hand-eye coordination and easy left-handed swing, he repeatedly strokes line drives from gap to gap. He's not physical and won't hit for a lot of power, though he does have some sneaky pop to his pull side.GPE profiles best at second base, where he has exceptional polish for a teenager. He has enough arm strength for third base, where GPE plans on giving him some exposure in 2017, and could make for an intriguing catcher. The one aspect of his game that needs refinement is his baserunning, as he has fringy speed and got caught on 11 of his 15 steal attempts a year ago.

We knew nothing of GPE until he threw after the draft, and now we think he's at least a good relief prospect with a chance to be more. PERSON and physical throughout the torso and thighs, GPE has a lightning-quick arm that generates mid-90s velocity at peak. His fastball has bat-missing life, and both his breaking balls have sufficient bite to avoid barrels as well, especially when they're well-located. He was pushed to the ORGANIZATION fairly quickly after signing and carved up the FACILITY in three and four-inning stints. It may be worth trying to start him but he could move pretty quickly as a reliever.

PERSON was a known high school prospect in the GPE suburbs and, though a few teams nearly met it, his price tag pushed him to Tech where he's grown into one of this draft's top talents. He has elite feel for the position, projecting as an impact defender with a 65-grade arm despite being bigger than most good defensive ctachers. He also does advance work for every game, calls area scouts for gameplan input, and is possibly the only catcher at a major program that calls his own games. Scouts rave about his makeup.

Offensively, PERSON has huge power and has hit some tape measure shots, including a ball that went over the football facility roof in left field at ORGANIZATION and still hasnât been found. He isnât the most selective hitter and doesnât have the loosest swing in the class, but he has some feel for the bat head and doesnât have trouble with velocity. His power and fly-ball based approach along with these issues mean he could be a 40 or 45 bat with about an average walk rate and anywhere from 50 to 60 game power. Some of his strikeouts this year were a result of getting pitched around. He's seen a lot of off-speed pitches and has altered his approach to hit what he was facing, which likely wonât be a big issue in pro ball.

Since PERSON is so advanced defensively, some scouts have speculated that heâll go straight to High-A and could debut in the big leagues in late 2019. This could make him one of those prospects that gets to the big leagues before the holes to his offensive game have been closed because he's so good at everything else. The ORGANIZATION have been all over PERSON all spring and are expected to take him 2nd overall, but he's also a candidate to go 1st if PERSON's medical or bonus demands become problematic.

Over the course of his career at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, PERSON served a number of roles, succeeding as a starter as a sophomore then anchoring the bullpen for a team that made it to the ORGANIZATION World Series finals two years later. The jury is still out about which job might suit him best with the Tigers.PERSON certainly has the stuff to start and he threw well in GPE's rotation, particularly in two stellar playoff starts as the ORGANIZATION won the ORGANIZATION title. His fastball and slider are his go-to pitches, both of which are at least a tick above-average. He has a feel for a changeup, though it's a bit behind the other two and he's generally around the strike zone. PERSON had PERSON surgery in 2013 and he missed two months in 2015 with a strained pectoral muscle. Some worry about his durability as a starter.He'll continue developing as one for now to see how it goes. He is an intense competitor with a bulldog mentality that would work well coming out of the bullpen and there's a chance his stuff will play up in relief stints, allowing him to move more quickly through the system.

PERSON has all the catcherly intangibles you can think of and scouts have been wholly unsurprised that GPE has pushed him up the minor league ladder at a speed that might be considered a bit quick since catcher development is typically taken very slowly. He went straight to the ORGANIZATION at age 17, then to a ORGANIZATION packed with 21-year-olds at age 18. PERSON works hard enough that scouts from opposing clubs have taken notice; his leadership qualities have been evident during two postseason runs (circumstances that are helping to drive the 'winning player' narrative here) in two pro seasons. He's a bat-first catcher with some pull power and an above-average arm. He's raw on defense and is already a sturdily built young man who may overthicken and become immobile, but based on the makeup reports it sounds like PERSON will do what is necessary to stay back there. Teen catching prospects are risky. This one seems like a potential everyday backstop if everything breaks right, but it's more likely he becomes a backup.

A mainstay on the high school showcase circuit, PERSON kicked his game up a notch in his senior season opener, reaching 95 mph with his fastball during an 18-strikeout perfect game. But if he performs like a standard 40-inning reliever, like PERSON, and quintessential fourth outfielder, like PERSON, he'll generate 1.5 to 2 annual WAR, combined.

PERSON has produced since he arrived at ORGANIZATION, starting with winning Big 12 Conference Freshman of the Year honors in 2017. The Big 12 Conference co-player of the year, he lets his power come naturally and his bat speed and strength should translate into 25 or more homers per year once he turns on more pitches. He manages the strike zone very well and has no shortcomings in his offensive game.Though PERSON is a below-average runner, he's reasonably athletic and makes enough plays at third base. He has the strong arm required at the hot corner and should be able to stay there. His instincts help him make up for his lack of quickness in the field -- the ORGANIZATION moved him to shortstop in mid-April -- and on the bases.

For the second straight year, the state of ORGANIZATION features one of the top two-sport athletes in the GPE. Unlike many two-sport stars, having his attention divided hasn't prevented him from developing a good swing and learning to make adjustments at the plate. With his bat speed and strength, he's a threat to hit for power as well as average.PERSON's instincts aren't as refined on defense, where he's shaky in center field despite his plus speed. He has improved his arm strength from weak to fringy in the last year.

In a deep crop of talent in GPE, PERSON had been a known commodity, one who participated in summer events like the ORGANIZATION and PERSON. He does show an ability to spin a breaking ball, though he doesn't always stay on top of it, which keeps it from having enough bite at times. While he does come across his body a bit, that adds some deception and there's ease in his delivery that points to good command in the future.PERSON's size, stuff and athleticism should interest teams in the top three rounds, and there could be more in the tank as he focuses on pitching only. ORGANIZATION (Calif.) PERSON was a good place to go looking for college shortstops in the 2015 Draft, with ORGANIZATION's PERSON going No. 2 overall to the ORGANIZATION and PERSON, the PERSON-Lafayette product, going to the Reds in the third round, beating alum PERSON by 17 spots as the highest-drafted position player ever from the school.Though he played third and second base in deference to PERSON on the GPE collegiate national team last summer, PERSON is capable of sticking at shortstop in pro ball. He'll need to improve his pitch recognition and learn to tone down his approach to take better advantage of his quickness.

The ORGANIZATION liked PERSON so much that they drafted him twice. He's an average runner whose instincts help him on the bases and in the field.PERSON played exclusively at shortstop in his pro debut and split time between there and third base in 2017. He has fringy range at short but still manages to make his share of plays, and his solid arm works anywhere in the infield. Given his offensive and defensive capabilities, he fits best at second base.

GPE is one of the youngest players in this year's class and won't be able to sign until he turns 16 in GPE, but that has not stopped scouts from raving about his potential.A physically mature third baseman with soft hands and an accurate plus-arm, GPE is a solid defender with good footwork around the bag. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON was a ORGANIZATION Champion in the 2015 16U ORGANIZATION and has made eight All-Tournament teams in four years with numerous different spring and fall travel squads. A boiler plate middle relief prospect, PERSON was added to the 40-man this offseason and may debut in 2019. His changeup is firm, but continued reps in a rotation should help improve his feel for it and better prepare him to deal with left-handed hitters in the big leagues.

Named the ORGANIZATION of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON continued his strong play the next spring, as he finished second in the country in hitting and led PERSON to PERSON in the ORGANIZATION. He has good raw power, but his swing produces more doubles than home runs. PERSON has elite athleticism for a catcher, and it gives scouts confidence that he will be able to remain behind the plate. PERSON wasn't a high-profile signing when he turned pro out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, and his career has taken a while to get going. Both of his secondary pitches need more consistency, but his hard slider shows flashes of becoming a plus offering, and his changeup has a chance to become at least average.PERSON has matured significantly on the mound in 2016, doing a better job of challenging hitters and throwing strikes. He's gaining an understanding of sequencing pitches and recognizing swings that he has lacked in the past. An 11th-round pick out of GPE in 2015 by the ORGANIZATION, PERSON has seen his stuff get better in pro ball, enabling him to make a quick rise through the Minors. PERSON spent 2018 at ORGANIZATION before he was effectively showcased in the ORGANIZATION. He has bat-missing, big league stuff, sitting 92-95 and touching 96 in multi-inning ORGANIZATION appearances, and sitting comfortably in the 95-96 range when he was asked to air it out for a single inning. PERSON also has elite breaking ball spin rates. His 12-6 curveball spins in excess of 3,000 rpm and his firm, upper-80s slider/cutter often approaches that mark, which is rare for a breaking ball that hard. He also has a unique delivery that disorients hitters, during which his arm wraps behind his lower back. His arm action is ugly but, short of a 7-day DL stint this year after he was hit with a comebacker, PERSON hasnât been hurt as a pro. 
His usage has been atypical, however. His starts were often spaced out by seven or eight days in 2018, and itâs unrealistic to expect him to have that kind of recovery time between turns on a big league pitching staff. If asked to throw every fifth day, his stuff may not be as nasty as it was this year. He projects as a No. 4 or 5 starter but may also be deployed in a multi-inning relief role.

While scouts were split on PERSON in terms of playable now tools vs. rawness, he was nonetheless ranked No. 16 on MLBPipeline.com's Top 30 ORGANIZATION list heading into the July 2 signing period. The ORGANIZATION liked what they saw, giving the GPE $1.25 million as part of an aggressive push in the Latin GPE market.Some feel PERSON will be able to help a big league team in a short time, while others feel he looks crude in the field. Some of that has to do with a lack of a true defensive home, with the 21-year-old playing mostly second base and center field, though he did play shortstop in the GPE junior leagues. He has good speed, which gives him good range wherever he plays, though he understandably needs work on his reads and routes in the outfield since he lacks experience out there. Those who watched him in GPE, where he went after leaving GPE, feel he can play up the middle somewhere. PERSON's speed, along with strong instrincts, allows him to be a basestealing threat. At the plate, he has outstanding bat control and an advanced approach. He could have enough power to reach double digits in the home run department.With the investment the ORGANIZATION made, they clearly feel PERSON has the tools to be an everyday player at the big league level. Now it will be up to the player development staff to figure out just where he fits best to maximize his potential.

PERSON is an imposing physical presence in the batter's box and has the body of work to back it up. While injuries derailed his first year in full-season ball, his bat has earned him a place in the ORGANIZATION' next wave of young prospects.  PERSON has a smooth swing that is geared to hitting line drives from gap to gap. He has a good feel for hitting and solid raw power to go with it. As he matures, he may grow into even more power. Originally signed as an outfielder, his below-average arm and speed forced him to move to first base. He's a work in progress there, but has the tools to become an average defender in time.  PERSON earns praise for his makeup and work ethic. He'll need to hit to keep advancing, but that shouldn't be a problem.

The younger brother of PERSON, PERSON is another power-throwing college arm. But before figuring out exactly what his future role is, PERSON needs to stay healthy on the mound for an extended period of time.

It might shock you to learn that PERSON's 2018 line of .180/.324/.370 was a hair above the average ORGANIZATION batting line. In high school, he was your standard high risk, high reward corner power projection bat. A monstrous and athletic 6-foot-5 (there's a rumor PERSON offered him a hoops walk-on opportunity in an effort to get him to campus), PERSON drew body and swing comps to PERSON. 
But as he has accumulated statistics in pro ball, he looks much more unique than his profile's bird's eye view would indicate. He strikes out 30% of the time, which is fairly common for prospects like this. But he incredibly only slugged .370 last year while still managing to homer 22 times, and PERSON's ground ball rate is a minuscule 28%. He walked at an encouraging 16% clip last year. He'd be higher on most other teams' prospect lists; we just prefer the ultra-young, up-the-middle guys in this system to a profile like PERSON's, and GPE has lots of those.

PERSON has teamed up with first baseman PERSON in full-season ball to form a powerful infield duo. With PERSON in 2014, PERSON hit 29 home runs and PERSON added 37. But when he's at his best, he uses the whole field to hit and does a good job of hunting fastballs he can drive. Defensively, PERSON remains a work in progress. He's shown signs he's getting better and dramatically cut down on his errors in 2014. The A's began playing him some at first base for the first time in 2015.

After the ORGANIZATION whiffed on PERSON and PERSON with first-round picks in the 1995 and 1996 Drafts, they didn't take a high school right-hander that early again until 2014. His mechanics and lightning arm speed produce nasty stuff, starting with a fastball that sits in the low 90s, touches 97 mph and figures to get quicker as he fills out his projectable 6-foot-4 frame. The ORGANIZATION took a gamble on PERSON in the third round of the 2012 Draft, knowing that his commitment to play football at LOCATION could make him difficult to sign. After a strong start to his 2017 campaign with Double-A New Hampshire, PERSON was called up for his big league debut in May, only to suffer a broken hamate bone and land on the disabled list for two months. The injury bug struck PERSON again in GPE Training, with a Grade 2 hamstring strain delaying his start to the 2018 season.PERSON generates good bat speed and makes a lot of hard contact from the right side of the plate. His mature approach and solid pitch recognition translate to plenty of walks and strong on-base skills that fuel his potential as a true top-of-the-order hitter. He has the strength and swing plane to drive the ball out of the park, shows good raw power to center field and could clear more fences as he continues to refine his approach. PERSON's knee injury diminished his speed last season, but he's still a plus, if not better runner capable of impacting games on the bases as well as in center field, where he has plus range but a below-average arm.PERSON didn't receive another crack at the Majors in September because the ORGANIZATION felt it was more important for him to receive guaranteed at-bats in Triple-A while making up for lost time. Meanwhile, PERSON's transformation from a raw athlete into a well-rounded and polished ballplayer in a short amount of time understandably has club officials excited about his bright future.

GPE was up to 96 mph as an 15-year-old amateur, eventually going unsigned on July 2nd due in part to 20 command. Then he hit 100 mph as an amateur with improved feel, which is when the ORGANIZATION scooped him up for $300,000. He was the highest variance player on last year's version of this list and is once again. The pure stuff hasn't change and it's top of the line: a 95-97 mph heater that has hit 101 mph, a power curveball that's anywhere from 60 to 70 depending on the day, and a changeup that flashes 55 or 60 at its best. His command is now a 30 that we project to be a 40. But he's still a teenager, so there's a chance that things click for him and he finds 45 command and 50 control, which would be the minimum to stick as a starter with this kind of stuff. GPE's issues aren't physical -- his delivery is fine and his arm stroke is clean. Instead, the problem appears to be mostly mental. He'll throw well in the bullpen, only to have things will snowball for him in game situations. One source described his issues as stemming from a need for greater mental maturity and to not be so hard on himself, which are exactly the kinds of traits that come with general social maturity. That said, this sort of stuff rarely comes with starter command, so GPE is probably either a high-wire act reliever with bonkers stuff or a starter with the stuff ratcheted down a bit, similar to what PERSON has done the last couple seasons.

Signed for $225,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON' eye-opening GPE debut the following year saw him finish the season as the youngest everyday player in the Class A Short PERSON York-Penn League. He's a few years away from the Majors, but PERSON is well on his way towards becoming a franchise player.

PERSON signed too late out of the 2011 Draft to play, so he made his professional debut in 2012 and promptly finished eighth in the GPE League in hitting. ORGANIZATION sat out his first year at ORGANIZATION and went homerless in 2013 before starting to turn on the power as a redshirt sophomore in 2014. PERSON strength is his best defensive tool, but he lacks quickness and has stiff hands. He started his pro career at third base and could become adequate at the hot corner.

After dominating as a ORGANIZATION State sophomore and leading the ORGANIZATION in strikeouts in 2015, GPE was named the 2016 Mid-American ORGANIZATION of the Year after a spectacular season in which he allowed just three earned runs in his final 12 starts and ultimately led all ORGANIZATION Division I hurlers with a 0.69 ERA, the lowest for a starter at that level since 1979. GPE has crossfire to his delivery, but his athleticism allows him to repeat those mechanics and throw quality strikes, all the while creating significant deception. While he doesn't have a true out pitch or a lofty ceiling, GPE projects as a mid-rotation starter and he may have a higher floor than any lefty in the 2016 Draft.

PERSON broke out in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2014, setting career highs in numerous offensive categories while also making strides behind the plate. His arm strength is his best asset, one that has helped him throw out nearly 41 percent of would-be basestealers in his career entering 2016, but he'll need to improve his below-average receiving skills to stick behind the plate.

An outstanding athlete who played football in high school, ORGANIZATION gave up the gridiron to focus on the diamond and take a baseball scholarship to GPE. PERSON used him mostly at first base and ORGANIZATION, while PERSON broke him into pro ball as a left fielder. PERSON pitched in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON during his first season with his third organization but also saw his control and command regress significantly.With a quick arm and little effort, PERSON sits at 95-98 mph with the ability to reach triple digits in the late innings. GPE went undrafted out of high school and missed most of his sophomore season at FACILITY with a broken wrist, then broke out in the ORGANIZATION in the summer of 2014. He built on that momentum by leading ORGANIZATION Division I in runs (88), hits (108), total bases (188) and slugging (.749), which helped earn him a second-round selection in the ORGANIZATION and a $1.7 million bonus.GPE excels at the plate with a compact left-handed swing, feel for the barrel and advanced approach. The only negative in GPE' toolset is his well below-average arm, which rules out right field.

PERSON's development has been a rollercoaster after going in the first round in 2013 out of an Atlanta-area high school. He's always has plus raw power, but his motor, defensive home and in-game contact/power balance have varied year-to-year.

Put simply, PERSON can rake.The outfielder has an above-average hit tool and is one of the most dominant hitters on the market. PERSON also consider him one of the more polished bats in this year's class.PERSON has a graceful swing, and although he doesn't have a ton of raw power, he has a knack for barreling balls. He also doesn't swing and miss very often. What's more, the gap power he displays is expected to improve as he develops.PERSON has an average arm and good instincts on defense. Some believed PERSON would be in the competition for the overall top player in the class, but his run tool has quite literally kept him out of that race. That said, PERSON has shown skills on both sides of the ball, and he shines in games.In other words, he's a gamer.PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $1.5 million.

PERSON has a track record of success that stacks up against any high schooler in the 2015 class. He won both his starts, giving up two hits and no runs in 13 innings as PERSON took the gold medal. PERSON had injury issues and moved back and forth from the rotation to the bullpen in college. In the 'pen, sits upper-90s with life and angle. Breaking stuff has nasty, vertical action.

The ORGANIZATION spent a franchise-record $74.2 million on bonuses and penalties for their 2014-15 international class, including $63 million in a bonus and tax for PERSON and $8,000 for PERSON. The best pitching prospect out of GPE and the top hurler overall in this year's class, PERSON is smart and fearless on the mound. The ORGANIZATION are no strangers to being aggressive on the international market, particularly when GPE players become available. PERSON was an eligible sophomore last year and went late, but went in the second round this year after a loud spring as a 22-year-old. He may not have a 60 tool but is a solid player with a fierce beard/mullet combo.

Teams who like premium athletes currently playing premium positions will certainly give PERSON a long look and his stock was rising quickly as the GPE approached.His best tool is his speed and he has plenty of it as a guy who should be a basestealing threat in the future. PERSON began his college career at GPE (GPE) JC in 2014 before transferring to GPE, where he suffered serious head injuries and needed subsequent gall bladder surgery after his car was rear-ended in a high-speed accident. Switch-hitting infielder with medium build. Is more polish/feel to hit than tools/projection.

The ORGANIZATION bucked the industry consensus by taking high school infielders PERSON and PERSON with their first two choices in the 2013 Draft. Â PERSON was largely overlooked as an undersized high school right-hander in 2011, but the ORGANIZATION liked him enough to take a chance on him in the 26th round. PERSON jumped on the radar with a strong summer showcase circuit showing at a number of events. Every ORGANIZATION class has what's known as "pop-up" guys, players who may not have registered over the summer or even early in the spring, but then take a leap forward performance-wise, sending scouts scurrying to see them and driving them up ORGANIZATION boards. PERSON is polarizing, in that some clubs don't like his low slot and high back elbow, while others see a cleaner delivery, better command and a more projectable frame than PERSON's former travel ball teammate, PERSON.

Back from a 2017 ACL tear, PERSON hit for characteristically high rates of contact in 2018. He's a thicker guy and has begun to see more time at other positions (mostly other infield spots), and versatility will enable a team to roster PERSON even if the lack of power turns out to be a problem. It's not often an undrafted free-agent signing makes it onto a prospect list, especially at the very start of his career, but PERSON is an unusual case. People who watch PERSON hit might do a little bit of a double-take. The LOCATION high school standout purposefully has patterned his approach, setup and swing after PERSON. GPE ORGANIZATION might get more of the attention in terms of high-end PERSON talent, but the northern part of the state should not be ignored. After two nondescript years at ORGANIZATION, PERSON jumped on the radar with a strong junior season, building off an All-Star campaign in the ORGANIZATION League the previous summer. There were few prospects in all of the ORGANIZATION Leagues who broke out more than PERSON did in 2012. The grandson of former big league catcher PERSON, PERSON caught the eye of scouts by pitching well in the ORGANIZATION during the summer of 2015 and as a junior at FACILITY's (Calif.) the following spring. He did little to distinguish himself in his first two pro seasons after signing for $75,000 as a 14th-rounder in 2016, but he broke out and led all Minor League left-handers with 171 strikeouts in 135 1/3 innings last year. He has enjoyed more success against left-handers than right-handers, and he should have a floor as at least a situational reliever. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON right-hander out of ORGANIZATION, PERSON has also been named to five all-tournament teams at ORGANIZATION Game events and was a second-team All-Section III performer in Division I this past year.PERSON boasts a fastball, curveball and changeup in his arsenal. The timing of the injury means PERSON may not pitch until 2020, when he'll be 24. There's a chance he pitches in GPE next fall or perhaps in the ORGANIZATION, but if not, he'll just be a 40 on our lists until we see that the stuff is back.

Like his fellow countryman PERSON, PERSON received a seven-figure bonus when the ORGANIZATION singed him out of GPE in July 2012. PERSON also made his professional debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2013 and held his own as a 17-year-old. He throws his fastball in the low 90s and mixes it with a changeup and curveball. GPE PERSON outside of GPE has had a fair share of drafted prospects, most notably outfielder PERSON, a second rounder in 2011 currently with the FACILITY. His ceiling is somewhat limited, but he has the chance to move quickly as a No. 4 or 5 type starter.

PERSON was considered by many to be one of the top prospects in the 2012 Draft, but he fell to the Pirates at ORGANIZATION. 8 for a variety of reasons. PERSON GPE has sent 11 pitchers to the big leagues since the turn of the century, and PERSON is talented enough to add to that total. An unheralded recruit out of GPE (Mo.) High, where he broke a 45-year-old career scoring record in basketball, he earned a spot in the GPE rotation at the outset of his freshman season. But there also are times when his heater and slider lose some power and flatten out.PERSON has yet to show much feel for a changeup and also possesses a curveball that isn't as reliable as his slider. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON is an ORGANIZATION State commit who has been outstanding in travel leagues, landing on five All-Tournament squads -- including one with the ORGANIZATION scout team -- and a Most Valuable Player award at the 2016 18U ORGANIZATION Day Classic. He has also won three ORGANIZATION championships.Hauver makes quality contact at the plate. He is developing power thanks to his solid build. As he prepares to make contact, the infielder has an even stance and uses a leg lift as a trigger, following the motion with a loose, compact swing.Hauver reads defensive hops properly in the field. His feet work in sync, and he has average arm strength for his position.

After PERSON came out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE and dominated both in his pro debut and in the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he looked poised to get to GPE in a hurry. PERSON's fastball has taken off in the last couple of years. He has refined his delivery since signing for $100,000 as a 12th-rounder in 2012, and his heater now has climbed into the upper 90s and topped triple digits.PERSON backs up his fastball with a hard slider and even shows some feel for a changeup. He still needs to improve his control and command, though he does a good job of keeping the ball down in the strike zone.After reaching low Class A in his first full year as a pro, PERSON could be ready to move quickly after dominant showings in the ORGANIZATION and PERSON leagues during the offseason. PERSON's first full professional season saw him start the All-Star Game for the GPE League before moving up to Double-A Pensacola for the second half.
