When he was a member of the ORGANIZATION' system, PERSON was often compared to PERSON for his stuff and deception. It didn't take long for PERSON to get to the big leagues and PERSON could be on a similar track.

PERSON has among the most impressive tools in the draft with the pure speed to comfortably project in center field as well as big raw power and arm strength. He's sushi raw and has struggled to hit, even against mediocre pitching as this spring has progressed, but he's also one of the class' youngest players and some orgs are projecting heavily on the bat because of PERSON' combination of youth and athleticism.

When 'pitchability' is one of the first words a scout uses to describe a teenager, we don't generally expect that teenager to also throw in the mid-90s. But such is the case with PERSON, who has a remarkable early-career ability to manipulate the shape of a fastball that touches 96. He can cut it, sink it, use variations in sequence together, and has feel for dumping in first-pitch curveballs for strikes. PERSON is still a lanky teenager who has problems repeating his delivery, so while he has obvious on-mound creativity, he doesn't always execute, and his ability to locate needs to develop. Aside from the fastball, PERSON's stuff is, or projects to be, close to average, and his likely long-term fit is at the back of a rotation. As soon as his command starts to improve, he'll be capable of carving up the lower levels by mixing in all these pitches, and if it happens in 2019, he could end the year with Low-A Charleston.

A Draft-eligible sophomore out of GPE when the ORGANIZATION took him in the ORGANIZATION B in 2016, GPE cemented his profile as a bat-first backstop with a solid first full season that saw him play across two levels of A ball. After reaching Double-A for the first time, the ORGANIZATION dealt him with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.GPE has shown that his power will play. That's especially true from the left side of the plate, where his pop is at least average and he's hit the majority of his home runs as a pro, though he has 45 power from the right side as well. There is some swing and miss, and he's never going to hit for more than average, but he's also willing to be selective in waiting for a pitch to drive, with the ultimate goal of lifting the ball in the air.GPE is less advanced defensively, but he has made progress and worked hard behind the plate. After throwing out roughly 22 percent of attempted basestealers in his first full season, he pushed that number up to 40 percent in 2018. He'll never wow anyone back there, but there is confidence he'll be capable enough to stay there. That gives him the chance to be a switch-hitting, offensive-minded big league regular catcher with power.

GPE and physical, PERSON has an exciting combination of speed and power, as well as promising ball/strike recognition. What he appears to lack at this point is barrel control and a bat path that enables the power. Those are important components and may not be easy to fix, especially the bat control issue. But PERSON's ball/strike and breaking ball recognition could help mitigate those issues, and his ceiling (a high ORGANIZATION center fielder with power) is lofty if they're overcome. A max-effort player with a fairly mature build, PERSON seems poised to have a strong statistical summer against ORGANIZATION pitching and defenses, perhaps enough that he'll see some LOCATION time late in the year.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON away from being a two-sport star at FACILITY A&M in 2013 and while he threw well during his full-season debut, a shoulder issue caused a drop in velocity and shut him down for most of the last six weeks of the season. PERSON and rehab appear to have righted the ship.PERSON has the upside of a future frontline starter. He'll throw his fastball up to 96 mph with good movement. His slider is his best secondary pitch, a power breaking ball thrown in the 84-86 mph range that can be an effective out pitch. PERSON also throws a curve and a changeup, both of which show signs of being PERSON average. PERSON brings a football-like competitiveness to the mound and while his walk rate went up in 2015, he's generally around the zone. Managing his Type 1 PERSON does not appear like it will be an issue. Aside from making sure the shoulder stays sound, the only concern surrounding PERSON is that he didn't miss as many bats as you'd expect, given his pure stuff. Still just 20 years old, there's time for him to learn how to use that stuff to his advantage more consistently.

| Overall:45PERSON and his outstanding defensive skills have now twice been included in trades. The first was the 10-player deal that sent him from GPE to GPE in July 2012. Just over two years later, in November 2014, PERSON was sent, along with right-hander PERSON, to the ORGANIZATION in return for PERSON Conger.A very solid defensive receiver, PERSON moves well behind the plate, with good footwork, a quick release and a strong arm that has allowed him to throw out 33 percent of would-be basestealers throughout his career. His glove has carried him through the ORGANIZATION and it's what should get him to the big leagues soon. He's not completely lost at the plate, with a line-drive stroke, a little gap power and a tendency to make contact.Right now, he profiles best as a solid, glove-first, big league backup. If the bat can develop, he has the chance to be a defensive-minded regular down the road.

PERSON has made steady improvement since signing out of GPE as a 17-year-old in 2010. He made a big jump in 2013 when he reached Double-A Bowie, and then finished the year as the starting pitcher in the ORGANIZATION championship game. The ORGANIZATION used him as trade bait at the 2014 Deadline, sending him to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON Miller.Initially more of a command-and-control lefty, PERSON has grown into his lanky frame and has seen his velocity jump as a result. He now throws his fastball in the low 90s, with good sink and movement. PERSON pairs his fastball with a hard changeup and a tight slider, both of which grade out as at least average offerings.PERSON wasn't quite as sharp in 2014, but at 21 years old, he's young for Double-A, and he still profiles as a possible middle-of-the rotation starter.

After a solid first full professional season in 2013, PERSON exploded in 2014. He dominated the ORGANIZATION in the first half of the season for Double-A Arkansas and was included in the package the PERSON sent to the ORGANIZATION in exchange for PERSON just after the All-Star break. PERSON made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in September, but his ORGANIZATION career was short-lived. In December, he was traded again, this time to the A's as a part of the deal that sent PERSON to GPE Diego.PERSON is all power on the mound. His fastball sits around 95 mph and can edge higher on the radar gun. After struggling to throw his curveball for strikes, PERSON replaced it with a slider that has quickly become a solid offering. He also occasionally mixes in a changeup.The PERSON didn't use PERSON much as a closer, but he has the stuff to pitch high-leverage innings. After getting his first taste of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON should soon be ready for a more regular role at that level.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 38th round of the 2016 Draft after he had a strong redshirt sophomore season, but he opted to return to ORGANIZATION. It turned out to be a wise move, as PERSON was the LOCATION player of the year and hit himself up to the ORGANIZATION. 35 overall pick, where the ORGANIZATION finally got their man to sign for full pick value.PERSON hit well with wood bats in summer leagues several times over, so a transition to the pro game shouldn't be too tough. His offensive game rose to a new level this spring when he adjusted his swing, used his lower half more and quickened his right-handed stroke. He showed an ability to get to his power more consistently, with improved plate discipline another contributing factor.PERSON runs better than you'd think given his size, with average run times out of the box and more once he gets going. He played first at ORGANIZATION, but he had played the outfield previously and the ORGANIZATION sent him out to start his pro career in left field.

Though PERSON had a track record of success and offered some of the best pitchability among high school pitchers in the 2015 Draft, his lack of physicality and a big-time fastball enabled the ORGANIZATION to get him in the second round. Since signing for $1,495,000, he thrived as a youngster in tough pitching environments in each of his first three pro seasons. The youngest ORGANIZATION qualifier in the GPE League by nearly a year at age 20 in 2017, he ranked fourth in the high Class A circuit at 4.17 despite pitching in GPE, possibly the best hitter's park in the Minors.PERSON shows the potential for four pitches that could be at least solid. His fastball sits at 92-94 mph and peaks at 96, and he keeps it off barrels with sink, angle and very good command. His tumbling changeup may be his most consistent plus pitch, though his low-80s curveball can be even better than that at times.Last year, PERSON added a slider that can reach the mid-80s and continues to improve as he throws it more. He repeats his clean delivery with efficiency and uses his high three-quarters arm slot to pound the bottom of the strike zone. He looks like a future No. 3 starter and perhaps more if he can get stronger and add more velocity.

If you wanted to see the very top of the D-backs' 2017 Draft class during their summer debuts, GPE in the short-season LOCATION was the place to go as first-rounder PERSON and ORGANIZATION B pick PERSON joined PERSON, the second-round pick out of PERSON, in a formidable lineup. PERSON got off to a good start, but tailed off in the second half.PERSON was teammates with ORGANIZATION. 4 overall pick PERSON, but it was PERSON who led PERSON in batting average, home runs and ORGANIZATION in 2017. He has the chance to hit for average and power and did so in the beginning of his debut before he struggled. He has easy raw power to all fields and has shown some feel to hit. He managed his strikeouts for the most part in college, drawing walks, and that carried over in GPE before he started to press and got out of his approach. Coming out of school, there were concerns about his defense, with some thinking he'd eventually move to first, but the D-backs were pleasantly surprised with how he handled the hot corner and don't have concerns about his future there.For PERSON to reach his potential as a power-hitting third baseman, he'll have to make sure he makes enough contact to tap into that power. The D-backs don't think there will be carry-over from his fade at the end of 2017 in his first full pro season.

GPE and toolsy, PERSON originally signed with the ORGANIZATION as a 17-year-old in 2005. He quickly proved to be an all-out performer in all facets of the game, but he has struggled to stay healthy since having two knee surgeries in 2011. PERSON was never able to truly break through in the ORGANIZATION outfield and was non-tendered in 2013. He signed with the GPE, where he will try to turn his promise into production. With quick hands, PERSON makes a lot of contact, but he also swings at just about everything. He doesn't strike out much, but he doesn't walk much, either. He has excellent speed that works on the basepaths and in the outfield. He has played center but profiles better in right field. He also has raw power that he's still learning how to use. PERSON has played in the ORGANIZATION in each of the past two years and could soon return there in GPE.

After being the consensus best catcher in the 2015 Draft class, PERSON went No. 11 overall and performed well in his pro debut. He needed a mulligan for his first full season, however, as a concussion, and then a wrist injury, kept him off the field and from important development time for much of the year. He was making strides in return to action in 2017 when a thumb ligament injury ended his season in July.The good news is that the ORGANIZATION high school product is still only 20 years old and he hasn't lost any of the tools that made him a first-round pick. At the plate, he has shown good on-base skills and can drive the ball to all fields. There should be more power to come as he grows into his 6-foot-4 frame. That is not the ideal size for a backstop, but PERSON does have arm strength and agility, especially for his size. He will need to continue to work on his footwork and to quicken his release. He spent a lot of time with former big league catcher PERSON in 2016 and was able to learn a lot about the mental side of catching, even when he was out of action.It looked like PERSON was starting to show why he was so highly coveted in the 2015 Draft class when the injury bug hit again. He'll have to try to hit another reset button in 2018.

PERSON showed glimpses of talent at ORGANIZATION (Mo.) High and got drafted by the Royals in the 33rd round in 2016, but no one envisioned him blossoming into potentially PERSON's first position-player first-rounder ever. He fouled a ball off his right foot and broke it last spring, costing him the final two months of his sophomore season and all of last summer. He has the best all-around tools in the 2019 college crop, though a rough spring in LOCATION play leaves his Draft status somewhat uncertain.PERSON's bat speed, strength and the leverage in his 6-foot-4 frame give him huge raw power that he's just beginning to tap into. He's a polished hitter with a sound left-handed swing, good balance and a mature approach that had him leading ORGANIZATION Division I in walks when he got hurt in 2018. He also has plus speed and the aptitude to steal bases, making him a 20-20 threat.After playing mostly left field as a freshman and a lot of first base as a sophomore, PERSON has looked comfortable in center field this spring. He has the quickness and strong arm to patrol anywhere in the outfield, with a chance to stick in center in pro ball and the tools to profile well in right. PERSON love his makeup as well.

After signing for $2.475 million as the 12th overall pick in the 2012 Draft, PERSON reached high Class A and performed well as an 18-year-old at the end of his pro debut. He returned to that level in '13, and his season couldn't have gone any worse -- he ranked last in the ORGANIZATION in hitting (.178) and first in strikeouts (160 in just 383 at-bats). Back at Winston-Salem again in 2014, PERSON has regrouped and looked much better at the plate.A year ago, the FACILITY thought PERSON got too focused on trying to race to the big leagues. In 2014, he showed better balance, pitch recognition and strike-zone discipline. PERSON will still pile up some strikeouts and may never hit for a high average, but he should be able to tap into his considerable raw power.PERSON has the best all-around tools in the system, though that won't mean much if he can't make consistent contact at the plate. His power, speed and arm strength all grade as above average, and he plays a solid center field. PERSON 6-foot-3 and 220 pounds, PERSON projects to move to right field once he fills out.

PERSON is a late-blooming power arm who took a step forward stuff-wise in 2018, but didn't take a step forward statistically until he was put in the bullpen for the last month of the season in the short-season GPE. After the full-time shift, PERSON threw 16.2 IP with 19 K and 3 BB. It's not as simple as you may think, with most of those relief outings going multiple innings, so it seemed to be more of a mental adjustment than being better in short stints, with some sources telling us his confidence increased in that role. PERSON will turn 22 in May and has a career 6.28 ERA with no experience outside of short-season leagues, so there are some clear concerns. On the other hand, he sits 96-100 and has hit 102 mph, mixing in a curveball that's plus at times, though he struggles to command it. His delivery is athletic and easy, and he'll throw an occasional low-90s changeup that is usable. PERSON needed more innings at a low level of competition to build into 2019 and went to the GPE ORGANIZATION this winter, throwing 13.1 IP with 19 K and 2 BB. At this point, PERSON is similar to a position player who converted to pitching in college and is now draft eligible with huge stuff but little polish; that guy goes roughly in the third round, which is right about where we have him pegged here, but he needs to move quickly and perform now that he's found his role.

As GPE has made slow progress in the ORGANIZATION system -- two summers in the ORGANIZATION, then his 2015 GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION League -- he has shown glimpses of his considerable set of tools. His first two years of full-season ball have been more of the same, with the ORGANIZATION excited to see what comes next.GPE plays the game with passion and without fear. He's very aggressive at the plate and definitely doesn't go up looking to walk. Breaking balls still give him some trouble, and he chases pitches out of the zone too frequently, but when he's under control, he has considerable offensive skills. He has the ability to make solid contact to all fields and while he hasn't shown any semblance of power to date, the ORGANIZATION feel there's a chance he'll still grow into some. His speed allows him to steal some bases. He's also an outstanding defender with a strong arm, one who has shown the ability to play both center and right.GPE might have as much ceiling as any position player in the ORGANIZATION system, even if he's still far away from reaching it. The end result could very well be a solid everyday outfielder in the big leagues.

A big-bodied corner infielder with easy plus raw power, PERSON heated up as postseason play began and raised his stock. He projects over to first base (where he plays when PERSON is ptiching) but could see time at third base early in his career to see if he can stick. His fluid extension through contact is gorgeous and he has the raw power to profile at first base, but whether or not the hit/power combo will be enough is questionable.

When looking at the numbers PERSON has put up in his two years in the GPE, itâs important to keep in mind the ORGANIZATION sent him straight to the full-season ORGANIZATION at age 19 for his stateside debut, then moved up a level in 2012. He definitely has some ability with the bat and has the chance to have above-average power, which really started showing up during his 2012 season in the ORGANIZATION. Heâs an aggressive free-swinger who will have to improve his plate discipline a bit to become a better all-around hitter. He has the defensive tools, from range to arm, to stick at shortstop, but heâs also seen time at second base, giving him the positional flexibility heâll need once PERSON catches up to him.

The ORGANIZATION spent more than $150 million on bonuses, guaranteed salaries and penalty tax on international players during the 2015-16 signing period, and none of them have a higher ceiling than PERSON. A GPE defector who cost GPE Angeles a $16 million bonus and a matching amount in tax, he had a reputation for wildness but showed a surprising amount of polish in his 2016 pro debut. PERSON woes reappeared last season when the ORGANIZATION promoted him aggressively, yet he was overpowering when he found the strike zone.Few pitchers can match PERSON's combination of athleticism and arm speed, which allows him to sit at 94-97 mph into the late innings and reach 101 mph with life on his fastball while exerting little effort. However, his heater can get hit hard when he can't locate it down in the strike zone. Similarly, his upper-80s slider can be a wipeout pitch but also can be ineffective when he can't get it over the plate.PERSON's struggled even more in 2017 with his changeup, which was too firm to throw hitters off balance. He also has messed around with a hard curveball, though refining his slider is a greater priority. If he can't deliver more strikes after his walk rate jumped from 3.2 per nine innings in 2016 to 4.9 last year, his projection will change from frontline starter to high-leverage reliever.

PERSON helped lead LOCATION High School to the Mississippi 4A state championship this spring and was then drafted 36th overall by the PERSON. The pick raised some eyebrows around the industry, but the PERSON believed he had some of the best catch-and-throw skills in the GPE class. PERSON has a strong arm and was clocked up to 92 mph when he pitched for LOCATION. At 6-foot-3, he has a large frame for a catcher, but his athleticism gives him a chance to remain behind the plate. He is a good receiver and blocks balls well. PERSON isn't as advanced offensively. Though his swing is more geared toward contact than power, scouts expect him to add some pop as he physically matures.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON has attended numerous Under GPE showcases, and he earned a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a selection onto the 2016 ORGANIZATION Second Team for his efforts.At the high school level with PERSON, ORGANIZATION won GPE 6-6A ORGANIZATION, which helped spark his commitment to PERSON A&M.

PERSON was ranked No. 17 on MLB.com's ORGANIZATION prospects list leading into the 2012 signing period and the ORGANIZATION were thrilled to get the top-ranked catcher from that class for $575,000 as part of a big haul that summer that also included PERSON. PERSON hasn't quite developed as hoped, but he's still young for his level despite having spent the last two full seasons with PERSON in the Class A GPE Atlantic League.The stocky backstop has made some progress and it started to translate a bit into his offensive numbers in 2016. He's shown more extra-base ability over the last two seasons as he continues to work on refining his approach and plate discipline. He had gotten off to a strong start in 2016 when he missed nearly a month with a shin contusion caused by him fouling a ball off his leg. PERSON has one of the strongest arms of any catcher in the ORGANIZATION and a passion for catching, but he has to continue to improve his game calling and working with a pitching staff.PERSON's conditioning has gotten away from him a bit in the past and he will have to work hard to keep his body in shape. But he was also just 20 for all of the 2016 season, giving him plenty of time to develop into the everyday catcher the ORGANIZATION envisioned when they signed him.

PERSON was a name in the back pocket of area scouts in the ORGANIZATION entering the winter of his draft year. Then word started to trickle out that the kid who had missed the summer and fall showcases with an ORGANIZATION tear had turned into a completely different player, one who now had 70 bat speed. Early in the spring, videos of his first few majestic homers led to a rush of national crosscheckers and scouting directors getting in to see PERSON, as most of them never had before. It's rare for a prep hitter to land in the first 10 picks with only one spring of looks and data, none of it on ORGANIZATION, and almost none of it against pro-quality pitching, but PERSON's tools were just that loud: 70 bat speed, easy plus raw power, plus speed, and a plus arm. 
It's similar to how PERSON looked at the same stage, though GPE had a long summer of production, faced strong prep competition, and still only went fifth overall. PERSON's pro debut revealed some weaknesses that aren't evident against mediocre prep pitching and he was clearly overmatched in the ORGANIZATION during his first pro summer and often visibly frustrated. He was 19 in Low-A last year and was able to hit for average, but very little power. Like GPE, PERSON has a good chance to lose a step as his body matures, and move to right field as a result, so pressure is on the bat. Pro scouts don't see the impact power that amateur scouts saw. We're cautiously optimistic that improved strength and swing work will tease out more game power during his age-20 season in the hitter-friendly ORGANIZATION.

When GPE was a surprise callup to the big leagues with the ORGANIZATION in 2015, he became the second pitcher from the GPE Virgin Islands to pitch at the highest level. That was just a one-game visit, but he pitched his way from Double-A to the big leagues again in 2017 with the ORGANIZATION, who acquired him in June 2016 via the ORGANIZATION deal.GPE misses a ton of bats with his fastball-changeup combination. While he'll sit in the 92- to 93-mph range with his fastball, he can get 95-96 mph whenever he needs to and throws it with good life. His bread and butter is that changeup, thrown in the mid-70s with the same arm speed, generating a lot of swings-and-misses. He will mix in a below-average slider to keep hitters honest, but it's really those two offerings, thrown with a ton of deception, that's led GPE to hold hitters to a miniscule batting average against.Improvements with his breaking ball have helped, and he's thrown more strikes this year, though his overall control could stand to improve as well. He has the ceiling of a setup man in the big leagues in the near future. Seeing him in a seventh-inning gig is also a possibility.

A gigantic lefty with a very heavy 88-93mph fastball and advanced usage of three viable secondaries (inluding an excellent changeup that he seldom uses), PERSON's junior season zenith was a 20 strikeout performance against PERSON in April.

Groshans immediately stood out to scouts on the showcase circuit, showing a ORGANIZATION starter kit with similar swing mechanics, plus raw power projection, a plus arm, and a third base defensive fit. He essentially held serve on that first impression and went 12th overall to the ORGANIZATION out of the same GPE high school as the ORGANIZATION' second round pick, PERSON. Groshans isn't quite the same level athlete as PERSON, and there are contact concerns with an active swing like that, but there are some bat-to-ball skills and plenty of mistake power he can already tap into, as shown in a loud debut in the ORGANIZATION. Many of the pro scouts who saw Groshans weren't fans and saw below average tools in their looks when he fatigued late in the pro season, but the things to watch for here are the plate discipline and contact skills, because the position and power aren't really up for debate right now.

PERSON's development has been a winding road but he's now trending up once again after a 2019 trade from GPE for PERSON. He's age appropriate in Double-A, performing well while striking out a good bit, but his underlying ORGANIZATION numbers suggest he's been unlucky with results, is hitting the ball very hard and is still solid-average in center field.

GPE is the oldest player on The ORGANIZATION and he's only here, despite a career rife with injury and inconsistency, because his stuff is so good. He's among the hardest throwers in professional baseball and also one of the best at spinning the baseball. He is wild and the quality of his secondary stuff is inconsistent, but at times he looks unhittable. He struck out 33 in 23 big league innings last year, but he's currently on the ORGANIZATION with a forearm strain. He could one day pitch his way into high-leverage innings as long as he has this kind of stuff, which he has maintained despite the many maladies.

PERSON didn't perform in his first try at the ORGANIZATION State League, reaching base at just a .255 clip before his season ended with a thumb fracture, which required surgery. Don't be fooled by his unconventional swing; he has feel to hit and feel for lifting the ball in the air regularly. But too often, PERSON swings at whatever he's offered, limiting the quality of his contact and his ability to reach base. At first base, that might be a problem. Scouts have mixed opinions about his body and how it projects into his mid-to-late-20s, which is when PERSON will likely be on the 40-man fringe, perhaps a fit for some clubs in need of, or with room for, a big-bodied masher on their 40-man. The raw power and feel for lift/contact are enticing, but a more sentient approach would be nice.

The top-rated high school left-hander in the 2015 Draft, PERSON has moved quickly since signing with the ORGANIZATION for an over-slot $3,042,400 as the 14th overall pick. But while he made his Major ORGANIZATION debut at age 20 in 2018, his stuff has plateaued and he stands out more for his high floor than his stuff. The ORGANIZATION acquired him this July in exchange for strike-throwing reliever PERSON's fastball comes in at 88-93 mph, grading out as fringy based on velocity, but it plays up to average because he commands the pitch well. Both his changeup and curveball can be above-average, but neither present themselves as true out pitches at the big league level. He's a good strike-thrower but needs pinpoint command to have success in the Majors.PERSON is way ahead of the curve age-wise, providing hope he can figure things out. He knows he can't make a mistake over the plate and is very good to his arm side, but he needs to improve his glove-side command. If he can do a better job of pitching inside against right-handed hitters, that could help him stick as a back-end starter in the big leagues.

Over the summer, PERSON created buzz with his power at the plate, competing in the ORGANIZATION in GPE during All-Star festivities. But teams interested in the standout from PERSON, the same high school 2016 Draft prospect PERSON attended, are more interested in his 6-foot-6 frame on the mound.It was a little tricky evaluating PERSON this spring, between living in a cold-weather area in GPE and a minor shoulder issue that kept him off the mound for a while. But he returned late in the spring and showed some of the stuff that interested scouts in the first place. PERSON has a fastball that he can get up to 95 mph, though he showed more of that over the summer, and sits comfortably in the 90-92 mph range. He struggles with repeating his delivery and his arm slot, which impacts his command. PERSON's velocity would fluctuate, but he'd also show enough left in the tank to touch 93 mph late in games. PERSON has a good feel for a slider, and it could be at least a Major League average offering. He doesn't have much of a changeup.PERSON has a strong commitment to ORGANIZATION and could very easily follow the footsteps of his teammate PERSON, who went on to GSP. Already 19, he would be a Draft-eligible sophomore in two years.

The ORGANIZATION led all organizations by spending $8.4 million during the 2013-14 international signing period. Their biggest bonus went to GPE, who moved from third base to right field after signing for $1.8 million. After batting just .180/.256/.235 in GPE ball in his first two years as a pro, he made the leap to low Class A and began living up to his scouting reports this season despite battling a shoulder injury.GPE has a nice right-handed swing that generates plenty of bat speed, which combined with his strength and the leverage in his 6-foot-3 frame gives him plus raw power. That pop gives him some of the best offensive upside in the system, even if he's a long way from reaching his potential. He still needs to tone down his overly aggressive approach at the plate, but as a guy who will be 19 throughout the season, he has time to work on that.GPE's below-average speed and quickness precipitated his move from third base but shouldn't prevent him from becoming a competent right fielder. He has a strong arm suited for right and has seen limited action in left and center field as well.

PERSON was drafted as a shortstop and then quickly transitioned to the outfield as a professional. His tools and athleticism give him vast potential if he is able to refine his approach at the plate. PERSON is susceptible to good breaking balls and too often swings at pitches out of the zone. If he can become more consistent at the plate, he has a wealth of raw power to tap into. That, combined with his plus speed, could make him an offensive force.  PERSON is much more advanced defensively. He has a solid arm and his speed allows him to effortlessly cover ground in center field. If his bat continues to come around, PERSON could become a solid everyday Major Leaguer.

Because he was a high school teammate of 2019 5th overall pick, PERSON, PERSON was heavily scouted as he broke out during his senior spring. He's a likely third baseman with solid average tools and good actions. He'll likely start in pro ball at shortstop.

A bonus-skimming scandal in 2008 destroyed the FACILITY' international scouting department, which didn't make a significant signing for another five years. That drought ended with PERSON, who signed for $1.6 million out of the ORGANIZATION as ORGANIZATION's No. 2-rated prospect in the 2013-14 international crop (behind only current organizationmate PERSON). PERSON and hamate injuries ruined his first two full years as a pro before he ranked fifth in the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION with 16 homers in 2017 -- though that season ended two weeks early when he punched a dugout door in frustration and broke his left pinky.PERSON has two exceptional tools in his raw power and his arm. His combination of bat speed, strength and loft and leverage in his right-handed swing gives him massive pop to all fields. He still needs to make more consistent contact, though he improved last year when he started to recognize pitches better and became less pull-conscious.PERSON has the best arm strength among GPE's position prospects, further enhancing his right-field profile. He has average speed and should be an average defender on an outfield corner. He was diagnosed with a torn flexor muscle and a strained ulnar collateral ligament in his elbow during Spring Training, then played well with the injury until the FACILITY shut him down in July so he could get PERSON surgery in time to be ready for 2019.

PERSON PERSON went third overall in the 1985 Draft before winning 142 games during a 16-year big league career. His son could go even higher in the Draft in 2019, as he's the consensus top prep prospect available. He performed well at several prominent 2018 events, winning the ORGANIZATION at the All-Star Game and claiming ORGANIZATION honors at the Under PERSON All-America Game, the ORGANIZATION and the 18-and-under PERSON in GPE. PERSON named him its 2019 national high school player of the year.A rare potential five-tool shortstop, PERSON didn't always make consistent contact on the showcase circuit last summer but scouts aren't worried about his bat. The right-handed hitter shows good barrel control and some willingness to use the entire field, so he could hit for average if he modifies his aggressive approach. His raw power and speed are both plus tools, which, combined with his baserunning instincts, could make him a 20-20 player.PERSON covers plenty of ground at shortstop, has quick hands and possesses the arm strength to make all the necessary throws -- as well as pump mid-90s fastballs from the mound. His love for the game is evident, and scouts praise his makeup as much as his physical ability. He'll turn 19 shortly after the 2019 Draft, making him old for his class and sophomore-eligible in '21 in the unlikely event he follows through on his commitment to GPE.
GPE is GPE and was one of the youngest players in the 2019 draft. He is an insane athlete with 80 speed and above average bat speed, but is still very raw.

Scouts considered PERSON one of the most polished high school left-handers in the 2016 GPE, but his determination to attend PERSON dropped him to the ORGANIZATION in the 37th round. He emerged as the ORGANIZATION' most reliable starter in the second half of his 2017 freshman season and starred in the ORGANIZATION during the summer, putting himself in position to join PERSON as the only players in school history to go in the first round. He has maintained that status despite being a little inconsistent this spring.PERSON has one of the best curveballs in the GPE, a sharp breaker with power and depth. He works in the low 90s with his fastball, can hit 95 mph when he needs to and locates his heater to either side of the plate. He also mixes in a slider with some tilt and a changeup with some fade.Add in his athleticism, strong build and easy delivery, and PERSON has everything he needs to remain a starter at the next level. His stuff and his control have improved in each of the last two years, and he may not be done getting better. He has extra leverage as a GPE-eligible sophomore.

GPE ORGANIZATION never has had more than one player selected in the first five rounds of a Draft but could have three in June. PERSON and first baseman PERSON have posted strong offensive numbers for three years, while PERSON was the ORGANIZATION's 2019 pitcher of the year. He set GPE records for single-season strikeouts (124 in 83 innings through the regular season) and consecutive scoreless innings (31 entering the conference tournament).PERSON is just 5-foot-11 but produces 88-93 mph fastballs and tops out at 95 with a combination of arm speed and an effortful delivery. His best pitch is his curveball, a plus offering in the upper 70s with 12-6 break when at its best. He also can display a decent changeup but struggles with his feel for the pitch.PERSON' size, mechanics and inconsistent command have him pointed to the bullpen in pro ball. Working in shorter stints, he could have two plus pitches with a harder fastball and curve. He may get an opportunity to prove what he can do as a starter, but he could accelerate quickly to the big leagues as a reliever.

Signed out of GPE in 2013, GPE had a solid, albeit unremarkable, debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2014. So when the infielder hit over .400 during his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION, then kept on raking after a bump up to the GPE, he surprised more than a few people. After a subpar year with the bat in his first try at full-season ball in 2016, he hit his way from the GPE to the ORGANIZATION State League in 2017. That progress caught the attention of the ORGANIZATION, who acquired him in February in exchange for PERSON. An offensive-minded middle infielder whose bat is a little bit ahead of his glove, GPE can really impact the baseball. He has some potential at the plate to hit for average and good extra-base pop, even if that doesn't mean a ton of home runs. He makes consistent hard contact with a fairly advanced approach. He's likely going to be an average runner once he physically matures and has a chance to stay at shortstop with a plus arm and future average range. Still maturing, it's unclear how big GPE might get, but if he can't stay at short, he could be a good defender at second. The ORGANIZATION had no plans to move GPE to another position, though that could change now given the shortstop glut, led by PERSON, in GPE's system.

GPE little pitching prospects aren't supposed to suddenly throw three ticks harder than they did the year before, but GPE went from sitting 89-92 to sitting 92-94, and rose three levels last year. The feel GPE developed for his changeup and curveball while he had a 40 fastball was necessary for his survival at that time. Now, they're out pitches after he gets ahead of hitters with this new heat. There's some risk that this fastball backs up, as upticks in velocity are sometimes fleeting and pitchers soon return to what they've been for most of their careers. So long as that doesn't happen, GPE projects as a good fourth starter and should help the big league club this year.

One of three high school pitchers the ORGANIZATION paid seven-figure bonuses in the middle rounds of the 2014 Draft, PERSON signed for $1 million as a fifth-rounder. As the 139th overall selection, he was the earliest Mississippi prep arm drafted since the ORGANIZATION made PERSON a second-rounder in 1999. He made the jump to full-season ball for the first time in 2016, but he had mechanical issues that affected his stuff and control.PERSON attacks hitters with three pitches that grade as solid or better when at their best. He sits at 91-92 mph and reaches 95 with his fastball, which generates groundballs with its sink and run. He can miss bats with his curveball, which has good depth and is getting more consistent, and also has a deceptive change with fade.PERSON isn't the most physical pitcher, and his control and command are still works in progress, so there's some thought that he'll wind up as a reliever. But as an athletic lefty with a three-pitch arsenal and a strong competitive streak, he could develop into a mid-rotation starter.

It's possible PERSON would be talked about now as one of the better pitching prospects of the game if he hadn't gotten hurt. But the talented right-hander needed PERSON surgery after just three starts in 2014, missing the rest of that and the 2015 season. PERSON has a big arm when he's healthy, sitting in the 93-95 mph and touching the upper-90s. PERSON's breaking ball has morphed a bit over time. It was more of a power curve two years ago before the injury, but it's turned into more of a slider and looked like it could be a plus one eventually based on how he was throwing it at instructs last fall. He has good feel for his changeup, giving him the chance to have three above-average pitches once he gets back to full strength. PERSON is still learning how to pitch, but there wasn't too much rust upon his return even though he hadn't pitched competitively for nearly two years. If he is back to where he was before the surgery, he has the chance to have among the best stuff in the ORGANIZATION system.

PERSON originally tried out for teams as a 6-foot-4 shortstop in the ORGANIZATION before signing with the ORGANIZATION as a pitcher for $85,000 in October 2012. He spent his first two pro seasons in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION before making a huge leap forward in 2015, performing so well in extended spring training that he skipped a level to the ORGANIZATION. He got off to a late start in 2016 after coming down with a sore elbow during Spring Training.The most physical pitcher in GPE's system, PERSON is bigger than his listed 6-foot-4 and 200 pounds and still has projection remaining. His present stuff already is enticing, starting with a 92-95 mph fastball that can reach 97 and plays up because of its movement, angle and plane. His curveball lacks consistency but features power and shows signs of becoming a plus offering.PERSON's changeup is less refined but he exhibits some feel for the pitch. He has good athleticism and body control for a big pitcher, allowing him to repeat his delivery and pound the strike zone.

An elite athlete, PERSON is a three-sport star in high school. The same athleticism that allows him to throw down dunks on the basketball court has helped him develop into a coveted right-hander. PERSON' fastball sits in the low 90s and tops out at 95 mph with excellent life. His sharp slider is his best secondary offering and has the potential to be a swing-and-miss offering. His changeup and curveball give him two more pitches that have the chance to be average or better. PERSON, a GPE recruit, has a loose, easy delivery and repeats it well. His long, lean build leads scouts to believe he could add more velocity as he gets stronger and focuses solely on baseball.

GPE is the grandson of PERSON, who pitched at ORGANIZATION State before saving 110 games in an 11-year big league career. GPE spent his first two college seasons and the beginning of his third in the bullpen before transitioning to the rotation in mid-March. He initially pitched well in his new role before tiring down the stretch.GPE operates at 91-93 mph with sink on his fastball and is capable of reaching 96. His slider shows signs of becoming a plus pitch and creeps into the mid-80s, though it gets slurvy at times. His changeup has occasional tumble but lacks behind his other two offerings.There's some hesitation in GPE's delivery that costs him consistency with the quality of his pitches and his command. His arm action and lack of size almost certainly will point him back toward the bullpen in pro ball, and his fastball and slider could play up in shorter stints.

An everyday player at multiple infield positions for Michigan the last three years, GPE set a school record with 12 saves as a sophomore in 2014 and has shuttled between the bullpen and rotation this spring. The burden of double duty and changing mound roles caused his stuff to fade down the stretch, but scouts would love to see what he can do when he focuses solely on pitching in pro ball.GPE has the best splitter in the GPE, and 83-86 mph offering that tumbles at the plate and elicits consistent swings and misses. He uses it too much, to the detriment of his fastball command. His heater ranges from 88-94 mph with some run and sink, and he also has an inconsistent slider.GPE figures to get an opportunity to start as a pro but likely will be a reliever. He lacks size, has a so-so delivery and had surgery to repair a torn labrum in his shoulder following his freshman year. Part of the ORGANIZATION's national team identification program in high school, he's a good athlete and a tough competitor.

Injuries to his left foot and shoulder dogged PERSON in college at GPE, and surgery on his foot forced him to miss his first pro summer after the ORGANIZATION drafted him in the 11th round in 2015. The younger brother of ORGANIZATION catching prospect PERSON, he broke into pro ball by posting an .891 OPS in high Class A in 2016, leading the GPE League in runs (96), hits (159) and doubles (39) while stealing 30 bases. He has been productive since, albeit with less power, while earning comparisons to PERSON for his athleticism and energy.PERSON offers steady if not spectacular offensive production. He has hit for average and shown on-base ability throughout his ORGANIZATION career, making repeated contact from the right side of the plate. He's strong and has some quickness to his swing that has translated into gap power, and he's an aggressive baserunner with solid speed.Though PERSON played primarily in left field during his first two pro seasons, he has spent more time in right field in 2018 and has the range and arm strength to play all three outfield spots. He also played third base for the ORGANIZATION and could handle spot duty on the infield corners. His versatility helps his cause because he profiles more as a reserve than as an everyday outfielder.

PERSON's athleticism got him drafted in the second round by the ORGANIZATION in 2013 but didn't translate into immediate results in pro ball. After PERSON traded him to the PERSON for PERSON in January, he struggled so much in training camp that he was held back in extended spring training to work on his delivery. He reported to low Class A Quad Cities in May and earned a promotion to high Class A Lancaster two months later. PERSON pitching coaches have helped PERSON with his mechanics, and the result is that he's throwing more strikes than ever. His slider also has improved significantly and looks like it will become at least an average pitch. PERSON's best offering is his fastball, which currently ranges from 89-92 to 94. He's so athletic and projectable that he should add more velocity in the future. He also shows some feel for a changeup with sink and could have three average or better pitches when he's fully developed.

When the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the first round of the 2014 Draft, they knew it might take some time for his raw tools and athleticism to translate into productivity. A quad injury that allowed him to play just 53 games in 2015 didn't help his development and needing PERSON surgery last August will delay him even further.More than anything, PERSON needs to stay healthy. Before the elbow injury late in 2016, he was showing signs of figuring some things out and gaining confidence. He needs to continue to improve his pitch recognition and his game plan, striving to have better barrel awareness in the strike zone. PERSON strength will help him at the plate, though he's not likely to be a big over-the-fence power threat. His best tool is his outstanding speed. It allows him to steal bases -- he had 35 in 2016 -- and play a highlight-reel-caliber center field on a regular basis. He's learning things like bunting to further take advantage of his speed.It can take some players longer to figure things out and patience with a player that has these kinds of tools is essential. The ORGANIZATION still feel that once he's healthy and he physically matures, it will start to come together for PERSON.

During his professional debut in 2013, PERSON led the GPE League in ORGANIZATION and was named the ORGANIZATION of the LOCATION playoffs after a promotion to short-season Vancouver. Though he wasn't quite as good statistically when he moved to full-season ball the next year, he earned All-Star honors in the ORGANIZATION and another late-season promotion to high Class A GPE.PERSON has quick hands and generally maintains a good approach at the plate, though his production dipped when he returned to GPE in 2015. He shows big raw power during batting practice, but that hasn't shown up much yet in games. Defensively, he's improved his play at third base and has a strong arm.Power is often the last tool to develop and if PERSON can unlock his, he'll have all the makings of a prototypical third baseman.

As a high school third baseman at ORGANIZATION in GPE, PERSON went undrafted. After three years at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, that won't happen again, as he was swinging a hot bat at the right time as the GPE approached.PERSON was making consistent, hard contact for the ORGANIZATION as his junior season progressed. He's always had raw power, but didn't always look like he could tap into it consistently. Lately, however, he's shortened his swing and begun to use the whole field more effectively, showing extra-base pop to the opposite field. Much of his success stems from a more open stance which has helped him get his hips through more consistently. He's a first baseman only with well below-average speed, though his hands and footwork at the corner infield position should be adequate. As a right-right first baseman, the bat is really going to have to play. Offensive college performers tend to do well in the GPE, and PERSON's raw natural power was giving him some helium as the spring progressed.

It's easy to fall in love with PERSON after just watching him take infield. Not only is he coordinated and acrobatic, but his throws to first sizzle through the air, even with just a flick of his wrist. He has one of the best infield arms in the minors and should be an above-average defender at maturity. At the plate, he lacks even a modicum of strength and has near bottom-of-the-scale power from both sides of the plate. He's a competent slash and dash hitter, but that's becoming less common, even at shortstop. Tigers fans who visit this site are likely acquainted with PERSON' player page. PERSON was a better defender than PERSON (and, well, just about everybody) and had better feel for contact with similar power, and is someone we'd ideally have as a 45 or 50 on prospect lists based on his' WAR production. PERSON, PERSON needs to be beneath those tiers. He could be a speedy, versatile bench infielder for a long time, though.

PERSON missed much of the 2012 and 2013 seasons after undergoing PERSON surgery. He has played well since returning to action - appearing in back-to-back Futures PERSON - and his longterm outlook hasn't be negatively affected by the injury.  PERSON is a defensive-oriented catcher. His strong arm has helped him to throw out more than 40 percent of would-be basestealers in his career. He is athletic behind the plate and blocks balls well.  PERSON's bat isn't as well regarded, he has a solid offensive skillset. He is an aggressive hitter, but doesn't give away at bats. He drives balls to the gaps with his line-drive swing and strength. His defense is enough to get him to the big leagues as a backup and if he proves he can hit a bit, he could become something more.

Blessed with arm strength, but not always the ability to harness it, PERSON has moved slowly through the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION system since signing back in 2012. The ORGANIZATION left-hander spent two seasons in the ORGANIZATION before making his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. Another step forward to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn PERSON led to him making his full-season debut at age 22 in 2017.The ORGANIZATION have long liked PERSON's stuff. He'll sit comfortably in the low-90s and touch the mid-90s on occasion, thrown with good life. His secondary stuff still needs some work, but he has improved in that area as well. He does show a feel to spin a breaking ball and will flash an above-average one from time to time. It will vary from curveball to slider shape. He does have a changeup that has the chance to eventually become an average offering. PERSON's biggest issue has been with his command. He cut his walk rate considerably in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn PERSON in 2016, but he still carried a 5.7 BB/9 ratio into the 2017 season.The good news is that PERSON keeps improving his overall pitchability as he continues to move forward. Working out of a rotation will allow him to keep working on all of his stuff and his feel for pitching, with PERSON knowing his live arm could work well out of the bullpen if needed.

PERSON was viewed as a bit of wild card heading into the 2013 Draft after PERSON surgery had wiped out his entire senior season at GPE (Ariz.) High. Intrigued by PERSON's upside, the ORGANIZATION selected him in the third round and convinced him to sign for $500,000, $150,000 less than his pick value. But the right-hander experienced numbness in his arm and hand when he got back on the mound, prompting surgeons to treat him for thoracic outlet syndrome by removing one of his ribs to alleviate a pinched nerve. When his symptoms failed to improve, PERSON had a nerve removed from his elbow. After making a healthy return in 2016 and building up his workload the following year, PERSON broke out in earnest in 2018, earning PERSON of the Year honors in the ORGANIZATION State League before a late bump to Double-A. The ORGANIZATION added PERSON to their 40-man roster after the season. Big and strong, PERSON will sit at 92-95 mph and touch 97, throwing his heater with downhill plane and sinking action that makes him difficult to barrel. His power curveball flashes plus, registering at 75-79 mph with tight spin and late bite, and he shows feel for throwing a firm changeup that improved as the season played out. What's more, PERSON racked up more strikeouts in 2018 (8.4 K/9) than at any point in his career and led all Minor League hurlers (140 IP min.) with a 59.1 percent ground-ball rate. More important than the results, PERSON stayed healthy for the entire season, accruing 152 2/3 innings across 27 starts. There are a range of outcomes in projecting PERSON's development, but more and more the signs are pointing to a bright future for him as a Nos. 4 or 5 starter.

Initially drafted out of high school by the Nationals in the 14th round of the 2015 Draft, PERSON opted not to sign. But instead of heading to PERSON, he went to GPE Beach State, a two-year junior college. That meant he was eligible for the Draft a year later, and the D-backs nabbed him in the sixth round. He struck out more than a batter per inning at two stops during his summer debut.The big lefty has the chance to have a good three-pitch mix when all is said and done. He has good life on his low-90s fastball and can command it to both sides of the plate, impressing the D-backs with his willingness to pitch inside effectively. He can spin a good breaking ball and has feel for his developing changeup. With a good delivery and mound presence, there might be more in the tank as he physically matures.PERSON's pro debut last summer had the D-backs encouraged, though he struggled to replicate the results during his full season debut in 2017 There's some ceiling here, with the potential for the southpaw to develop into a solid mid-to-back-of-the-rotation piece.

Few players in the ORGANIZATION system have as great a difference between their present ability and future potential than PERSON, who was signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011. He has spent four consecutive years in GPE ball before he started to show signs of breaking out in 2015. That breakout has become a reality for the left-hander this season, as he ranks among the ORGANIZATION leaders in most pitching categories. In GPE, PERSON pitched for the World squad in the ORGANIZATION Game.PERSON is a 6-foot-6 left-hander with a fastball that already reaches 94 mph and features nice life. And with room to add even more strength to his large frame, some scouts believe he will eventually sit in the mid-90s. He has a chance to have two average secondary pitches, with his changeup currently grading better than his slider.Pedromo's control and command are still very much works in progress, but he has enough deception and natural movement to generate whiffs and weak contact even when he missed a spot. As a southpaw who could grow into a mid-90s fastball, he'll get plenty of opportunity to prove himself as a starter. At the same time, it doesn't take much effort to envision how his stuff might play out of the bullpen.

ORGANIZATION didn't make much of an impression with a 9.45 GPE in GPE's top league as a 17-year-old in 2011-12, but he showed enough in a workout facing other GPE defectors that the PERSON signed him for $40,000 in September 2014. He has the best pitchability among PERSON's pitching prospects, which has allowed him to succeed at every level of the system. He had his best year yet in 2017, reaching Triple-A while topping PERSON farmhands in GPE (2.04), strikeouts (146) and ORGANIZATION (1.04).Hitters can't square up ORGANIZATION' fairly ordinary stuff because he moves his deep repertoire all around the strike zone. His lone above-average pitch is his deceptive changeup, which he has complete faith in. He can change eye levels by mixing sinking 88-92 mph two-seam fastballs and riding 91-95 mph four-seamers, and he also knows how to play his average curveball and slider/cutter off each other.ORGANIZATION tends to fall off the mound with his delivery, which throws batters off even more without compromising his ability to throw strikes. He has to be fine with his pitches and he is. A safe bet to become a back-of-the-rotation starter, he has nothing left to prove in the Minors but returned to Triple-A because PERSON has no openings in its rotation.

PERSON had a storied amateur career in GPE and was ranked No. 2 in the 2012 international free agent class by MLBPipeline.com before signing with the ORGANIZATION. His amateur success carried over to the professional ranks and he led the LOCATION in a host of offensive categories in 2014. In November, he was a part of the package the A's acquired in exchange for PERSON Donaldson.PERSON is an aggressive hitter but has a knack for putting the bat on the ball. His compact swing and quick hands allow him to consistently make hard contact. He has more home-run power than most middle infielders and is a plus runner.In the field, PERSON isn't as advanced. He has good range and a strong arm, but he's very erratic and lacks the natural actions of a shortstop. He's just a teenager, however, and will get every opportunity to prove he can stick at the position.

GPE and prospect status came on late to put GPE in the top group of pitchers in the class. He's been into the mid-90's and has some projection, but the offspeed stuff and feel is a bit behind the other arms in the top tier.

When PERSON was coming out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE in 2015, he had one of the best power bats in the entire Draft class. Since the ORGANIZATION took him 34th overall that June, he has more than lived up to that hype, hitting 58 homers over his first two full seasons of pro ball and carrying a career .508 slugging percentage into the 2018 season.Thanks to a very quick bat, PERSON can drive the ball out of the park, and for extra bases, to all fields. There will always be some swing and miss to his game, but he did cut down his strikeout rate a touch in 2017 and he does offset the whiffs by drawing a good amount of walks. He has worked on his overall approach and tried to cut down on his swing to allow him to tap into his tremendous raw power consistently. PERSON is going to have to hit because he is a below-average defender in left field with a below-average arm. The ORGANIZATION love PERSON's work ethic and that he doesn't just spend all of his time in the cage working on his one carrying tool, instead putting in great effort to show he is capable enough to play the outfield regularly. The ORGANIZATION think he'll catch what he can get to and won't be a DH only. Either way, his power bat is just about ready to contribute in GPE.

PERSON was reaching the mid-90s on the mound last summer but hasn't been throwing well this spring . Despite that, he's hitting for huge power with (literally) magnitudes more home runs than strikeouts. He's a premium athlete with with plus-plus bat speed and a ORGANIZATION body comp. Scouts have questioned his feel to hit but PERSON has already shown an ability to make some adjustments, evidence he'll be able to make more sould he need to in pro ball. He runs well but the body projects out of center field and, assuming his arm strength returns, to right field where he's a risky, potential middle of the order bat.

PERSON didn't generate any headlines when he signed for $225,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, but he has attracted plenty of attention since making his GPE debut two years later. He started drawing comparisons to Jose PERSON and teams almost immediately started asking for him in trade talks. After leading the Minors with 82 steals when he made the jump to full-season ball in 2015, he's putting together a nice encore in high Class A -- with the exception of a two-week suspension for insubordination in July that cost him a trip to the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON Game.A true top-of-the-scale runner, PERSON can get from the right side of the plate to first base in less than 4.0 seconds and has basestealing skills to boot, succeeding on 83 percent of his attempts in his first four pro seasons. More than just a slap-and-dash guy, he has wiry strength and displays solid raw power during batting practice that has yet to manifest itself during games. He could develop into a 15-homer threat, though getting on base is a higher priority and he'll need to tighten up his strike zone to do that.Initial scouting reports on PERSON raised some concerns about his throwing arm, but it has gotten stronger and now grades as a plus tool. With his actions, range, hands and arm, he'll stay at shortstop for the long term. He needs to improve his defensive consistency after making 30 errors in 99 games last year.

In mid-July, PERSON was moved from the bullpen (where he had been in college) to GPE's rotation, and his performance dipped despite the fact that he had often thrown multiple innings as a reliever. He struck out a batter per inning in relief but as a starter his velo was down, his strikeout rate was significantly down (from 24% to 14%), and he was more hittable. It's a sign his future is in the bullpen as a fastball/curveball middle reliever.

ORGANIZATION (N.C.) HS had a nice Draft run in the mid-1980s, with first-rounders and future big leaguers PERSON (1985) and PERSON (1986) plus third-rounder PERSON (1987). The ORGANIZATION's best prospect since then, PERSON posted video-game numbers as a junior, going 12-1 with a 0.08 ORGANIZATION and 174 strikeouts in 83 1/3 innings as ORGANIZATION lost in the state 1-A finals after winning championships in his first two seasons. His stuff has taken a dramatic leap forward during his senior season, so much so that he's in a group of players the Twins are considering with the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall choice. PERSON named him the national player of the year.After PERSON's fastball sat at 89-92 mph and reached 94 last summer, it has jumped about 3 mph this spring. He has maintained his newfound velocity into the late innings and continues to show feel for spotting his heater on both sides of the plate. His curveball has emerged as a true plus pitch and the best of his secondary offerings, which also include a hard slider and a tumbling changeup that also grade as plus at their best.Scouts love PERSON's athleticism and competitiveness. He employs a big leg kick and gets good extension in his delivery, creating a deceptive look that can throw hitters off. He's committed to GPE but unlikely to get there after his development this spring.

PERSON was outstanding as ORGANIZATION's ace and finished his college career with a 23-9 record and 2.80 ERA, racking up 285 strikeouts over three seasons. The A's selected the right-hander in the second round of the 2014 Draft, and he offered a taste of his potential in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League after signing for $750,000. Although he struggled during his introduction to full-season ball in 2015, PERSON was able to make some adjustments over the course of the season and finished the year on a high note before truly breaking out in '16.PERSON's fastball sits in the low 90s, topping out at 95-96 mph, and has arm-side run and late sinking action. His curveball projects to be above average and is his best secondary offering at the moment, though he also has good feel for a changeup that could be at least PERSON average once developed. His slider was his go-to out pitch at ORGANIZATION, but it's been below average as a pro and requires further refinement.Though pounding the zone has never been an issue for PERSON, his first full season indicated that the quality of his strikes must improve. Some scouts wonder if he'll have the durability to remain in the rotation, although that hasn't been an issue so far. ORGANIZATION officials believe he has what it takes to be a big league starter, and the club's track record of developing undersized right-handers bodes well for his future in the role.

GPE is a bat-first prospect with power and some chance to stick at second base, who signed for $1 million as a 2017 fourth round pick. Early-career hip surgery has limited his defensive mobility, so he's more of a wait-and-see, somewhat one-dimensional prospect to keep an eye on in 2019. If everything comes together he could be a passable second baseman with game power.

GPE has recognized PERSON as one of the more polished prep pitchers in GPE, but he didn't raise his profile until his body and stuff got stronger this spring. Now he's a good bet to get selected in the first five rounds and signed away from his commitment to Tennessee.After sitting at 85-88 mph with his fastball last summer, PERSON has added 15 pounds and now deals at 89-91 mph and peaks at 93. He commands his fastball very well and excels at getting it inside on the hands of righties. While his curveball needs more power and consistency, he shows feel for spin and his bender has some depth.PERSON also shows some aptitude for throwing a changeup but mainly works with his fastball and curve. He repeats he fluid, high-three-quarters delivery well. He may not have a true plus pitch, but his stuff plays up because he can command it and gives him a higher floor than most high school pitchers.

PERSON's career may have started off on the wrong foot, with the 2013 second-round pick needing PERSON surgery the fall after he was drafted. But it really took off in 2015 as the switch-hitting catcher made the most of a promotion to Double-A, improved every facet of his game and earned organizational Minor League player of the year honors.There's no question PERSON can hit, with the ability to hit for average and power from both sides of the plate. He improved his plate discipline in Double-A, a big reason for him getting on a roll and seemingly never stopping. Fully recovered from his surgery, PERSON's solid arm can help control the running game. He's made progress on the other facets of catching, showing the ability to call a good game and work well with a pitching staff. PERSON knows his receiving skills still need work and he's fully invested in improving them.PERSON's breakout puts him very firmly on the catching prospect map. He's a half-step ahead of PERSON developmentally, and he and the trade acquisition potentially could battle it out for everyday catching duty in GSP.

Few prospects have more raw power than PERSON, but questions about his ability to make contact and play defense cloud his future. The D-backs traded PERSON to the ORGANIZATION to get PERSON in July 2014, but PERSON's new front-office regime shipped him to the Royals in January 2017 for PERSON right-hander PERSON. In between, PERSON hit six homers in 36 big league games -- including shots off PERSON and PERSON -- but also fanned 32 times in 79 plate appearances.PERSON's power is legit. He has the ability to hit the ball out of any park to all fields. That has translated into 106 homers in four full PERSON seasons, including 24 in 105 Triple-A games last season. Whether he can tap into it consistently at the highest level remains to be seen, as a lack of plate discipline and length to his swing lead to high strikeout and low walk totals. PERSON broke into pro ball as a catcher but has receiving and throwing issues, and he was erratic and lacked range when he tried to play third base. He has a strong arm but doesn't have much athleticism or quickness, so he has migrated to left field and first base. Moving to an ORGANIZATION club where DHing is an option could be a positive for his career.

PERSON was a well-regarded prospect coming out of high school in 2012 and he began his career sharing the left side of the infield in the ORGANIZATION organization with PERSON, the first overall pick in that year's Draft. That duo was broken up in January when the ORGANIZATION included PERSON in the package they sent to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade.After struggling at the outset of his professional career, PERSON made a mechanical adjustment to his swing that has led to much better production. His power largely translated to doubles to doubles in the low levels of the ORGANIZATION, but as he physically matures he should start driving more balls over the fence. PERSON was acquired from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal and has loud tools, with all but the hit tool grading above average. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON is an uncommitted 2018 prospect who has interest from GPE, PERSON, ORGANIZATION and GPE. As a sophomore in 2015, PERSON served as PERSON's No. 1 starter ahead of eventual Twins second-rounder PERSON. PERSON became the highest drafted player out of GPE in nearly 40 years when the ORGANIZATION took him with the first pick of the second round in 2013. PERSON was a two-way player in his first two seasons at FACILITY A&M, serving as a reliever and bat off the bench in 2012 and as a starter and a regular at ORGANIZATION in 2013. PERSON was one of just two ORGANIZATION Division I players to total 20 homers and 15 steals in 2017, joining PERSON star and PERSON supplemental first-rounder Brent Rooker, but his stock took a hit as a junior after he changed his setup and didn't hit for as much power. GPE: A young PERSON Lofton.What's more, PERSON has been compared to GPE so often that many in the ORGANIZATION simply know him as "Suzuki."Scouts that have seen him play call him another name: Gamer.The speedy PERSON has an aggressive approach at the plate and has added mass to his frame since he left PERSON last year. PERSON PERSON pitched in the ORGANIZATION for 14 years and seemingly has passed on some of his feel for the game to his son, Brandon.PERSON began the 2014 season pitching behind eventual first-rounder PERSON in the ORGANIZATION State rotation, but he was hit in the left knee by a ball and was sidelined for most of the spring by a severe bone bruise. Signed for above slot value by the Pirates in 2014 after they drafted him in the supplemental second round, PERSON spent two years in GPE's system before heading to the ORGANIZATION with PERSON in a December 2015 trade. He struggled with the move up to Class A Advanced Carolina in 2017, but he returned there last season and earned honors as a mid-season All-Star before advancing to Double-A in late May. PERSON pitched well in the LOCATION, showing an impressive four-pitch mix en route to a 2.91 ERA over 16 starts, and the ORGANIZATION added him to their 40-man roster after the season.PERSON's velocity has improved as he's grown into his big frame and learned to better repeat his delivery, and he spent his breakout 2018 campaign sitting in the low 90s and touching 95 mph. The 6-foot-5 right-hander will use his height to create angle to the plate, showing feel for pounding the bottom of the zone or elevating his heater with some riding life. His slider and changeup have above-average potential, and he throws both more than he does his mid-70s curveball, a fringy pitch that he can locate for strikes. His feel for mixing his pitches translates to solid, if unspectacular strikeout rates right now, and he might not miss as many bats at higher levels given his velocity and lack of a put-away pitch. That said, PERSON has all the ingredients to be a successful big league starter, with size, stuff and feel for pitching that point to him becoming a durable, back-of-the-rotation asset for the ORGANIZATION.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 22nd round out of high school in 2010 as an outfielder, and he spent most of his freshman season at ORGANIZATION as a position player. GPE is rumored to have turned down around $2 million out of high school from the ORGANIZATION, then he got scooped up after two years at ORGANIZATION by the ORGANIZATION in the 9th round. PERSON had a breakout 2017, then blew out his elbow early in 2018. He's back throwing bullpens as this list goes to publication. PERSON's dalliance with college basketball is now over, after two years at ORGANIZATION's and then one sitting out at ORGANIZATION State Northridge. PERSON made some tremendous adjustments in 2014, and the ORGANIZATION added him to the 40-man roster during the offseason. Now that he's truly invested in learning how to pitch, he has the chance to really take off.

Teams have likely already studied this, but during our in-person looks at PERSON, which date back to 2014, he seems to generate top spin on batted balls with more regularity than is typical for hitters. That's not a good thing, as the same way a curveball does, it causes PERSON's fly balls to sink and die at a lesser distance than they should. We have no idea if the ability to hit balls with no spin (which is ideal) is a skill hitters have, but if it is, PERSON probably isn't one of them. He does have power though, and he's a viable defensive third baseman who'd be capable of moonlighting at short or second base if PERSON needed him to. We like him as a versatile, bat-first prospect who can play all over the place.

ORGANIZATION' PERSON stock was largely based on his abilities behind the plate, where he was clearly the best defensive catcher in the 2016 PERSON class. He helps his cause with a willingness to draw walks.At the outset of his pro career, ORGANIZATION looked like he fit the defensive-minded backup profile perfectly. If he keeps swinging the bat like he did in his first full season, it's easy to see him as a glove-first regular in a big league lineup.

PERSON hasn't let the fact that he came from GPE, with no high school baseball team, get in the way of working his way up the ORGANIZATION organizational ladder. PERSON has gotten bigger and stronger as he's matured and his power has started to show up a bit more consistently. He may have seemed like a long-term project when he was drafted, but PERSON isn't too far off from helping out in GPE's outfield. It seems like every year a hitter or two comes out of nowhere and causes quite a ruckus in Lansing. This year it was PERSON, who hit .285/.363/.445 with 50 extra-base hits and 44 steals for the ORGANIZATION. The travel ball circuit is not kind to economically disadvantaged families, and part of the reason PERSON was under-scouted as an amateur, as he told our own PERSON, was because his family could not afford to attend heavily scouted showcases. 
Another reason he may have slid toward the end of the draft was because he was constantly moving around. He was under the international scouting umbrella while he was young and living in the ORGANIZATION, then spent his early high school years in GPE before relocating to GPE for his senior season.
