The ORGANIZATION got a deal done for $200,000 and PERSON has been a strong early-career performer. Pro scouts see him as a bit of a tweener but think there's a chance he might be an everyday center fielder if absolutely everything comes together. He's not a typical center field sprinter (our sources all have either a 50 or 55 on his speed) but he's instinctive, and fine there for now. If PERSON does move to a corner, his hit/power combination is on the fringe of profiling. A switch-hitter, PERSON has power from the right side of the plate but he's strikeout prone due to a lack of bat control. As a lefty, he has a gap-to-gap approach and good bat control, but not typical over-the-fence thump. 
It's possible that, even with middling offensive ability, PERSON could be such an excellent corner defender that he plays everyday anyway, and his makeup is universally lauded, so we like his chances of reaching and staying in the majors as some kind of role player.

PERSON had put up solid numbers in rookie ball, then surprised some when he made the full-season LOCATION Power out of Spring Training in 2012. All he did there was lead the circuit in total bases while finishing in the top 10 in a host of offensive categories. PERSON makes consistent contact and can drive the ball to all fields and will use an inside-out swing as well. An outstanding bunter, he also has the strength to show occasional home run power. He has very good speed and is still learning how to use it to his benefit on the basepaths. Defensively, he has the range and the hands to stay at shortstop, but his arm has been erratic. PERSON will stay at shortstop for now, and more people believe he can stay there than they did before his full-season debut, but some feel he'll eventually move over to second base.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

GPE runs well enough to stay in center field but his bat speed is below average which limits his offensive impact and, thusly, his role. He projects as a fourth outfielder, though his patience, if refined, might allow him to reach base enough to play every day.

A talented enigma at GPE, PERSON's prodigious stuff was finally deployed with some consistency in 2017 as he struck out a whopping 191 hitters in 141.1 innings. His fastball and curveball are both plus while his changeup, slider and command remain fringey, but fringe command is still more than a grade better than what PERSON showed in college. He's progressing but remains a volatile prospect with #2/3 starter potential

The track record of developing high school catching isn't a particularly good one, with some top picks not making it and others switching positions. PERSON will no doubt be able to stay behind the plate long-term and has the chance to be the kind of all-around backstop to buck that trend.The son of ORGANIZATION head coach PERSON Sr., ORGANIZATION is committed to playing for his father should he head to college. PERSON transferred from his ORGANIZATION high school to play closer to his father for his senior year. He has all the tools to be a very good defender behind the plate, with outstanding catch and throw skills to go along athleticism that allows him to move well. He likes to throw from his knees, and while he can do so effectively, he can fall in love with it as well. Offensively, he has tremendous bat speed and he shows pull power now. A refined approach and continued added strength should help him become a better all-around hitter. There are some issues with his swing, causing some swing and miss.Scouts watched his bat carefully this spring and there are enough who saw the potential there to make him one of the best all-around catching prospects in this year's Draft.

PERSON is still very much the complete package of size and stuff that made him a top prospect in 2012. ORGANIZATIONw back at ORGANIZATION for his senior season after not coming to terms with the ORGANIZATION, the big right-hander has the chance to be the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick yet again.He has a plus fastball that sits comfortably in the mid-90s with good movement. His hard slider and circle change are both outstanding offerings, at least above-average at times. He can throw all three pitches for strikes and has very good mound presence. The only minor concern is that with that kind of stuff, some scouts feel he doesn't get as many swings and misses as you'd expect, but he still profiles as a top of the rotation starter when all is said and done.In his first three years at ORGANIZATION, two as its Friday night starter, PERSON had gone 18-9 with a 3.22 ERA, striking out 8.11 while allowing 8.41 hits and 2.54 walks per nine. He's been even better in his senior year than he was as a junior, when he had a 2.56 ERA, 9.51 K/9 and 7.10 H/9 rates.

PERSON entered 2013 as a likely first-round pick in a Draft light on shortstops, but he struggled with the bat as a high school senior. That enabled the ORGANIZATION to get him in the second round with the 57th overall pick, and they signed him for $1.5 million.In his pro debut, PERSON continued to show the defensive wizardry that endears him to scouts. He has very good actions and instincts at shortstop, enabling him to cover plenty of ground. He also has soft hands and a strong arm.PERSON didn't hit much in his first taste of pro ball, posting a .597 OPS in GPE ball, but PERSON has faith that he will. The ORGANIZATION like his swing and believe he'll develop some gap power. He's an average runner with good baserunning instincts.

GPE ORGANIZATION not only won the ORGANIZATION World Series in 2017, it had a large chunk of its roster taken in the Draft that June. PERSON was the third GPE taken, in the fifth round by the GPE, and he went out and had a very strong pro debut in the GPE League.PERSON began his collegiate career at GPE, but transferred to GPE after redshirting his sophomore year and being told he would be a part-time player. He put up huge numbers with GPE, but might have been dinged by some team's models that discount production at the junior college ranks. At least in his debut, PERSON's approach translated quite nicely to the pro game, making consistent contact and drawing walks in an approach that's still hit over power. A solid athlete with very good range defensively, PERSON has average speed and likes to run. His plus arm will work very well from the hot corner.It appears that PERSON has an exciting package of tools to eventually develop into an everyday third baseman. That's starting with full-season ball and the end result could be one of the better steals of the 2017 Draft.

The move to Double-A can be a challenging one for prospects and how one handles the jump, and the adversity that can often come with it, can be as telling as immediate success. GPE, the junior college standout who went in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft, scuffled with the move to hitter-friendly Reading in 2018, but righted the ship and was pitching very well when an oblique injury ended his season in July.GPE's stuff, and he has a full repertoire of weapons at his disposal, fluctuated at times particularly early in the year. He'll throw both a four- and two-seam fastball and can still get the former up to 95 mph, while he sinks the latter in the low 90s to get groundball outs. The life and deception he uses to throw his fastball allows it to nearly play up to a plus pitch. Both of his breaking balls will flash above-average and he mixes in a cutter to go along with a changeup that is plus at times.At his best, GPE commands his fastball to both sides of the plate and goes right after hitters, something he struggled with in the early going a year ago. PERSON and athletic, he shouldn't need too much more time to be ready for a gig as a mid-rotation starter.

It appears that PERSON is all the way back after August 2011 PERSON surgery. The red-shirt sophomore has been very effective as PERSON's Friday starter. PERSON has a lively fastball that he'll throw up to 95 mph and command well, working quickly and getting many ground-ball outs. His secondary stuff -- a slider and a changeup -- isn't quite as good as his fastball, though both have the chance to develop into consistently PERSON average offerings. With that three-pitch mix and some decent pitchabilitiy, PERSON could be the type of college arm that moves quickly once he's drafted.

We still know very little about PERSON compared to most 22-year-old pitching prospects. He popped up seemingly out of nowhere as a sophomore at a lesser ORGANIZATION junior college but quickly entered the first round discussion when ORGANIZATION ball kicked off in January of 2017. As the draft approached, PERSON was showing better secondary stuff in games and bumping 100 mph in bullpen sessions for scouts. He forced his way up draft boards even though teams had little history with him, and some were skeptical of the new velocity or concerned it would lead to injury. 
PERSON made seven short but dominant appearances in the LOCATION during the summer and was poised to begin 2018 at ORGANIZATION (an aggressive assignment), but he suffered an intercostal strain and began the season on the ORGANIZATION. In his final extended spring rehab start, he was sitting 94-96 and touching 98 with the fastball. He finally toed a ORGANIZATION State League rubber that week and lasted 1.2 innings before a comebacker struck his wrist and forearm and fractured his ulna. The injury ended his regular season after just five outs. 
After rest and some rehab during instructs, PERSON went to GPE for the ORGANIZATION. His stuff was electric there, his fastball always sitting 95-99 and cresting 100 mph often. He threw a 104 mph fastball and a 95 mph slider during the ORGANIZATION game, and he was able to dump his upper-70s curveball in for strikes throughout his six-week tenure, though he threw no changeups. PERSON was also horribly wild at times. It's fair to conclude that rust was to blame for his occasional wildness but because the pro side of the industry has seen so little of PERSON, it's impossible to know for sure. 
There's a strong possibility that he just ends up in the bullpen, but if he does and he breathes one-inning fire like he did during ORGANIZATION, he basically has PERSON's stuff (though perhaps not the same extension or approach angle). Provided he stays healthy, PERSON's future is bright, albeit unclear. He's likely to be handled with care for a while in order to keep him healthy and manage his workload after what was essentially a lost 2018, but given the wide variance and top shelf stuff, there is still frontline starter potential.

PERSON knee issues and constant setbacks kept him off the field for most of last season. When healthy he has a typical right field profile, with power and perhaps some strikeouts. He's a hard working player and GPE's best prospect.

PERSON like PERSON's muscular and projectable body. He has shown plenty of power, but he's also developing into an overall hitter, focusing on avoiding balls out of the strike zone. He's already displayed a polished approach in the batter's box.PERSON's batting practice sessions are a sight to behold, in large part because of the hard, low line drives he sprays all over the field. On defense, PERSON can play all three outfield positions and has shown good instincts. However, his overall skill set might make him best suited for a corner spot. PERSON also like his arm, and he's expected to improve on all parts of his game once he enters an academy and receives professional instruction on a daily basis.A star in GPE's ORGANIZATION, the teenager also impressed in the ORGANIZATION 18U Pan American Championship in 2014. PERSON trains in the ORGANIZATION with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

Drafted by his hometown team, GPE took a step forward in 2013, pitching in the ORGANIZATION. He took a step back in 2014 while repeating the Double-A LOCATION, but he landed on the temporary inactive list in late June due to his struggles.When he's on top of his game, GPE has drawn comparisons to PERSON, both for his size and his stuff. He can throw his fastball in the low-90s from a three-quarters arm slot. GPE throws a changeup and a big sweeping curveball, which is his best offspeed pitch. All three of his pitches have a chance to be at least Major League-average offerings.GPE has struggled with his control throughout his professional career, and finding a way to improve it will be critical to his success as a starter in the ORGANIZATION. If he can lower his walk rate, GPE profiles as a middle-of-the-rotation starter.

The ORGANIZATION have one of the best catchers in the big leagues in GPE and one of the top catching prospects in the Minors in GPE. Nevertheless, they couldn't resist the temptation to draft PERSON when he was available with the 52nd pick in the 2014 Draft. The ORGANIZATION USA Player of the ORGANIZATION signed for $1.1 million.PERSON has a mature approach, employs a short stroke and uses the entire field. He makes consistent hard contact and could provide 15 homers per season once he adds some more strength.PERSON's offense stands out more than his defense, though he should be able to stay behind the plate. He has an average arm but still needs to polish his receiving and blocking skills. A top student, PERSON has the work ethic to make the necessary improvements.

PERSON had PERSON surgery as a freshman at ORGANIZATION, returning as a redshirt freshman in 2016 and pitching out of the bullpen. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON an Underclass 2nd Teamer in both 2015 and 2016, PERSON was targeted by five major college programs before he committed to the ORGANIZATION. Few prospects anywhere have more raw power, which he creates with an impressive combination of bat speed, strength and launch angle, not to mention an extremely aggressive approach. He shows some patience to draw walks and is at his best when he uses the middle of the field, though he often sells out for home runs, lengthens his right-handed swing and chases pitches out of the zone.While PERSON has below-average speed, he has worked hard to make himself into a solid defender at third base. His range is ordinary, but he has good hands and a strong arm that delivered low-90s fastballs and effective sliders in college. Because they also have PERSON in GPE and PERSON in Triple-A, the ORGANIZATION began exposing PERSON to first base in 2018.

It's amazing what some strength and conditioning can do. Initially a diminutive glove-only shortstop when he signed in 2012, PERSON has been through the organization's strength program twice. The result was a breakout 2015 season that saw him make the LOCATION League All-Star Team and earn a promotion.There are some who feel PERSON is the best defensive shortstop in the system, high praise considering J.P. Crawford's presence. PERSON has all the tools to play the premium position at a high level, with a plus arm, glove and range. His 60 speed on the scouting scale allows him to have excellent range and makes him a basestealing threat. His offensive tools all play up now thanks to that added strength. He can drive the ball to the right-center-field gap with authority and his 40 extra-base hits show that he no longer will have the bat knocked out of his hands.PERSON still has a ways to go in terms of refining his approach and improving his offensive game. But he's headed in the right direction and now looks like he has the chance to be an everyday shortstop at the big league level.

A former two-sport star at GPE (Calif.) High, PERSON was selected by the ORGANIZATION in the second round of the 2012 Draft and signed for $750,000. He made his full-season debut the following year and moved up to Class A Advanced PERSON in 2014, where, at age 20, he paced the ORGANIZATION State League with 36 doubles while also stealing 22 bases. His performance was less consistent last season at ORGANIZATION, and his struggles continued during his return to the LOCATION in 2016.PERSON is both athletic and toolsy, with an overall feel for the game that has long impressed evaluators given his multi-sport background. A right-handed hitter, he has good bat speed, advanced bat-to-ball skills and a knack for pounding the gaps. The ORGANIZATION tried to get him to generate more power last season by adjusting his setup and stride, though it only detracted from his natural hitting ability. PERSON's best tool is his above-average speed, but he's still learning how to be an efficient basestealer. His speed also serves him well in center field, where he's an instinctual defender with good range.Though he took a step back last season in Double-A, the ORGANIZATION believe he'll make the necessary adjustments to push through those struggles. He still has a chance to develop into a big league regular in center field, though scouts seem to be a bit more leery after his drop-off in production at the Double-A level.

Though he's just an average runner without the silky smooth hands typically associated with the position, PERSON has an above average arm and good defensive feet that might allow him to play there long term. He also has plus bat speed and above average pull power, though PERSON is vulnerable against breaking balls on the outer half. He has a chance to play short and hit for some power and scouts think the bat might profile at third or second should he have to move.

An athletic, toolsy outfielder when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in 2012, PERSON turned that promise into production in a breakout 2014 season. He was named the ORGANIZATION of the Year after posting a .905 ORGANIZATION, collecting 153 hits and scoring 87 runs in 130 games between Class A Quad Cities and Class A Advanced Lancaster. The following July, he was the headline prospect in a four-player package that PERSON sent to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON, PERSON and 2015-16 international bonus pool money. In his first two years in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON looked more like a top-of-the-order hitter, thanks to his patience, contact-oriented approach and speed. He tweaked his swing in 2014, allowing him to tap into newfound power, and he hit 17 home runs after not homering in his first two years as a professional. He's also an above-average runner, giving him an intriguing power-speed combination. PERSON' speed gives him a chance to stick in center field, though some scouts think he's better suited defensively for right field. His strong arm will profile at either position.

The ORGANIZATION reportedly offered PERSON a $1.5 million bonus in 2014 after drafting him in the first round, only to pull it off the table when PERSON. 1 overall pick PERSON's deal collapsed and the club no longer could afford PERSON with its reduced bonus pool. Both pitchers wound up with ORGANIZATION's (PERSON, Fla.) post-graduate program and were drafted once again in 2015, with PERSON going to GPE in the third round and signing for $900,000. He made strides on all fronts during his full-season debut, showing improved velocity, stuff and stamina, qualities that have followed him up the ladder to Class A Advanced Lake Elsinore in 2017.The Padres helped PERSON clean up his delivery late that season, and those adjustments have made him more consistent on all fronts. He sits 92-95 mph while reaching 97 with his fastball, all while showing increasing comfort with repeating his delivery. PERSON also made strides with his curveball, throwing it with more depth and sharper downward action that makes it a plus pitch in the eyes of evaluators. His changeup should at least be average, and he's adept at throwing strikes with all three pitches..PERSON answered questions about his durability last season by logging 105 innings as a 20-year-old, and he has plenty of room left to grow into his athletic and projectable frame. He's a potential PERSON. 3 starter in the big leagues, especially if the changeup and his command continue to improve.

PERSON was supposed to head to GPE, but had his roster spot and scholarship rescinded, so he walked on at GPE and started as a freshman when PERSON got hurt. This season, as a junior, he upped his offensive profile to his strong defensive game to land in the third round and get full pick value from the ORGANIZATION.There's no question about PERSON's defensive ability, with excellent catch and throw skills. His above-average arm plays up even more because of his quick release and accuracy. He moves well behind the plate and works very well with pitchers. An improved approach at the plate allowed PERSON to be GPE's best hitter in 2017, showing some extra-base ability from the right side of the plate.If PERSON can continue to show a more consistent bat, he has the chance to be a glove-first regular, something the ORGANIZATION clearly are hoping for. At worst, though, he should be a very solid backup at the big league level.

ORGANIZATION used PERSON exclusively as a reliever on teams that went to the ORGANIZATION World Series finals in 2014 and 2015 (winning it all in his freshman year), and he dominated out of the bullpen while earning co-playoff ORGANIZATION honors in the ORGANIZATION in the latter summer. The ORGANIZATION tried him as a starter at the beginning of his junior season before shifting him back to the bullpen as a closer. The ORGANIZATION eased him into pro ball in short stints after signing him for $1.6 million as a second-rounder.As a lefty with three pitches and a durable frame, PERSON has the ingredients to pitch in the middle of a big league rotation. His 90-95 mph fastball plays up because it has late life and steep downhill plane. He also shows feel for a sinking changeup and has a three-quarters breaking ball that fluctuates between a low-80s slider and a high-70s curveball.Colorado is still undecided about PERSON's long-term role. Though he could move quickly as a possible high-leverage reliever, he also has mid-rotation potential and a fresh arm that logged just 96 1/3 innings in three seasons at ORGANIZATION. His control and command improved steadily during his college career, but to make it as a starter he'll have to show that he can maintain a quality fastball into the late innings.

PERSON has a frame and profile reminiscent of Cubs 1B/DH prospect PERSON and many scouts were lukewarm on him last summer, but PERSON lost a few pounds and mashed against pro pitchers, getting to his easy plus raw power while player forthe GPE Junior National team that toured PERSON.

As a college football player at ORGANIZATION who didn't return to baseball until his senior year of college, winning the Big East Triple Crown in the process, PERSON has followed one of the more unusual paths to pro ball. He went from the fourth round of the 2012 Draft to Triple-A in three years in the ORGANIZATION system, then joined the ORGANIZATION in December as the player to be named in the deal that sent PERSON to GPE. While he might be older than the average prospect at his level, he's not, in terms of experience. The more he's played, the more rust PERSON has knocked off to reach Triple-A in 2015. His approach at the plate is a bit unorthodox, but he continues working to smooth out rough edges along the way. His move to Triple-A marked the first time he didn't hit for both average and power. PERSON is a good athlete who is an average runner, and the ORGANIZATION have given him looks at third, where he started his career, first and the outfield. He might be best suited in left field or at first, where he's been better than anticipated. After spending most of his first three pro seasons at third base, PERSON saw most of his action in 2015 in the outfield and first base. He's a good athlete with average speed, but his fringy arm strength and range limit his defensive value. He earns raves for his makeup, which, along with his power, should help him find his way to the big leagues in the near future.

There might not have been another college arm who shot up ORGANIZATION boards more than this ORGANIZATION ace during the spring. His rise slowed a bit with some struggles, perhaps caused by fatigue, in April. But he still has the size, stuff and command to potentially be a frontline starter at the highest level. PERSON's fastball will touch 97 mph and is consistently at least above average with good sink. He throws a nasty slider, and his changeup projects to be a legitimate weapon as well.PERSON has above-average control and command and the ideal athletic frame scouts love to see in a pitcher. There's room for gaining strength, which gives him a high ceiling as well.

After pitching with an upper-80s fastball on the showcase circuit last summer, PERSON dedicated himself to getting stronger in the offseason. His work paid off when he came out touching 93 mph early this spring and held his improved velocity throughout his senior season. He could go as early as the third round and figures to get picked high enough to sign him away from an Ohio State commitment.PERSON now operates in the low 90s early in games and should throw a bit harder as he continues to develop physically. He can flash a good curveball at times but it's below average at others and he can't always land it in the strike zone. He shows some feel for his changeup, which has fade and should become an effective third pitch.PERSON is athletic and has a clean delivery, so he should be able to iron out the inconsistencies with his control and command. Though he's not especially tall, he uses a high-three-quarters arm slot to create downhill plane on his pitches.

Extremely projectable and athletic, PERSON could prove to be a steal as a ninth-rounder from the 2012 Draft. The ORGANIZATION thought enough of him to send him to low Class A as an 18-year-old to open '13, and while he struggled at first, he fared better once he returned there in mid-August after a demotion.PERSON generates easy velocity on his fastball, working from 90 to 95 mph and showing the ability to cut and sink the pitch. All three of his secondary pitches have the potential to become average or better down the road, with his curveball currently rating ahead of his slider and changeup.PERSON will need to do a better job of trusting his stuff as he advances. He's also working on smoothing out his delivery so he can throw more strikes. PERSON is still just 19, so he has plenty of time.

So young is PERSON that he had to wait almost two months after the July 2 signing day to turn 16 and become eligible to put pen to paper on his pro contract, which included a $1 million bonus. He's a typical, frame-based projection outfield prospect at a lean, high-waisted, broad-shouldered 6-foot-2. His upright swing is currently suited for high-ball contact but, based on the GPE propensity for enacting swing changes, that will likely change pretty quickly. As he grows into his body and better incorporates his lower half into his swing, he could have serious in-game power at maturity. Likely a long-term developmental project, PERSON may not be stateside for actual games until the 2020 AZL.

Though PERSON was a catcher when he signed for $45,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, he spent the majority of his first three pro seasons at third base before moving behind the plate full-time last year. Despite the increased defensive responsibilities, he finished second in the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION in doubles (35) and slugging (.489) and slammed a pair of homers in the playoffs to help GPE win the championship. He broke a bone in his right thumb when he was hit by a pitch in GPE Training this year, missing most of the season's first month before reporting to high Class A.PERSON's offense is ahead of his defense. He's strong and makes consistent hard contact from the right side of the plate, though his lack of patience could be exploited by more advanced pitchers as he rises through the Minors. Most of his power comes to his pull side and he might generate more if he adds some loft to his swing and hits fewer ground balls.PERSON is still a work in progress as a catcher, especially in terms of his receiving and game-calling. He has a strong arm but inconsistent footwork creates inaccurate throws at times. For now, he profiles as an offensive-minded backup capable of filling in on the infield corners.

He can't match PERSON's loud tools or his ceiling, but PERSON outhit him on the same teams in 2014 and 2015. Though he won't displace PERSON as the ORGANIZATION' shortstop of the future, PERSON has enough all-around ability to claim a utility role in GPE. His play in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 earned him a spot on the 40-man roster, and he has kept it heading into 2017.A switch-hitter, PERSON has tremendous hand-eye coordination that makes him one of the best contact hitters in the system. He drives the ball more from the right side of the plate, but he isn't a power threat by any means, and he'll likely will fit at the bottom of a big league batting order. PERSON is an average runner who won't steal many bases.While he may make only modest offensive contributions, PERSON' defensive versatility enhances his value. He has the range and arm strength to be a solid shortstop. At second base, he's a plus defender with quick hands made for turning double plays, and he also can get the job done at the hot corner.

When the A's acquired PERSON in December 2011 as a part of the trade that sent PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION, he had just celebrated his 19th birthday and was coming off an impressive stateside debut. He emerged as one of GPE's better pitching prospects in 2013 and moved up to Double-A the following year, only to have his season all but wiped out by PERSON surgery in May. He returned to the mound last June at ORGANIZATION A Advanced GPE, but was held to a strict 60-pitch/four-inning limit as he continued to work his way back from surgery.PERSON's velocity was down during his initial starts at GPE, but, by the end of the season, the right-hander was back sitting in the 92-95 mph range and bumping 96 with his fastball. His changeup has above-average potential and complements his fastball well, and he'll also mix in a show-me curveball. His slider was inconsistent but showed the makings of becoming a third average-or-better offering up until he blew out his elbow. The A's didn't have him throw it in 2015, though, as they instead emphasized building up arm strength and regaining feel. Throwing strikes has never been a problem for PERSON, who has walked just 1.9 batters per nine innings as a professional.PERSON returned to PERSON in 2016 but was inconsistent across his starts for GPE. He began to show signs of finally turning the corner in late July, which is when the A's promoted him to Triple-A. The right-hander had made significant strides in the year before his injury, and if he's able to fully recapture that ability and develop a more consistent breaking ball, he has a chance to become a solid Major League starter.

King stood out as one of the best pitchers at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship last October, generating buzz as a potential first-rounder. He hasn't quite lived up to that billing this spring, though his powerful right arm still has attracted plenty of attention and helped keep GPE (GPE) atop the national high school rankings for much of the year until the ORGANIZATION lost in the state 6-A regional semifinals.After King threw several 94-95 mph fastballs at the ORGANIZATION event, scouts hoped he'd pitch there more consistently as a senior but he has worked mostly at 89-93. With his projectable frame and his quick arm, he eventually could operate in the mid-90s and approach 100 mph. His heater has running and sinking action that generates groundouts when he keeps it down in the zone.King's slider also was harder and sharper last fall but still shows flashes of becoming a solid offering. The ORGANIZATION recruit shows aptitude for a changeup with some fade as well. There's some effort in his delivery and he lands with a stiff front leg, which could compromise his health and his command and eventually lead him to the bullpen.

GPE forces scouts to project heavily on his secondary stuff, and not everyone thinks he'll be able to develop an especially effective breaking ball. But he has elite velocity, prototypical size and the athleticism and fluidity to at least project on his changeup and command pretty significantly.

A GPE PERSON drafted in the second round by the D-backs out of a GPE high school in 2014, PERSON won ORGANIZATION honors in the Rookie-level PERSON in 2015 before getting traded to the ORGANIZATION in a deal for PERSON the following January. He led the Class A ORGANIZATION with 20 homers in his first season in the ORGANIZATION organization but slumped in his second, then got dealt to the ORGANIZATION as part of a package for eventual ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION PERSON. He struggled again at the plate in 2018, batting .232/.340/.399 between Double-A and Triple-A, but still has more offensive upside than most middle infielders.PERSON's best attribute is his plus raw power, with his bat speed and the strength in his compact frame translating into hard-hit balls to all fields. He can get aggressive at times but his hand-eye coordination and patience should have translated into better than a .254 career average in his first five pro seasons. He did make some adjustments last year to reduce the uppercut in his left-handed stroke but they didn't produce noticeably better results.PERSON needs to reach his offensive potential to make it as a big league regular because he doesn't stand out in other aspects of the game. While he has good instincts on the bases, his average speed doesn't make him much of a threat to steal. Signed as a shortstop, he gets the job done at second base but his average arm limits his usefulness on the left side of the infield.

First of all, PERSON has the durable and athletic frame evaluators seek in starting pitcher prospects. He also features a lot more.The young right-hander has an easy, repeatable delivery paired with a loose and under-control arm action. He has shown the ability to throw strikes and his mix of three quality pitches stands out for a player his age. PERSON's fastball usually sits in the 90 mph range for multiple innings and he has been up to 92 mph with good command. More velocity could be on the way as he grows and his body develops. PERSON's curveball sits in the low 70s with depth and good tempo and his change hovers in the low 80s with some arm-side fade. Overall, his present pitch abilities and stuff combined with body projection has some scouts believing PERSON has middle-of-the-rotation upside. He's a competitor that also known for his good makeup. He's confident on the mound. He is trained by PERSON in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON ORGANIZATION and PERSON weren't the only pitchers who drew scouts to the ORGANIZATION in GPE, Fla., last spring. While the two aforementioned hurlers pitched for ORGANIZATION's post-graduate program, PERSON emerged as a star for the high school squad. But signability concerns caused him to fall to the eighth round of the 2015 Draft, where the ORGANIZATION were able to lure him away from a GPE commitment with a $725,000 bonus. He was excellent in his abbreviated pro debut, and then was shipped off to the ORGANIZATION as part of the ORGANIZATION trade in November. In 2016, PERSON had continued to make strides during full-season debut with PERSON before landing on the disabled list in early June with left elbow soreness.PERSON's prospect stock took off last spring behind an uptick in velocity that pushed his formerly below-average fastball into the 90-94 mph range. His heater has good life, too, which makes it difficult for opponents to barrel. PERSON's arsenal of secondary pitches is equally impressive, as his slider, curveball and changeup all have the potential to be average or better once fully developed.PERSON's advanced feel for pitching made for an easy transition to the professional ranks, and he showed the ability to throw each of his four pitches for strikes in his debut. PERSON may not have the ceiling of some of the other young pitchers in the ORGANIZATION' system, but, with his pitchability and strong command profile, he could be the first to reach the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON doesn't have the stuff to match likely-top-10 picks PERSON (ORGANIZATION) and J.B. Bukauskas (LOCATION) or possible first-rounder PERSON (GPE), but he held his own against all three of them in well-scouted matchups this spring. Though he has a fringy fastball, he has enough craftiness as a left-handed starter to factor in the top five rounds of the draft. His younger brother PERSON was a redshirt on the ORGANIZATION' national champion football team in the fall. PERSON can carve up hitters with his changeup, a plus offering that he sells with deceptive arm speed and bottoms out at the plate. He has a pair of average breaking balls that he locates well, a mid-70s curveball with depth and a low-80s cutter/slider. His 86-88 mph fastball peaks at 91 and grades as his worst pure pitch, though it's effective because he sinks and commands it well and delivers it with good angle.While PERSON has always thrown strikes, he has little margin for error and didn't thrive as a college starter until he bolstered his command this spring. PERSON love his cerebral approach to pitching and his competitiveness, which enhances his chances of making it as a back-of-the-rotation starter.

PERSON (Ga.) PERSON has produced a pair of big league infielders in GPE Treadway and PERSON, and it may have a third on the way in PERSON. He's PERSON's best prospect since PERSON and profiles as more of an impact hitter than the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 2008 PERSON has become.PERSON has the tools and approach to hit for power and average. He offers bat speed, strength and patience from the left side of the plate. He uses the entire field and has better pitch recognition than most high schoolers.Currently a shortstop, PERSON will move to a less challenging position at the next level. The ORGANIZATION recruit has good hands but lacks the quickness to play in the middle infield. His arm hasn't been as strong this spring, when he has dealt with biceps tendinitis, but it and his bat would profile well at third base.

GPE of a crazy-deep ORGANIZATION high school pitching crop in 2016 -- PERSON went fourth overall to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON signed for $3.05 million as a supplemental first-rounder, PERSON nearly doubled his slot value in the sixth round -- PERSON could have been a top-three-rounds pick if he hadn't been set on becoming a Jayhawk. Three years later, his scouting reports read pretty much the same and he has the same upside in the GPE. He has a big arm that produces inconsistent results, as evidenced in early April when he gave up nine runs against PERSON and then struck out a career-high 14 against PERSON in his next start.PERSON is capable of working with a 93-96 mph fastball as a starter and has climbed as high as 98, though there are games where he'll operate at 90-93. His heater is fairly straight considering he throws from a low-three-quarters slot, an angle that makes it tough for him to stay on top of his slider, which ranges anywhere from 80-87 mph and from a below-average slurve to a plus offering with hard bite. His changeup grades better than his slider at times, though it also lacks consistency.PERSON is athletic but tends to get under his pitches, costing him control and quality. He doesn't have a track record of throwing strikes, leading several scouts to project a move the bullpen, where he could regularly feature a double-plus fastball in shorter stints. He's at his best when he pitches closer to a traditional three-quarters arm angle but has trouble doing so.

Of the three third basemen selected in the first two rounds of the 2012 Draft by the LOCATION, just one has stuck at the hot corner. PERSON has moved to right field and first base, and PERSON has shifted behind the plate, with only Wisdom remaining at third base.Wisdom's tools fit the position profile well, starting with his well above-average arm strength and plus raw power. The question is whether he'll hit enough to reach his promise. He has some holes in his right-handed swing, gets pull-happy at times and struggles to recognize breaking pitches, though he made some progress in Double-A in 2015.Wisdom needs to become more consistent defensively as well. He has soft hands and good agility to go with his cannon arm, but he he makes more errors than he should.

The ORGANIZATION traded PERSON to PERSON in an August 2017 waiver deal, and he only played in 23 games as a Rays farmhand before he was sent to GPE as the ORGANIZATION in the C.J. PERSON swap. He had a breakout 2018, traversing three levels to the tune of a .299/.399/.451 line, while tallying as many walks as strikeouts, 50 extra-base hits, and 41 steals. So judicious is PERSON's eye for the plate that if he were cloned 15 times and each clone forced to be an umpire, there might be a lot less talk of electronic strike zones. He identifies balls and strikes early in flight and often relaxes before balls have even entered the catcher's mitt. There's a chance that PERSON's lack of power (he has more from the right side) limits the way his eye for the zone plays in the big leagues, since pitchers will be more likely to attack him without fear of him doing damage on his own. Most of his doubles come by slashing balls down either baseline, or when he turns gappers into extra bases because of his speed. We think there's enough bat to retain most of the on-base ability PERSON has shown so far and that, combined with his multi-positional versatility, could yield super-utility value. 
Though he spent all of last year playing either second base or shortstop, PERSON also has experience in both outfield corners and at third base. The ORGANIZATION added PERSON to the 40-man this offseason and while they're well-stocked on the infield (PERSON, PERSON, PERSON, GPE), they're rather thin in the outfield, and very right-handed. As such, PERSON's first opportunity could come as an injury replacement out there, or he may fall into a Chone Figginsy utility role. Eventually though, he may end up as the regular second baseman.

Before back and oblique injuries sidelined him for a month late in the season, PERSON established himself as one of the best junior college prospects in the GPE. He still may have shown enough to go in the first five rounds, and he'll transfer to GPE for 2016 if he doesn't go pro.PERSON has a loose, quick arm that's capable to delivering fastballs up to 95 mph. He usually deals at 90-93 mph with some armside run. His tight slider gives him a solid second pitch and he shows some aptitude for throwing a changeup as well.While PERSON has three pitches and a starter's build, he's probably destined to be a reliever as a pro. There's some effort in his delivery, which he tends to rush, costing him some velocity and control.

PERSON had modest success in his first two years at GPE before taking off as a junior in 2017, saving 14 games to rank 10th in ORGANIZATION Division I. After the ORGANIZATION took him in the supplemental second round, he got knocked around in his pro debut while they had him focus on establishing his fastball. He overcame a rough first month this season to emerge as a reliable closer at ORGANIZATION A Asheville. PERSON relied heavily on his slider with the ORGANIZATION, but GPE has had him use his fastball more often and he now operates at 94-96 mph and tops out at 98, up about 3 mph from his college days. His heater stands out more for its plane, the product of his 6-foot-6 frame, than its life. His slider is still a weapon, arriving in the mid-80s with two-plane break.Though he has a durable build and can show a decent changeup, the ORGANIZATION have no plans to try PERSON as a starter, a role he filled briefly at GPE. He's doing a better job of throwing strikes and locating his pitches now that he's gotten acclimated to pro ball. If he keeps this up, he could be a seventh-inning reliever or possibly more in GPE.

PERSON suffered a torn meniscus in February, but his physical immaturity almost certainly had him ticketed for the ORGANIZATION, so while he may be brought along slowly as minor league spring training gets underway, he should be fine for game action during extended spring training, and when rookie ball starts in June. He's a graceful but unexplosive shortstop, with a limber, projectable frame. His arm and body control are clean fits at short, though his first step leaves a bit to be desired. He may grow into some power as his body matures, which may enable him to play every day, but it's more likely that he becomes a utility type.

PERSON, who is of GPE heritage, likely would have reached the majors in 2018 had he not been sidelined with shoulder fatigue in early-June. The injury effectively ended his season, as he was up for one August rehab appearance and then shut down again for the rest of the year. The exact nature of the injury is unknown and it's not clear if PERSON will be ready for the start of spring training. When healthy, PERSON has an effective four-pitch mix led by a fastball that sits in the 93-97 range and will touch 100. PERSON doesn't have precise fastball command and throws a middling ratio of strikes, but he throws hard enough to get away with mistakes in the zone, and his ability to execute his breaking balls -- the slider down and to his glove side, the curveball in the bottom of the zone or beneath it -- gives him a pretty good chance to start. There are clubs that have PERSON evaluated as a reliever either because of the lack of fastball command or due to perceptions about his deilvery and health. If not for uncertainty surrounding his injury, he'd be right behind PERSON on this list as a near-ready mid-rotation arm or dominant 70-80 inning reliever.

PERSON is a slick defensive shortstop who walked more than he struck out at ORGANIZATION and Triple-A last year. Those traits make him very interesting and perhaps someone we aren't properly enthused about. He's small and has very little raw power, but PERSON's feel for contact is so good that he ends up with sneaky, in-game doubles pop. His three-year ORGANIZATION projections have him at nearly two annual WAR, which means he arguably belongs on our Top 100 list. His realistic ceiling is that of an average regular, something that may be harder to accomplish if PERSON's presence forces him to second base, where the offensive bar is higher.

GPE comes from a football family -- his grandfather PERSON, father PERSON and uncle Kris all played professionally -- but has made his name in baseball. He won the LOCATION's batting title (.408) and freshman of the year award in 2016 and stayed at ORGANIZATION State for four years despite getting drafted by the ORGANIZATION in the 30th round as a sophomore and by the ORGANIZATION in the 32nd round last year. One of the best seniors in the 2019 Draft, he broke PERSON' ORGANIZATION career hits record in April before finishing his career with 383 hits. He also led all of ORGANIZATION Division I as a senior with 108 hits, which was also a ORGANIZATION State single-season record. The scouting report on GPE has changed little during his college career. A switch-hitter, he has an extreme contact approach that results in a lot of opposite-field singles but few walks and little in the way of power. His best tool is his well above-average speed and he did a better job of translating it into stolen bases as a senior.GPE also has improved as a center fielder during his time with the ORGANIZATION, showing better reads and routes instead of just relying on his quickness to track down balls. He has a stronger arm than most at his position and touched 93 mph with his fastball when he started five games on the mound as a sophomore. One scout likened him to a faster version of PERSON.

Signed in July 2012 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON spent his first three pro seasons in GPE ball before finally advancing to a full-season level for the first time in 2016.
