PERSON continued to perform well in the ORGANIZATION, and the A's added him to the 40-man roster after the season.PERSON makes a lot of contact from the left side of the plate, where he employs an open setup with a flat swing that enables him to spray the ball across the whole field. While it does limit his power potential, PERSON has a knack for finding the gaps and uses his plus speed to take extra bases when possible. That speed also makes PERSON a capable center fielder, and he has the requisite arm strength needed to play right field.With his left-handed bat, speed and defensive versatility, PERSON has the makings of becoming a future bench outfielder at the highest level. If he can make further strides as a hitter, and possibly add some power to his game, he could take on a greater role.

PERSON PERSON surgery wiped out PERSON' first two college seasons at GPE, and he pitched sparingly on a loaded 2016 Gators staff that included five future first-rounder. But the ORGANIZATION saw enough to take him in the fourth round that June, and he has proven healthy and durable since. He led the Minors with 15 wins in 2018 and made a successful jump to Double-A this year before going to the Indians in a three-team trade in July that sent PERSON to Cincinnati.PERSON won't be a pitcher who wows people with his stuff because all three of his pitches grade as average. But he has a 91-92 mph fastball that gets on hitters quickly because he commands it well and gets excellent extension in his delivery. PERSON liked his slider more than his changeup in 2018, but the latter pitch has been more effective this year.Though PERSON struggled with his control early in the 2019 season, he settled down and resumed throwing strikes. His ceiling is somewhat limited, but he knows what he's doing on the mound and misses enough bats to eventually be a fifth starter or swingman in the big leagues.

Even among a historically talented group of ORGANIZATION shortstops (PERSON, PERSON, GPE Turang), PERSON was clearly the most gifted defender of the group and the best defensive high school infielder a lot of scouts have ever seen. He has 80 hands, above-average range, a plus arm, and an intoxicating flare and confidence not typical of humans of this stature. PERSON's size, or lack there of, is why he fell to the draft's third round, as there was concern he would not have the requisite physicality to hit big league pitching. After a few years of pro ball, scouts think his wrists and forearms are strong enough to put viable contact in play, but probably not with enough force to truly profile as an everyday shortstop. 
Sources who have seen PERSON and other punchless leatherwizards think the likes of PERSON and PERSON had more thump than PERSON does at the same age. That's not to say that they don't think PERSON is a big leaguer, as everyone thinks he's going to have a very long big league career as an elite defensive shortstop and infield utility man a la PERSON or PERSON. That type of player is going away, but we think PERSON is exceptional.

A 2013 international signee out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON opened eyes the next year during his impressive professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. That success carried over into his first stateside action in 2015, when he slashed .344/.380/.469 in 45 games between the ORGANIZATION and GPE York-Penn Leagues. PERSON advanced to full-season ball for the first time in 2016, only to miss a portion of the first half with an ankle injury and appear in just 73 games.PERSON's quick hands from the left side of the plate fuel his game as a slap hitter who predominantly hits the ball on the ground and sprays it from line to line. He's also an adept bunter and gets out of the batter's box quickly, utilizing his above-average speed. PERSON will never offer much in the way of power, but he makes enough hard contact to accrue his share of doubles and triples.A raw defender when he signed, PERSON was one of GPE's more improved outfielders in 2016 after making strides with his routes and angles to the ball. He's capable of playing center field but profiles better in left, where his speed and average arm strength are cleaner fits.

After yo-yoing back and forth between the bullpen and rotation since college, PERSON was finally 'penned in 2018 and had a two-inning sip of coffee with the GPE last June before he fractured his right fibula during a play at the plate. He would need season-ending surgery. PERSON's command has long foreshadowed an eventual permanent move to the bullpen, but he has the stuff to accrue big league outs. He can alter the shape of his mid-90s fastball to sink or cut, has a fine mid-80s curveball, and a power changeup that averages 90mph. He didn't throw his hard cutter/slider during his short appearances with the ORGANIZATION last year, but we're unsure if the pitch has actually be scrapped. It's an unusually deep repertoire for a reliever, probably one better suited for inducing ground balls than strikeouts, but is possibly enough for PERSON to go for four or more outs at a time.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION Player: PERSON is a two-sport star for PERSON, excelling on the gridiron as a wide receiver along with on the diamond as a middle infielder. He participated in ORGANIZATION's Breakthrough Series event this past year.A switch-hitter, ORGANIZATION has an athletic build and a medium frame which allows him to make consistent contact. He has a medium-length swing from both sides of the plate and boasts fair bat speed.

One of the youngest players in the 2013 Draft, PERSON didn't turn 18 until three months after he signed for $159,700 as an eighth-round pick. He spent most of his first two pro seasons in GPE ball before making a strong impression during his full-season debut in 2015.PERSON has one of the purest bats in the ORGANIZATION system. He employs a compact left-handed swing that sprays line drives to all fields and has a knack for working counts. His approach doesn't result in a lot of power, though he can sting the ball into the gaps on occasion.PERSON has solid speed but still is learning how to apply it on the bases and in the outfield. A center fielder in 2013 and 2014, he has played mostly left field this season. His below-average arm precludes him from seeing action in right field.

A 2017 PERSON breakout coincided with good health and a pair of prescription lenses. He walked more than he struck out across three minor league levels, and rose to Triple-A and into our overall top 100. He had a similarly strong 2018, which included a Futures Game invite, a .390 OBP at Triple-A, and then a strong 30-game big league stint in GPE and September, all reinforcing that PERSON's 2017 breakout was legitimate. A solid if unspectacular defender, PERSON's pop times were depressed during his big league cameo, hovering between 2.05 and 2.10, both below average for a catcher. But he's an average receiver and ball-blocker, and is a perfectly acceptable defensive catcher without a disqualifying shortcoming. 
Where PERSON shines is in the batter's box. His hands work in a tight loop, giving PERSON the capacity to catch velocity and still lift the baseball, and he's strong enough to muscle out balls to his pull-side, though to this point his approach has yielded more doubles than homers. He is a pull-only plodder and he'll likely always be a low ORGANIZATION guy, and it's possible major league pitchers will find ways to attack him in ways that limit his power output, but he's going to make a lot of contact and reach base, which, at catcher, could make him an All-Star.

PERSON found a better slider in 2019 and went from a lefty with average stuff to one with an out pitch. His fastball command is crude, and he especially struggles to work fastballs to his glove side right now. When he can get it in there, the angle is tough on righties and it helps set up backfoot sliders, which PERSON locates pretty consistently. He has fastball-heavy starter stuff and repertoire depth, but below-average command will probably limit him to inefficient, five-ish inning outings, or perhaps move him to the bullpen. If his velo ticks up out of the 'pen then it could be a dominant pitch, as it already plays up due to extension and angle.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON twice, in the 17th round out of an ORGANIZATION high school in 2008 and in the 25th round as a redshirt junior from GPE Tech four years later. In between, he spent a season each at LOCATION and GPE (Ariz.) CC and had PERSON surgery. Signed for $5,000, he made his big league debut in September 2014 and was sold to the Athletics a year later.PERSON somehow misses bats despite lacking a true plus pitch. He operates at 89-94 mph with a fastball that has some armside run, throws a downer curveball to left-handers and back-foots his slider against righties. He also mixes in a changeup that can be an average offering at ORGANIZATION's control and command never have been his strong suits. He did a better job of locating his pitches where he wanted in 2014, though his walk rate jumped back up in 2015. He's unusual as a situation lefty who's not easy prey for right-handed hitters.

PERSON had a rough first season in pro ball as a 20-year-old in the ORGANIZATION. His bat was raw coming out of high school, especially for a hitter who was old for his class, but he was a second round pick because he already had big power and was likely to grow into more. He remains an archtypical right field prospect. There's power, a huge frame, and arm strength. He'd be a sophomore-eligible college player in 2019 had he gone to PERSON and the ORGANIZATION typically send newly drafted collegians to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. That means PERSON will likely begin 2019 in extended spring training and, since he'll essentially be repeating that level until June, he needs to start hitting while he's there.

While shortstop PERSON was creating buzz running up ORGANIZATION boards as a superior college shortstop, PERSON was more than making a name for himself with as consistent a performance on the mound as any college starter in the country.PERSON has moved around during his college career, starting at ORGANIZATION, moving to PERSON as a sophomore, then moving to the ORGANIZATION and becoming their Friday starter as a junior. He might now have wow stuff, but what he has has been really good in 2015, all coming from an easy, simple delivery. He pitches off his fastball, which is a tick above-average sitting in the 92-94 mph range, and it plays up because of his feel for the strike zone. His slider has been a bit inconsistent, but he's shown it can be a solid breaking ball in the past. His changeup needs some refinement and looks kind of like a hybrid splitter-type pitch.PERSON will need to improve his third pitch to continue to have success at the pro level, but he's raised his stock this spring and has the makings of a solid, innings-eating starter.

The biggest over-slot signing by the ORGANIZATION in the 2013 Draft, PERSON got $278,000 in the 18th round to pass up his commitment to PERSON. He has made steady progress, getting stronger and polishing his all-around tools to blossom into a potential five-tool player. A strong start in Triple-A this season earned him his first big league callup in late June, but he ruptured the patellar tendon in his right knee when he ran into an outfield wall in his first game with the ORGANIZATION and was lost for the year. Nearly a month after suffering the injury, PERSON was dealt to the A's with PERSON and PERSON at the ORGANIZATION for right-hander PERSON. PERSON makes repeated hard contact with a short, quick left-handed stroke. His bat speed, strength and plus speed give him 20-20 upside, though he's still learning to be an efficient basestealer. To reach his offensive ceiling, he'll need to get more selective at the plate because he walks infrequently and puts too many early-count pitches in play rather than waiting for one to drive.PERSON has made tremendous defensive improvement since turning pro. He has worked diligently with outfield instructor PERSON to refine his reads and routes, going from spending the majority of his time on the corners in his first two season to being a quality center fielder. He also has bolstered his arm strength to at least average.

PERSON was one of the top two-way players available in the 2014 Draft, with the majority of teams believing he had a higher upside on the mound. PERSON bucked that consensus, however, by taking him as an outfielder and paying him $914,600 as a second-round pick.The ORGANIZATION winner at the Under PERSON All-America Game at FACILITY last August, PERSON combines bat speed, strength and feel for hitting, making it possible that he could develop into a .285 hitter with 20 homers per season. He broke into pro ball as a center fielder, but he eventually should move to right, where his plus arm will fit well. PERSON is an average runner.On the mound, PERSON's three-quarters delivery gives him good angle and movement on his fastball, which averages 89-91 mph and peaks at 94. He also features a promising curveball and a changeup with some life.

GPE may have posted the second-worst ORGANIZATION (4.69) of his career in 2016, but his year didn't lack positives. He worked a career-high 134 1/3 innings, ranked third in the Triple-A PERSON in strikeouts (122) despite not arriving there until mid-May and would have placed second in whiff rate (10.2 per nine innings) if he hadn't fallen just short of enough innings to qualify. He continued to build on that progress in 2017 -- until he received a season-ending suspension on July 1 after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs.GPE's fastball sits at 91-94 mph and peaks at 96, but it's much nastier than its velocity alone would indicate. He's 6-foot-7 and his long levers give him great extension and create a difficult plane and angle when he keeps his delivery in sync. His secondary pitches lack reliability, though his mid-80s slider is solid at times and his fringy changeup is improving.San Francisco still envisions GPE as a starter, and he'll need to refine his changeup, control and command to succeed in that role in the big leagues. He could make for a very dynamic reliever, giving hitters an unusual look while theoretically adding more velocity in shorter stints.

PERSON entered 2012 as a first-round candidate before a lackluster high school senior season and his commitment to PERSON dropped him to the ORGANIZATION in the 39th round. He has had a hard time staying healthy since, redshirting in 2013 after thoracic outlet and PERSON surgeries and pitching once in 2014 because of a stress fracture in his back. He pitched well in the ORGANIZATION rotation last year, though signability and health questions cause him to fall to the Cardinals in the 28th round, then missed the first three months of the 2016 season with a lat strain.In three truncated starts at the end of the regular season, PERSON showed why scouts have been tracking him for years. He sat in the low 90s and touched 96 mph with his fastball, which features run and heavy sink. His low-80s slider continued to show flashes of becoming a plus pitch, and he seemed to trust his developing changeup more than ever.Though he has three pitches and consistently delivers strikes, PERSON's lack of durability makes it hard to project him as a starter in pro ball. With his size (6-foot-7) and fastball/slider combination, he could become a high-leverage reliever if he can stay on the mound. Because he's already 22 and has such an extensive medical history, he's a wild card for the GPE.

PERSON ORGANIZATION has had its fair share of draftees, PERSON being by far the most successful, but only a half-dozen have been taken in the top three rounds of the regular Draft in June. PERSON's size and stuff give him the chance to give the program a lucky No. 7 taken in the early rounds this year.A product of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks, PERSON's 6-foot-4 frame and plus fastball have gotten plenty of attention this spring. He's been touching 95 mph consistently throughout his starts. He throws two breaking balls, a fringy curveball and a slider that flashes above-average. He mixes in a viable changeup as well. PERSON's arm action can get a bit long, making it tougher for him to repeat his delivery. That, in turn, leads to command issues.PERSON's arm strength, durable frame and potential four-pitch mix could give him the chance to at least get sent out as a starter. But a team taking him in the top three rounds will also know that shortening him up and putting him in the bullpen could allow his fastball-slider combination to play up and get him to the big leagues more quickly.

PERSON went through his redshirt sophomore season at Nevada-Reno without too much fanfare, though he did hit over .400. It was unbeknownst to anyone, it seems, that he was actually PERSON eligible. That fact was discovered as he was playing well for the GPE National Collegiate Team, with several teams expressing interest. The ORGANIZATION won out, signing him for $735,000 as a non-drafted free agent.PERSON is a fast-twitch athlete who went out in his pro debut and did what he had done all spring and early summer: hit. He has a solid approach at the plate, one that is geared to line drives and hitting the gaps. He does have some raw power, but he has a firm understanding of what his game is. That's getting on base and causing damage with his plus speed. That speed works in the outfield as well, where he covers a lot of ground and plays an above-average center field.PERSON might profile best as a fourth outfielder type, one who can play good defense at all three spots and impact the game with his speed. If he hits enough, though, he could end up being a table-setting regular in center field.

The ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the 14th round in 2016 out ORGANIZATION, where he had posted a career .355 average over three seasons. He continued to show an advanced bat during his pro debut, but opened his first full season behind schedule due to a wrist injury. When he finally took the field in mid-May, PERSON torched PERSON pitching at a .361/.431/.530 clip to earn a late promotion to Class A Advanced Lynchburg. PERSON is a toolsy college product with remaining upside. Hitting from an open stance, he creates leverage to the ball and keeps his barrel in the zone for an extended period of time. It in turn allows him to effectively cover both sides of the plate and use the entire field, something he has always done well. PERSON does have some pop in his bat, though it's mostly to the gaps right now. He's an above-average runner who gets out of the box well and finished fourth in the ORGANIZATION' system with 20 steals in 2017 despite limited action. PERSON's speed also plays well in right field, where he spent his entire full-season debut, and his above-average arm strength is a natural fit at the position. While his hit-over-power profile at a corner position might not hold up as well at higher levels, PERSON's broad set of skills and solid tools give him a solid chance to consistently outperform projections.

Ever since PERSON signed out of the ORGANIZATION for just $90,000 in 2009, he's shown glimpses of very exciting tools. He's been as enigmatic as he's been productive, however, making it a bit tough to evaluate his future.The 2015 season was a microcosm of PERSON's development. The young infielder was hitting for average and decent pop, stealing bases and playing good second base. When he didn't get called up following injuries to PERSON and PERSON, PERSON wasn't happy, and it showed in his performance. PERSON continues to be the key to his inconsistencies. PERSON has the tools to be a top-of-the-order hitter with more extra-base power than you'd expect. He always had the range and hands to play shortstop, his original position, but the mental grind proved to be too much. PERSON is capable of playing good defense on the right side of the infield.PERSON has played second, the outfield and a little bit of third base in Triple-A during the 2016 season while continuing to take ground balls at short, and he did make his big league debut briefly in May. To stick, he might have to break in as a super-utility type. But he'll have to earn his way there and prove he can handle the bright lights of the big leagues.

GPE finished runner-up at the 2014 College World Series, thanks in part to a lineup that featured four players drafted in the first seven rounds. The 2015 version of the ORGANIZATION won it all in 2015. ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION' fifth-round pick, was supposed to be the team's top returning hitter, but back surgery in late January altered those plans. When healthy, ORGANIZATION is a pure hitter who controls the strike zone well and excels at getting on base. At 6-foot-3 and 215 pounds, he has the strength and leverage to produce above-average left-handed power. To do so, he'll need to get more aggressive, incorporate his lower half better in his swing and turn on more pitches, something he struggled doing when he first returned. ORGANIZATION moves better than most players his size, using his solid speed well on the bases and in the outfield. The only below-average tool in his arsenal is his arm, which relegates him to left field, a spot he played during his pro debut.

Even though PERSON' frame hasn't filled out very much since he teenage days, his velocity has climbed. PERSON and spindly, the low-slot lefty now sports a fastball that sits in the low-to-mid 90s. PERSON uses his curveball to attack both left and right-handed hitters, and his lack of changeup development to this point is the chief reason why he may project to the bullpen, where he may throw even harder and turn into something resembling PERSON. We like lanky, athletic pitchers with feel for spin. Though there are clear things to work on, PERSON is one of those. He should spend 2019 at Hi-A.

The ORGANIZATION were able to sign PERSON out of their own backyard with an over-slot deal that kept him from attending PERSON. Then they sent the big right-hander to full-season ball to make his debut in 2011 and pushed him up a level to the ORGANIZATION in year two. He finished fourth in the organization in strikeouts and batting average against while pitching nearly the entire season at age 20. PERSON has a terrific pitcherâs frame and flashes the stuff to go with it. His fastball can be above-average, up to 93-94 mph. Heâll show glimpses of an average curve and his changeup has the chance to be average as well. His secondary stuff can be inconsistent, particularly command-wise. If he can continue to find a level of consistency with his delivery, his stuff has the chance to take a leap forward. Heâs continuing to move up the ladder, still fairly ahead of the curve age-wise.

After going undrafted out of high school, PERSON spent the 2016 season at ORGANIZATION (Fla.) JC, where he showed dynamic athleticism and tools but produced uneven results. The ORGANIZATION still made him their 11th round pick that June, and he signed for $400,000.Much like they did with 2015 second-rounder PERSON, the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON with the intention of making him a switch-hitter. He's impressed the club with his aptitude in learning to hit from the left side, but, overall, he's a bit of a project at the plate. PERSON's elite speed is a weapon, both in center field and on the basepaths, but he needs to improve his basestealing technique. PERSON also has a well above-average arm, especially for center field. Team officials rave about PERSON's athleticism, speed and promising hitting ability, and the belief is that he'll eventually develop the necessary baseball skills.

GPE, in GPE, is known more for producing wine than baseball players. PERSON, a strong, athletic right-hander from PERSON, could change all of that.PERSON has been on radar screens for a while, but really saw his stock soar as the spring progressed. While other intriguing prep arms in GPE have been inconsistent, PERSON has been impressive on a regular basis. The 6-foot-3 righty has some serious power stuff, headlined by a fastball that has consistently been up to 94-96 mph this spring. He throws two breaking balls, with the curve a bit ahead of the slider. Throwing from a higher slot, he gets under the slider at times, but when he stays on top of it, it can be a nasty out pitch. His changeup is a bit behind, but is a viable option. In addition to his stuff, scouts love the ORGANIZATION commit's competitiveness and the football mentality -- he was also his high school's quarterback -- he brings to the mound. That should help him maximize his formidable raw stuff and fly off the board as early as the first round.

PERSON's velocity was up during the ORGANIZATION. Low-slot lefties who touch 96 and have an average breaking ball typically end up in someone's bullpen, and we thought PERSON had a shot to be picked in the Rule 5. He was hurt a few times during the spring and summer and his fastball has a hittable angle, so we're rounding down a bit on what otherwise looks like a fine middle relief piece if you just look at the stuff.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON MLB Player: PERSON has emerged as one of GPE's top recruits due to his success in 2015-16. He even made an All-Tournament Team with the ORGANIZATION at the 2016 ORGANIZATION World Championship. PERSON can hide his arm well with a quick delivery and thus has no problem holding runners on at first base. His fastball still sits just below average in terms of velocity, but it can sneak up on hitters, and he pairs the heater with a slow curveball.

PERSON's broad, square, muscular shoulders look like they belong to a D1 high school football prospect. He has one of the better frames in the class and plenty of room to add power to a body that already produces a lot of it. PERSON has explosive hands and a natural uppercut swing. He hits many more balls out during BP than is typical for a hitter this age and has taken his peers deep in games, too. PERSON's feet and actions are workable on the infield but he struggles with throwing velocity and accuracy when he's forced to throw from a lower arm slot, as shortstops often are. If he can't correct it he'll need to move to the outfield. PERSON's power separates him from most of the rest of the class and he's a potential star if he can stay at short.

In the not-too-distant past, a player like PERSON would have been overlooked by many teams because of his size. The combination of more organizations embracing analytics and the success of players like PERSON, not to mention the superb performance of the 5-foot-7 infielder, had PERSON poised to perhaps be the top college position player taken in the 2018 Draft. A broken wrist at the start of the season slowed him down, but he returned in April swinging a hot bat.While PERSON might have been more of a gut feel kind of player for scouts, he now has track record on top of being a scout favorite. Analytics departments love him because of his approach at the plate that led to more walks than strikeouts in 2017, and while he doesn't have a ton of over-the-fence power, he makes consistent hard contact and is a legitimate extra-base threat. His speed and instincts should allow him to continue to be a base stealer.While PERSON has played mostly second base in deference to PERSON at FACILITY, some feel he could handle shortstop if need be. If not, he has the chance to be a ORGANIZATION caliber second baseman in the future. Even with the injury, he should land squarely in the top 10 in June.

Before the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the 29th round of the 2011 Draft, no one had ever been selected from PERSON in GPE. It's been a long and winding path for the hard-throwing right-hander, but things appeared to start clicking a bit in 2015 as he reached Double-A for the first time. After a strong ORGANIZATION showing, he was added to the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster.PERSON has always had premium velocity and a decent slider, but has been all over the place. He'll sit in the mid-90s and touch 97-98 mph regularly, throwing it with a ton of sink to get a lot of ground-ball outs. His slider is an out pitch at times and he'll mix in a splitter. In the past, he'd look like a world-beater one night and like he'd never pitched before the next. In 2015, he started to figure it out and find some level of consistency, though command is still an issue.Continued strike-throwing could raise PERSON's profile a bit, though he's likely never going to close games. A career as a seventh-inning guy might be his ceiling.
GPE is a well-rounded prospect who has a chance to play everyday so long as he stays at shortstop as his bat, though competent, looks as though it will offer little impact.

PERSON's velocity was way down last year, often resting 91-93 and sometimes ranging to 89-93, after he had gone long stretches of high school starts where he'd sit 93-95. His violent head whack and arm action caused considerable consternation among amateur scouts who worried about his long term arm health, but the org attributes PERSON's 2018 velo decline to the rigors of pro ball, something it believes PERSON will be better prepared to deal with in 2019. The most electric version of PERSON has a high-leverage fastball/curveball combination, a two-pitch duo that could close games. If PERSON's changeup and command improve, he has mid-rotation upside. He made strike-throwing strides in 2018, but the changeup is still below-average. He should be ticketed for full-season ball and see a substantial innings increase, but the key variable to watch when camp breaks is his velocity.

GPE was a two-way prospect in high school before a shoulder injury ended his future on the mound. It didn't hinder his ability in in the outfield, however, and his above-average speed and athleticism make him a prototypical center fielder. He covers ground well and has shown improving outfield instincts. At the plate, GPE has quick hands and a smooth left-handed swing. In order to reach his potential, he will have to improve his approach. He has surprising pop in his wiry frame but has a tendency to try to hit home runs too often. PERSON hasn't had an easy transition to the ORGANIZATION, his raw tools still give him the chance to develop into a solid everyday player.

PERSON spent three years in the UNC-Greensboro rotation, but they were uneven seasons, at best. The ORGANIZATION, though, liked his size and his potential enough to take him in the third round of the 2014 Draft. He rewarded their faith with a strong full-season debut the following year and continued to climb the ladder in 2016, culminating with an impressive second-half showing in Double-A. But PERSON's time with the ORGANIZATION came to an end late in November, when PERSON dealt him and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON uses his 6-foot-8 frame well to throw downhill, and while his four-seam fastball doesn't feature a ton of sink or life, that plane can help him get ground-ball outs. It will sit in the 92-93 mph range and can touch 95-96 on occasion. His changeup is his best secondary pitch and he also throws a true curveball, a breaking pitch that might improve if he can tighten it and add a little velocity to it.More athletic than you'd think given his gangly frame, PERSON fields his position well and repeats his delivery better than you might expect, translating in strong control and command and giving him the chance to be at least a back-end rotation guy in the future.

PERSON was a huge standout player at the heavily-scouted ORGANIZATION showcase in the GPE in February. He didn't swing and miss in about a dozen swings (a rarity for the event) and made consistent loud contact while also displaying his above average speed and projectable power. PERSON is the ORGANIZATION got on him hard especially after this event and I was also at this event, so I buy the upside here, even if the swing is a little unique. PERSON has a chance to stick in center field, but at this age and body type, it's hard to predict the differnce between 50 and 55 and 60 speed at maturity, so you're buying more the well-rounded skillset than a particular position at this point.

After hitting .240 in his first three seasons at LOCATION, PERSON batted .346 with 20 steals as a senior, won the PERSON as college baseball's best catcher and was named Pac-12 Conference defensive player of the year. He has continued to impress after signing for $100,000 as an eighth-rounder in 2015, batting .304/.391/.469 and reaching Double-A during his first full pro season.His 5-foot-10, 175-pound frame leads to a lot of questions about whether he'll be durable enough to be a big league starter, but that's the only real concern. His size also makes him the player he is, as he's much quicker and more athletic than the typical catcher. He receives and blocks well, and he enhances solid arm strength with fast footwork and impressive accuracy -- which allowed him to throw out 51 percent of basestealers in 2016.PERSON excels at making contact at the plate and has walked (64) more than he has struck out (53) in his first two pro seasons. He uses a simple left-handed swing but can drive the ball on occasions and improved his slugging percentage at each of his first four Minor League stops, so he might be able to provide double-digit homers on an annual basis.

Five years after PERSON went No. 1 overall in the PERSON, PERSON has another hard-throwing right-hander poised to go in the first round. Unlike PERSON, PERSON was a prospect in high school, too, though signability knocked him down to the 41st round in 2011. He can light up a radar gun like no other college arm in this year's PERSON, as he's capable of working in the mid 90s and hitting 98 mph with his fastball, with triple-digits within reach in shorter stints. PERSON has a lot of moving parts in his delivery and still is learning to control his 6-foot-6 frame, so he lacks consistency with the rest of his pitches as well as his control and command. His low-80s slider has the most potential of his secondary offerings, and he also throws a curveball and a changeup. PERSON moved to the bullpen this spring and was throwing well as PERSON's closer. If he can't develop a reliable second weapon and do a better job of locating his pitches, that could be his long-term role at the next level.

Signed for $1.1 million in mid-July, PERSON had an eye-opening instructional league. His range, hands, actions and arm are all easy fits at shortstop, and he could be a plus glove there at peak. His entire offensive profile depends on his frame filling out. PERSON's lack of strength is evident with the bat in his hands, but you can go kind of nuts projecting on much of his skillset, including the speed and arm strength, because PERSON so clearly has lots of physical growth on the horizon and is an above-average athlete. He's so young that he wasn't even eligible to sign on July 2nd because he was still 15. Were he a domestic high schooler, he wouldn't be draft eligible until 2020, when he'd be just shy of 18. His development may initially be slow, but he has significant literal and figurative growth potential and a non-zero shot to be a well-rounded shortstop at peak.

Coming from the GPE Virgin Islands, PERSON obviously didn't have a ton of top-level baseball experience. But he may have found a home, and a way to move quickly, coming out of the bullpen. The ORGANIZATION initially wanted PERSON to get some time as a starter so he could build up some innings. That plan was scrapped heading into 2014 and his first taste of full-season ball. The ORGANIZATION decided to see how his stuff would play full-time out of the bullpen and it turned out to be a ridiculously good fit. Coming over the top in his delivery, PERSON' 93-95 mph fastball is deceptive, making it seem even harder. He has a plus changeup, with a 15-mph separation from his fastball, that hitters just can't see from that arm slot. His breaking ball is serviceable, but it's that fastball-changeup combination that has allowed him to miss so many bats.The ORGANIZATION added PERSON to the 40-man roster, sure someone would take a chance on him in the Rule 5 Draft, and he received a surprise callup to the big leagues for a game in June.

PERSON was a mid-tier prospect in high school and took a big step forward as a freshman at ORGANIZATION, developing the raw power to be more than just a catch-and-throw type. He still didn't put up much in the way of traditional statistical production until the second half of his draft year, which amazingly occurred after a quick return from a broken hamate bone. PERSON' frame is compact and stout, and his bat's impact is a question mark, but he has everyday tools.

PERSON had a breakout campaign on the Cape after his freshman year and, while he's lost a step since then, he still may be able to play second base and he has one of the most advanced bats in the draft.

For the second time in five years, GPE PERSON could have a shortstop selected in the first round. PERSON isn't as tooled up as PERSON or the other top shortstops in a deep college crop, but he has a high floor as a steady up-the-middle defender with surprising power. He was one of four players to hit 10 or more homers in GPE Coast Conference games in 2018, joining PERSON. 2 overall pick PERSON, PERSON first-rounder PERSON and PERSON second-rounder PERSON Conine.Though he's not physically imposing, PERSON has quick hands and deceptive strength that give him at least above-average raw power. A right-handed hitter, he has a knack for putting the barrel on the ball. He shows the ability to hit for average and power, and he has done a better job of drawing walks this spring despite his aggressive approach.The biggest knock on PERSON is his below-average speed. Most big league shortstops run better than that, though some scouts think he can stay at the position because he has quick actions and hands. Others believe his speed and average arm will land him at second base, where he played as a freshman and still would profile well offensively.

A small middle infielder with sparkplug type skills, GPE has shown a penchant for playing above his tools against very good competition.The high school shortstop was a standout for ORGANIZATION's 18 and Under team last summer on both sides of the ball. He handles the bat well putting the ball in play consistently; he didn't strike out once with PERSON. He's not particularly physical and power will never be a part of his game, leading to more PERSON comps than, say, PERSON or PERSON. He has plenty of speed and maximizes it as a base-stealing threat. The ORGANIZATION State commit has the tools to stay at shortstop thanks to his quickness and accuracy, though without pure arm strength. He's a natural leader and a coach on the field from short.Teams will have to look past GPE's size and project some added strength when deciding to take him. With his tools and plus makeup, he's the type who proves any skeptics wrong.

PERSON (pronounced with a vowel sound like 'plow' or 'allow') was an under-the-radar, bat-first prospect at ORGANIZATION who the ORGANIZATION picked in the third round. He has always been a second baseman but was never the pedigree type given his position and average at best speed, defense, and arm. He also tore his ORGANIZATION as a freshman. His indicators were positive--plate discipline, contact skills, bat speed, enough power to profile--and we were high on PERSON entering the year, pegging him as a 45 FV. He went off in 2018, following a fine Double-A look in 2017 by demolishing the level in 2018, then performing even better at Triple-A, earning a big league look, where he put up almost 1.0 WAR in just 43 games. The offense has taken off even more than those highest on him internally had expected, with some chance for 50 hit and 60 game power with passable defense at second, along with versatility to play left field and possibly first base if needed. PERSON is now in the weird prospect spot where he isn't the highly-drafted, tooled-up brand name type you typically find in the middle of a top 100, but he's about as low risk of a bat as there is with prospect eligibility, and he can also play up the middle, so his six years of control have tons of value to a small market team like the ORGANIZATION.

Walters State (Tenn.) CC had two early-round picks in the 2014 Draft, and both are off to promising starts in pro ball. Right-hander Brent PERSON became the second-highest pick in GPE history when the ORGANIZATION grabbed him in the second round, and PERSON became the third-highest when the ORGANIZATION took him in the fourth.PERSON's best pitch is his curveball, a plus offering when at its best with power and depth. He has added some fastball velocity since signing and now works in the low 90s and touches 95 mph with some cutting and tailing action when he keeps the pitch down in the strike zone. He also has improved his feel for a sinking changeup.PERSON has gotten stronger since signing and still has room for more projection on his athletic 6-foot-4 frame. He has made strides with his control and command as well and has the potential to blossom into a mid-rotation starter if he keeps getting better. Hitters have difficulty handling his pitches because his high-three-quarters delivery creates deception and plane.

PERSON figured they would be spending a lot of time at ORGANIZATION in GPE to see lefty PERSON and his teammate PERSON this spring. PERSON went down with PERSON surgery and while PERSON has been healthy, his inconsistent performance at the plate has left some scouts scratching their heads.There have been times the ORGANIZATION All GPE has shown offensive ability, barreling up the baseball well and showing some power as well. But evaluators don't love the swing and aren't sure how it will play at the next level. A shortstop in high school, most see a move to third in his future, where he has a good chance to be an above-average defender.It will be a team that believes in the bat that will take PERSON in the top five rounds. It also might have to be a team with multiple picks and bonus pool creativity, as it might take an above-value deal to sign PERSON away from attending PERSON.

Teams that like speed will certainly spend time in GPE at ORGANIZATION, alma mater of previous top Draft prospects like PERSON in 2012, PERSON in '09 and PERSON in '02.That's where PERSON currently patrols center field. He profiles as a top-of-the-order type, a guy who will use his speed on both sides of the ball to be a basestealing threat and an excellent defender in the outfield. He's a slashing slap-and-run hitter with a short stroke that sprays line drives at times.PERSON is an outstanding athlete who reminds some of a ORGANIZATION or PERSON Revere-type player who can become a tablesetter atop a big league lineup in the future.

So conservative was PERSON' swing when he first arrived in the states that ORGANIZATION coaches were trying to make adjustments to his lower-half use in the middle of games in the hopes that it would unlock power that was clearly dormant in his hands. He has good control of the strike zone and feel to hit for a teenager but despite playing some second and third, he may ultimately wind up at first base. If that's the case, a change that enables the power is necessary.

Since the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON from his GPE high school, he's performed well with largely average stuff. That hasn't kept him from being in demand, as he's been traded twice, first from the M's to the ORGANIZATION following the 2016 season, then again from GPE to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal for PERSON. In 2017, PERSON showed his feel for pitching would work at the upper levels, pitching well for both the ORGANIZATION' and ORGANIZATION' Double-A affiliates while topping 150 innings for the second straight season and finishing an astounding 19-1. His walk rate did spike a bit following the trade, but there's confidence he'll return to the guy who has walked just 2.2 per nine innings in his pro career. His fastball is average velocity-wise, in the low-90s, but it plays up because of his command and life. His curve flashes plus and is his best secondary offering and his changeup gives him a third at least average offering. PERSON mixes his pitches well and gets a ton of groundball outs.PERSON's ability to work ahead and command the ball is the key to his future success. The ORGANIZATION were excited to have PERSON, who has the ceiling of a No. 4 type starter, in their system for a full season and he received his first big league callup in June.
GPE's stuff went from electric in the summer before his prep draft year to pedestrian in college, but ticked back up to it's highest levels in the last few weeks.

Born in GPE, PERSON attended high school in GPE. His elbow blew out when he was a senior, just as he was experiencing an uptick in velocity. WHen he returned, so did his mid-90s fastball. PERSON was traded as part of a package for several good A's relievers. He's advanced from a stuff and pitchability standpoint, enabling him to succeed at Double-A already at age 20. He's a potential mid-rotatino starter.

If not for suffering a left ORGANIZATION tear during a rundown in early May, PERSON, who had a 23-game hit streak at the time, probably would have debuted in 2018 due to PERSON's middle infield woes. Instead, PERSON missed much of the season and is on track for a likely 2019 debut. He'll be the first native GPE to play in the majors. PERSON was acquired (along with PERSON) as part of a lopsided package for PERSON. His elite hand-eye coordination and bat control drive a contact-oriented offensive profile. Since coming over from GPE, PERSON has thickened his once frail-looking frame and improved upon some of the things that limited his in-game power. He was rotating better early in 2018, with the timing of his hip/hand spearation being better, too, and he was no longer ditching his leg kick with two strikes. His 2016 GPE and 2017-2018 ORGANIZATION slugging outputs are probably cariacatures of his true talent level, but PERSON should at least have doubles power. Defensively, PERSON is passable at shortstop and second base. He saw time in center field during the 2016 Fall League but hasn't played there since. Lots of scouts like him as a super utility type, but PERSON will be 25 in July and he hasn't played anywhere other than the middle infield at any point in his career, save for that Fall League. It's more likely he gets a chance to be PERSON's everyday shortstop in 2019 and, provided he hasn't lost a step due to the ORGANIZATION tear, we like him as a low-end regular there.

The ORGANIZATION went high-risk, high-reward when they took PERSON, the GPE high school standout, in the second round, and gave him a well over-slot bonus of $2 million to keep him from heading to GPE PERSON. His pro debut showed there's much work to be done and he repeated the rookie-level ORGANIZATION in 2015.Right now, PERSON is a bit of an all-or-nothing hitter. He has tremendous raw power and a ton of bat speed, with a lot of force and explosion in his swing. He will have to improve his pitch recognition and overall approach considerably for him to be able to progress so he can make more contact and tap into that power. PERSON does have a right fielder's arm, but his below-average speed does limit his range somewhat. PERSON will be the key for PERSON and he's far from a can't-miss prospect. But if it clicks, he's the type of high-ceiling player who could have a huge impact in a lineup.

PERSON is an exception to the rule that high school second basemen aren't usually highly regarded as top pro prospects. His stock soared right before the 2013 Draft, and the ORGANIZATION didn't let him get past their second-round pick at ORGANIZATION. 66 overall.PERSON continued to raise his profile in pro ball, leading the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League with six home runs and a .924 ORGANIZATION. He has struggled in low Class A in 2014, but his bat-on-ball skills and his plus speed should help hit for average as he climbs the ladder. PERSON also has wiry strength and good pop for a middle infielder.PERSON's high baseball IQ and athleticism make him a fine defender at second base. He has quick feet and turns the double play well. GPE may give PERSON a chance to show what he can do at shortstop.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON after his 2017 freshman season, but he went back to school, raised his stock, and was the first ORGANIZATION arm off the board the following year. He has power stuff -- 93-96 with cut action at times, and a plus curveball -- but is wild and may be a reliever, though probably a very good one.

PERSON began his post-high school career on the junior college circuit, at ORGANIZATION State College in GPE. He transferred to PERSON and pitched in relief as a junior, albeit not with good results. The ORGANIZATION liked his stuff enough to take a flier on him in the 30th round of the 2017 Draft. After being sent out as a reliever during his pro debut, PERSON got a chance to start and ran with it, pitching his way across three levels and finishing the year in Double-A.PERSON relies heavily on a fastball-splitter-changeup trio to get hitters out. He'll throw his fastball in the low-90s with occasional life. His split-finger changeup is his out pitch, and it's a good one, thrown in the low-80s with tumble that can miss bats and get weak contact. He mixes in a breaking ball as well and has shown the ability to throw strikes, with all three pitches coming from a quick and repeatable delivery.In all likelihood, PERSON ends up back in the bullpen, where his fastball-split combination could play up. His success as a starter has opened some eyes, and at the very least, he has shown he could be a multi-inning reliever.

The younger brother of GPE pitching prospect PERSON, PERSON might offer more arm strength than his older brother did at this age, but with less feel for pitching.There is a lot to like about the younger PERSON, starting with the flashes of his plus fastball. Early on, PERSON was throwing his heater in the 94-97 mph range, and with good movement at times. He would couple that with a decent breaking ball and even an occasional, albeit inconsistent, changeup. As the spring wore on, PERSON was throwing more in the 90-93 mph range. That, plus his spotty command caused by some delivery issues, likely didn't help his draft stock.At 6-foot-4, PERSON is "what they look like," with room to fill out that ideal pitcher's frame. At some point, a team is going to want to take on that project and try to sign him away from the ORGANIZATION of GPE.

When the ORGANIZATION made the decision to blow well past their international bonus allocation for the 2015-16 signing period, their four pool slots (used to determine their spending allowance) held little value to them. They traded all of them, sending three worth a total of $1,071,300 to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON and infielder PERSON and the fourth to the ORGANIZATION for right-hander PERSON and outfielder PERSON. A second-round pick in 2012, PERSON jumped to high Class A after the deal and helped PERSON win the GPE League title.PERSON is more about polish than power, with his downer curveball qualifying as his lone above-average pitch. He gets good downhill plane on his 88-92 mph fastball, but the pitch lacks life and may not miss many bats at higher levels. His fringy changeup shows some fade and could improve if he used it more often. PERSON has good feel for pitching and always has filled the strike zone. He's an extreme flyball pitcher with a career 0.69 groundout/airout ratio, a cause for concern now that PERSON is playing as one of the best home run parks in the ORGANIZATION. There's still room for some projection in his 6-foot-4 frame, but unless he adds some power to his pitches his ceiling will be limited to GPE. 4 starter.

PERSON opted to return to PERSON for his senior year after being selected in the 18th round in 2016. He immediately improved his stock by hitting .374 to capture the ORGANIZATION batting title, and then followed it with a .315 average and 19 steals as a senior. He ended up signing with ORGANIZATION for $50,000 as their third-round pick in 2017, though a minor injury from PERSON's college season kept him from making his pro debut. After a solid if unspectacular first full season at ORGANIZATION A Hagerstown, PERSON advanced to ORGANIZATION A Advanced Potomac in 2019 and garnered midseason All-Star honors in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is a sum of all parts player who knows how to get the most out of his modest tools. As an undersized right-handed hitter, PERSON focuses on making line-drive contact and putting the ball in play so as to utilize his plus speed. He has pop to the gaps but little-to-no home-run power. He shows instincts, range and soft hands at second base, and he's increased his versatility in 2019 with reps in center field, where his wheels make him a rangy defender. PERSON's lack of impact potential at the plate limits his overall ceiling, but he does enough things well to conceivably reach the Majors in a utility role.

Signed as a skinny infielder at age 17 in July 2013 and immediately transitioned to the mound, PERSON has added size and strength to his 6-foot-1 frame over time. A big '17 that saw him go to the ORGANIZATION, lead the organization in strikeouts and get added to the 40-man roster put him more firmly on the map. He reached Double-A in 2018, but wasn't nearly as dominant in the process.Stuff-wise, PERSON has more than enough to get big league hitters out. He has a lively fastball that he throws consistently up to the mid-90s that can miss bats and get weak contact on the ground. He'll show a plus curveball that can be a true out pitch and a changeup that might be above-average when all is said and done. The premium stuff can play down at times because of his below average command and control. He walked just over four per nine innings in 2018, in line with his career rate, though he really struggled to find the strike zone when he moved up to Double-A.PERSON has some effort to his delivery and can fly open at times, leading to those control problems. There's long been talk about him being a reliever in the future, where his outstanding stuff would play up and his durability could allow him to handle multiple innings.

GPE has tracked as well as scouts could have hoped when he was a gangly, unrefined amateur outfielder. He's shown an ability to make mechanical adjustments and has now performed up through Triple-A, reducing his once concerning strikeout rate as he has climbed the minor league ladder. He'll likely get plenty of playing time with PERSON in 2018 and, though he make take some time to adjust to big league pitching, hit for plus power while playing center field.
GPE spent most of his 2019 junior season injured, but has average stuff when healthy.

From a pure raw tools standpoint, there weren't many better players in the 2013 Draft class than PERSON. In terms of performance, well, that's a different story.PERSON has the tools to do just about everything on the baseball field, but they didn't play out too consistently during his career at ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION felt the athleticism was worth taking a shot in the second round. PERSON was having a strong pro debut before a knee injury ended his season. The approach was to simply throw him out there defensively and free up his offense, which worked initially. PERSON saw most of his game time in center field, got reps at shortstop and he played shortstop exclusively while performing well in his full-season debut.Wherever he ends up, the ORGANIZATION think PERSON is an up-the-middle athlete. If they can unlock the toolbox, the dividends could be huge.

The ORGANIZATION aren't strangers in GPE, signing players like PERSON and ORGANIZATION in the past. PERSON is just getting going in his pro career, making a strong GPE debut in 2012, when he hit .343 in the ORGANIZATION and he continued to hit with a move up to the GPE League in 2013. He has a good approach at the plate and makes consistent contact, avoiding strikeouts, albeit without much power to date. PERSON played both shortstop and third in 2012, but has focused almost entirely at the middle infield spot in 2013. He has good actions and a strong arm and he'd have more value if he can stick at short.

Known as a heady player who gets the most out of his tools, PERSON made his Major ORGANIZATION debut in 2013. He wasn't able to break into the ORGANIZATION crowded outfield in 2014, instead spending the whole season with Triple-A Gwinnett, where he finished in the top 10 in the ORGANIZATION in hits and batting average, but he was back in GPE in 2015. PERSON's first move as general manager of the ORGANIZATION was to claim PERSON off waivers from the ORGANIZATION.A switch-hitter, PERSON makes consistent contact from both sides of the plate. He has minimal power, instead using his above-average speed to get on base and make things happen. He's a solid defender, capable of playing all three outfield positions. PERSON was able to break through into a less crowded outfield in 2015 and showed the ability to fill a role as a fourth outfielder type at the big league level.

A bit of a late bloomer, PERSON didn't make the varsity team at GPE (Calif.) PERSON until his junior year. Despite his slow start, he established himself as an elite hitter in high school, and that carried over to the professional ranks, where he excelled as an 18-year-old in the ORGANIZATION before heading to the ORGANIZATION in the big December three-team deal that made PERSON a GPE Diego Padre.PERSON earns some comparisons to PERSON, a fellow GPE alumnus. He barrels up balls well with his short compact swing. PERSON has shown some power already, and scouts believe he'll be able to unlock more as he physically matures.PERSON is an excellent defender at first base, though he doesn't have the tools to play elsewhere. That means he'll have to keep hitting as he moves through the ORGANIZATION.

GPE and pure stuff wise, ORGANIZATION looks like a top-notch pitching prospect at times. It's the "at times" part that has held him back. With really good pure stuff, ORGANIZATION has shown the ability to miss bats, striking out more than a batter per inning in each of the last two seasons. His fastball is a tick above-average, and he throws it downhill from his 6-foot-4 frame, but it's his changeup that is his out pitch. He also throws a slider, though it's behind the other two pitches. ORGANIZATION's biggest enemy has been his fastball command. When he can throw the pitch for strikes, with that changeup, he has the chance to excel. It just hasn't happened with any consistency as of yet. As a result, ORGANIZATION could end up in a bullpen, and he showed signs of it being a good fit in the ORGANIZATION. For now, though, he'll stay in a rotation and work on his fastball command.

PERSON is a former hockey defenseman who brings that mentality to the mound, attacking hitters with three above average pitches and command. He attacks the zone with a low-90s sinker down in the zone and is a pitch efficient starter who isn't gunning for the strikeout. He's also a shorter strider so his velocity plays down a bit, making his command and offspeed pitches even more important. PERSON's changeup went from rarely used to a pitch that flashes plus in the last year or so, and his high-spin hybrid breaking ball has always been a trusted secondary pitch. He missed much of 2018 with a muscular issue in his shoulder, but was ready to pitch in the big leagues in September, hitting the mid-90s in simulated games and only staying out of competitive contents because of the ORGANIZATION' cautious approach to his rehab.

The ORGANIZATION have a number of young and intriguing pitchers from PERSON, and PERSON features the best combination of stuff and polish. Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in December 2014, he made his GPE debut last season and struck out 70 in 56 innings across three levels. PERSON has a strong arm that routinely delivers 93-95 mph fastballs and can hit the upper 90s. He does a nice job of locating his mid-80s slider, which is a plus pitch at times but slurvy at others. His changeup doesn't have enough separation from his fastball yet, but he isn't afraid to throw it and it figures to develop into an average offering.PERSON likes to challenge hitters and shows signs of being able to command his secondary pitches. He had trouble maintaining his stuff while pitching out of the stretch last summer, so PERSON had him address that problem by working solely out of the stretch during instructional league play -- and his fastball topped out at 99 mph. He has yet to reach full-season ball but the makings of a No. 3 starter are there.

Despite hitting 98 mph with his fastball and flashing a hammer curveball as a high school senior, PERSON lasted 67 picks in the 2012 Draft because he lacked consistency. That same scouting report is true five years later, as he'll look like a frontline starter on some days and a middle reliever on others. He totaled just 315 innings in his first five pro seasons, missing time in 2015 and 2016 with elbow and forearm inflammation.When he's at his best, PERSON can display a double-plus fastball and a plus curveball and changeup. His fastball can sit at 93-95 mph and touches 97 with late life that generates ground balls, though he still has to prove he can hold that velocity deep into games and over a full season. His secondary pitches can be as erratic as they are promising, and he also has added a hard cutter that GPE may have him turn into a true slider. PERSON's control regressed last year and he gets hit more than his stuff indicates he should because his command is unreliable. His dedication to his conditioning and his rehab has frustrated the ORGANIZATION at times, and they're hoping that renewed focus will help him stay healthy and make improvements in 2017. He's still young and they haven't given up on him as a starter, but it's becoming increasingly likely that he'll wind up in the bullpen.

In a year where a lot of the best college catching prospects are skewed heavily in favor of offense (PERSON's PERSON, GPE's PERSON) or defense (ORGANIZATION's PERSON), PERSON is one of the better all-around backstops available. He's a quality defender who has upped his offensive game as a junior.PERSON stands out most for his work behind the plate. He has solid arm strength and such a quick transfer that he consistently records pop times of 1.9 seconds or less and opponents rarely try to run on him. He's a good receiver who has more athleticism and agility than most backstops.After batting a combined .235 in his first two years at ORGANIZATION, PERSON has been one of the ORGANIZATION' most productive hitters this spring. He has a compact right-handed swing that lends itself to contact and getting on base, if not much power. He has at least average speed and can steal a base on occasion.

Initially recruited by the ORGANIZATION of GPE as a third baseman, PERSON blossomed on the mound and some clubs thought PERSON was the best pitcher available in the 2012 Draft. The ORGANIZATION were delighted to grab him with the fifth overall selection and a $3 million bonus. They hoped he could contribute to their big league club by 2014 at the latest, but elbow, biceps, lat and shoulder woes limited him to 152 2/3 innings in his first three pro seasons, including just 4 2/3 last year. When healthy, PERSON fits the ace profile. He usually works at 93-97 with his fastball, which has reached triple digits, and his hammer curveball can be equally as devastating. Both his slider and changeup show the makings of becoming solid options as well.PERSON is also an outstanding athlete who repeats his delivery well, so he has no trouble throwing quality strikes. The ORGANIZATION hoped offseason arthroscopic surgery to clean up his shoulder would return him to full health, but he had a setback and didn't appear in a game until late May. PERSON opted to ease him back into action as a reliever but still envisions him as a starter in the long run.

GPE went undrafted as a GPE high school outfielder in 2012 and couldn't get on the field as a Duke freshman the following spring. He transferred to PERSON (Fla.) CC because he wanted to pitch and immediately attracted scouts when he showed arm strength similar to that of his older brother PERSON, who's now with the ORGANIZATION. The second juco player drafted (third round) in 2014, GPE dominated PERSON A hitters when he became a full-time reliever last year but has seen his control disintegrate in 2017.After operating with an 88-92 mph fastball in his two seasons as a pro starter, GPE recaptured the velocity he flashed at PERSON when he moved to the bullpen. He now works at 94-97 mph and can hit 99 with some natural cutting action. He has scrapped an ineffective changeup in favor of a splitter that shows potential and is better than his soft curveball.There's a lot of effort in GPE's delivery, which hampers his control but does bolster his deception. He'll always be much more about power than finesse, but he'll have to find the strike zone much more consistently to realize his upside of a set-up man.

PERSON was seen as a football-first prospect until late GPE 2018. He played at a couple of showcase events in the summer of 2017 and had some raw tools, but wasn't yet under consideration for the top few rounds of the baseball draft. He was, however, a top 100 football recruit, set to head to GPE to play wide receiver, where his father was on the coaching staff.
