Ultimately signed for $50,000 as a 16th-round pick out of GPE in 2012, he struggled to harness his stuff in his first three years as a pro. He cleaned up his delivery and broke out at high Class A in 2015, earning a spot on the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster. Strictly a reliever, PERSON works with two pitches. His fastball sits in the mid 90s and can reach triple digits, featuring good life to go with its plus-plus velocity. His mid-80s slider can be a wipeout pitch at times, but it lacks consistency and gets slurvy.PERSON's mechanics still aren't pretty, but he's doing a better job of taking a direct path to home plate and finding the strike zone. He walked just 2.5 batters per nine innings in 2015 after averaging 7.6 in his first three pro seasons, and he could advance quickly if he continues to throw strikes.

PERSON's first full professional season saw him start the All-Star Game for the GPE League before moving up to Double-A Pensacola for the second half. After his breakout year, the ORGANIZATION traded him to the Phillies in exchange for PERSON. None of PERSON's pitches jump off the page, but he does have four of them that he can throw for strikes. His fastball can touch 93-94 mph, and his slider has the potential to be an above-average pitch, as well. PERSON mixes in his curve and changeup well to keep hitters guessing. All of his stuff plays up because of the deception his unusual delivery creates, making it tough for hitters to pick up the ball.When he was a member of the ORGANIZATION system, PERSON was often compared to PERSON for his stuff and deception. It didn't take long for PERSON to get to the big leagues, and PERSON could be on a similar track.

Because he hails from GPE, PERSON is going to draw the too-easy comparison to PERSON, who was signed by the ORGANIZATION back in 2007. The ORGANIZATION would love to see the middle infielder follow a similar path as the current ORGANIZATION shortstop.PERSON is similar to his fellow countryman in that he's an athletic infielder with very good defensive actions. He doesn't quite have PERSON' arm, but he has enough to stay at short, though he made multiple trips to the disabled list in 2016 with right shoulder issues.. The ORGANIZATION actually feel he has a better feel to hit and is a bit more consistent than PERSON was at the same stage of his career. A right-handed hitter, PERSON makes consistent contact and sprays the ball to all fields. He runs well enough to steal some bases once he gets on.The biggest key for PERSON, especially as he reaches the upper levels of the system, is to add strength. He's put on good weight as he's developed, but more needs to come if he's going to hit enough to be an everyday player at the big league level.

A bat-first high school catcher who was considered a long shot to stay behind the plate, PERSON has made sufficient developmental progress as a defender and now projects to stay back there. Always in possession of a strong throwing arm, his once thick frame is now learner and more agile, enabling him to better handle the athletic burdens of catching. He also has huge raw power that he doesn't often get to in games because PERSON's bat path causes him to drive the ball into the ground at a 50% clip and he's also prone to swing and miss. Now that PERSON's defensive future is more in focus, he may just be a swing tweak away from a statistical breakout.

An Ontario native, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $25,000 as a 10th-rounder from ORGANIZATION in 2014, but he blew out his elbow shortly thereafter and missed the entire 2015 season following PERSON surgery. When he returned, PERSON made him a starter, a role he hadn't filled since he was a sophomore at ORGANIZATION State (Okla.) JC in 2013. Though he performed well in that role over the next three seasons, the ORGANIZATION didn't protect him on their 40-man roster and lost him in the Rule 5 Draft to the FACILITY, who sold him to the ORGANIZATION.PERSON's fastball sits comfortably at 92-94 mph, with good life and some run, and reaches 96 mph. His power slider gives him a second above-average pitch capable of missing bats, especially against right-handed hitters. Neither his curveball nor his changeup is particularly advanced, and he'll need to make the latter a viable offering to be successful against lefties at higher levels. Most scouts think that PERSON will eventually return to the bullpen given the proven effectiveness of his fastball-slider combo against same-sided hitters. The ORGANIZATION plan on giving him a chance to win a relief role in GPE Training. If he doesn't stick with the big league club, he has to clear waivers and get offered back to the ORGANIZATION for half of his $100,000 Draft price before he can get sent to the Minors in 2019.

PERSON mostly played shortstop in GPE, but the ORGANIZATION liked his potential behind the plate and moved him there as soon as they signed him for $1.3 million in 2012. Many of GPE's top catching prospects in recent years have been offense-first players, but PERSON profiles as a solid defender who can contribute with the bat. He'll miss the entire 2015 season after surgery to repair a torn labrum in his shoulder in January, but he'll still be 19 when he returns in 2016.He has a strong arm and has had no problems figuring out the quick footwork and transfer he needs as a catcher, throwing out 41 percent of basestealers in his first two pro seasons. PERSON' receiving is still a work in progress but he has the hands and athleticism to improve in that regard.PERSON has a mature approach at the plate, showing patience and using the whole field. He has a quick bat and should provide double-digit home run power once he gets stronger. He may lack PERSON's potential impact bat but has a better chance of remaining a catcher.

PERSON was a 45 FV on last year's ranking, evaluated as an MLB-ready utility infielder or low-end regular at shortstop. During the offseason he was shot in the hip during a robbery in GPE and required surgery. The initial surgery was botched and PERSON needed a second operation during the summer, which ended his regular season. When he returned to action in the ORGANIZATION, he had clearly lost a step overall, but it was most obvious when watching PERSON play defense. There's a chance this was just rust and that PERSON will go back to doing the things that placed him in the ORGANIZATION' offseason infield conversation before he was shot; average range and plus actions at short, a plus arm, some speed, and feel for contact. He'll bounce back into the 45 FV tier if those things return in the spring, but he looked like a fringe bench piece last fall.

The ORGANIZATION have a knack for finding and developing tremendous pitching talent and PERSON is no exception. The former high school standout from the ORGANIZATION has thrown very well at two rookie levels since joining the organization in 2011 as the ORGANIZATION try to protect his impressive left arm. PERSON will touch 94-95 mph with his fastball now and there might be more in the tank as he matures. His changeup is the better of his two secondary offerings right now and it might be a consistently plus pitch for him. His slider might project to plus as well, though it's just average right now. He generally throws strikes and he should have at least average command in the future. The ORGANIZATION are great about being patient with their pitching prospects, so PERSON will start moving more quickly when he's ready.

Some college catchers have excellent bats while the jury is out about whether they can stay behind the plate. PERSON is the opposite, a sure-fire backstop defensively who will have to prove he can hit at the next level. A hamate injury that kept him out for a chunk of the 2017 season didn't help matters, though he did return as the ORGANIZATION approached and showed enough that the GPE felt comfortable taking him in the sixth round.PERSON has serious defensive skills behind the plate. He's the kind of take-charge player teams like to see from the position. He works with pitchers well, has good hands and catch-and-throw skills. There's a reason he was chosen to catch for the GPE National Team both as a high schooler, when he hit well, and last summer for the ORGANIZATION, where he didn't swing the bat effectively. There is some pop in his bat, but it is definitely behind the defensive tools.When healthy, PERSON pushed teammate JJ Schwarz from behind the plate because of his superior defensive skills. He profiles as a future defensive-minded backup, though it's fair to believe there might also be some untapped potential in his bat.

After signing PERSON out of GPE in 2010, the ORGANIZATION sent him to the ORGANIZATION League the next season to make his professional debut as a 17-year-old. The ORGANIZATION acquired him two years later in exchange for PERSON. PERSON has been young for his level throughout his career but has developed a solid reputation as a hitter. He has a good feel for the barrel, leading to high batting averages and low strikeout totals. His swing mostly produces line drives instead of home runs, but there might be some more power waiting to be unlocked in his projectable frame. PERSON is a below-average runner, limiting him defensively. He has improved in left field, but his bat will have to continue to produce as he advances through the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON spent two summers in the ORGANIZATION after signing out of the GPE in 2011. The slightly undersized right-hander didn't disappoint in his highly anticipated stateside debut in 2014, when he showed the ability to miss bats with electric stuff en route to recording 10.1 strikeouts per nine innings in the Rookie-level PERSON. The ORGANIZATION expected big things from him in 2015, though he was unable to take the next step as an avulsion fracture in his elbow limited him to just 20 innings. He finally made his full-season debut in 2016, pitching as part of a loaded piggyback starting rotation at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin. In December, he was selected by the Twins with the first pick in the Rule 5 Draft, only to be traded to GPE.  When healthy, PERSON's lightning-quick arm generates a fastball in the mid-90s with late movement from a high three-quarters slot. His slider, thrown in the 75-77 mph range with good lateral action, has the chance to be an out pitch if he can throw it for strikes. His changeup lags behind his two other offerings, but club officials believe it will become an effective third pitch for him once he creates better velocity separation relative to his heater. He has the ability to miss bats naturally, though his control and command require refinement, as does his mechanics. PERSON's elbow injury required subsequent surgery, but he was not limited by the injury in 2016. Although the ORGANIZATION may continue to develop him as a starter, his fastball-slider pairing gives him undeniable upside in a late-inning bullpen role.

A relative veteran of the amateur showcase circuit, PERSON has been a prospect for quite some time. With his size and stuff, he has the chance to make an even bigger name for himself at the next level.PERSON has room to add strength to his 6-foot-4 frame, and that might allow him to add to his fastball that often touches 93 mph and features a ton of heavy sink. Both his changeup and his breaking ball have the chance to be at least PERSON average. He has a good feel for pitching overall and has improved his command thanks to some refinement to his delivery. PERSON may not light up radar guns to the extent some of this year's Draft prospects do, but his ground-ball ability, feel for pitching and room for growth still make him very intriguing.

That the ORGANIZATION were unable to sign 2013 first-rounder PERSON is more and more looking like a blessing in disguise, as it gave the club the financial freedom to give ORGANIZATION an $850,000 bonus as a 30th-round pick. He has established himself as one of the best all-around hitters in the system in 2015 and made a smooth transition to Double-A last year, hitting a career-high 23 home runs and finishing second and third in the LOCATION in on-base percentage (.387) and slugging (.530), respectively.ORGANIZATION's robust raw power has been on display since his days at ORGANIZATION (Calif.) High, but it wasn't until 2015 that he began tapping into it in games with consistency. A physically strong left-handed hitter, ORGANIZATION possesses the requisite bat speed to turn on premium velocity as well as the barrel control to drive the ball out of the park the other way. A more consistent and confident approach resulted in vastly improved strikeout and walk rates in his first Double-A exposure, and he also showed more utility against same-side hurlers. Though a fringy defender at first base, ORGANIZATION has worked hard to upgrade his defense to where it should at least be serviceable. Meanwhile, ORGANIZATION officials rave about ORGANIZATION's work ethic and makeup, citing his determination to improve his body and defense as examples.While the emergence of All-Star first baseman PERSON doesn't bode well for ORGANIZATION cracking the ORGANIZATION' lineup anytime soon, it will provide him with as much time as needed to develop in the ORGANIZATION. The first-base-only profile is a notoriously difficult one to achieve, but he has the hitting ability and power to make it happen.

We're undeterred by PERSON's childlike measurables because, for a 5-foot-8 guy, he actually has a good frame and lots of present baseball skill that should start yielding on-field results as he gets stronger. He's a plus athlete and runner with a high baseball IQ, switch-hits, and is going to stay on the infield. Unlike his prototypically-sized peers, whose attributes are more obvious in showcase environments, it takes longer to get a feel for and appreciate skillsets like PERSON's. We think it's why skills-over-tools infielders like this tend to sneak up on us, and we're trying to suss out this profile earlier than we have in the past. If PERSON's strength never materializes, he's probably just a utility guy, at best. If it does, he could be a well-rounded every day player.

After a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON was well on his way to being a top-five pick in the 2014 GPE before undergoing PERSON surgery in May. Despite his injury, he didn't fall far on GPE day, as the ORGANIZATION grabbed him ninth overall.PERSON hasn't fully grown into his lanky 6-foot-4 frame, yet at times he works in the mid 90s and hits 98 mph with his fastball. His big-breaking curveball can be equally devastating and his changeup can be a plus pitch at times. He throws a decent amount of strikes but will need to refine his command to become a frontline starter in the big leagues.As long as he's healthy, PERSON gives the ORGANIZATION farm system another impact arm. He'll have a chance to prove that when he makes his professional debut in 2015.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $2 million just before the clock struck midnight on the 2015-2016 ORGANIZATION Agent signing period, then traded him to PERSON for PERSON a few weeks later, before PERSON had even played a pro game. PERSON took things slow for the first year 10 months, and left PERSON in the ORGANIZATION in 2016 and in GPE Spring Training to start 2017, but he has moved very quickly since then, climbing to a new minor league level every half season. And he has performed. PERSON is a career .301/.381/.507 hitter in the minors, has always been young relative to his level, and reached Triple-A last year shortly after he turned 21. He has big, all-fields raw power, and balls he mis-hits will often still find their way to the warning track. While PERSON has good natural timing in the box and isn't often fooled by breaking stuff, he does have limited bat control and we anticipate his batting averages will be lower in majors than they have been thus far. 
ORGANIZATION for his size, PERSON has mostly played left field as a pro and he's a 40 runner underway, but he appeared to stiffen last year and most teams have him projected to first base or DH. That will limit his overall value and makes his lack of bat control a little scary, but we still think PERSON will become an average regular, and possibly get an opportunity quite soon.

The ORGANIZATION gave seven-figure bonuses to three high school pitchers in the 2014 Draft: $1.1 million to PERSON in the fourth round, $1 million to PERSON in the fifth and $1.5 million to since-traded PERSON in the sixth. All three have had elbow surgery since turning pro, with PERSON succumbing to PERSON surgery last August. He had been enjoying his best pro season, ranking second in the ORGANIZATION with a 2.92 ERA when he blew out his elbow.PERSON began to make the transition from thrower to pitcher in 2017. He did a better job of commanding his fastball, which ranges from 91-97 mph with groundout-inducing sink. He got more consistent depth and missed more bats with his curveball, and he also showed more trust in his changeup.PERSON also made progress with his control and command, though both need further improvement. More athletic than physical, he has started to create hope that he could become a mid-rotation starter. He returned to the mound earlier than expected in mid-2018, showing the same stuff that began to get GPE excited before he got hurt.

One of the better two-way talents in the 2018 Draft class, GPE has a fastball that peaks in the low 90s and a promising breaking ball. He shows even more promise as a hitter, enough to get selected as early as the third round. Whether that will be high enough to lure him away from a ORGANIZATION commitment remains to be seen.GPE's quick right-handed swing with loft and his strength combine to generate impressive raw power, which he showed off by finishing second in the home run derby at the ORGANIZATION All-American Classic last August. He lets his pop come naturally and uses the entire field, showing the potential to hit for average as well. He has a track record of performing well against top competition on the showcase circuit, starring on the loaded PERSON travel team.While GPE is a well below-average runner, he moves well enough to make plays at third base. His hands and arm strength are assets, and he could become a solid defender if he can improve his agility. He'll have to maintain the conditioning of his thick frame to remain at the hot corner.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON took part in the 17U ORGANIZATION Development Program in 2016, going 2-for-8 over three games with the ORGANIZATION team.PERSON has an upright stance and was impressive in batting practice, barreling several balls out of an upright stance. In game action, PERSON struggled to adjust to offspeed pitches but has a chance to improve with maturity.The catcher has the arm strength to play the position, but he presently lacks accuracy throwing to second base.

GPE's top prep prospect in 2015, PERSON was best known for his speed but wowed the Cubs by driving the ball to all fields during a pre-PERSON workout at FACILITY. He became one of their four seven-figure bonus babies in that PERSON, passing on a ORGANIZATION commitment to sign for $1.3 million in the fourth round. He made adjustments after a slow start at short-season Eugene last summer and one club official compared his upside to that of PERSON has some of the best all-around tools in the system, starting with well above-average speed that drew him football recruiting interest from PERSON and PERSON as a wide receiver. His quickness enhances his ability to get on base and he knows how to use it once he does. It also makes him an asset in center field, where he displays fine instincts and has an average, accurate arm.While PERSON will need time to develop at the plate, he could become a .275 hitter with 15 homers and 30 steals on an annual basis. He has a compact left-handed swing and generates sneaky power with his ability to backspin the ball from center to right field. He makes a lot of hard contact but is still in the process of solving left-handed pitching.

GPE ORGANIZATION has three right-handers who could go in top three rounds of the 2017 Draft in PERSON, PERSON and PERSON. PERSON was as good as any pitcher in the talent-laden LOCATION during the first half of the 2016 season before tiring down the stretch and taking the summer off. He put up better numbers than ever as a junior despite pitching through an oblique injury, though his chances of going in the first round took a hit when he blew out his elbow in late April and required PERSON surgery.PERSON relies heavily on a 92-94 mph fastball that can reach 96 and features power sink. Both his slider and curveball can be plus pitches at times but also lack consistency, and he also mixes in a decent changeup. He generally throws strikes but can be vulnerable if his pitches wander up in the strike zone.PERSON isn't the most physical pitcher but got stronger as a sophomore after working around 90 mph as a freshman. He maintained his improved velocity until he got hurt this spring, but scouts don't love his delivery and now have even more questions about his durability.

The ORGANIZATION shocked other teams when they gave PERSON $4.95 million to sign out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, a record that should stand for a while thanks to bonus limitations established in the latest ORGANIZATION Agreement. The ORGANIZATION saw him as a prospect with a tremendous body and power potential, and they believe he's on the verge of a breakthrough.PERSON still is growing into his 6-foot-4 frame and is raw at the plate, yet he managed to hit 13 homers as an 18-year-old in low Class A last year. He has the bat speed and loft to provide plenty of home runs, though like many of GPE' top position prospects, he'll need to tone down his aggressiveness.With his power and solid arm strength, PERSON profiles easily in right field. He's a below-average runner but has improved his reads in the outfield and gets the job done defensively.

Since the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the fourth round of the 2013 Draft and went above slot to sign him away from the ORGANIZATION of GPE, he's looked like the prototypical pitchability lefty, one who was poised to contribute to the big league rotation in 2018. When he did get the chance in GPE, however, he really struggled to find the strike zone. His command in the ORGANIZATION regressed a bit as well, but he didn't get hit en route to finishing second in the organization in ORGANIZATION. An elbow injury kept him from making any progress in 2019.Outside of an inflated walk rate in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON wasn't hittable and posted low ORGANIZATIONs in both Double-A and Triple-A when healthy, using his typical feel for pitching and deception to allow his largely average stuff play up. His fastball will sit in the low 90s, though he can reach back for more on occasion, and he throws it with good life. His sinking changeup is his best pitch, a plus offspeed offering that he keeps down in the zone. He mixes in his average curveball effectively.The ORGANIZATION hope the adversity PERSON faced in his brief big league stint will help him move forward in the long run. He worked with pitching coach PERSON, focusing on the mechanics with his lower half, to streamline his delivery. The combination could help the 6-foot-5 southpaw be ready to contribute in a bigger way once he is 100 percent healthy.

A product of PERSON (PERSON, Ga.), PERSON has a similar profile to former ORGANIZATION. He turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 28th-rounder in 2013 to attend PERSON, and he impressed last summer in the ORGANIZATION, where he was one of the fastest players and ranked fifth with five homers. His ORGANIZATION stock has suffered because he hasn't hit with as much authority since a ball tipped off his glove and broke three bones in his face right before the season started, though he should go in the first three to five rounds.PERSON still brings well above-average speed to the table, with some evaluators giving him double-plus run grades. Though he's an obvious basestealing threat, he doesn't swipe as many bags as he could and needs to refine his technique. His quickness makes him a fine defender in center field, where he has a playable arm.PERSON is still searching for his identity at the plate. His speed could translate into on-base ability at the top of the order, but he also has shown the potential for at least gap power in the past and has the strength to pull some home runs to left field. He sometimes gets caught in between the two approaches and doesn't control the strike zone particularly well, though scouts do rave about his makeup and believe he may figure it out in pro ball.

PERSON looked like an elite international prospect when he dominated the 18-and-under World Championships in September 2012, but his stuff and delivery regressed significantly by the time he pitched for GPE as an 18-year-old in the World Baseball Classic the following spring. Undaunted, GPE signed PERSON for $1.625 million last July.The early returns on that investment have the ORGANIZATION optimistic that they could have a future No. 3 starter on their hands. PERSON was so impressive in Spring Training this year that GPE sent him to Class A for his pro debut, and he got off to a terrific start at ORGANIZATION County.PERSON's stuff has bounced back to where he's pitching with a consistent 90-95 mph fastball. He also can get swings and misses with his curveball. PERSON has advanced feel for his changeup and for finding the strike zone with all three of his offerings.

The son of former big leaguer PERSON, and brother of ORGANIZATION farmhand PERSON, PERSON clearly has some serious baseball bloodlines. Though he didn't come off the board as early as his brother did back in 2011, when the ORGANIZATION took him 51st overall, PERSON's impressive bat still got him drafted by ORGANIZATION in the second round (ORGANIZATION. 66 overall), not to mention an above-slot singing bonus of $1,100,000. Like the others in his family, PERSON does things in an unconventional way, but he has had some success against good competition. Over the summer, PERSON showed the ability to square up quality pitching, and his raw power was on display when he won the Under PERSON All-American Game Home Run Derby in GPE. This spring, he was still hitting the long ball but also was getting tied up on mid-range fastballs inside. While he doesn't have the same exact leg kick setup as his father and brother, there are a lot of moving parts to his swing, which concerns some scouts. He does have more bat speed than his brother did coming out of high school. A below-average runner, PERSON may continue to see time at shortstop, but, in the long run, he's probably best suited defensively for second base, or perhaps even left field.PERSON immediately rewarded the ORGANIZATION by raking during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION. There will continue to be questions surrounding his unorthodox setup and swing mechanics, but he's well on his way to becoming a productive, offensive-minded player at the highest level.

A 33rd-round pick by the ORGANIZATION in 2012 out of the ORGANIZATION prep ranks, PERSON was a two-way player at the ORGANIZATION of LOCATION in 2013 before signing with the GPE for $120,000 as a ninth-rounder. He took off after making some delivery adjustments last year, and then continued to climb the ladder in 2017, moving up to Double-A and becoming an LOCATION All-Star. PERSON's progress caught the eye of the ORGANIZATION, who acquired him and second baseman PERSON for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION. PERSON can run his fastball up to 92-93 mph but usually sits more in the 88-91 mph range. Though not overpowering, PERSON's heater plays above its velocity on account of his deception, allowing him to induce whiffs inside the zone. He has good feel for his curveball, showing the ability to throw it for a strike and also bury it in the dirt when vying for whiffs, and he's adept at adding and subtracting with the pitch as needed. His changeup gives him a third average-or-better offering, albeit one he uses sparingly, and he has good command of all three pitches.Because he lacks a plus pitch and thrives based on deception, PERSON will have to prove himself at each level. He has handled every challenge so far, and while he's not a top-tier prospect, the left-hander has a legitimate floor as a backend starter in the ORGANIZATION.

Throwing out of the bullpen ever since he signed back in 2012 out of GPE, PERSON has moved steadily through up the ORGANIZATION' ladder as a two-pitch short reliever. After a 2016 season that saw him reach Double-A at age 21 and go to the ORGANIZATION, PERSON was added to the 40-man roster to be protected from the Rule 5 Draft. He's rewarded the organization's faith in him by pitching well enough to make his big league debut in 2017.PERSON gets swings and misses on both his fastball and slider, striking out 10.5 per nine innings in his ORGANIZATION career heading into the 2017 season. He throws his fastball in the 92-95 mph range and it plays up because of its plus run, sink and spin. His slider is more slurvy than anything else, but it has a lot of depth to it. He's not a sidearmer by any means, but he does employ a low and short arm slot that provides a lot of deception. Hitters do not pick the ball up well coming out of his hands. He's done a very nice job in his career of staying in the strike zone.PERSON has closed games throughout his ORGANIZATION career, saving 32 over the last two seasons combined. His stuff is probably a little short to keep doing that in the big leagues, but he's looking like he'll be able to fill a bullpen role there in the near future.

A small-ish infielder with above-average bat speed, PERSON has good pull-side pop for an 18-year-old. His swing is geared for contact at the top of the strike zone, which is where more and more pitchers are starting to work. He's a bit over-aggressive and needs to get stronger as he ages, but there are power-hitting components here if he can, as well as a good shot to stay on the infield at either second or third base.

PERSON appeared to be on his way toward becoming a first-round pick in the 2016 GPE after a strong start to his junior season at GPE, only to miss most of April and May with a shoulder injury. But he was able to get back on the mound and prove that he was healthy in the weeks before the GPE, and the A's felt good enough about his medicals to take him in GPE Round A with the 37th overall pick. They assigned him to Class A Advanced Stockton for his first full season, but PERSON made just two starts before it was announced he would need season-ending PERSON surgery. PERSON can add and subtract from his heater, sitting comfortably in the low 90s but also reaching back for 95 mph, with feel for locating to both sides of the plate as well as down in the zone. His changeup is his best secondary pitch, a mid-80s offering thrown with fastball-like arm speed and late fading action, and he has the makings of a slider that projects to at least Major League-average. A consistent, over-the-top release point allows him to create plane towards the plate, and everything he throws plays up due to his advanced control and command. Meanwhile, scouts expect PERSON to miss more bats with improvement to both his changeup and slider. PERSON is a good athlete with clean arm action and a repeatable delivery, though as an undersized righty, he'll need to prove he can physically handle the rigors of a full season on the mound. He'll miss the remainder of the 2017 season, as well as some of the following year, but PERSON possesses the stuff and pitchability to become a No. 4 starter in the big leagues.

In 2015, ORGANIZATION set the single-season strikeout record at LSU-Eunice, a junior college that produces a lot of pro baseball talent. He transferred to GPE and spent his junior year pitching mostly out of the ORGANIZATION bullpen. He signed for $100,000. GPE has tried him in the rotation and in long relief and ORGANIZATION has been fairly successful at both, but he projects as a two-pitch reliever long-term. His low-90s fastball has flat plane and lives in the top of the strike zone. It's hard to differentiate between it and his 12-6 curveball, which is effective against both-handed hitters.

Traded from GPE in exchange for PERSON, PERSON was a heavy-bodied, power-hitting prospect with no position. Since the trade, he has remade himself physically, and now has a physique similar to PERSON O'Neill. GPE term, PERSON still projects to first base and he may lack the approach and contact skills to produce at the level necessary to profile there.

GPE was viewed as one of the more advanced college hurlers in the 2015 Draft following an impressive career at ORGANIZATION that included a national championship (2013). The ORGANIZATION took GPE 16th overall, making him the highest-drafted college pitcher in franchise history, and then signed him for $2.65 million. Unfortunately, injuries have subsequently derailed GPE's development, as a strained flexor muscle in his forearm limited him to just three starts in is first full season, while PERSON surgery the following spring wiped out his entire 2017 campaign. It will now be up to the A's to get GPE back on track after they acquired him, PERSON and PERSON for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.After working at 88-92 mph in college with a fastball that stood out more for its sink and command than it did for velocity, GPE saw his velocity jump to 93-96 mph while touching 99 upon entering pro ball. He possesses a deep secondary arsenal, including a curveball, slider and changeup that all grade as at least above-average pitches when they're on. Scouts have praised PERSON's athleticism and they like his projectable body. In the batter's box, PERSON has gained a reputation for making good contact, especially in the inner half of the plate. The ORGANIZATION teen racked up five hits and scored four runs in three games during PERSON's ORGANIZATION in February. He also walked twice.PERSON is trained by his father, PERSON.

The ORGANIZATION signed PERSON, the top-rated pitcher on MLB.com's Top 30 international prospects list in 2013, for $1.3 million only to trade him to the Brewers the following offseason part of the ORGANIZATION trade. He made the jump to full-season ball with promising results, as the right-hander emerged as one of the better young hurlers in the low minors, earning All-Star honors at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin, en route to a promotion to the ORGANIZATION State League in July. While he's taken a step back in 2017, PERSON remains one of the more electric and projectable hurlers in GPE's system.PERSON's big-time arm strength belies his undersized, slender frame, as he'll produce a fastball that can reach 98 mph and sits at 92-96 mph with late movement. And with remaining physical projection, many scouts expect the right-hander to sit in the mid-90s at maturity. PERSON complements his heater with a plus slider, and he has surprisingly advanced feel for throwing a changeup. After showing solid control of his entire three-pitch mix in 2016, PERSON's feel for the zone has been inconsistent, resulting in elevated pitch counts and too many abbreviated outings.PERSON is adept at missing bats and generating weak contact with his two plus pitches, giving him the ceiling of a No. 3 starter or a high-leverage reliever if he can regain his control and command. ORGANIZATION officials are quick to praise the young righty for his makeup and overall aptitude, qualities they believe will help him stay the course as a starter.

PERSON has proved to be the advanced hitter the ORGANIZATION hoped he'd become when they signed him out of the ORGANIZATION in December 2013. After advancing to full-season ball in 2015, PERSON saw his stock skyrocket last season in the Class A Advanced California League, where, as the circuit's youngest everyday player on Opening Day, he won the batting title and ORGANIZATION award at age 19. Moved up to Double-A in 2017, PERSON has reaffirmed why scouts view him as one of the ORGANIZATION' more advanced hitters with an All-Star campaign in the ORGANIZATION League.With an approach that belies his age, PERSON demonstrates an advanced feel for the strike zone and has excellent pitch recognition, the combination of which netted him more walks (40) than strikeouts (36) in 2016. The right-handed hitter's bat-to-ball skills are equally impressive, as his short, level swing produces line drives across the entire field. And while he may never offer much over-the-fence power in games, PERSON should be a consistent source of extra-base hits thanks to his knack for pounding the gaps. An average defender at second base with an above-average arm, PERSON has made a smooth transition to shortstop in 2017.PERSON' advanced approach and innate feel for hitting has him poised to become an impact player in the big leagues, while his successful transition to shortstop only increased his value.

PERSON powered GPE to its first PERSON Series appearance and first outright Big Ten Conference regular-season championship since 1932 last year, slugging a school-record 18 homers and ranking third in ORGANIZATION Division I in that category. He offers lots of strength and bat speed from the left side of the plate, and he's not a one-dimensional hitter either. PERSON controls the strike zone well and repeatedly barrels balls, so he should hit for a high average as well. His offensive ability could make him a star as a catcher -- provided that he can stay behind the plate. While he moves well for his size, his throwing and receiving both grade as below average and could prompt a move to the outfield, where he has seen time for the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON spent two years at ORGANIZATION in the GPE, GPE., area before switching his academics to the online PERSON and his baseball to the ORGANIZATION. He finished his coursework to graduate last fall, giving him months to focus on baseball full-time to prepare for life as a pro or as another talented arm at the ORGANIZATION of Florida.The work allowed PERSON to get his body in shape and helped him show off his arm strength more consistently. He's capable of running his fastball up to 96-97 mph, especially in shorter stints. His breaking ball will flash average, but it will often get caught between a curveball and a slider with a 10-to-4-type break, though at times he'll go to a more conventional slider, and he does have some feel for a changeup. While he throws strikes with his heater, its lack of movement makes it play down a bit. He can be inverted in back during his delivery, impacting his plane.As a result, some see a future reliever profile, though he has shown the stuff and control to start. The biggest thing that might keep PERSON from going in the top six rounds is a rumored price tag, with him donning a Gators uniform in the fall a distinct possibility.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON, GPE.

There were several things the ORGANIZATION knew PERSON would have to work on when they signed him in the summer of 2013. He was coming from a relatively non-baseball playing country in GPE, he had been an infielder, and he was almost painfully thin, so there wasn't much of a foundation of any sort to build from.PERSON has made strides on all those fronts, though forearm strains have limited his ability to take the mound. He's added a lot of strength and now tops 200 pounds, a far cry from the 155 he weighed when he signed. The right-hander throws what's best described as "easy gas" that gets up to 95-96 mph consistently, coming from a very quick arm. He shows he can spin an improving breaking ball, but both his curve and his changeup are inconsistent and need to be refined. PERSON can get too amped up on the mound and needs to learn to manage his effort level, with an understanding that his stuff will still be there when he does so.It's possible PERSON's high energy style to go along with his fastball-curve combination, might be best suited coming out of the bullpen. For now, he'll keep starting so he can get more reps to continue making progress on building that foundation.

Back in 2015, the ORGANIZATION spent a Draft-record $17,865,000 on bonuses. That included shelling out $900,000 for PERSON in the 11th round, when signability concerns drove his stock down. It's been extremely slow going for the left-hander, though he was gaining some traction and pitching well in 2018 when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in a deal for catcher PERSON's best pitch continues to be his curveball, a slow deep breaking ball that flashes plus. He'll throw his fastball in the 88-92 mph range and will mix in an average slider and will show good feel for an average changeup as well. As PERSON has progressed, particularly in 2018, his command has improved and he throws a ton of strikes with all four of his pitches.PERSON's ceiling is somewhat limited to that of a back-end starter. He'd never thrown more than 62 innings in a season before the 2018 season, with the ORGANIZATION perhaps getting him right when he's starting to figure things out.

PERSON PERSON made a name for himself in GPE and international baseball circles. Now, he has his eyes set on fulfilling his Major League dream.PERSON, 21, is a 5-foot-10, 185-pound center fielder with a good mix of power and speed, and lots of potential. Because of his age and experience, PERSON will be subject to the international signing guidelines. GPE has a big frame, smooth arm action and has run it up to 97 mph along with an above average curveball, so the starter traits and solid health indicators are there, but the lack of a plus secondary pitch has him in the second tier of prep arms.
